fields.headline: The villains of the piece
fields.standfirst:
Hamlets everywhere, a play in a playground and continuing controversy at the National

More Observer Theatre coverage
fields.trailText: Susannah Clapp on the hits, the turkeys and the continuing controversies of the theatre year.
fields.body:
Was it millennial anxiety that gave rise so many Hamlets in 2000? This was the most diversely interpreted play of the year. In an over-holy production at the National, Simon Russell Beale was a wonder: witty, grave and powerfully intelligent. At the Globe, a fine and melancholy Mark Rylance had his second triumphant go at the part, and proved that this often-derided but vivacious space can be intimate as well as rousing. Peter Zadek's bold production, in German, at Edinburgh, made the centre of Elsinore a corrugated railway-truck, and cast a woman - Angela Winkler - in the title role: she played Hamlet like a lost child. And in Paris Peter Brook, with Adrian Lester as the Prince, created his own cut and re-ordered version: rapt and intense - a meditation on the play.

The dispute of the year was about the National: was it falling to pieces? It hasn't been a clear-cut case: the quality of its productions see-sawed violently. There have been stinkers: the clumping Villains' Opera, a snail's pace Romeo and Juliet. But there have also been superb occasions: Trevor Nunn set a benchmark for future directors with his Redgrave-filled Cherry Orchard; Jeremy Sams brilliantly revived Michael Frayn's Noises Off. What's been lacking wasn't talent, but surprise and diversity. The National shouldn't be monolithic: it is, after all, three theatres. It should fuel arguments about the different things that are lively on the stage. Of course, it should go on producing musicals as well as straight plays. But it should also find room to acknowledge movement theatre, devised work, and the confessional and documentary accounts that are beginning to invigorate the stage. It has to do more than it did this year to champion new writers - and new directors.

Some of the most stimulating dramas of 2000 began outside London; most were not staged in purpose-built theatres. In Edinburgh, Grid Iron Theatre company took over a children's playground for Decky Does a Bronco, a tale of child abuse and bullying, acrobatically enacted in the open air: adults sinisterly stuffed into children's clothing spun high in the air on a row of swings, with the grey terraces of the city co-opted as backdrop.

This was a production which made you think about what it is that makes a stage. As did the vivid work of the Dublin-based Corn Exchange which brought its Car Show to Greenwich for the Docklands International Festival, setting four short plays in four cars -- with, in each case, an audience of three on the back seat, and a different cast of two (always terrific) actors in the front. The wing- mirrors of the vehicles served as miniature sets, reflecting the world outside.

And at the Southwark Playhouse, The Woman Who Swallowed a Pin escorted the audience through and outside the theatre (originally a warehouse) in order to uncover the building's history and a woman's past. In doing so, it provided a prime example of the way in which a theatre can be used like a piece of origami, endlessly transforming itself to shape the sense of what is being said.

The year's most illuminating director was Michael Grandage who - working with the designer Christopher Oram - brought magic to The Jew of Malta at the Almeida, to Passion Play at the Donmar - and to the Crucible in Sheffield, where he staged As You Like It, with Victoria Hamilton as a Rosalind who went straight to the heart. In each case, it was as if a veil between audience and actors was lifted away.

The resurgence of the year came from the RSC where, after some patchy times, the decision to stage all Shakespeare's Histories - using different directors and designers, and all three of the Stratford theatres - was an inspired big idea. No dud productions, and compelling acting, particularly from Sam West as an incisive Richard II.

Theatrical architect of the year was the firm of Haworth Tompkins. First it refashioned the Royal Court, plaiting together innovation and history, stretching theatrical tentacles under Sloane Square. Then it remade the old Gainsborough Studios for a sell-out season by the Almeida.

It was at the Gainsborough that you could hear superlative speaking of Shakespeare by the great Barbara Jefford, and see a stage in Shoreditch covered in a verdant lawn. Later in the year, the Cottesloe was also given over to sward for its stirring All My Sons. The accessory of 2000 was definitely grass.

fields.headline: Graham makes Sugar seem sweet
fields.trailText: The Railway Tavern is one of those places where Spurs fans go to whinge or, occasionally, celebrate after a home game. You can't get in without a ticket and you can't get out without an earful of one sort or another.
fields.body:
The Railway Tavern is one of those places where Spurs fans go to whinge or, occasionally, celebrate after a home game. You can't get in without a ticket and you can't get out without an earful of one sort or another.

On Monday night, after the 1-1 draw against Arsenal, it was the place to be. Losing a dodgy goal in the last minute to the Highbury lot was no novelty, but losing Alan Sugar was. Time for mixed feelings?

And then there on the telly was the chairman, saying that nobody should have to put up with the sort of abuse that had been visited on his family over the past few years; he'd had enough, he was selling up. Oddly, this did not elicit an outbreak of remorse in the bar. I thought the boys held it together quite well, actually. How somebody didn't glass the set is beyond me.

This is what hardcore Spurs fans think about the chairman...

What 'rocket scientist' could not see that the only way for the big clubs to compete was to spend as much as the other big clubs? What 'rocket scientist' turned Tottenham into Watford, rather than Manchester United? What 'rocket scientist' thought he knew better than the likes of Martin Edwards?

Is it a coincidence that the marketing genius who has made United the most marketable sporting brand name in the world learnt his business at White Hart Lane? Naturally, Spurs let him go.

And why do you think Teddy Sheringham left for United? Because Spurs wouldn't spend money on a decent defender.

Sugar did save Tottenham, as Gary Mabbutt points out. Big deal. That's what he signed up for. Or is it? Sugar walked away last week with £22 million. In 10 years at White Hart Lane, Sugar can hardly complain that he was personally out of pocket.

These are familiar gripes. But what I find most annoy ing about Sugar is that he claims to be a shrewd businessman with successful companies throughout the world. Yet his lack of business bottle, his refusal to spend money at the right time (as opposed to desperately, when there was no alternative), not only damaged the football club, but it was a commercial miscalculation, undermining confidence in Tottenham plc. How clever is that?

Enic, who bought him out, were making the usual noises on Thursday: 'We're going to have to work together... there are ambitions... but success is not going to come overnight.' Whatever the latest flannel, it will take the new chairman at least another 10 years to repair the damage of the past 10 - if ENIC don't cut and run too.

All that saved Sugar from wholesale booing in the Railway on Monday was an interview straight afterwards with his most unpopular signing: George Graham.

George, you've done all right, but a small tip: whatever the truth, don't ever admit that Arsenal deserve to share the points - especially when they nick it in the 89th minute at White Hart Lane.

Even Sugar wouldn't do that.

fields.headline: Venables makes his point
fields.trailText: Much ado about nothing-nothing indeed. Terry Venables will not see it the same way after his new Middlesbrough side eked out a valuable point in their struggle against relegation, but this was a Christmas turkey. If you didn't know their competitive natures better, you might have thought that in the absence of the departing Tottenham chairman Sir Alan Sugar, Venables and the Spurs manager George Graham invoked the old pals' act.
fields.byline: Ian Ridley at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
Much ado about nothing-nothing indeed. Terry Venables will not see it the same way after his new Middlesbrough side eked out a valuable point in their struggle against relegation, but this was a Christmas turkey. If you didn't know their competitive natures better, you might have thought that in the absence of the departing Tottenham chairman Sir Alan Sugar, Venables and the Spurs manager George Graham invoked the old pals' act.

Middlesbrough are still nothing special, carrying lit tle goal threat, but at least Mister Tees has brought some much-needed shape and organisation to their ranks. Spurs simply could not break them down, though television replays showed two offside decisions that ruled out second-half 'goals' to be marginal. As Graham is likely to tell the club's new owners, ENIC, his team need quality and subtlety in several areas. 'Quite nice really,' was Venables' verdict on his first visit to White Hart Lane since leaving so acrimoniously after a falling-out with Sugar seven years ago. He even managed a smile at the final whistle for his old mucker Graham, the pair having played together at Chelsea but last meeting competitively when Graham brought his Arsenal side to Venables' Tottenham in the early Nineties.

Graham enjoyed the occasion less. 'It was obvious in the first five minutes the way they set about killing the game,' he said. 'We dominated the game but we needed a goal. We did everything else. I've seen the TV replays and the two goals we scored were not offside.'

Venables began the game in the directors' box and must have been encouraged by the way Alen Boksic went round Sol Campbell to create an opening for Keith O'Neill. Typically of their shot-shy approach, though, O'Neill passed instead of shooting.

With the lively Stephen Carr more readily causing concern down Middlesbrough's left flank, Venables made his way to the bench with less than quarter of an hour gone. The alarms grew fewer as he bellowed instructions, though Carr looked certain to score from Stephen Clemence's cross, Colin Cooper blocking the header, and Mark Schwarzer had to turn Tim Sherwood's diving header round a post.

Les Ferdinand did not re-appear for the second half after a bang on the head in the first and his replacement, Chris Armstrong, twice had the ball in the net, turning home after Sherwood's shot had been deflected into his path and then touching the rebound into the net after Schwarzer had spilled Carr's cross shot. Both times, a linesman's flag was up, however.

Spurs might have scored when Sergei Rebrov seized on Schwarzer's awful clearance, but Ugo Ehiogu intervened to divert the shot on to the bar. Amid the siege, Venables emerged from the bench to instruct his team to stop defending so deeply, as they have been accustomed to.

'I've started by working on the defensive play,' said Venables, ever a pragmatic coach who likes the basics right before adding the more exciting aspects of the game. 'But I always say that the last thing you learnt is the first you forget under pressure.'

His team will have to start scoring goals, only Boksic posing a threat yesterday, though the classy Croat was guilty of shooting wide when put through by Paul Ince. But two clean sheets - the latest against a team unbeaten at home - is a promising start.

fields.headline: Svensson wins by a head
fields.trailText: It should be a much happier Valley this Christmas than two years ago, when a run of 11 games without a win effectively sealed Charlton's relegation.
fields.body:
It should be a much happier Valley this Christmas than two years ago, when a run of 11 games without a win effectively sealed Charlton's relegation.

This victory, secured by Matty Svensson's early goal, ended a run of four games without a win that threatened to raise the ghosts of Christmas past.

Indeed Alan Curbishley is already hoping he can start looking forward to next Christmas in the Premiership, and this victory was as important for Charlton's confidence as it was for the three-point gap they opened above Everton.

'A lot has been said about what happened two years ago, when we had eight straight defeats and went 11 games without a win, but we always felt that this time we had enough about us to bounce back,' said the Charlton manager.

'It was nice to get some points after the last few weeks and I would have settled for us to put on a shocking performance and win if that was what was needed.'

His side started as brightly as they had done a fortnight ago against Manchester United. Jonatan Johansson almost put them ahead in the sixth minute when he lobbed the ball over Thomas Myhre but Michael Ball saved Everton by heading clear for a corner. However, it was a brief reprieve as Claus Jensen's in-swinger was headed into the far corner of the net by Svensson.

Myhre, back to replace the injured Paul Gerrard, made a fine save to claw away a header from Richard Rufus, and then saved well when Svensson tried his luck with an acrobatic overhead shot from outside the penalty area.

Everton did not really threaten the home goal until Duncan Ferguson was introduced as a substitute after 62 minutes. The big Scotsman has not played since being injured in the home win over Charlton in August, but he was soon back in his garrulous groove. He had barely been on the pitch a minute before he gave away a free-kick and was almost booked for disputing the decision.

But his height and aggression clearly unsettled the Charlton defence and gave Everton a real chance of equalising, with Israeli striker Idan Tal going closest when his bicycle kick hit the woodwork.

fields.headline: Savage strikes final blow
fields.trailText: It sounds bizarre, but a place in the Champions League has become a realistic aim for modest Leicester after they moved level on points with second placed Arsenal with half of the season now complete.
fields.body:
It sounds bizarre, but a place in the Champions League has become a realistic aim for modest Leicester after they moved level on points with second placed Arsenal with half of the season now complete.

This was not their most convincing win - but how important. And they play at Arsenal on Boxing Day with the chance to make the second spot their own.

This remarkable start for Peter Taylor in his first season as Leicester manager has been achieved while he has also had the distraction of being in charge of the England team.

He said: 'If we are joint second after 38 games well be in it, but we will have to be very lucky with injuries and lucky to stay in good form. But if we do that we will give people a game.

'I'm enjoying life here, but I still think there are some people who need convincing, judging by some of the letters I get.'

West Ham, unbeaten in their previous eight games, felt hard done by and manager Harry Redknapp blamed his wasteful forwards.

But they were flying at the start and were deservedly ahead in eight minutes. Trevor Sinclair crossed from the right and Matt Elliott weakly blocked the ball straight to Frédéric Kanouté, who scored with a rising right-foot shot from the edge of the area.

Leicester initially offered little in response and West Ham had chances to close the game. They paid for not taking them by letting Leicester back in with a scrappy 26th-minute equaliser. Ade Akinbiyi headed down a Gary Rowett cross from the left and Muzzy Izzet reacted to stab the ball in from close range.

Elliott was carried off on a stretcher on the stroke of half-time suffering with leg cuts which required stitches, a victim of his own bravery in blocking a goal-bound Kanouté shot.

He was replaced by Steve Guppy for the start of the second half and the switch knocked Leicester out of rhythm as the game became marred by errors.

An Ian Pearce howler, typical of the game then, gifted Leicester victory in the 62nd minute when he swung and missed at a Guppy through ball and Robbie Savage ran clear to score with a first-time shot from 10 yards out.

West Ham improved and had chances to equalise as Flowers saved superbly from Rigobert Song and Sinclair drove inches wide from a great last-minute opening. On chances, therefore, the result was not necessarily a fair reflection of the game.

webTitle: Row over Express chief's tax avoidance

fields.headline: Row over Express chief's tax avoidance
fields.standfirst: Special report on the Express takeover
fields.trailText: New Express owner Richard Desmond's huge publishing and TV sex empire has paid just £200,000 in corporation tax since it was established eight years ago, The Observer can reveal.
fields.body:
New Express owner Richard Desmond's huge publishing and TV sex empire has paid just £200,000 in corporation tax since it was established eight years ago, The Observer can reveal.

The news will heighten the controversy over the porn baron's £125 million purchase of the Express titles from Lord Hollick's United News & Media a month ago.

Last week an investigation by the Guardian linked Desmond's companies to an internet website offering live sex, despite his insistence that he has nothing to do with hard-core pornography. Worried Labour MPs have also called on Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers to use his wide powers to refer the Express takeover to the Competition Commission.

Desmond plans to relaunch the Sunday Express as a second Mail on Sunday, part of his vow to take on the Daily Mail. The Express titles, however, are in turmoil, with editor Rosie Boycott and Desmond - both of whom have since met Tony Blair - at each other's throats.

Bonus payments totalling £1 million from Hollick to selected senior journalists have also left staff deeply resentful, while the position of editor Rosie Boycott - and her possible pay-off - is a source of continued speculation.

'It is chaos here,' one senior insider said. 'They now want to imitate the Mail on Sunday slavishly, yet on some sections the MoS has more staff than both Express papers.'

Desmond's empire includes the OK! celebrity gossip magazine, the Fantasy Television sex channel and a string of soft porn magazines.

His two main holding companies - Northern & Shell Group Ltd and Portland Investments Ltd - are owned by trusts in Guernsey, the Channel Islands tax haven.

Since the firms were set up in 1992 they have notched up a combined turnover of £301m, gross profits of £91m and pre-tax profits of £5.6m. Yet, Companies House records show that their total tax bill to the end of 1999 was just £200,000 - an effective tax rate of 3.6 per cent, barely a tenth of the 30 per cent most UK firms pay.

'There are all too many British "patriots" who feel they serve their country best by avoiding paying tax and putting their money offshore,' said Brian Sedgemore, one of 10 Labour MPs to sign a parliamentary motion attacking the Express sale.

There is no suggestion Desmond has done anything illegal: tax avoidance, to minimise bills, is not against the law. Days after the deal, however, the Express attacked Labour-supporting businessmen - including Hollick - for paying well below the going UK corporation tax rate.

Northern & Shell Group owns OK! magazine, while Portland Investments runs the soft porn magazines, the cable TV sex channel and controversial websites.

Desmond's offshore dealings bear the classic hallmarks of clever tax planning. In 1992 both companies were owned by two offshore trusts, Old Court Ltd and First Court Ltd, which received shares in exchange for the transfer of assets owned by Desmond.

The trusts were administered by Rothschild Guernsey, but in the mid-1990s transferred the companies' shares to new accounts at Guernsey fund manager Guinness Flight & Calder.

Desmond's clever tax planning has now extended to the Express. According to sources close to the publisher, there was yet another 'tax re-organisation' in November to accommodate the deal.

This included a new parent company RCD1 Ltd - after Richard Clive Desmond - also run by Guinness Flight. Further new companies were also formed - Northern & Shell Media Ltd and Northern & Shell Media Holdings Ltd - as part of the restructuring.

Last week Desmond was in Thailand. Neither Paul Ashford, his editorial director, nor Ian Monk, his spokesman, returned calls.

Until he bought the Express, Desmond had planned to float his empire for up to £750m. Instead, it is now mortgaged to Germany's Commerzbank, which advanced nearly £100m. Barclays also provided a guarantee to the Germans, official filings show.

fields.headline: Ole stars in double act
fields.trailText: No fairy-tale second spot for the Tractor Boys this Christmas then, and no crisis at Manchester United either, unless you count only managing a couple of goals against a side they famously beat 9-0 five years ago.
fields.body:
No fairy-tale second spot for the Tractor Boys this Christmas then, and no crisis at Manchester United either, unless you count only managing a couple of goals against a side they famously beat 9-0 five years ago.

Ipswich have come a long way since then, but like everyone else in the Premiership they have a distance still to go to match Old Trafford standards. Even with three of their four regular strikers missing, United took advantage of Arsenal's defeat at Liverpool to go eight points clear.

'There's still a long way to go,' said a predictably uncarried-away Sir Alex Ferguson. 'The table might be slightly misleading in that Arsenal have played all their tough away games whereas we have ours still to come.'

Obviously judging last week's gamble of playing Paul Scholes up front to have been a failure, Ferguson shuffled his resources to let Ryan Giggs share the striking duties with Ole Gunnar Solskjaer, with Quinton Fortune filling in on the left wing. Oddly, this seemed to suit Scholes's attacking instincts much better - getting forward as regularly as ever, the England midfielder was only inches off target with two shots and a header in the first 15 minutes - but the sparkling Solskjaer was the real beneficiary.

The Norwegian would probably not mind playing alongside Giggs every week. Actually, he might settle for just getting a game every week, but the pair presented a threat that Premiership defences are unused to handling. Eschewing the usual emphasis on crosses from the wings, David Beckham and Roy Keane simply sat back and enjoyed the luxury of hitting two front men, who could not only control their passes instantly but also run intelligently off each other. 'United deserve to be running away with the championship,' George Burley said. 'We might have showed them a bit too much respect, but Ryan Giggs was virtually unplayable.'

Ipswich kept their shape but were always back-pedalling, and the accuracy of United's passing would have made any defence look square. It certainly found out Burley's team, who have impressed against most other Premiership sides this season, though of course the whole point of Manchester United is that they are no ordinary Premiership side.

If Scholes could have had a hat-trick in the opening minutes, Solskjaer should have had one by half-time. All it would have taken was for Giggs to look up after a 40-yard dash from halfway, but the Welshman kept his head down and ran into trouble with his partner waving vainly in an ocean of space. In fairness, this was an isolated breakdown of communications.

There was nothing wrong with the radar when Beckham chipped over the Ipswich defence after 20 minutes for Giggs and Solskjaer to exchange passes until the latter was clear in front of goal. At that point you would have put money on Solskjaer scoring, though not necessarily in such a nonchalant manner, rounding Richard Wright to walk the ball into an empty net.

Solskjaer's second was an even sharper piece of finishing. Beckham's 40-yard pass from the right was firmly drilled and at an uncomfortable height, yet Solskjaer pulled it down and buried it beyond Wright with almost insolent ease. 'He has a marvellous instinct for goal,' Ferguson purred. 'He controlled the ball and put it in the net before the defender could get close.'

Burley sent on Alun Armstrong at half-time and saw his substitute bring a point-blank save from Fabien Barthez with virtually his first touch, but that was about as good as it got for Ipswich. The only other occasion Barthez was worried was when Wes Brown sliced a clearance and almost contributed an own goal.

United replaced Giggs after an hour with David Healy, a 21-year-old who has scored five times for Northern Ireland but is still waiting to open his Old Trafford account. He almost managed it 15 minutes from time, but was unlucky to see his firm header from Beckham's cross strike an upright.

Those incidents apart, the second half was anti-climax, though Ipswich will be well content with one win in Manchester per week. No one wanted to see Burley's players humiliated, and you can't blame United for pacing themselves.

They've got the FA Cup to worry about this season, after all.

fields.headline: Hutchison works best
fields.trailText: The wait goes on for Shaun Wright-Phillips. The diminutive midfielder is still looking for his first Premiership goal, but went agonisingly close again during Manchester City's second-half pursuit of a point they warranted.
fields.byline: John Wardle at The Stadium of Light
fields.body:
The wait goes on for Shaun Wright-Phillips. The diminutive midfielder is still looking for his first Premiership goal, but went agonisingly close again during Manchester City's second-half pursuit of a point they warranted.

It's a frustrating time for the adopted son of Ian Wright and increasingly unfortunate for City, who have hit the bar in recent matches more often than a festive drunk.

Yesterday, it was the post that denied Wright-Phillips when the smallest player on the pitch was left in space and headed Paul Dickov's cross past keeper Thomas Sorensen.

'He's getting better - he used to head them over the bar,' said City manager Joe Royle, whose joke couldn't disguise his dismay at their seventh defeat in nine League games.

This was one of their better displays, though. Trailing to a first-half goal from makeshift striker Don Hutchison, City put together a series of second-half attacks that stretched Sunderland to the limit.

Sunderland may not be a stylish team who make the spirits soar and cynics will wonder if they are just riding their luck at the moment with a place in the top six. But they are mighty effective - and Reid has the uncanny ability to make the right decision. He plumped for midfielder Hutchison as the replacement for suspended striker Kevin Phillips yesterday and the Scot responded with the free-kick, which threaded its way through an ill-prepared wall and past wrong-footed keeper Nicky Weaver.

Weaver also saved from Niall Quinn's long-range effort in a first half when City's solitary threat was an eighth-minute shot from Shaun Goater. They were transformed after the interval, largely thanks to the introduction of substitute Ian Bishop's midfield awareness.

Sorensen saved from Dickov, while Wright-Phillips and Alfie Haaland went close and Sunderland defender Emerson Thome was twice in danger of beating his own keeper.

Reid admitted: 'We rode our luck. They were pouring men forward in the second half and we couldn't kill them off, but we are digging out results and that's a good habit.'

Royle said: 'There are not many sides who will come here and push back Sunderland like we did. We just didn't have the finish when we needed it.'

Which takes us back to Wright-Phillips. 'He's a very positive player,' said his manager. 'When he eventually gets his first goal, more will follow.'

City's destiny this season could depend on Royle being right.

fields.headline: Houllier's new dawn
fields.trailText: If Liverpool are not to win the Premiership title in 2001 they are certainly determined to do the next best thing and have a large say in who does.
fields.body:
If Liverpool are not to win the Premiership title in 2001 they are certainly determined to do the next best thing and have a large say in who does.

Seven days, six points, five goals and two clean sheets. The numbers add up to an extraordinary week for Gérard Houllier's Liverpool and, in all probability, in the fate of this season's championship contest.

The scoreline in the meeting between French heavyweights Houllier and Arsène Wenger flattered the former considerably, but, in the wake of last week's 1-0 victory at Manchester United, Liverpool are rapidly improving and the residual confidence left from that Old Trafford success so tangible it could be bottled and sold over the Christmas perfume counter.

'It is a good win,' said Houllier, making a late bid for managerial understatement of the year award. 'Not many teams win 4-0 against Arsenal and 1-0 at Old Trafford in the same week.'

Actually, Liverpool themselves did as well as that, five years ago this month under Roy Evans, beating United 2-0 and Arsenal 3-1 inside a week to launch another false dawn in the club's recent history. That championship challenge evaporated by the spring, which possibly explains why talk of title potential was muted at Anfield yesterday.

'I don't think Manchester United will drop 10 points in the second half of the season,' said Houllier, talking before the champions' meeting with Ipswich yesterday. 'I still regret that we are possibly five or six points short if we are to have a run at the Champions League. Even if we have beaten them, it doesn't mean we are at Manchester United's level. We are not. But this team will get better in the second half of the season.'

Better? Yesterday it looked good enough to easily dismiss Arsenal, who most 'experts' have nominated as runners-up elect. The excellent Steven Gerrard, irrepressible in successive games that have seen him take on and dominate Roy Keane and Patrick Vieira, opened the scoring with a 23-yard right-foot shot after Vieira's clearance from Markus Babbel's long throw-in fell to him outside the area.

Arsenal began to exert some control as the half drew to a close but the game hinged on the opening moments of the second period when Sander Westerveld superbly kept out a long-range Dennis Bergkamp volley. Their frustrations mounting, Arsenal were pedestrian at the back as Emile Heskey shrugged off Martin Keown in the 61st minute, had his shot parried poorly by Alex Manninger for Michael Owen to beat Silvinho to the loose ball.

Wenger said it was that which finished his side off. 'After that we weren't able to fight back mentally any more. Maybe we were guilty of being not mentally capable of reacting, but basically the second goal was the end of the game. We were not good enough.'

Certainly Arsenal's heads dropped after the second goal and eight minutes later, a fully fledged rout was in motion. Vladimir Smicer, an efficient replacement for the disappointing Danny Murphy, threaded the ball through for Nick Barmby to lift it over Manninger.

This being Anfield, there was the opportunity for a little soap opera intrigue with Robbie Fowler, supposedly at odds with the manager and supposedly soon to be sold, brought on for the last 11 minutes. With Arsenal pushing forward, there wasspace for him to operate effectively. A deserved Fowler goal came with almost the last kick of the game, a superb finish from a tightish angle after excellent approach play by Barmby.

webTitle: Derby set for happier New Year

fields.headline: Derby set for happier New Year
fields.trailText: It took Derby 14 games to record their first victory of the season, but after this fully deserved victory they have lost just one of their last six and are edging slowly away from the relegation that for so long this season has seemed their destiny.
fields.body:
It took Derby 14 games to record their first victory of the season, but after this fully deserved victory they have lost just one of their last six and are edging slowly away from the relegation that for so long this season has seemed their destiny.

Having won their first two games of 2000, Derby have spent most of the last 12 months trying to repeat the feat. For most of that time winning even single games has been difficult enough, but in following last week's defeat of Coventry with this win they are ending the year in the manner that it began. 'Even before a ball was kicked we knew this would be a crucial period for us,' said Jim Smith, who suggested three causes of their recent improvement: 'Confidence, consistent team selection and Taribo West'.

It helps to be playing teams as bad as Newcastle were. Their second-half performance was poor; their first-half display much, much worse. Alan Shearer was their only inspiration, twice coming close with headers - one saved, the other cleared off the line - and twice stretching the home defence with low centres. From the second of those Stephen Glass, eight yards out with an open net to aim at, hit embarrassingly high.

By then, though, Newcastle were already two goals down, both coming from Craig Burley crosses after free-kicks. In the 33rd minute, Horacio Carbonari was rewarded for good work in the build-up when Warren Barton's misdirected clearing header from Burley's cross found him free to volley home.

Deon Burton made the game safe in the 73rd minute, scoring with a simple volley when found unmarked by Burley's cross. The entire Newcastle defence, it seemed, had followed Didier Domi's lead in going awol. With Leeds and Manchester United to come before the turn of the year and three more players forced off through injury yesterday, that may not be such a bad idea.

All of which left Bobby Robson incandescent. 'Derby played very well, but they scored from two set-pieces, which has annoyed me intensely,' he said. 'We talk about it, practise it in training but we still can't do anything about it. All I want is for my players to be alert, to be alive, and to be bright. If you're careless driving a car you get killed, so don't be careless on a football pitch.'

Last week an investigation by the Guardian linked Desmond's companies to an internet website offering live sex, despite his insistence that he has nothing to do with hard-core pornography. fields.headline: Said and Done
fields.trailText: Lazio, Leo and the prince
fields.body:
Lazio, Leo and the prince

Lazio, Cameron Diaz and Leonardo Di Caprio have admitted failing to spot an elaborate hoax during the 1-0 Roman derby defeat by Roma last Sunday night. Officials realised after the game that a man claiming to be Prince Andrea Casiraghi of Monaco, who had spent the evening with Diaz, Di Caprio, Daniel Day-Lewis and other glitterati in the VIP suite, was in fact an out-of-work actor. Details of the scam emerged last week when the drama student admitted he had posed as the prince, supported by another actor, Paolo Calabresi, as valet and a by-stander as bodyguard. They saw the whole game with full VIP treatment, plus write-up the next day in the Italian press. It was Calabresi's greatest triumph so far - previous scams include strolling into a San Siro suite to see AC Milan, posing as Hollywood star Nicolas Cage. Diaz and Di Caprio's security were said to be 'damn unimpressed'.

Brolin dishes up

Tomas Brolin - Observer fan and elk hater - has found his true vocation: after dabbling in shoes, skin creams, hoover nozzles and property he's finally opened his first restaurant. The hefty Swede, a regular contributer to Said & Done, has named the Stockholm gastrodrome Undici, and says he's finally found something he feels qualified to do. 'It was a big moment. This is a dream I have had since I was in Italy,' he says. 'All the dishes in here, in this place of mine, are my own ideas and I am proud of it. When I was in Italy eating wonderful food this idea came to me - and I've added some dishes from the north of Sweden which my mum made me like.' Opening reviews have been mixed, but that's nothing new for the big man. 'I'm not the finished article yet,' he admits. 'But I am learning all the time and I am getting sharper every day.'

The Brolin business empire in full: TU & CO AB (catering), Femkes AB (property), Tomas Brolin AB (shoes), Twinnovation AB (vacuum cleaner nozzles), Ponsus Pharma AB (skin care), and four Swedish race horses.

Nice one my Sun

Another top Sun world exclusive hit pages three and six on Thursday - 'On me 'ead son! Ginola dyes bonce - Exclusive'. Sun hacks revealed how David Ginola has 'admitted a dark secret - he has started dying his hair' and wheeled out Mickey Droy to pass a furious 'in my day' verdict, headlined 'If I'd Put Hair Gel On Before A Big Match The Lads Would Have Kicked Me To Death In The Dressing Room'. Good stuff - copied quote for quote, of course, from last week's Said & Done .

Win: new Rough Guide

A top New Year present: the latest version of the Rough Guide to European Football is out now. Featuring club guides for 30 countries, travelling tips, matchday info and photos, it's still the definitive guide to surviving away legs at Kuusysi Lahti. To win one of 10 copies, answer this: which film star shares a name with the Sturm Graz stadium? a) Brigitte Bardot b) Macaulay Culkin c) Arnold Schwarzenegger? Send your answer to Rough Guide competition, Observer Sport, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or email sport@observer.co.uk.

The Rough Guide to European Football (£12.99) is available now.

Quote of the week

'Nobody tells me how I should present myself in public. I will completely shit on anybody who doesn't like that.'

Bayern captain Stefan Effenberg after criticism from club president Franz Beckenbauer of his Christmas Party dress code violation. Effenberg wore cowboy boots and lederhosen.

webTitle: Phlegm to fantasy makes me a cynic

fields.headline: Phlegm to fantasy makes me a cynic
fields.standfirst: Alan Smith says he thought he had 'lost' the Palace fans
fields.trailText: It was 24 October. Only eight-and-a-half weeks ago but it seems like an eternity in my career as manager of Crystal Palace. That was the night we lost at home to Grimsby, our sixth consecutive defeat in the league, and the moment when I honestly believed I had lost it as far as Palace's fans were concerned.
fields.body:
It was 24 October. Only eight-and-a-half weeks ago but it seems like an eternity in my career as manager of Crystal Palace. That was the night we lost at home to Grimsby, our sixth consecutive defeat in the league, and the moment when I honestly believed I had lost it as far as Palace's fans were concerned.

I remember walking down the tunnel with their phlegm on my overcoat and their jeers ringing in my ears, and I really didn't know how I was ever going to win them back.

Yet now, as we sit in mid-table with a Worthington Cup semi-final against Liverpool to come, it seems a long, long time ago - notwithstanding our Friday defeat at home to Blackburn which ended our recent unbeaten run. The whole experience, which most managers go through at some time or another, is very unpleasant and hurtful, and from has certainly made me more cynical about this business. When you get letters of vile abuse - not even signed - you realise what sort of people there are out there. You cannot help but take it personally, and it is even worse for your family and friends.

My wife and family attend every game and probably took the abuse more personally than I did.

I have been lucky enough to be able to turn our situation round, but it did not always look possible. It didn't start well when, on the day I was appointed last August, I had to appease a group of fans who could not understand why I was taking over from Steve Coppell, who was a hero to them for keeping the club going during all the upheaval last season.

It was a similar situation a few years ago when I succeeded Martin O'Neill as manager of Wycombe Wanderers. He was an icon there, and consequently there was a lot of resentment towards me trying to impose new ideas.

One of my biggest problems at Palace was that I had so little time in which to do it. The players were clearly unfit. I tried to introduce some of the things that I'd seen Jean Tigana do at Fulham, but the difference was that he'd been appointed in May and had so much more time to change things.

Looking back, perhaps I tried to do too much, too soon, things like training twice a day, gym sessions, changing the players' diets, and so on. I had to show my hand early and one of my first jobs was to trim the squad of players who were not up to it as far as I was concerned. Unfortunately some of them were also some of the most influential, and subsequently became the most disruptive.

It was only when we finally paid up contracts and got rid of them that we eliminated the problem. Expensive, yes, but it could have been far more costly to the club to let it fester.

The chairman, Simon Jordan, backed me all the way and his support was and still is a huge factor. He made it absolutely clear that certain players were more at danger of being kicked out than me - that sharpened their minds.

On the pitch, we had played quite well against some decent sides and had just not got the rub of the green, but we had also played badly and without much passion. I remember a defeat in that manner at Preston, the second game of our bad run. The fans started chanting for Coppell, and the comments and body language of the players told me that things were not right.

I told them there and then that things would have to change, but it got worse. At that stage I could not even look at the league table - and hardly dared pick up the local paper.

I was losing the support of fans who had previously argued my case, and after that Grimsby game, they'd had enough and wanted a change. And then two things happened_ I had it out with the players and went public with the criticism, which is not something I thought I'd ever do, and our luck started to change.

The two may be related but whatever the reason, our fortunes improved. Next game, at Bolton, we came back to equalise with the last kick of the game. Suddenly there was hope that we might get the breaks we desperately needed.

It started our run which including victories against Leicester and Sunderland, both good Premiership sides. Confidence came flooding back through the club to the fans and people are starting to talk about making the play-offs.

That may be fanciful - but at least I can walk with pride among Palace's supporters - and dare to read the results pages again.

fields.headline: Lynam to front new show
fields.trailText: ITV will screen a Premiership highlights programme on at least two, and sometimes as many as four, nights a week from next season.
fields.body:
ITV will screen a Premiership highlights programme on at least two, and sometimes as many as four, nights a week from next season.

The main Saturday show will be fronted by Des Lynam and broadcast early in the evening in a concerted effort to get more than the 4-5 million audience which currently watches Match of the Day . But ITV will also have a regular Monday-night package, starting around 10.30 or 11pm.

There will be an occasional Sunday Premiership pro gramme too, although this will be limited to 10 weekends per season because Sky's contract with the Premier League requires it to release just three minutes of highlights of its Sunday game to other broadcasters. So ITV needs at least two other clubs to be playing at home that day as well to justify a Sunday slot. Therefore the longer Premiership clubs stay in the Uefa Cup, which is played on Thursdays and involves moving league games to Sundays, the more Sunday shows ITV will show.

In addition to that, the network also plans an occasional Wednesday late-evening Premiership show, but only when most teams are playing midweek, as happens early and late in the season. There will be six of these at most.

ITV executives are aware that, especially as they already show a Champions League match on 17 Wednesdays, this feast of football may strike some as too much. But having won the rights from the BBC, for the huge sum of £61 million a season, they are determined to show their arch-rivals how to properly exploit such a lucrative asset.

fields.headline: Football's rulers accused of 'fixing' watchdog
fields.trailText: Football's rulers have been accused of trying to secretly rig the appointment of the game's first 'independent' watchdog in a bid to get someone sympathetic to them.
fields.body:
Football's rulers have been accused of trying to secretly rig the appointment of the game's first 'independent' watchdog in a bid to get someone sympathetic to them.

Having already controversially secured a seat on the selection panel which will pick the chairman of the new Independent Football Commission, the football authorities have now persuaded the Government to seek new candidates for the chairman's post - because they did not like contenders who had applied by last month's supposedly final deadline.

Despite that process having thrown up several strong candidates, football's governing bodies - led by the Premier League - are insisting that 'the quality of the field is poor' and that other people should be approached to put themselves forward.

Headhunters are now likely to be appointed to solicit fresh applications, with the Football Association or the Premier League almost certainly paying the thousands of pounds involved.

Fan groups have con demned this latest intervention by football's powers-that-be in the setting-up of the watchdog as a blatant attempt to 'fix' the IFC chairmanship. 'This is the football authorities once again meddling in the process', said Adam Brown, a fan activist and member of the Government's Football Task Force.

'It's ridiculous that football has a representative on the selection panel and it's absolutely absurd that the Premier League are being allowed to find someone they find sympathetic to chair this body. If football pays for headhunters to approach candidates, when we have already gone through an open and fair public appointments procedure, that will make a mockery of any idea of the IFC chairman being independent', added Brown. 'The football authorities clearly do not like the candidates who have already applied and are trying to skew the process in their favour.'

Advertisements for the £15,000-a-year, part-time job said the IFC chairman should be 'an outstanding individual [who would] establish and lead a new self-regulatory body overseeing the football industry'. When applications closed, more than 40 people had applied. Of those, three or four are said to be good quality applicants.

Although the IFC is meant to be independent, football's rulers fear the chairmanship might go to someone who will use it to investigate clubs and pursue fans' complaints with, for them, potentially uncomfortable zeal. Observer Sport revealed last week that FA chief executive Adam Crozier believed that appointing Richard Scudamore, his Premier League counterpart, as football's representative on the four-strong IFC selec tion panel would send out negative signals to supporters about the new body's integrity.

Scudamore has persuaded Chris Smith, the Culture, Media and Sport Secretary, that new candidates should be approached in order to 'widen the field'.

But this latest move in the long-running watchdog controversy may be part of a behind-the-scenes effort by football to block one of the handful of 'quality applicants' already identified because it fears he may be too independent-minded.

fields.headline: Best ever, says Fergie
fields.trailText: Perhaps a touch of Christmas cheers had settled over the Manchester United training ground last week or perhaps Sir Alex Ferguson had simply been caught up in the season of giving.
fields.byline: Ian Whittell hears lavish praise heaped on Old Trafford's newest generation
fields.body:
Perhaps a touch of Christmas cheers had settled over the Manchester United training ground last week or perhaps Sir Alex Ferguson had simply been caught up in the season of giving.

Whatever his motives, especially in the light of two successive League results that, in relative terms, amount to a United crisis, the praise Ferguson heaped upon his current United squad was lavish and unfettered.

At various stages in recent seasons, Ferguson has often referred to his sides as being the best United squads of his stewardship, but that assessment has been upwardly revised in the wake of the opening five months of the current season.

This, he claims, is not only the best United team of his 14-year reign, but the best United team ever, a view that is apparently shared by Sir Bobby Charlton, current football club director and one of the inspirational figures of the 1968 Sir Matt Busby European Cup winning side, an eclectic group of talent that many would still honour with the 'best ever' tag. The present side also, Ferguson controversially suggests, eclipses the earlier Busby teams, including the 1958 'Babes', simply because the Munich disaster robbed that side of the chance to fulfil their enormous potential.

'This is the best side this club has ever had,' said Ferguson. 'I have spoken to Bobby about this a couple of times and he probably shares that opinion.

'It is difficult to compare eras. But the number of games they have got, the media profile they have nowadays, these players handle it very well. The statistics point to that also. They have surpassed the '68 team. The '58 team, no one knows. That probably would have been the greatest team ever, but no one knows.

'The point about this team is that it is not me that has to make the decisions about their place in football history. They will do that themselves. If they keep that momentum going, keep winning, eventually people will say it's a terrific team.

'At the moment there will still be some discerning, reluctant voice about how well they have done. The important thing, the vital ingredient, is that hunger they have got, wanting to achieve. That's what pleases me. And when you have seen them growing up together. It's terrific.'

Ferguson's view is one that is certain to spark debate among both United and football fans in general.

Traditionally, it has been deemed almost sacrilegious at Old Trafford and its environs to suggest that a line-up including the 'holy trinity' of Best, Law and Charlton could be eclipsed by any of their successors.

Yet, as Ferguson points out, the bare statistics support his claim emphatically. Sir Matt Busby won two League titles, the FA Cup and, of course, the European Cup in a six-season period from 1963-68. In the eight seasons since Ferguson led United to the Premiership title, he has amassed six championships, three FA Cups, the 1999 European Cup and Inter-continental championship later the same year.

Whatever the arguments about the relative merits of the domestic game in the Sixties and Nineties, in terms of pure volume Ferguson's teams have shown a thirst and desire for success far superior to that displayed by their predecessors.

As Irving Berlin said, 'The toughest thing about being a success is that you've got to keep on being a success,' and it is this aspect of United's continued dominance that gives their manager the most pleasure. 'I use the analogy that some people just want to go on a foreign holiday once in their life, they want to go to Spain to say they have been there and come back. That's it,' said Ferguson.

'My players want to win, they have great pride, they are hungry. The hunger they have got is nothing to do with putting bread on the table or getting £1 million in the bank. It is about trying to achieve things, and then strive for other things. They have been great that way.

'You always hope there is a percentage, an inch of improvement to come. That is the way life is. We have got to be like that, it's a moving bus, we can't wait for people.

'I think the maturity this team has shown is the main reason for that. The players have grown up together, it's a good team now, a really good team.

'The team spirit has got better. They have forged a lot of friendships that are going to last, there is a good spirit in the dressing room. Even when a player is left out, they are sharing in his disappointment, because they are friends.

'And if a player is left out, he is supporting the player who has got his position. I think that is unusual in modern football.'

Of course, the timing of Ferguson's comments, coming after an uncharacteristically sloppy 3-3 draw at Charlton and their first home league defeat in two years against Liverpool, could have been more appropriate.

A league title race that looked as interesting as a Christmas TV schedule a few short weeks ago has suddenly been transformed into a contest of US presidential proportions, so desperate are sections of the media to present Arsenal's five-point deficit as cause for nail-biting drama and tension. If the second half of the season is to provide United with more obstacles than the first, it is a challenge Ferguson and his players will relish.

'I think the competition is a good thing for us. The important thing about the last two results is it brings the focus on winning all the time,' said Ferguson.

'If complacency sets in in March or April it is difficult to get it back. This has been a nice reminder that we're going to have to work as normal to win this league, the challenge could come from anywhere.

'After New Year we will have a good indication of where the main challenges are coming from, by the halfway stage. If we can be in first place on New Year's Day when we play West Ham, we will have a big chance then.

'As chasing teams, I don't think you can ever give up on these things. Look at '98 when we were 12 points ahead of Arsenal and they won the league from us. You can't say for certain.

'But I would like to think, unless we have a catastrophe of an injury list, that if we're 12 points ahead this year we won't lose it.'

webTitle: Cruising: I buried my fag packet at sea

fields.headline: I buried my fag packet at sea
fields.standfirst: Michael Holland will stand on the burning deck no more
fields.trailText: Michael Holland will stand on the burning deck no more.
fields.body:
It is 1.45pm during the fag end of Italian summer time, and I have just smoked what I fervently believe to be my last cigarette. This is it; this is the moment when, after 30 years of smoking this infernal weed, I quit. No patches, no inhalers, no gum; just plenty of good old plain cold turkey - and the small fillip of a week's cruise around the coast of Italy from Rome to Venice aboard a five-masted luxurious sailing ship.

They say that one good way of stopping smoking is to do something really indulgent to help keep your mind away from the nagging compulsion of the habit. Well, this is my indulgence - to be one of the 312 guests being pampered by the 163-strong crew of the Wind Surf.

We are promised haute cuisine and fine wines, and no worries about keeping it all down as the ship has a unique computer-controlled ballasting system which prevents a heel of anything more than two to three degrees and limits the pitch and roll of the waves to a gentle rocking of the deck.

We are promised 156 elegant en suite staterooms, each with a sea view, TV, video, CD player, fridge and phone. We are promised day rooms and lounges, and bars, of course: deck bars, pool bars, piano bars and more. We are promised hot tubs and cool pools and a gym and an open-air drop-down sports platform at the stern with snorkelling, scuba diving, sailboards, waters skis, kayaks and inflatables.

But most of all we are promised the wide open ocean and strengthening winds snapping at seven enormous sails strung fore-and-aft from the masts that rise 204ft above us. And we are promised the salty Mediterranean sting of sunlit days and star-pricked nights framing lashings and lashings of fresh, fresh air, untrammelled by the ghastly rasp of a gasper.

There is a Sheraton hotel on the outskirts of Rome, not far from Fiumicino airport, that through no fault of its own is the final place of infamy in my grimy tar-encrusted pantheon of smoking. Here the last snout was lit and seven minutes later stubbed out on the floor of the poolside bar when those travelling to Civitavecchia to embark the Wind Surf were summoned to their coaches for the hour's drive to the little town being developed as Rome's new cruise terminal.

In late September the power of the summer sun is waning but still it is strong enough to radiate waves of drowsiness through the windows of the bus as it passes through the un- inspiring countryside north-west of Rome. But then, as we turn off the main drag and wind down a small slope leading to the port, Wind Surf's magnificent masts finger their way above the horizon. Fifteen minutes later and we are handing over our passports, having our tickets checked and baggage labelled before climbing the gangway aboard.

We 300-plus are quickly processed and having marked our nests for the next seven days are just as quickly back on deck to line the rails for our departure. With bow thrusters and a couple of tugs, Wind Surf seems to be able to turn her 17,745 gross tons in little over her 617ft length, and soon we are heading past the last mole and out into the open sea. Ah, this is the life - standing almost at the bows, wind in my hair, glass of champagne in one hand and, oh no, a gaping void in the other where the cigarette should be. It's my first pang of craving, the first of so many.

But then, as was often to happen on this trip, something unexpected slew the wicked demon of addiction perched just out of sight on my left shoulder and whispering in my ear: 'Go on, have one. What's the difference? One's not going to make a difference. Go on, you're on holiday. You'll love it.' This time it was the unfurling of the sails as the wind speed indicators on the bridge passed the minimum 10 knots needed and the captain gave the order.

Wind Surf may boast a crew of more than 160, but no one has to run up the rigging and out on to the yardarms to hang these sails. More than 90 per cent of the crew are here to look after every whim of the guests, and the few that don't directly - deck, bridge and engineroom officers and crew - are pretty well protected from the elements. On the bridge the captain gives the order and electric motors whir into life rotating the forestays of each mast around which a sail is wound while at the same time a small truck drags the aft end of the sail back along the hydraulic booms. In two minutes the sails are set, as they were more than half the time we were at sea.

A few more glasses of champagne and, blow me, it's time for dinner, as in five-course dinner consisting, for instance, of an appetiser of a tower of smoked salmon with crème frache, followed by red onion soup, seared sea scallops with chive mashed potato, crème brlée and followed by coffee and petits fours. Five courses, every night; it meant that the post-prandial blow round the deck under the stars became obligatory if one wanted to a) maintain some level of basic fitness and b) cast out the ciggie demon. And so to bed, lured to sleep by the cosseting swell of the Tyrrhenian Sea.

Our course for the next seven days would take us south-east from Civitavecchia to the tiny port of Amalfi in the Gulf of Salerno, south-south-easterly to Taormina in Sicily, a long run across the Ionian Sea north-east to Corfu, north-north-west into the Adriatic to picturesque Dubrovnik, north-west, threading through the hundreds of islands off the Dalmatian coast to the medieval town of Rab, and a final west-north-westerly hop across to Venice.

But first there was breakfast to negotiate, taken al fresco on the top, or Star, deck of the ship. The Wind Surf, like its smaller sister sailing ships, the Wind Star, Wind Spirit and Wind Song, is American-owned, though crewed by mainly Indonesians and Filipinos with British and Norwegian officers. Prices are in dollars and pomposity is at a minimum. Dress is casual, though you could add 'elegant' to casual for dinner.

One good thing about this is of course today's attitude towards smoking on the part of most Americans - if you do choose to do it, you are a pariah and are relegated to a small area topside at the stern with the dwindling band of the rest of your kind. If you don't do it you can join the happy smiling majority with the freedom to roam the ship or call in for a chat about our progress at the ever open bridge.

Another good thing, as I was smokelessly saying, is breakfast: cereals, mounds of fruit, eggs cooked any way you want, hickory-smoked bacon, waffles, pancakes, French toast, freshly squeezed juice and brewed coffee. All is taken while the ship swings at anchor to the backdrop of whichever port while fantastically smart immigration officials spin out to clear us for landing.

Once the officials give the green light, Wind Surf drops its own launches into the water and begins a regular tender service to the shore. At each port we visit, guided excursions are on offer - to Pompeii from Amalfi, to the Achillion Palace in Corfu, to the Konavle Valley for a traditional lunch outside Dubrovnik, for example. Alternatively, you hop ashore and make your own entertainment,.

An unmissable excursion for me was to Mount Etna in Sicily, beginning as surprisingly few of us piled into buses on the quayside at Giardini Naxos, just below Taormina. (Actually, for me it had really started with a dawn call to watch our passage through the Straits of Messina followed by a brisk two-mile walk - five and half turns around the Bridge Deck equals one mile - to work off last night's dinner to make room for this morning's breakfast.) An hour later, we were pulling into a cable car station having climbed 6,250ft along tiny roads winding through old lava flows. The cable car lurches up a further 1,900ft before a fleet of four-wheel drive minibuses takes us through a black scorched moonscape to just under 10,000ft.

Whenever I crave tobacco, I think of a trick our guide proudly showed us amid the swirling sulphrous mists and their faint stink of rotten eggs. 'Anyone have a cigarette?' she asked. Instinctively I put my hand in my pocket. Someone else came up with the goods. She lit one, and leaning down blew smoke towards a small indentation. Immediately there was a rancorous exhalation by the very blackened ground. I think of my lungs and my breath; as aversion therapy it's unbeatable.

They say - them again - that the worst times when giving up smoking come in threes; three days, three weeks, three months, even three years. Well, the third day was awful. It was the day of the long reach across the Ionian Sea, so no port of call today. It started fine; breakfast, reading and sunbathing till lunch, then more sunbathing while the captain shut down the engines leaving us under canvas alone for three hours or more. It was wonderful and exhilarating to watch the prop wash disappear and feel the vessel ride the waves rather than plough through them. So good I thought I'd have a cigarette. No, banish the idea, but this time it wouldn't go.

I don't know how I got through the rest of that day. I kidded myself that I could have a cigar after dinner but the cheapest one was 18 bucks (money is another good averter). But get through it I did, and the rest of the week, thanks to the magnificent indulgence of this gentle vessel and the attention of its dedicated crew. And thanks to the memory of it I got through the three-week watershed. And now, coming up to Christmas, pray for me, please.

 Michael Holland's voyage was organised by Windstar Cruises, 77-79 Great Eastern Street, London EC2A 3HU; tel 020 7739 5414 ; fax 020 7729 1235; www.windstarcruises.com. He flew to Rome from Heathrow and from Venice to Heathrow with British Airways. Mediterranean cruises start at £2,115 for seven nights, including flights. Windstar vessels also cruise in the Caribbean.

fields.headline: Hayles strike rescues Fulham
fields.trailText: Fulham showed their character as well as their skill in coming from behind to win 2-1 at Crewe.
fields.body:
Fulham showed their character as well as their skill in coming from behind to win 2-1 at Crewe.

Before the match, Crewe's manager Dario Gradi, recalling the 2-0 defeat by Fulham at the start of the season, said: 'We hardly had a kick of the ball and I think they must have thought they were doing shadow play.

'I hope we can do better than that, but we'll have to get the ball and try to keep it. We've got different ways of playing and I've asked the players what they want to do. That should mean they have a chance of doing the jobs I want them to do.'

Gradi must certainly have been pleased with his struggling team in the first half, especially when Mark Rivers latched on to Neil Sorvel's looping cross to volley past Maik Taylor in the 18th minute. But Fulham, who appeared well below their best, salvaged some of their pride through a Luis Boa Morte equaliser just after half-time, and Barry Hayles completed the job.

Bolton, Fulham's closest Championship challengers, owed much to their substitute, Michael Ricketts for their 2-0 win at Burnley. They dominated the first half, but were repeatedly denied a goal by Burnley's keeper, Nick Michopoulos. But Ricketts broke the deadlock with his first touch and added the other to bring his total to 14.

If any team threatened with relegation can be expected to be led to safety, it is surely one with a man by the name of Moses.

In the case of Huddersfield, the man in question is Adie Moses, the 25-year-old defender whom they have signed from Barnsley for £225,000 and who made his debut at the heart of their defence at Watford.

He must have wondered what he had got himself into when Huddersfield, having deservedly gone ahead through Peter Ndlovu, allowed Watford to get back on level terms through a back-pass by one of his teammates - Tommy Heary which eluded the Huddersfield keeper and bounced into the net.

But Huddersfield, who belied their bottom-of-the-table position, were given a 2-1 victory by Daley Facey. All of which augurs well for Moses helping Huddersfield to survive. He is one of the most versatile defenders in the league, and Huddersfield's manager, Lou Macari, says of him: 'Adie is exactly the sort of player we have been looking for. He is strong, quick and can play anywhere across the back four. He'll be a valuable addition to our squad.'

Moses had 18 months left on his Barnsley contract and the decision to sell him was taken by Dave Bassett. Following Bassett's resignation last week, Barnsley's caretaker-manager, Eric Winstanley, attempted to keep the player with the offer of a new agreement. But in an interview on Huddersfield's official website, Moses said: 'I look at this move as a fresh start after spending all of my career with one club.

'I enjoyed my time with Barnsley but I felt I needed a new challenge and when Huddersfield expressed an interest their offer was too good to turn down. Huddersfield are a massive club who I believe are in a false position in the League. Hopefully, I can help change that.'

Two other notable First Division performances came from QPR, who held Birmingham to a goalless draw, and Wimbledon, who gained their eighth away win of the season at the expense of Tranmere.

They had Rob Gier sent off, when they were 2-0 ahead, but still managed to increase their lead to 4-0. Jason Euell scored their last two goals and their other scorers were Trond Anderson and Mark Williams. Among the best goals of the day was the one scored by Wolves's captain, Kevin Muscat, from a free kick, which gave his side a 1-0 win at Sheffield Wednesday.

But Fulham, who appeared well below their best, salvaged some of their pride through a Luis Boa Morte equaliser just after half-time, and Barry Hayles completed the job. Bolton, Fulham's closest Championship challengers, owed much to their substitute, Michael Ricketts for their 2-0 win at Burnley. They dominated the first half, but were repeatedly denied a goal by Burnley's keeper, Nick Michopoulos. But Ricketts broke the deadlock with his first touch and added the other to bring his total to 14. If any team threatened with relegation can be expected to be led to safety, it is surely one with a man by the name of Moses. In the case of Huddersfield, the man in question is Adie Moses, the 25-year-old defender whom they have signed from Barnsley for £225,000 and who made his debut at the heart of their defence at Watford. He must have wondered what he had got himself into when Huddersfield, having deservedly gone ahead through Peter Ndlovu, allowed Watford to get back on level terms through a back-pass by one of his teammates - Tommy Heary which eluded the Huddersfield keeper and bounced into the net. But Huddersfield, who belied their bottom-of-the-table position, were given a 2-1 victory by Daley Facey. All of which augurs well for Moses helping Huddersfield to survive. He is one of the most versatile defenders in the league, and Huddersfield's manager, Lou Macari, says of him: 'Adie is exactly the sort of player we have been looking for. He is strong, quick and can play anywhere across the back four. He'll be a valuable addition to our squad.' Moses had 18 months left on his Barnsley contract and the decision to sell him was taken by Dave Bassett. Following Bassett's resignation last week, Barnsley's caretaker-manager, Eric Winstanley, attempted to keep the player with the offer of a new agreement. But in an interview on Huddersfield's official website, Moses said: 'I look at this move as a fresh start after spending all of my career with one club. 'I enjoyed my time with Barnsley but I felt I needed a new challenge and when Huddersfield expressed an interest their offer was too good to turn down. Huddersfield are a massive club who I believe are in a false position in the League. Hopefully, I can help change that.' Two other notable First Division performances came from QPR, who held Birmingham to a goalless draw, and Wimbledon, who gained their eighth away win of the season at the expense of Tranmere. They had Rob Gier sent off, when they were 2-0 ahead, but still managed to increase their lead to 4-0. Jason Euell scored their last two goals and their other scorers were Trond Anderson and Mark Williams. Among the best goals of the day was the one scored by Wolves's captain, Kevin Muscat, from a free kick, which gave his side a 1-0 win at Sheffield Wednesday.

fields.headline: Gunnarsson's blunder rescues Wigan
fields.trailText: Wigan salvaged a point they scarcely deserved courtesy of a 90th-minute own goal by Stoke's Brynjar Gunnarsson, which served to punish the visitors for failing to take their chances.
fields.byline: Mike Prestage at The JJB Stadium
fields.body:
Wigan salvaged a point they scarcely deserved courtesy of a 90th-minute own goal by Stoke's Brynjar Gunnarsson, which served to punish the visitors for failing to take their chances.

Last year's fixture between the sides was marred by crowd trouble, when the memory of Stoke legend Sir Stanley Matthews was sullied when home fans ignored a minute's silence for the recently departed football knight and fighting broke out between rival fans. As a result this season's encounter kicked off at noon and there was a heavy police presence to marshal a crowd of just under 9,000. Happily, there were no problems this time.

Last year Stoke were the victors and they looked to have maintained their jinx over second-placed Wigan. They had taken a well-deserved lead in the 65th minute when the ball was swung in from the left by Rikhadur Dadason and James O'Connor arrived in the box unmarked to send a well-directed header wide of Derek Stillie in the Wigan net.

Against a Wigan side looking increasingly clueless as the game wore on Stoke had ample opportunities to make the points secure. Bjarni Gudjonsson hit the bar with a nonchalant chip, a powerful shot by Peter Thorne was beaten away by Stillie and the Wigan keeper palmed a powerful shot from Graham Kavanagh to safety.

There was always a chance that Stoke would be made to pay for such profligacy and so it proved. Wigan committed themselves to attack as the clock ticked down, but even then they struggled to carve clear chances against a solid Stoke defence. In the end the goal was a gift from the hapless Gunnarsson who, challenged by Lee Ashcroft, turned an Andy Liddell cross into his own net.

It ensured Wigan maintained an enviable record of having only lost one league game this season.

Both sides made the play-offs last campaign and on this showing both look good enough to at least equal that feat this year. The Wigan manager, Bruce Rioch, correctly identified the need for a proven goalscorer, pointing out that his side had scored an average of 10 goals less than their top-of-the-table rivals.

'It was an interesting game played in a good atmosphere,' he said. 'I think in a game of this magnitude it is always going to be tight. We finally got the goal and though it came late it was certainly a case of better late than never.'

Wigan had actually started the match the brighter side. They had a goal by Liddell ruled out for offside and created other clear chances where poor finishing let them down. But Stoke then wrested control and established comfortable supremacy in midfield.

The Stoke manager Gudjon Thordarson believes his side have hit form at just the right time. Certainly memories of an 8-0 hammering by Liverpool in the Worthington Cup and the ignominy of losing an FA Cup tie to non-league Nuneaton Borough appear to be fading.

'There were times when we could have killed the game but we didn't,' he said. 'Before the match I would have taken a point but at the end I am disappointed we did not hold on for the win.'

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Andrew
fields.trailText: Happy new year, keep your mind open and savour the feeling of freedom that you had on the plane - that's real life, not escapism. And don't think of it as a "gap" year...most people's lives amount to one big gap between birth and death, but we are the lucky ones.
fields.body:
Dear Milly,

Please don't imagine that you're "doing nothing" for a year. If you approach it in the right way, you will be doing more and learning more than in ten years of the so-called real world.

Take me for example. I went straight from school to university to a lucrative and supposedly worthwhile career. But looking back, those were just so many years of stagnation for me - five "gap years" of nothingness before I quit, started travelling and began my real life.

Travelling turned into two vocations - writing and English teaching - and I'm now into my sixth year in Asia (at the moment, I'm teaching Tibetan students in northwest China). My only regret is that I didn't leave sooner.

So, happy new year, keep your mind open and savour the feeling of freedom that you had on the plane - that's real life, not escapism. And don't think of it as a "gap" year...most people's lives amount to one big gap between birth and death, but we are the lucky ones.

(Good idea to get that degree first though.)

Best wishes.

fields.headline: A stroll at the Bridge
fields.trailText: If Ken Bates has a vision for English football, yesterday probably summed it up. Do Christmas shopping at the Chelsea Megastore, rest your legs watching a spot of football, do more shopping at the Chelsea Megastore. S and F: shopping and football - it's the Bates fantasy.
fields.body:
If Ken Bates has a vision for English football, yesterday probably summed it up. Do Christmas shopping at the Chelsea Megastore, rest your legs watching a spot of football, do more shopping at the Chelsea Megastore. S and F: shopping and football - it's the Bates fantasy.

Yesterday more fuel was added to it with the tills ringing and his team securing a relatively comfortable victory that sends them into the top half of the table. Now all they have to do is cure what the programme calls 'the curse of away'.

Chelsea lined up in their now usual 3-4-2-1 formation with Frank Leboeuf slotted in at right-back. He looked lost initially but it was to prove to be a cunning ploy.

But first, and briefly, Bradford threatened. A Benito Carbone free-kick was hesitantly punched away by Ed de Goey. A sharp free-kick from Dean Windass put Stuart McCall into a threatening position from which he failed to threaten. That was about as good as it got for Bradford.

For now the Chelsea plan came into play. They would pass the ball prettily and it would eventually come to Lebeouf. He would then launch it accurately 40 or 50 yards to Eidur Gudjohnsen, Gustavo Poyet, Gianfranco Zola or Dennis Wise. In such a way the Bradford offside trap was rendered useless.

And on 21 minutes Chelsea went ahead. The impressive Samule Dalla Bona released Gudjohnsen; his first shot was blocked by Gary Walsh, his second shot was blocked by Walsh, but the ball broke to Poyet who scored with ease.

They should have doubled or trebled their lead. Zola created a one-on-one but failed to convert it. Then, after a clever build-up involving Poyet and Dalla Bona, he scuffed his shot just wide. The Chelsea machine never quite clicked.

All the while, Ranieri looked on, standing neat and prim and proper, by the side of the dugout with his hands clasped behind his back. He and his sidekicks all wore heavy overcoats and resembled the Sopranos, dressed for a formal occasion, hanging around outside their favourite café, the one that serves suckling pig. Stories that he can't speak English may be exaggerated for he had little difficulty in communicating his displeasure with his team, in particular, Marcel Desailly, who was the object of a couple of Ranieri tantrums.

The game improved in the second half. A precise pass from Poyet played in Gudjohnsen, who shot against the bar. Suddenly there was life and passion in what had previously been a rather soporific encounter.

With 25 minutes to go an injured Lebeouf made way for Morris thereby enabling Chelsea to field a three-quarters English midfield. It was the foreign quarter, however, that won it. Dalla Bona received the ball from Gudjohnsen just inside the Bradford half and jinked and jagged through their defence prior to stroking the ball into the net.

Wise and Zola went close to adding further goals, while Morris and Dalla Bona, given time, could become a fine midfield partnership. At last, a youth system begins to emerge at the Bridge. Another part of it might be Gudjohnsen, who with virtually the last kick of the game scored from a tight angle.
