fields.headline: A cruise director reveals all
fields.standfirst: Ken Rush, cruise director of the Explorer of the Seas
fields.trailText: Ken Rush, cruise director of the Explorer of the Seas.
fields.body:
What does your role involve?

A cruise director is in charge of all the activities and entertainment on board. Not only do I M.C. the major events but I am also responsible for putting some of the shows together and I do the scheduling, too. I currently work on Royal Caribbean International's Explorer of the Seas, the largest cruise ship in the world. She is 138,000 tonnes and the facilities include a full-size ice rink, a rock-climbing wall 200 feet above the sea, the largest spa at sea and many different restaurants. I manage a staff of 114 people and I chose to be a cruise director because I love people.

Any famous passengers?

Not so many passengers as the entertainers. Bill Cosby once did a charter cruise and he and I smoked cigars in his suite before his show. He is a great guy; very down to earth.

Your biggest challenges?

Difficult guests are the biggest challenge. Unfortunately there are some people you just can't please, no matter how hard you try. It doesn't happen too often on our ships but when it does I always try to win them over. The best moments are when guests come up to me and tell me that we have made their vacation. A change of itinerary because of bad weather can also be a challenge.

What is the worst part of the job?

I miss my family.

What are your favourite islands?

St Thomas in the Virgin Islands and St Maarten come to mind because they have beautiful beaches and a nice town. But sometimes I don't go ashore at all since I have been to the ports so many times that it is a good time to catch up on paperwork. However, some particularly good bars and restaurants, with authentic food, include Pancho's Backyard in Cozumel and Sloppy Joes and the A & B Lobster House in Key West. Miami is packed with fantastic restaurants, such as Joe's Stone Crab on Miami Beach.

Any tips for future passengers?

Relax. Don't worry about anything!

 Royal Caribbean International: 0800 018 2020. A nine-night Eastern Caribbean cruise on Explorer of the Seas starts at £929 per person (including flights and transfers).

fields.headline: Homewood Park Hotel, Bath
fields.trailText:
Does Homewood Park feel like home?
Homewood Park is a country house hotel, about six miles outside Bath. We arrived at night and from a distance it looked magical, illuminated like an advent calendar with little golden windows in a Georgian building. There was a burst of laughter (from diners within) as we pushed open the front door and a scent of woodsmoke. The atmosphere was welcoming yet not exactly homely. The hotel is a little too close to the road for perfection (though not so close as to disturb your sleep). The decor is conventional, floral - luxury counts more than beauty.
fields.body:
Does Homewood Park feel like home?
Homewood Park is a country house hotel, about six miles outside Bath. We arrived at night and from a distance it looked magical, illuminated like an advent calendar with little golden windows in a Georgian building. There was a burst of laughter (from diners within) as we pushed open the front door and a scent of woodsmoke. The atmosphere was welcoming yet not exactly homely. The hotel is a little too close to the road for perfection (though not so close as to disturb your sleep). The decor is conventional, floral - luxury counts more than beauty.

Luxury?
It is a haven for the weary. Our suite contained a triumphant bath (Victorian in inspiration, free-standing). And if it had been summer, the bathing need never have stopped. A few steps outside our private sitting room was a swimming pool. But the suite costs £250 a night, including breakfast. Slightly less swanky accommodation starts at £94.50. And we have one cavil on the luxury front: someone should keep those logs fires blazing; they were lit but lying low.

Anything more on the subject of Bath?
It's a joy. The Georgian city is flattered by winter, its yellow stone enlivens the eye. We loved the austere grace of Royal Crescent and enjoyed visiting the Roman baths but Jane Austen (whose museum is here) had to make way for Christmas shopping. A great place for it, though, with a tremendous menu of shops.

Menu?
Yes, tremendous menus everywhere. The hotel restaurant definitely earns its Michelin star. The food is a French/English hybrid, each dish an exquisite, precarious masterpiece. I greatly approved of breakfast, too, where the same perfectionism is applied (tea made with real leaves; aromatic porridge, toasted brioche.)

Verdict?
Homewood Park is like a dream: dominated by French taste and (charming) French waiters - yet in the middle of the English countryside. Strange but magnifique.

· Homewood Park Hotel and Restaurant, Hinton Charterhouse, Bath BA3 6BB (01225 723731).

webTitle: Cruising: Mutiny on the high teas

fields.headline: Mutiny on the high teas
fields.standfirst: As our minds turn to holidays next year we look at options afloat. Here Michael Freedland finds that being a ship's purser involves rather more than just wearing that cute uniform
fields.trailText: As our minds turn to holidays next year we look at options afloat. Here Michael Freedland finds that being a ship's purser involves rather more than just wearing that cute uniform.
fields.body:
It was when I was handed a loaded shotgun that I realised I was all at sea - and there was more to being a ship's purser than I thought.True, the original definition of the term meant someone looking after the vessel's purse - in other words, controlling all the money on board. But a shotgun?

That just shows you, I reasoned, how seriously they take the responsibilities of securing the cash and valuables on the good ship Hebridean Princess. But then, come to think of it, being the chief purser on this boat isn't like wearing a senior officer's uniform on any other ship either. Any more than the Hebridean Princess is like any other cruise ship. Everything about the Princess tells you it shouldn't work. Just imagine. It's a converted ferry boat. There are chintz curtains in every room. Some of those rooms have coronets of curtains over the bed - making them look like four-posters. There's even a fireplace in the main lounge. And all on a ship, cruising on the high seas.

But it works marvellously. This is a luxury cruise ship sailing round the Western Isles of Scotland, and it's as beautiful as the surroundings. It is intimate in a way that big ships never are. No more than 48 people are on board at any one time - and, unlike the case on most luxury cruises, the passengers are nearly all British.

You know the captain, Michael Hepburn, well enough to chat about the route. He is always around and says you are welcome on the bridge any time you want. You know the housekeeper, Amanda, by name because she is there every minute of the day, checking that the stewardesses have put the right amount of soap in your bathroom or that the brass rails are shining as brightly as the mirrors. Your waiters and waitresses know what you want the minute you sit at the tables facing the wide, high windows that always give you views, not just of the sea, but of the miles of islands, too.

And you also know Andrew Quarry, the chief purser. Well, how could you not know him? You see him everywhere, too. A nice job, I thought. All the time on the ship, laughing and joking with the guests. Not passengers, but guests. As Captain Hepburn told me: 'Passengers are going somewhere; on the Hebridean Princess, we think they have already arrived.'

That was a good enough reason to try the chief purser's job for size - if only for a day.

'Put this apron ON,' Andrew told me. It was halfway through the day in which I had become a Quarry clone, and lunch was about to be served. I had no idea how creative I could be, portioning out the right amount of lamb on a bed of rice and without staining the edge of the plate. The couple sitting at the table next to ours - who earlier in the week had had no knowledge of my prowess - were particularly impressed. Andrew kept his view to himself. But then he's been at it for 11 years.

Personally, I was mostly taken by the uniform. I imagined that achieving the exalted rank of chief purser - four rings on the immaculate black tunic - required not just experience in adding up the takings of the week and writing the £5,000 weekly food bill, but also a due period of square bashing.

Not at all. An ability to stand up without falling down during a force eight gale might be an advantage, but there was no need of any such requirement during the week of our stately trawl round the Scottish coast and the isles of Mull, Skye, Harris and Eriskay. And I did like that uniform.

Starting at 7.30am was something that I tended to like rather less. And there were meetings to be had, decisions to be made, announcements to be broadcast, guests to be welcomed, the guide - Ian Conde (one of the best in the business) - to be asked for advice, food to be served, champagne to be poured, rooms to be visited.

Then, it has to be admitted, Andrew Quarry isn't your average purser. Not simply because he wears a kilt on dress nights - 'the name is really Andrew McQuarry,' he assured me, a distinct advantage on the Hebrides run - but because this job involves being a combination of hotel manager, cruise director, maitre d' and, well, yes, purser.

I had my first peek behind the scenes the day before I went on duty. Andrew allowed me into the kitchen - sorry, galley - as he was preparing a picnic.

This wasn't your usual basket of sandwiches and warm beer. The ship docked on Mull where a coach was ready to transport people along some of the most picturesque roads in the British Isles (once the guests were off, the ship was sailing for the next three hours, so that it would be ready to meet them on their return). Andrew and the staff, meanwhile, had a minibus ready to follow the coach with a four-course lunch, served in a local hall.

The lunch had been prepared on the ship - so had the soaps, towels and toilet rolls . 'We can't risk the toilets not being up to our standard,' he explained. Not just that. The wine was at just the right temperature. Diets were taken care of. Wheat-free, non-dairy, gluten-free, kosher, vegetarian, diabetic. The biggest problem that the chief purser had that day was a request from one of the guests. 'Do you have a toothpick?' he was asked. Andrew said he was afraid that he didn't.

My first public assignment was to help steer a couple of charming Americans who wanted to know about the route we were taking. I tried to blind them with the science of charts and suchlike, but since I get lost on the M25, I had to hope against hope that they wouldn't be too worried about confusing the Isle of Skye with the Isle of Muck, which is precisely where I would have been if they ever found out.

Then there were the coach companies. On the first stop of the day we had to be sure they were ready to provide the vehicles that would be taking the people on their tours round the islands, down to the beautiful beaches, up the mountains and to places like a tweed mill on the Isle of Harris, a salmon smokery and on to the nearest castles. They weren't the coaches we needed for this cruise, you understand. Those had been booked long before. I was acting on behalf of the Hebridean Princess, and planning for next year; the same coaches and the same dray on Skye, the one drawn by two huge horses, which makes the short trip from the dock and up the road to a nearby garden. I was satisfied that all would be well in 2001.

There was a staff meeting. Someone reported seeing soot at the foot of the funnel. 'Clean it,' I said. My executive decision of the day. Later, I was informed the soot had gone. The power of a chief purser is amazing.

I hadn't noticed two stains on the carpet in one of the cabins - sorry, 'staterooms'. That was one reason why I wasn't a full-time chief purser. Once they were pointed out, I suggested the carpet be taken out and cleaned when we docked the following Thursday. Instantly agreed.

I went on deck. No more soot. Then, inside again, I examined the flowers. They looked fine. There were no cigarette ends lying around. What more could I ask for? To make sure that the food stocks were holding up, for one thing. They were. That's critical on a ship where no one is served frozen food. The Princess line's head office at Skipton, Yorkshire, had to be given a rundown of what the guests on this cruise liked. They wouldn't be given red meat if we knew they ate only fish or poultry. Diabetics would be sure to have sugar-free desserts prepared for them. Vegetarians wouldn't be offered, let alone served, anything they could not eat. They would be sure to serve only sparkling mineral water to those whose file said they required it. I am sure that if still water were supplied it would be a sacking offence.

And then there was The Highlander, a gentleman who, dressed in traditional gear, came aboard one night after dinner and told the story of the Jacobite Rebellion. The fate of which, as far as he is concerned, was the great tragedy of the Scottish nation. He had to be phoned and booked for next year.

My broadcasting experience proved invaluable when we tied up close to the grave of Flora Macdonald, heroine of Bonnie Prince Charlie's escape from the marauding Redcoats. 'Happy day,' I called on the ship's microphone, 'now the fun begins.' I thought Andrew looked a little shocked. Maybe he thought that the red blazer I habitually wore when I wasn't in uniform revealed some hitherto hidden experience at Butlin's. I assured him it didn't - and my fellow guests told me they appreciated the friendliness of it all.

I thought that would be more successful than organising the clay-pigeon shoot on board the afternoon we were at sea. That was when I was handed the loaded shotgun. My military background - National Service, Royal Army Service Corps - could not help. In those days there were more bulls in the field next to the range than on my score card. But I had to set an example.

First shot: into the blue. Second: a little too close to a real seagull for my liking, to say nothing of that of the seagull. And then the third one, a shot that will forever be recorded in the annals not just of the Hebridean Princess, but of the peace-loving Freedland family. A shot, carefully aimed - and one clay pigeon shatters in mid air. What a triumph. What an example to the ship's company. That's the moment I earn my four stripes.

Next year's cruises on the Hebridean Princess start on 3 March. They range from four to 14 nights (although most people choose to go for one week).

 Prices for a seven-night cruise start from £1,280 per person for a single cabin to £7,955 per person. The four-night Taste of the Hebrides and the Hebridean Sampler tours start at £885 for a single cabin and £1,765 per person for the Isle of Arran suite.

The Hebridean Spirit sails from Leith to the Baltic on its inaugural cruise on 3 July 2001. Built in Italy in 1991 but refitted in the style of the Hebridean Princess, the Spirit will 'follow the warmth of the sun', covering the Baltic, Italy, Greece, the Red Sea and the Indian Ocean. Prices start at £2,380 for a six-night On the Heels of the Longships cruise from Sandefjord to Poole.

There are chintz curtains in every room. Some of those rooms have coronets of curtains over the bed - making them look like four-posters. There's even a fireplace in the main lounge. fields.headline: 'Tis the season to be busy
fields.standfirst: Joanne O'Connor  takes a look at some hangover-banishing events taking place over the festive period
fields.trailText: Joanne O'Connor takes a look at some hangover-banishing events taking place over the festive period.
fields.body:
Sing some carols

What better way to get in touch with the true spirit of Christmas than at a Christmas Eve carol service? There will be carols and Christmas readings at Westminster Abbey (020 7222 5152) at 4pm today, or you can enjoy a Festival of Nine Lessons and Carols in the spectacular setting of Canterbury Cathedral at 3pm: arrive early for a seat. For a warm glow without the hangover, try attending midnight mass at your local church. And if you are in Oxford, New College Chapel (01865 279555), which has one of the city's finest choir schools, will be holding its Christmas Eve service at 11.30pm.

Go for a brisk walk

If you've gone a Turkish delight too far then put on some sensible shoes and join one of the National Trust's post-Christmas guided walks. Stroll through the grounds of Shugborough Estate in Staffordshire at 2pm on 30 December - or find out what's happening in your area by calling 020 8315 1111 or visiting the NT website.

There are plenty of walks on New Year's Day. The Wildfowl and Wetlands Trust, Washington, Tyne and Wear (0191 416 5454), promises an invigorating New Year's ramble while the Moors Valley Country Park, Dorset, will have a Winter Wildlife Quiz Trail (01425 470721) - a guided walk with wildlife questions for all the family.

Have a day at the races

The racing calendar goes into overdrive at this time of year, so if you fancy a flutter the chances are you won't have to look very far. One of the premier race events of the season is on Boxing Day - the King George VI Chase Day at Kempton Park (01932 782292) in Middlesex. Gates open at 10am. Tickets from £10 to £29 on the day and children under 16 get in free. Also check out Taunton (01823 337172) on 28 December; Carlisle (01228 522973) on 29 December; and Warwick (01926 491553) on 30 December. On New Year's Day there will National Hunt racing at Cheltenham (01242 513014) from 1pm, £16 on the gate; and at Exeter (01392 832599).

Swap unwanted presents

If Santa got it wrong again, don't despair. Take that itchy bobble hat and those horrible socks and exchange them for something you really want at SuperSwops (07940 014740). The cash-free store at 127 Brick Lane, London E1, opened in time for International Buy Nothing Day in November and will be holding a Christmas Present Reshuffle from 1pm to 5pm every day until Friday, including Christmas Day. Bring anything except food to barter with.

Visit an historic property

Many historic houses and gardens go into hibernation for the winter but those that do stay open usually throw themselves wholeheartedly into the festivities. Costumed musicians will be making merry during the Tower of London's Medieval Christmas celebrations from 27-31 December (020 7709 0765). You can follow a New Year Treasure Trail through the grounds and gardens of Leeds Castle in Kent from 30 December - 1 January (01622 765400). Contact English Heritage (01793 414910) for a list of Christmas events and opening times at its historic properties.

Learn something new

Museums and visitor attractions will be making an extra effort to lure families with restless children during the Christmas holidays. The Theatre Museum in Covent Garden, London (020 7943 4700), will be holding half-hour Pantomime Workshops with make-up demonstrations and a chance to dress up in pantomime costumes every day from 27-31 December, while London's Imperial War Museum (020 7416 5320) will have a Christmas Cracker Gallery Hunt with lucky dip prizes until 7 January. On 31 December the Tate Modern at Bankside (020 7887 8000) is holding an event called Start, with free gifts and special trails through the galleries to introduce families to modern art. There will be Victorian Christmas storytelling sessions from 27-31 December at London's Tower Bridge Experience (020 7403 3761). Not wanting to miss out on the action, the Lawnmower Museum in Southport (01704 501336) will be hosting Santa's Lawnmower Party on 28 December. Santa will swop his sleigh for an electric lawnmower on this special children's day. You probably don't need reminding that this is also your last chance to visit the Dome (0870 606 2000) before it shuts for good on New Year's Eve . Admission prices are reduced to £1 today and £10 on Boxing Day. Christmas events include a winter carnival parade, carol singers, bell ringers, snowball fights and a daily pantomime. There will also be the chance to skate on an indoor ice rink.

Welcome in the New Year

Last year's millennium celebrations will be a hard act to follow, but for information on New Year events nationwide go to at VisitBritain. Edinburgh is officially full up on 31 December but Glasgow promises a lively alternative and towns such as Dundee, Aviemore and Inverness will have traditional Hogmanay celebrations. Do it Welsh-style carrying a horse's skull on a long pole - the ancient tradition of Mari Llwyd will be re-enacted in Llanwrtyd Wells - or head for the home of Greenwich Mean Time for an afternoon of music and pyrotechnics in Cutty Sark Gardens from 4.30pm to 7pm. Southampton will also be putting on a show with its Gateway to the World celebration (0238 022 1106) comprising street theatre, concerts, ghost walks around the old town and docks and a carnival of light.

Start 2001 with a splash

There's something about this time of year which makes the British want to dress up in funny costumes and do strange things. After a night of overindulgence what better way to clear your head than plunging into an ice-cold murky grey sea for a refreshing swim? Actually we don't recommend this, but you might like to sponsor some other brave soul to take a dip. The Seaburn Centre in Sunderland expects more than 1,000 people to take part in its charity fancy dress competition and dip on Boxing Day at 11am. At noon on 1 January the hardy folk of Peel on the Isle of Man will parade into the sea while the good people of Poole prefer to spend New Year's Day braving the waves in a bathtub - though apparently most of them end up swimming. Turn up at Poole Quay at noon for the entertaining annual Bath Race (01202 682247).

While they are battling to stay afloat the residents of Kirkwall in the Orkney Islands will be carrying on a 200-year-old tradition with the Men's & Boy's 'Ba' - a mass street football game with goals at the site of an old castle and the harbour - which is also played on Christmas Day. It can last for several hours and attracts up to 400 players in teams of 'Uppies' and 'Doonies'.

webTitle: Comment: English as it is spoke

fields.headline: English as it is spoke
fields.standfirst:
When even the Queen doesn't speak Queen's English, what is happening to our language?

Special report: what is Britain?
fields.trailText: When even the Queen doesn't speak Queen's English, what is happening to our language?
fields.body:
So the queen speaks estuary English. I can't honestly say that I'd noticed, but then, I wasn't around in her more clipped Celia Johnson days. But now you come to mention it, although she's not quite Jamie Oliver, there is a certain mellowing of her vowel sounds. Why should one be surprised? Standard pronunciation across the country has also changed.

Furthermore, the age of deference is dead, so where once broadcasters, opinion-makers and other more vocal setters of the spoken word aped the accents of the court, now the remnants of the class élite are sinking into the speech patterns of the people. Language is nothing if not a social tool; as society changes so must speech change with it.

There are precedents or pertinent analogies. In the nineteenth century, before the coming of the railways, time was not regularised throughout the country, but rather each major town set its own time, determined each day by setting the town's clock-hands to 12 when the sun was at its highest.

But obviously, once there were trains and, therefore, train timetables, there needed to be a consistent, standardised time throughout the land. We would surely find it curious to live now in a country divided into different time zones. Is the consternation voiced now at the erosion of our once-various accents any more logical?

For it is patently the case that as the telegraph and the train set a standard for time, so television has set a standard for speech. Much as people may baulk at the influence of the metropolitan élite (which, while it may not be a social élite in the class sense, is certainly a geographical élite), it isn't surprising that a form of London accent has prevailed. This is a small country and a far more centralised one than any other in Europe and certainly far more so than America.

The type of estuary English that most broadcasters (certainly most broadcasters under 40) speak has become the vernacular of the age. It isn't a case of a widespread adoption of mockney, or symptomatic necessarily of what are taken to be the inverted snobbery and anxiously democratising principles of the age, but a reflection of the obvious powers of mass communication. In much the same way, many children's speech patterns now betray a certain transatlantic twang; after all, most of the linguistic influences they receive are through American television programmes.

But what is so wrong with a democratising principle governing our speech habits? Why do we hold so nervously to our old, class-defining patterns and accents? Of course there are casualties, though I don't say this in a spirit of self-pity. When I was a child, my accent, for example, was Received Pronunciation; now I am given to understand it is posh. I can live with that.

To change one's accent consciously would be the act of a phoney and shifts in pronunciation are piecemeal rather than the product the sort of Meryl Streep-like virtuosity brought about by a dialogue coach. What it means simply is that what constitutes RP is different.

Furthermore, if we feel that a standardised spoken language is against natural laws, we should also remember that the notion of standardised spelling is relatively recent. The age of mass literacy required a shared system of spelling, brought about by the power of the public prints, and we would find it as odd to return to an age that dispensed with this as we would to adopt the jumble of timescales that once unquestioningly pertained.

But as with all change, the shift in speech patterns is hardly sudden. For all that the Australian linguists have only recently offered their apparently inflammatory breakdown of the monarchical tongue, it was many years ago that John Honey made just such claims in Does Accent Matter? (Faber 1989), a book that investigated the history, influence and susceptibilities of accent.

Not only should Does Accent Matter? never have been allowed to go out of print, but it should be used as part of illuminating textual analysis in every school in the country. Among many other cases, John Honey recorded the shifts in the accent in which Princess Diana spoke in the first 10 years of her public reign, for want of a better word.

It might sound vehemently anti-democratic to site (or cite) confirmation of language change by concentrating on the evolving accents of the royals, but it is pertinent, nevertheless. If the idea of a shared accent makes any sense, it has to be shared by all levels of society.

For whatever reason, we do not have the ability of, for example, the Germans, who find it seamlessly easy to speak in their native dialect at home and in standard hochdeutsch in public. We are not nearly so versatile and therefore need to accept that our language will reflect that.

If the only reason that we want variety in speech is to hold on to the old prejudices, then we are truly better off with an impoverished system. The fact that the royal family, voluntarily or not, have become part of our linguistic reductionism does not in itself makes it either a good or a bad thing. But surely what colours our judgment is what the change, or changes, do away with, namely, precise stratification and instant labelling.

No one can be naive enough to believe that a standardised spoken language denotes a truly egalitarian age - and I can see the argument that it props up a hidden and even more subtle classification - but it is most definitely a prerequisite of it.
fields.bodyText: So the queen speaks estuary English. I can't honestly say that I'd noticed, but then, I wasn't around in her more clipped Celia Johnson days. But now you come to mention it, although she's not quite Jamie Oliver, there is a certain mellowing of her vowel sounds. Why should one be surprised? Standard pronunciation across the country has also changed. Furthermore, the age of deference is dead, so where once broadcasters, opinion-makers and other more vocal setters of the spoken word aped the accents of the court, now the remnants of the class élite are sinking into the speech patterns of the people. Language is nothing if not a social tool; as society changes so must speech change with it. There are precedents or pertinent analogies. In the nineteenth century, before the coming of the railways, time was not regularised throughout the country, but rather each major town set its own time, determined each day by setting the town's clock-hands to 12 when the sun was at its highest. But obviously, once there were trains and, therefore, train timetables, there needed to be a consistent, standardised time throughout the land. We would surely find it curious to live now in a country divided into different time zones. Is the consternation voiced now at the erosion of our once-various accents any more logical? For it is patently the case that as the telegraph and the train set a standard for time, so television has set a standard for speech. Much as people may baulk at the influence of the metropolitan élite (which, while it may not be a social élite in the class sense, is certainly a geographical élite), it isn't surprising that a form of London accent has prevailed. This is a small country and a far more centralised one than any other in Europe and certainly far more so than America. The type of estuary English that most broadcasters (certainly most broadcasters under 40) speak has become the vernacular of the age. It isn't a case of a widespread adoption of mockney, or symptomatic necessarily of what are taken to be the inverted snobbery and anxiously democratising principles of the age, but a reflection of the obvious powers of mass communication. In much the same way, many children's speech patterns now betray a certain transatlantic twang; after all, most of the linguistic influences they receive are through American television programmes. But what is so wrong with a democratising principle governing our speech habits? Why do we hold so nervously to our old, class-defining patterns and accents? Of course there are casualties, though I don't say this in a spirit of self-pity. When I was a child, my accent, for example, was Received Pronunciation; now I am given to understand it is posh. I can live with that. To change one's accent consciously would be the act of a phoney and shifts in pronunciation are piecemeal rather than the product the sort of Meryl Streep-like virtuosity brought about by a dialogue coach. What it means simply is that what constitutes RP is different. Furthermore, if we feel that a standardised spoken language is against natural laws, we should also remember that the notion of standardised spelling is relatively recent. The age of mass literacy required a shared system of spelling, brought about by the power of the public prints, and we would find it as odd to return to an age that dispensed with this as we would to adopt the jumble of timescales that once unquestioningly pertained. But as with all change, the shift in speech patterns is hardly sudden. For all that the Australian linguists have only recently offered their apparently inflammatory breakdown of the monarchical tongue, it was many years ago that John Honey made just such claims in Does Accent Matter? (Faber 1989), a book that investigated the history, influence and susceptibilities of accent. webTitle: Racism row over drug arrest league tables

fields.headline: Racism row over drug arrest league tables
fields.trailText: The number of black and Asian people arrested for drugs offences compared to white people will be revealed for the first time by the Home Office in an attempt to find out who is behind most crimes in England and Wales.
fields.body:
The number of black and Asian people arrested for drugs offences compared to white people will be revealed for the first time by the Home Office in an attempt to find out who is behind most crimes in England and Wales.

The league tables, which were yesterday condemned by black groups worried that they will fuel debate about whether race is a factor in drug crimes, will be published next month.

In a report entitled 'Statistics on Race and the Criminal Justice System', the Home Office will detail the 'ethnic appearance' of all those arrested for drugs offences. It will be the first time that such sensitive data on drugs will be released to the public.

Home Office sources said last night that it was only by collecting the figures that a serious debate could begin on who is arrested and why. It will be up to the police to define racial identity.

Officials said that the figures could also be used to show that the police were predominantly arresting black people for drugs offences, re-opening the debate sparked by stop-and-search figures which showed that far more black people are stopped by the police than white people.

However, black organisations warned that racist groups could seize on the figures, which are set to show that proportionally more black people are arrested for drugs offences in London than white people.

The Commission for Racial Equality (CRE) has urged 'extreme caution' in the use of the statistics, saying that the possibility of misuse was a 'danger that had to be dealt with'.

'The whole idea makes me feel deeply uneasy,' said Trevor Phillips, the chairman of the Greater London Assembly and a campaigner on black issues. 'The idea we should publish figures based on the subjective judgment of the police will anger a lot of black and Asian people. This seems to be being put together by people who want to make race the big issue.'

fields.headline: US slowdown lifts the euro
fields.standfirst: Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: The euro's recent surge is set to accelerate into the new year amid mounting evidence of a slowdown in US growth.
fields.body:
The euro's recent surge is set to accelerate into the new year amid mounting evidence of a slowdown in US growth.

Analysts of market trends predict that the euro will reach dollar parity in the first half of 2001, and surpass it later in the year.

'The momentum is clearly there. The euro's heading quickly for the next level of technical support at $0.96. The way it looks now we should be reaching dollar parity by the second quarter,' says Steven Wesiak of ABN Amro.

After reaching five-month peaks above $0.92 last week, and surpassing the transitory highs following September's intervention by the world's leading central banks, analysts are confident that the euro's fortunes have finally turned a corner.

Gloomy prospects for the US economy are the main reason, economists say. Euroland growth is expected to surpass US growth in 2001, and the Federal Reserve last week signalled a cut in interest rate. Economists predict a US drop of between 50 and 100 basis points, and a much smaller cut in Europe later in the year. Heavy investment flows into US equities from Europe have fallen back and may now reverse, say analysts. Foreign direct investment in US technology is also expected to slow.

'Some of the extreme gloss has come off the dollar,' says John Llewlyn, global chief economist at Lehman Brothers. 'If the US slows, the EU will slow but not too badly - the rule of thumb is if US growth falls by 1 per cent, Europe falls by 0.25 per cent.'

Gwyn Hacche at HSBC says: 'It's a weakening dollar story rather than a strengthening euro. We predict a hard landing in the US. In Euroland, although growth may slow, it will be nothing like that in the US.'

Europe will be comparatively insulated from any slip in world demand. Only 15 per cent of euro zone GDP is traded externally. Nor is consumer confidence in Europe as sensitive to share prices as it is in the US.

Furthermore, the US economy's acute structural imbalances - low household savings and a high current account deficit - threaten to unravel, turning slowdown into recession, according to some economists.

fields.headline: Sale away - without sinking
fields.standfirst: It might be tougher to find bargains this January but, says Tracey Boles, they're out there if you know where to look
fields.trailText: It might be tougher to find bargains this January but, saysTracey Boles, they're out there if you know where to look
fields.body:
Everybody loves a bargain and January is the month when many of us rush to the shops in search of that elusive must-have item at a fraction of its usual price. The 2001 sales are threatening to fall short of the last couple of years, according to the British Retail Consortium, due to lower stock levels and smaller discounts, but there should still be some good deals out there for dedicated bargain-hunters.

The best are likely to be found at the clothing and footwear retailers. This is because their wares are bought in bulk and have a limited shelf life ruled by the vagaries of fashion and the seasons. Electrical outlets might also yield some real finds if, for example, a line of computers or TVs is being replaced, or the shop wants to get rid of old models gathering dust.

BRC spokesman David Smith says: 'There has been a lot of overstocking in the past couple of years, with clothes in particular, which has led to pre-Christmas markdowns because the stock was just taking up space.' This year, he says, retailers have been exercising more caution in their stocking levels.

However, overstocking is not the only factor that determines price cuts. If trading up to Christmas has been tough going, then shoppers are more likely to benefit from dramatic price cuts in the New Year.

This year pre-Christmas trading has been 'subdued', according to one retail analyst. Consumer confidence has been dented by several factors, including interest rates and the slowdown in the housing market. And there is none of the feel-good factor generated by the millennium celebrations that buoyed the market last year.

But if none of this puts you off, there are some golden rules to remember. Sale signs screaming '50 per cent off' are usually just headline-grabbing promotions designed to draw you into the shop and very few lines are likely to carry such big reductions.

Another common trick among retailers is phasing in the depth of the price cuts throughout January. You may feel you have picked up a bargain but after a couple of weeks it may have another 10 per cent shaved off - if it is still there, of course. If you are not going to bother wading through the shops because you didn't fancy the look of anything before Christmas, bear in mind that there will be more than just markdowns. A lot of retailers bring in so-called 'special purchases' to put in the sale.

Goods are often colour-coded to indicate the category they fall into - special purchase, markdown or shop-soiled - so look out for these.

In Scotland, most sales will start this year on Tuesday, while in the rest of the country they get under way on Wednesday. One analyst says: 'Most clothing retailers are holding off the start of their sales because they do not want to get sucked into a tit-for-tat situation which arguably only benefits the consumer.' So what can you expect?

The High Street

Shoe shops Saxone and Barratts say they have not settled on when their sales will start; they prefer not to decide until the last minute because the factors that influence their decisions change all the time. But fellow shoe shop Faith has already started its sale.

Marks & Spencers' sale starts in five stores nationwide on Boxing Day and in other M&S stores from the day after.

The troubled high street giant is advertising price cuts on selected items across womenswear, menswear, lingerie and homeware using that magic phrase 'up to 50 per cent off'. Winter coats that would normally set you back £160 will be £80 and there is a 'major clearance' of leather. Mohair jumpers will also be half price at £14.

M&S's famous underwear department will have bras from £12 and knickers from £2, including what it promises are items from the more glamourous end of its range.

Sportswear will be 40 per cent cheaper on average. Men's shirts will be available from £12 and ties from £4.

British Home Stores will be slashing the prices on some of its clothing and homeware items by between 50 and 75 per cent. Clothes which will cost just a quarter of their current retail prices include stretch jeans and a berry-coloured ladies' polyester suit. The sale starts at 9.30am on 27 December in London's Oxford Street and at 12pm on 26 December in Edinburgh.

If you can brave the famous queue, the Harrods sale, which kicks off on 3 January, has 75 per cent off many of the ladies autumn/winter designer collections, including Ck from Calvin Klein and Betty Jackson. DKNY will be reduced by 40 per cent and Gucci by 50 per cent. For men, Paul Smith is down 40 per cent and Armani 50 per cent.

There are also bargains to be had in the homeware department, such as 60 per cent off Harrods' own-brand porcelain dinnerware. Harrods account holders will receive an extra 10 per cent off many purchases made on 6 and 20 January. Knightsbridge's most well-known landmark produces a catalogue previewing some of the sales deals. It can be ordered on 0845 605 1234.

HMV will be hosting its annual 'clearout' this New Year. While CDs will be available from £1.99, it says the works of higher profile artists such as Primal Scream will retail for £8.99 and some former chart toppers will set you back £10.99. Videos will start at as little as £2.99, but Jerry Maguire will be £4.99 and Men in Black £6.99.

Rival Virgin Megastore will have CDs from £1.99, videos from £2.99, games from £4.99 and DVDs from £9.99.

Electrical outlet Dixons is unable to release details of its sale yet, while rival Comet no longer has one.

fields.headline: And they all shall have prizes
fields.standfirst: Who was Renaissance Man of the Year? What was the heroic spin of the year? It's time for The Observer's awards for political achievement
fields.trailText: Who was Renaissance Man of the Year? What was the heroic spin of the year? It's time for The Observer's awards for political achievement.
fields.byline: Andrew Rawnsley, columnist of the Year
fields.body:
After agonising weeks during which a divided nation held its breath, this column's Supreme Court can finally declare who has won and who has lost The Observer 's awards for political achievement in the year 2000.

The Always Look On The Bright Side Of Life Award goes to Philip Gould who wailed to the Prime Minister that the New Labour brand was as 'badly contaminated' as a shedload of condemned turkey meat. The diviner of the focus groups told his master that everyone thought Tony was a phoney and a flake who was incapable of holding a position for more than three seconds and was hopelessly in thrall to image manipulators and pollsters like, er, Philip Gould.

Talking of which, The Shrinking Violet Award is won by Alastair Campbell. PMOS - as the Prime Minister's Official Spokesman is known to his friends - announced his retirement from frontline briefing duties, the top-spinner telling lobby journalists that in future they would have to make do with his deputy, a dead bat from the Civil Service. A rare case, perhaps, of the messenger shooting himself. Or not, as it turned out to be. Just days later, our bashful champion was the star of a full-dress television documentary with a supporting cast of bit-players including a seven-minute appearance by Campbell's press officer, Tony Blair.

The Consistency Is An Overrated Virtue Award is presented to Ann Widdecombe. It is a paradox of our times that it is often those politicians who regard themselves as rocks of unswerving conviction and unbendable principle who execute the most U-turns. The road surface of the Black Widder's career has been spectacularly slippery. In the wake of the Tony Martin case, the Tories were going to change the law in favour of a farmer's inalienable right to shoot burglars - until sense prevailed. Asylum-seekers were to be detained - until someone counted the cost of building all these Stalag Widdecombes. And there would be zero tolerance for cannabis smokers - until Tory MPs clocked that their own children would be turned into criminals. What good fortune for Ann that three strikes and you're out doesn't apply to politicians.

Which seamlessly moves us on to The Unfrank Confession Award. Mo Mowlam started a lamentable trend when she revealed that she had smoked dope. But had she enjoyed the giggleweed? Perish that thought. It became de rigueur for politicians to confess to flings with cannabis, but to deny that they had drawn any pleasure from the experience. Eight members of the Shadow Cabinet coughed that they had been youthful skank heads. Oliver Letwin, the Shadow Chief Treasury Secretary, gurgled that 'friends put it in my pipe'. It is an illustration of the hopelessness of the Tories that it did not occur to him that admitting to having smoked a pipe was much more likely to be damaging than confessing to using pot. Hats off to the Tories' Agriculture spokesman, the only politician to confess that not only had he indulged in the weed, but he had actually found it rather 'agreeable'. Well done, Tim Yeo!

Meantime, the Conservatives' leader dedicated himself to warning the nation about the evil consequences of excessive drinking. Let this be a warning: consume too much alcohol as a young man and you could grow down into William Hague. When the self-revelation that he once sunk 14 pints failed to have the desired effect of rounding out his image, an increasingly desperate Leader of the Opposition then bragged that he had necked 32 rum and Cokes. That must have been just before he made his - now defunct - tax guarantee. Mr Hague's speeches had an intoxicating effect on the Conservative Party. The morning after, colleagues were left with the sensation that a toad had curled up on their tongues before dying in their throats.

As for the Prime Minister, he caused head-scratching among an audience of German theologians when he unleashed his Big Idea of frogmarching hoolies to the nearest cashpoint. None of the many critics expressed themselves quite so effectively as his own son, Euan, who eloquently retched over this lame-brained idea in Leicester Square. Our award for Most Heroic Spin Of The Year is presented to the Home Office Minister who explained away the Prime Minister's dud wheeze by describing it as 'a metaphor'. Congratulations, Charles Clarke, from whom we expect great things in the future.

The Remind Me What All The Fuss Was About? Award attracted many nominations ranging from the birth of Leo to the fuel protest to the Nice summit. The winner is the election for Mayor of London. How gravely did the newspapers pontificate about the calamity that would befall New Labour if Ken Livingstone seized control of the capital. How profoundly disturbed was the Prime Minister who suggested that it would be the equivalent of the Fire of London rolled into the Great Plague. If the newt-fancier became Mayor, lice-infested Londoners would fight each other to the last rat to feed their starving families. The Prime Minister pledged to fight Red Ken 'with every breath of my body'. When I last looked, Tony Blair still seemed to be alive - and London was still standing. As for Ken, his singular achievement after more than six months as Mayor has been to threaten the pigeons in Trafalgar Square. They don't look worried.

The Renaissance Man Award is presented to Peter Mandelson. In a busy year for the Northern Ireland Secretary, he told one audience at the Labour conference that the Government's critics failed to appreciate its manifold achievements because 'New Labour defies description'. How much truer is this of dear Peter himself. He found time in his crowded diary to deliver speeches on subjects as diverse as the European single currency and the future of local government, the upset this caused to Gordon Brown and John Prescott being an incidental bonus. Thank goodness for the Government that Peter has so much free time to think and speak, things being as peaceful as they are in Belfast.

The George Washington Memorial Prize is won by Gordon Brown. 'I did not lie, I would not lie,' the Chancellor assured the nation when his role in the Ecclestone Affair was revealed by a book, the title of which is on the tip of my tongue. We also had the Chancellor's word for it that an extra 75p a week was quite enough for pensioners - until he was forced to hand over a fiver. That it was irresponsible to alter fuel duty in reaction to short-term fluctuations in the oil price - until he did. And that he and the Prime Minister are the bosomest of buddies - except when they are shouting and swearing at each other.

The Did I Really Say That? Award is won by Tony Blair who once declared that the Millennium Dome would be the 'first line of my next manifesto'. He was obviously planning a manifesto rammed with tat, universally panned by the media, largely empty and with massive queues for the few good bits. The Prime Minister was eventually driven to confess that the Greenwich Wok, as it was dubbed by one of its kinder critics, had not be a 'runaway success', in much the same way as Emperor Hirohito surrendered by telling the Japanese that the war had not turned out quite as expected.

Which brings us to The Non-Resignation Of The Year Award. In a crowded field, the favourite was Charlie Falconer. After the most weighty consideration, Lord F reluctantly concluded that the country would be better served if he did not quit over the multiple mishaps of the Dome of Doom. Our winner, though, is Mo Mowlam. She managed the unique feat of resigning from the Government but remaining a member of it, thus brilliantly signalling her discontent with Number 10 while continuing as a member of the Cabinet.

The Outed Award is won by Michael Portillo who dragged himself out of the closet as a Spaniard. As if talking to them in his native tongue wasn't dangerous enough, the Shadow Chancellor further startled the Conservative conference by telling them that the Tories welcomed people of 'whatever sexual orientation'. We all know this is nonsense. Such is the state of the Conservative Party, only sado-masochists need apply.

And finally, to our award for Best Speech By A Politician For Whom English Is A Second Language. Despite the many nominations for John 'Macho? Moi?' Prescott, the prize has to go to George W. Bush. Among the aperçus of the next President of the United States, Dubya reassured us that 'the human being and fish can co-exist peacefully'.

This idiot savant will soon be in charge of the planet's only superpower and the world's most massive nuclear arsenal. Merry Christmas.

fields.headline: Little green shoots on Mars
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: It's a veggie, Jim, but not as we know it. Scientists have successfully raised a crop of fresh greens on Martian soil, significantly boosting the possibility that there is, or at least could be, life on the Red Planet.
fields.body:
It's a veggie, Jim, but not as we know it. Scientists have successfully raised a crop of fresh greens on Martian soil, significantly boosting the possibility that there is, or at least could be, life on the Red Planet.

The experiment has not taken place on Mars itself - where the temperature is rarely warmer than an inclement minus 60 C - but in a laboratory in New Zealand. Taking soil samples scraped from meteorites which fell to earth from the planet thousands of years ago, a team of researchers have grown tiny asparagus and potato plants.

In comparison with soils from other planets, the samples show high levels of phosphates - necessary for growing good vegetables. The best results came from scrapings from a meteorite that landed in Australia in 1969 which soil fertility indicators showed had similar properties to the soil on earth.

'If we build colonies in space we will have to grow plants for food, so obviously we need to know that the soil can support that. It shows that space-based soil could potentially support future human expansion in the solar system,' said Dr Michael Mautner, leader of the research team.

It took Mautner and his colleagues only a few weeks to grow shoots several millimetres high. Previously whole crops have been raised on space stations. Cereals planted in space on orbiting units have even produced fertile seeds. Professor Colin Pillinger of the Open University said the new research confirms previous work with Martian soil.

Pillinger himself has replicated the red planet's soil on earth and planted seeds in it. 'We grew some lovely vegetables; peppers, cucumbers, tomatoes and so on. We exhibited them at Chelsea Flower show and won a gold medal,' he said.

The Open University team's research has shown it is possible to extract water from Martian rocks. 'Everything is there for life except the life itself,' said Pillinger, who believes humans will live on Mars within 30 years.

Scientists may eventually be able to plant some forms of life throughout the galaxy, seeding distant planets to test if they could support life. The New Zealand experiment has shown materials from interplanetary dust, meteorites and comets could have helped trigger life on earth. One theory is that organic compounds and whole cells could have been transported across galaxies by comets made of ice. If materials in the meteorites could grow potatoes then they could have provided the first micro-organisms with nutrients needed for survival.

Britain's first landing on Mars, with a tiny robot explorer called 'Beagle Two' is scheduled for Boxing Day 2003. The 60kg unit will land on the surface of the planet and 'sniff' for organic chemicals associated with water and life and, presumably, little green men.

Two weeks ago scientists at the American space agency Nasa said a four-year study of a Martian meteorite that was discovered in Antarctica in 1984 had concluded that it contained microscopic magnetic crystals that were identical to grains produced by bacteria on earth.

The crystals are so similar that anyone studying the meteorite who did not know that it came from Mars would almost certainly conclude that it held evidence of life, the scientists who made the discovery said.

The meteorite is about 4.5 billion years old and has lain in the Antarctic ice for 13,000 years. The vital crystals are so small that a billion of them would fit on the head of a pin.

webTitle: Hollywood grasps nettle of America's failed drugs war

fields.headline: Hollywood grasps nettle of America's failed drugs war
fields.standfirst: A brilliant new film lifts the lid on the failure of US policy to deal with the billion dollar narcotics trade, says Edward Helmore in New York
fields.trailText: Steven Soderbergh's Traffic lifts the lid on the failure of US policy to deal with the billion dollar narcotics trade, says Edward Helmore in New York
fields.body:
America has waged war on drugs for 30 years but it is only now that Hollywood, for so long preferring either to romanticise or condemn the issue, is tackling the subject for the vast, devastating problem it is.

When Traffic (pictured) opens in US cinemas on 27 December, its director, Steven Soderbergh, hopes it will re-ignite public debate over America's $19b a year drugs war just as a new administration is sworn in and the US embarks on Plan Colombia, a $1.3bn package of aid, including military hardware, that some warn will turn the world's largest drug producing region into a new Vietnam.

The thriller, based on a Channel 4 mini-series Traffik, accomplishes what no other film has attempted. Through interrelated stories, and with a large cast including Michael Douglas and Catherine Zeta-Jones, the film looks at drugs, their corrupting appeal and the futility of current efforts to stop them.

The film has has already won numerous awards from critics' circles in New York and Los Angeles as well as five Golden Globe nominations. Instead of making drug producers, traffickers, users and anti-drug forces the problem, Soderbergh goes after the complete picture. 'Drugs are a key social issue in our culture today: everyone knows someone who has been touched by it,' he says.

The film opens as the Clinton administration prepares to hand on to the next President a commitment to finance Colombia's drug war, an effort that may take years to yield results and could widen to neighbouring countries. Around 70 per cent of the US aid is to go to financing, training and supplying army anti-narcotics battalions in south-eastern Colombia, where an estimated 60 per cent of Colombia's coca and opium is grown.

Opponents of Plan Colombia say it will lead to the 'narcotisation' of the peace process, and to a further escalation of the war with guerilla insurgents.

Last week, Jorge Rojas, director of the Consultancy on Human Rights and Displace ment, said that under the pretext of the fight against drugs, 'control over national territory, the exploitation of natural resources and the biodiversity of the Amazon jungle are being put at risk for the benefit of the United States'.

In the Caribbean, the recently ended US Operation Libertador has been touted as 'a major takedown' by the Drug Enforcement Agency after police reported arresting 2,876 people, including the region's alleged narco-kingpin, Martin Paulino Castro, and seizing 20 tonnes of cocaine, 29 tonnes of mari juana and 82,000 tablets of ecstasy in a month.

But former Jamaican police colonel Trevor McMillan, who was fired after starting a clean-up of the island's police force in 1996, countered that America's war on drugs had done little more than corrupt. 'What the drug war has done is to drive the price of drugs up. Until we remove the profit from trafficking, nothing will change.'

As the US escalates funding for the war on drugs, the makers of Traffic make no claim to have answers to the problem. 'We wanted to make a film that asks what should we do, what can we do, are we doing the right thing?' says producer Laura Bickford. 'We've got praise for not presuming to have answers but for raising questions.'

But the film does suggest the drug issue is a problem of human nature, not a criminal one. And with 500,000 drug-related offenders in the US prison system and a further million on parole or probation for drug offences, America seems to be ready to re-examine its attitude to drugs.

In the recent elections, voters in five states overwhelmingly passed drug policy reform initiatives, including Proposition 36 in California, which will shift the criminal justice system's focus from incarceration to treatment. The measure won more than 60 per cent of the popular vote, 7 per cent more than Al Gore received in the state, and 18 per cent more than George W. Bush.

But qualms over 'America's Prison Generation', the 14 million mostly black or Latino Americans who will spend part of their lives behind bars, have not yet been reflected in Washington.

In the election campaign, drugs were barely mentioned as an issue by Gore or Bush, except to say they planned to get tougher on them. 'The silence around on the issue was deafening,' says Bickford, who spent years studying the subject for the film. But many hope the voter initiatives on drug policy will work their way into the White House.

Of course, politicians in Washington cannot afford to look soft on drugs and, with two consecutive Presidents with dubious pasts (Clinton's 'didn't inhale' fiasco and Bush's 'youthful indiscretion'), it is unlikely there will be an official shift in policies.

Traffic takes no position on the whether the war on drugs is futile but Bickford says the US is in danger of treating it like the war on Communism. 'You cannot attack supply without attacking demand and expect to get anywhere. Plus we wanted to say platitudes about the "war on drugs" don't work and just stopping supply isn't going to work either.'

fields.headline: Winning rounds
fields.standfirst: Know your Arbois from your Elbling? Then take our Christmas challenge and win a £300 case of wine
fields.trailText: Know your Arbois from your Elbling? Then take our Christmas challenge and win a £300 case of wine.
fields.body:
Think you know a bit about wine? That you can tell Muscat à Petits Grains from your Muscat d'Alexandrie and Pouilly-Fuissé from Pouilly-Fumé? Then have a go at our Christmas quiz - 30 questions of varying levels of difficulty. Some are as easy as sinking a glass of lightly wooded Aussie Chardonnay; others will tax the most dedicated of wine buffs.

If you're looking for a useful source book, you could do worse than sneak a look at The Oxford Companion to Wine. Good luck!

1. Which of the following is not an Australian wine region?

a) Frankland River

b) Mornington Peninsula

c) Fiddletown

2. Bourgogne Passetoutgrains must contain

a) At least one third Pinot Noir

b) At least one third Gamay

c) Equal proportions of the two grapes

3. Manzanilla Sherry is produced only in

a) Jerez

b) Sanlúcar de Barrameda

c) Torremolinos

4. What is the greatest threat facing California's vineyards?

a) Pierce's disease

b) Families on picnics

c) Flying ants

5. Which of the following wines does not come from Germany?

a) Bend in the River

b) Wild Boar

c) Goats do Roam

6. The grape of Barolo is

a) Negra Mole

b) Nebbiolo

c) Negroamaro

7. The first names of the Gallo brothers are

a) Eddie and Jack

b) Ernesto and Jeronimo

c) Ernest and Julio

8. Melnik is

a) A Bulgarian grape variety

b) A Hungarian grape variety

c) The name of the Slovakian prime minister

9. Which Bordeaux chteau was promoted to first growth status in 1973?

a) Mouton-Rothschild

b) Latour

c) Mouton-Cadet

10. Grand Vidure is a synonym for

a) Cabernet Sauvignon

b) Carmenère

c) Malbec

11. LBV stands for

a) Late-Bottled Vintage

b) Latterly Bottled Vintage

c) Late-Bottled Vinifera

12. The town of Shiraz is to be found in

a) Iran

b) Iraq

c) Israel

13. A field blend is

a) A mixture of brandy and wine drunk by vineyard workers

b) A mixture of different grape varieties planted in the same vineyard

c) Neither of the above

14. Chateau Hornsby is in

a) Alice Springs

b) Harare

c) The Napa Valley

15. The oldest New World wine producing country is

a) South Africa

b) Mexico

c) Australia

16. An estufa is

a) A knife used by pickers in the Alentejo

b) The Portuguese name for a fence post

c) Part of the production process for Madeira

17. Ehrenfelser is a crossing of

a) Riesling and Silvaner

b) Silvaner and Muscat

c) Trebbiano and Doradillo

18. Coonawarra is famous for

a) Its red terra rossa soils

b) Its railway station

c) Its hilly terrain

19. The main Argentinian grape-growing region is called

a) La Pampa

b) La Bamba

c) Mendoza

20. The character of Trygaios appears in a play by

a) Aristophanes

b) Jeffrey Archer

c) Shakespeare

21. Armagnac is traditionally distilled

a) Once

b) Twice

c) Three times

22. A barrique is

a) A wooden hammer

b) A wooden barrel

c) A wooden stepladder

23. A balthazar of Champagne contains the equivalent of

a) 14 bottles

b) 16 bottles

c) 18 bottles

24. Coteaux Champenois is

a) The name of a co-operative in the Champagne region

b) An escarpment to the south of Epernay

c) An appellation used for still wines in Champagne

25. Cloudy Bay Sauvignon Blanc was first made in

a) 1976

b) 1986

c) 1996

26. TCA, the compound responsible for cork taint, stands for

a) Tetrachlorophenol

b) Trans Cork Amalgum

c) Trichloroanisole

27. Which is the odd one out?

a) Perth Pink

b) Bangalore Purple

c) Ctes de Rod Laver

28. Geneva Double Curtain is

a) A grapevine trellising system

b) A Swiss military formation

c) A recently invented machine harvester

29. Which has the highest alcohol level?

a) Moscato d'Asti

b) Muscat d'Alsace

c) Muscat de Rivesaltes

30. PX is short for

a) Pedro Ximenez

fields.headline: Nigel Slater's gravy recipes
fields.standfirst: It's the final chore of the Christmas roast, but gravy is the savoury liquor that makes it all work
fields.trailText: It's the final chore of the Christmas roast, but gravy is the savoury liquor that makes it all work.
fields.body:
It is worth pinpointing the heart and soul of a dish and striving to get it right. Otherwise you might as well not bother. After years of cooking the Sunday roast, I now realise that it is neither the meat, tracklements (the mustard, redcurrant jelly and mint sauces) nor vegetables that is the crucial part, but the accompanying gravy. It is this savoury juice that holds the whole thing together. It is the gravy that makes the meal work.

The only gravy I want to know about is the one made with the pan drippings and meat juices of the roast it is to accompany. An 'integral' gravy whose heart and soul have come from the roast it is due to lubricate. To put it another way, I want my gravy to belong.

I have no doubt that we should make an impromptu 'sauce' to go with our roast. The fact that meat carves more easily and stays more juicy when given 15 minutes' rest between oven and table is surely evidence enough that we are supposed to make gravy to go with it. Fifteen minutes to hang around, tantalised by a glistening roast? Someone is trying to tell us something.

What doesn't quite get there is a sauce made without access to the caramelised juices and flavourings from the meat. A sauce whose heart is elsewhere.

One of my gripes with some (I say some) classical French cooking is that the meat and its sauce don't meet till they get to the plate. Yes, that sauce may well be flavoured and given depth with the reduced goodness from previous roasts - known as glace de viande - but this is rather like giving a newborn baby someone else's parents. There is much goodness there, but it is not quite the same.

Gravy is not a sauce. It is, or should be, a deeply savoury liquor made from the meat drippings and sediment that collects in the roasting tin. It may be let down with water, wine or stock to make it more palatable - not to mention making it go further - but the meat juices are its backbone. We introduce outside flavourings at our peril.

Dark and intriguing it may be, but there is little mystery to making gravy. A perfectly decent one (I might argue the best) can be made by pouring boiling water into a pan after removing the roasted meat, then stirring to dissolve the sticky goo that has accumulated during roasting. Voilà! But you can tinker with it to great effect, too, adding some appropriate wine or fortified spirit, or introducing some herbs or perhaps a little spice. The soul of the juice will still be there - all you have done is to introduce a little bonus.

Anything we add to a recipe should be appropriate, so with roast pork, for instance, we could add fennel seeds or maybe a squeeze of sharp Seville orange to the gravy. Either would flatter the meat. With lamb, you could add freshly chopped mint or some thyme. Neither would impose itself on the meat; they are natural partners. A mustard gravy for beef can be stunning, especially when you have a few spinach leaves to soften in its latent heat. It is simply a question of adding something that feels right, something that has an affinity and a history of working well with meat juices.

A great favourite of mine is to leave a few whole and unskinned garlic cloves in with the meat. As their skins brown, their insides become sweet and mild and can be squashed as easily as butter into the pan juices. This is a fine one to serve with a leg or shoulder of lamb. I have done the same with tomatoes too, crushing their flesh and juice into the pan with the back of a wooden spoon. Good with chicken, that one.

As a country, we can be divided into those who put flour in their gravy and those who don't. It is not a north/south divide, but I have detected a liking for thicker, possibly more sustaining gravies wherever I have lived in the north. That, for the record, means Ilkley, Yorkshire and the Lake District. My late stepmother, born and bred in the Midlands, was a flour and gravy-browning woman, her point being that the result should be as dark and thick as possible. Modern thinking is that flour is unnecessary and gravy browning a sin only just short of cannibalism.

I cannot say I don't ever put a bit of flour in my sauces. I do think the mock-horror and raised eyebrows that inevitably follow the sprinkling of a spoonful of MacDougall's is nothing more than misplaced snobbery. Sometimes a thick gravy seems appropriate, say, when the weather is cold, and always with liver and onions or sausage and mash. It is not just a case of stirring in a spoonful of flour to thicken; the raw starch needs cooking, browning nuttily in the fat.

You can faff about with arrowroot or cornflour if you wish, but I find gravy thickened in this manner often more gloopy than luscious. What we are after is, whether as clear as amber or as voluptuous as a velvet throw, not simply a savoury lubricant, but something that brings our meal together, be it Sunday beef or Christmas turkey. As I said, the heart of a dish. Its soul and, I think, its point.

A simple gravy from the roasting tin

the roasting tin and its fat, debris and aromatics wine, stock or water

Lift the roast from the tin and set it aside to rest. If there is a thick layer of fat in the tin, then tip it off into a heatproof bowl and save it. You can use it to roast potatoes. Leave the thin layer of the dark juices that lie under the fat behind in the tin, then scoop out the bits of herbs, garlic and onion that may be in the pan and discard.

Put the tin over a low to moderate heat and pour in enough liquid to make a thin layer in the bottom. The amount you add will depend on how rich you want your gravy to be and how much meat juice you have to work with. As the liquid comes to the boil, stir it with a balloon whisk or wooden spoon, scraping away at the debris and crusty bits stuck to the pan until they dissolve.

Let the mixture bubble and reduce for a minute or two, then taste and add a little salt and some black pepper. It will not thicken, so take it off the heat once it has concentrated to a thin but aromatic liquor.

A thick gravy

This is the gravy I use when I want a rich, meaty sauce to eat with sausages or, especially, Yorkshire pudding.Remove the roast from the pan and set it to one side to rest. Now stir in 1 tbsp flour and place the pan over a moderate heat. Stir the flour into the juices left in the pan, and let it cook until it smells nutty. Take care that the flour does not burn. When you have a thin, biscuit-coloured paste, pour in a little stock or water and keep stirring until it thickens, adding more liquid as you go, thinning the gravy to the consistency you like. Let it bubble gently for a minute or two longer than you would for a thin gravy.

A mushroom and Madeira gravy

A fine, richly flavoured gravy for roast birds, especially game birds and turkey. I have chosen to use a little flour to enrich this, as it is less temperamental than a sauce thickened with arrowroot and, I think, less detectable. Enough for a large chicken or medium-sized turkey.

the roasting pan, and its juices, sticky debris and aromatics

500ml stock (preferably made from the giblets)

100g small brown mushrooms, thinly sliced

1 tbsp plain flour

about 100ml Madeira

Pour off most of the fat in the roasting tin, leaving behind 3 or 4 tbsp of caramelised meat juices, the herbs and vegetables. Place it over a low to moderate heat, add the mushrooms and cook until they have coloured and softened, stirring them occasionally.

Sprinkle in 1 tbsp, no more, of flour and stir it in until the mushrooms are loosely bound together. Let the mixture cook for a few minutes, taking care it does not burn. You want the flour to cook so that there is no raw taste. Add a few tablespoons of the stock and stir until you have a thin paste, then continue adding the stock until you have a thinnish gravy. Bring towards the boil, adding salt and black pepper. Pour in the Madeira and continue cooking, at a low and leisurely bubble, for about 15 minutes. Pour the whole lot through a strainer, pushing hard with the back of a spoon to extract all the flavour from the mushrooms, into a small pan, bring back to the boil, check the seasoning and pour into a warmed gravy boat.
