fields.headline: Precious moments
fields.standfirst:
From cowslips to Chelsea and storms to
television schedules... the highs and lows of a
gardening year
fields.trailText: From cowslips to Chelsea and storms to television schedules... the highs and lows of a gardening year.
fields.body:
Not being a Christian, I have no religious sentiments about Christmas at all, but am glad to share in the general sense of goodwill and a fresh start. Christ or light (pace John 1: 4-9), certainly something is born anew.

I always arrive at Christmas with the relief of a sailor turning the Cape. For the past few months I have been battling against heavy weather, sailing into the wind, managing the garden from crisis to crisis. One day is completed in order to survive the next. But then you round Christmas, the Cape of Enforced Cheer, and the wind is suddenly tucked into your back. The currents are sweeping me towards spring like a conveyor belt. Sure, the days are short, the weather vile and good intentions undergo their own private shipwrecks, but I have a palpable sensation of heading for home, however high the local seas.

The light has a lot to do with it. Now that the solstice is past, the days are moving out, imperceptibly perhaps - but from now on the extra minutes at five o'clock matter as much as hours in midsummer. These are moments of light as precious as jewels.

I always spend the period between Christmas and New Year taking stock in the garden and preparing for next year. If I look back over this year it initially seems to have been dominated by the weather, and I see that exactly a year ago we were flooded, the garden half under water, and my garden diary has the one highly horticultural comment: 'No baths, washing machines, etc' (the 'etc' meant flushing loos).

Certainly my experience of this autumn has been just like everyone else's - sodden, although the summer was not too bad. It rained a bit and we had the odd chilly day but the sun also shone and the ground was, well, normal. By September the soil in the borders was really dry and even in October, when we were moving some apple trees in driving rain, an inch or two down it was bone dry. The important yardstick was that nothing in the garden was delayed or brought forward by the weather other than the slow creep of global warming that is nudging the seasons aside. So spring was in full flow by March. My diary entry for 4 March reads: 'Primroses in great mounds in coppice and violets extraordinary. Cowslips out - perhaps a dozen or more - weirdly early.' And autumn - despite the rain - was warm well into November, with all the tender plants we habitually grow, such as leonotis, tithonia, salvia and cosmos, blooming lustily yet.

I feel strangely ungrateful for these seasonal extensions, as they seem to be an increase in quantity rather than quality. Seasons in the garden are created by a series of impressionistic strokes that build a picture up and this early spring and drawn-out autumn are a watercolour wash. Not bad, but not really better.

Much of gardening 2000 was spent in front of a camera in someone else's garden, real and pretend. Real Gardens dominated my working life from March to September and has disappeared after three series. This is a real loss and I am certain Channel 4 has made a mistake. Real Gardens was a beautifully simple idea that really engaged with the day-to-day reality of people's lives via their gardens. It was sometimes uneven but at its best it reached parts that no other gardening programme has reached. Lost Gardens has another series going out in a month or so that we shot in the spring and is an enormously potent series to work on. Garden archaeology is fascinating and it still astonishes me how much evidence is left in the ground to uncover, from planting holes to hard landscaping. I know many people have a skewed vision of how television works - overestimating the veracity of half of it and simultaneously suspecting jiggery-pokery where none exists. But behind the scenes on Lost Gardens there is a real intensity of interest and involvement from everybody, from presenters to the people that do the computer graphics.

For the third year running - and probably the last for the foreseeable future - I was very involved in televising the RHS flower shows at Chelsea, Hampton Court and Tatton Park. The latter is a fine day out and the combination of the beauty of Hampton Court Palace and its park and the sprawling ease of the show itself makes Hampton Court attractive, but Chelsea is a dog. It is terribly aware of its own importance but entirely devoid of charm. I always find things that I like there and I want it to go on existing, but visiting it is an unpleasant experience and spending eight days making 10 television programmes devoted entirely to it is exhausting and numbing. The combination of unctuous deference and anxious, competitive point-scoring is not attractive and stymies real creativity. For sure you will see fabulous plants but the show never adds up to the sum of its parts. The money spent on most of the show gardens is absurd and the good stuff is often overlooked or deliberately snubbed. But by far the worst aspect of Chelsea is the sense that no one - other than the great and the good - is actively welcome. You come away with the unavoidable impression that all visitors, exhibitors and members of the media are there just because the corporate money-making machine must be fed.

Before anyone accuses me of paranoia, or of having a gratuitous go at the RHS, this is not the case at all at the Malvern, Hampton Court or Tatton Park shows - all run in a perfectly friendly, welcoming fashion by the RHS. It is a Chelsea thing and, having observed the show as closely as anyone over the past three years, I would say that nothing would improve it more than simply making it more enjoyable.

I gave the prizes away at the Garden Industries annual jamboree last June and elicited boos and jeers by suggesting they wake up to the fact of the growing organic movement. The knee-jerk response was that organics is some kind of lefty plot to undermine the industry. But afterwards, quite a few manufacturers and suppliers came up to talk about organics in a sensible, serious way. Certain sections of the horticultural world (not least the RHS) view organics in the same breath as astrology or acupuncture - they acknowledge its popularity then dismiss it as 'not serious'. Well, this year has seen a huge increase in interest in organic gardening and I am sure that will go on developing. Certainly I will do all I can to help that process.

And the best moment since last Christmas? No one thing of course - and a thousand half-moments. But flicking back through the garden diary I remember this particular entry on 9 June as both being suffused with pleasure and typical of the reason that I garden at all: 'Wrote Observer all day. Made bread. Little Gem v. good. Broad beans lovely 3in pods. Jewel garden brilliant but needs working on. Played cricket with Adam 7-8pm. Good fun. Sarah said coppice was "what she dreamed of" when we walked round together at 9pm. Lovely Prussian Blue sky at 11pm.'

Happy Christmas.

Your roots: 'Tis the season to be pruning...

If the days between Christmas and New Year are mild and dry, use them to winter prune all fruit.

 Autumn raspberries can be cut to the ground, pulling up any suckers that are spreading too far. Mulch thickly with compost.

 Apple and pear trees need any crossing or rubbing branches removed and the centre of the tree sufficiently thinned to let a good flow of air run through it. Leave a good system of short, knobbly spurs growing off each branch - these will produce next spring's buds and fruit.

 Gooseberries and redcurrants need their leaders cut back by about a third. Prune away all inward-growing growth so that the interior is clear - this will help ventilation and make it easier to deal with sawfly.

 Blackcurrants should have been pruned late summer but you can do it now. Cut all the stems that bore fruit this year back to the ground. These will grow back to fruit in 18 months' time. The remaining shoots will fruit next summer.

 Do not prune plums or greengages now; this should be done in the summer after fruiting (only cut out crossing branches or diseased growth).

My roots: A week in Monty's garden

I have just spent the day pruning the pleached limes and I can honestly say that now, at 4.45 on a Sunday evening, boots off, hands washed and cup of tea in hand, that I feel as good as I have done all winter. There was a shower when the logs were delivered yesterday morning - all in 6ft lengths that had to be sawn up and stacked to keep the Christmas fires burning - and I heard the rain lash the windows at 4am, but other than that it has been dry for two whole days. Sunshine, a wind keen enough to make the warmth of a jacket friendly and, above all, light.

The pruning of the limes is probably my favourite winter job. I peck at it for weeks, occasionally getting a whole day or two but more often an hour or so here and there, depending on the weather and other commitments. Over the summer the limes sprout with enormous vigour and put on as much as 6ft of whippy growth from innumerable buds. Almost all are removed, going back to the barest of skeletons. You can see why Grinling Gibbons loved lime so. It cuts better than any other wood. It is soft enough to reward a sharp pair of secateurs or knife and yet firm enough to be crisp edged. A good pair of secateurs is enough to cut all but the largest shoots, but I have a little arsenal of secateurs, knife, medium and long loppers and a pruning saw, too, just in case. I also have a ball of tarred twine and a bundle of straight hazel rods to complete the kit. The latter are for replacing broken supports to which the lateral branches are tied to train them to make the grid. When a section is done it looks severe but as long as you accept that this kind of pruning is artificial, this is fine. It is just the pleaching taken back to the wintry essence of itself.

I am having an ongoing battle of wills with our largest water butt. We inherited it and it is huge, but has been overflowing, the excess submerging the greenhouse and cold frames. So I put a hosepipe onto the stopcock and diverted it down to where the gunnera and hostas are - on the basis that they will relish any excess wet. But the stopcock is temperamental and fickle, varying from a flow to a dribble with seemingly no consistency whatsoever. Anything less than a steady flow will not keep pace with the rain and it still overflows. To use and store our rainwater more constructively would be one in the eye for all the rain we have had, and I think that this will be another project for next year.

Now that the solstice is past, the days are moving out, imperceptibly perhaps - but from now on the extra minutes at five o'clock matter as much as hours in midsummer. These are moments of light as precious as jewels. I always spend the period between Christmas and New Year taking stock in the garden and preparing for next year. If I look back over this year it initially seems to have been dominated by the weather, and I see that exactly a year ago we were flooded, the garden half under water, and my garden diary has the one highly horticultural comment: 'No baths, washing machines, etc' (the 'etc' meant flushing loos). Certainly my experience of this autumn has been just like everyone else's - sodden, although the summer was not too bad. It rained a bit and we had the odd chilly day but the sun also shone and the ground was, well, normal. By September the soil in the borders was really dry and even in October, when we were moving some apple trees in driving rain, an inch or two down it was bone dry. The important yardstick was that nothing in the garden was delayed or brought forward by the weather other than the slow creep of global warming that is nudging the seasons aside. So spring was in full flow by March. My diary entry for 4 March reads: 'Primroses in great mounds in coppice and violets extraordinary. Cowslips out - perhaps a dozen or more - weirdly early.' And autumn - despite the rain - was warm well into November, with all the tender plants we habitually grow, such as leonotis, tithonia, salvia and cosmos, blooming lustily yet. I feel strangely ungrateful for these seasonal extensions, as they seem to be an increase in quantity rather than quality. Seasons in the garden are created by a series of impressionistic strokes that build a picture up and this early spring and drawn-out autumn are a watercolour wash. Not bad, but not really better. Much of gardening 2000 was spent in front of a camera in someone else's garden, real and pretend. Real Gardens dominated my working life from March to September and has disappeared after three series. This is a real loss and I am certain Channel 4 has made a mistake. Real Gardens was a beautifully simple idea that really engaged with the day-to-day reality of people's lives via their gardens. It was sometimes uneven but at its best it reached parts that no other gardening programme has reached. Lost Gardens has another series going out in a month or so that we shot in the spring and is an enormously potent series to work on. Garden archaeology is fascinating and it still astonishes me how much evidence is left in the ground to uncover, from planting holes to hard landscaping. I know many people have a skewed vision of how television works - overestimating the veracity of half of it and simultaneously suspecting jiggery-pokery where none exists. But behind the scenes on Lost Gardens there is a real intensity of interest and involvement from everybody, from presenters to the people that do the computer graphics. For the third year running - and probably the last for the foreseeable future - I was very involved in televising the RHS flower shows at Chelsea, Hampton Court and Tatton Park. The latter is a fine day out and the combination of the beauty of Hampton Court Palace and its park and the sprawling ease of the show itself makes Hampton Court attractive, but Chelsea is a dog. It is terribly aware of its own importance but entirely devoid of charm. I always find things that I like there and I want it to go on existing, but visiting it is an unpleasant experience and spending eight days making 10 television programmes devoted entirely to it is exhausting and numbing. The combination of unctuous deference and anxious, competitive point-scoring is not attractive and stymies real creativity. For sure you will see fabulous plants but the show never adds up to the sum of its parts. The money spent on most of the show gardens is absurd and the good stuff is often overlooked or deliberately snubbed. But by far the worst aspect of Chelsea is the sense that no one - other than the great and the good - is actively welcome. You come away with the unavoidable impression that all visitors, exhibitors and members of the media are there just because the corporate money-making machine must be fed. Before anyone accuses me of paranoia, or of having a gratuitous go at the RHS, this is not the case at all at the Malvern, Hampton Court or Tatton Park shows - all run in a perfectly friendly, welcoming fashion by the RHS. It is a Chelsea thing and, having observed the show as closely as anyone over the past three years, I would say that nothing would improve it more than simply making it more enjoyable. I gave the prizes away at the Garden Industries annual jamboree last June and elicited boos and jeers by suggesting they wake up to the fact of the growing organic movement. The knee-jerk response was that organics is some kind of lefty plot to undermine the industry. But afterwards, quite a few manufacturers and suppliers came up to talk about organics in a sensible, serious way. Certain sections of the horticultural world (not least the RHS) view organics in the same breath as astrology or acupuncture - they acknowledge its popularity then dismiss it as 'not serious'. Well, this year has seen a huge increase in interest in organic gardening and I am sure that will go on developing. Certainly I will do all I can to help that process. And the best moment since last Christmas? No one thing of course - and a thousand half-moments. But flicking back through the garden diary I remember this particular entry on 9 June as both being suffused with pleasure and typical of the reason that I garden at all: 'Wrote Observer all day. Made bread. Little Gem v. good. Broad beans lovely 3in pods. Jewel garden brilliant but needs working on. Played cricket with Adam 7-8pm. Good fun. Sarah said coppice was "what she dreamed of" when we walked round together at 9pm. Lovely Prussian Blue sky at 11pm.' Happy Christmas. Your roots: 'Tis the season to be pruning... If the days between Christmas and New Year are mild and dry, use them to winter prune all fruit.  Autumn raspberries can be cut to the ground, pulling up any suckers that are spreading too far. Mulch thickly with compost.  Apple and pear trees need any crossing or rubbing branches removed and the centre of the tree sufficiently thinned to let a good flow of air run through it. Leave a good system of short, knobbly spurs growing off each branch - these will produce next spring's buds and fruit.  Gooseberries and redcurrants need their leaders cut back by about a third. Prune away all inward-growing growth so that the interior is clear - this will help ventilation and make it easier to deal with sawfly.  Blackcurrants should have been pruned late summer but you can do it now. Cut all the stems that bore fruit this year back to the ground. These will grow back to fruit in 18 months' time. The remaining shoots will fruit next summer.  Do not prune plums or greengages now; this should be done in the summer after fruiting (only cut out crossing branches or diseased growth). My roots: A week in Monty's garden I have just spent the day pruning the pleached limes and I can honestly say that now, at 4.45 on a Sunday evening, boots off, hands washed and cup of tea in hand, that I feel as good as I have done all winter. There was a shower when the logs were delivered yesterday morning - all in 6ft lengths that had to be sawn up and stacked to keep the Christmas fires burning - and I heard the rain lash the windows at 4am, but other than that it has been dry for two whole days. Sunshine, a wind keen enough to make the warmth of a jacket friendly and, above all, light. The pruning of the limes is probably my favourite winter job. I peck at it for weeks, occasionally getting a whole day or two but more often an hour or so here and there, depending on the weather and other commitments. Over the summer the limes sprout with enormous vigour and put on as much as 6ft of whippy growth from innumerable buds. Almost all are removed, going back to the barest of skeletons. You can see why Grinling Gibbons loved lime so. It cuts better than any other wood. It is soft enough to reward a sharp pair of secateurs or knife and yet firm enough to be crisp edged. A good pair of secateurs is enough to cut all but the largest shoots, but I have a little arsenal of secateurs, knife, medium and long loppers and a pruning saw, too, just in case. I also have a ball of tarred twine and a bundle of straight hazel rods to complete the kit. The latter are for replacing broken supports to which the lateral branches are tied to train them to make the grid. When a section is done it looks severe but as long as you accept that this kind of pruning is artificial, this is fine. It is just the pleaching taken back to the wintry essence of itself. I am having an ongoing battle of wills with our largest water butt. We inherited it and it is huge, but has been overflowing, the excess submerging the greenhouse and cold frames. So I put a hosepipe onto the stopcock and diverted it down to where the gunnera and hostas are - on the basis that they will relish any excess wet. But the stopcock is temperamental and fickle, varying from a flow to a dribble with seemingly no consistency whatsoever. Anything less than a steady flow will not keep pace with the rain and it still overflows. To use and store our rainwater more constructively would be one in the eye for all the rain we have had, and I think that this will be another project for next year.

webTitle: Scotch mist: Madonna, the media scrum and the invisible wedding

fields.headline: Scotch mist: Madonna, the media scrum and the invisible wedding
fields.standfirst: Even commando paparazzi tactics couldn't get uninvited guests into the pop star's impregnable castle
fields.trailText: Even commando paparazzi tactics couldn't get uninvited guests into the pop star's impregnable castle.
fields.body:
James and Robert Jones could have been forgiven for allowing themselves a pat on the back. Up against the world's most security-conscious pop star and its most ruthless paparazzi, they were within a hair's breadth of pulling off the most audacious celebrity scoop in decades: an illicit recording of the christening of Rocco John Ritchie, son of Madonna and her husband-to-be Guy Ritchie. In tabloid terms, gold dust.

Their methods were extreme. For more than 60 hours, Robert, 51, had managed to conceal himself inside Dornoch Cathedral's organ, along with two plastic binliners for bodily waste. At 8pm on Thursday, all feelings of hardship slipped away as he made his way towards the cathedral door. A full hour had passed since the proud parents, their son and the 30 A-list guests had left, and the team of private security guards had completed their final sweep of the building. Adrenaline pumping, he opened the door... and froze in horror as he was spotted by the guards being debriefed on the cathedral steps.

As the Madonna wedding party made its slow, hung-over retreat from the Highlands yesterday, the people of Dornoch were struggling to come to terms with the mayhem. Since Monday they have looked on in good-humoured bemusement as an incredible, no-holds-barred struggle for supremacy has unfolded between the celebrity couple and the media. It is a battle the celebrities appear to have won handsomely.

By late yesterday afternoon, the only solid evidence that the wedding took place in the exclusive Skibo castle estate was a terse statement from the Church of Scotland minister who conducted the ceremony on Friday evening. 'It did happen,' the Rev Susan Brown told reporters camped outside her front door.

Until then, the world's media had been left guessing. Even when the first convoy of sleek saloons carrying guests to Inverness airport slipped out of the castle's gates in the dark at 5.45am, there was no proof a marriage had taken place. No pictures of the happy couple had been released. More tellingly, none of the dozens of paparazzi who had spent the previous 24 hours blacked-up and dressed in camouflage gear, crawling through the undergrowth of the castle grounds pursued by the security team, had got close enough to grab a snap from the shrubbery.

By the standards of celebrity weddings, such total defeat for the media is unprecedented. The Jones team, from south London, are merely the most spectacular casualties of this failure. Instead of collecting fat pay cheques, they face a New Year of court appearances. 'We were very close to them all and could clearly see the faces of the celebrity guests,' said a dejected James Jones, 33, after his release from custody. 'The whole thing has cost me a fortune and I just want to go home.'

But the incident has blown open the previously hidden lengths the paparazzi will go to in pursuit of a celebrity exclusive. The men, both unemployed from south London, are believed to have been hired by one of Britain's more determined Sunday tabloids to breach the formidable security cordon Madonna and Ritchie threw around their nuptials. They are believed to have managed to make a video recording of the service, using a small, handheld camera.

The men, ex-soldiers who claim to have served in the SAS, arrived at the Royal Hotel in Tain, near Dornoch, on Monday and booked into Room 36. But 24 hours later one of them disappeared. 'They arrived on Monday, but we hadn't seen one of them since Tuesday,' said Mike Sangster, the manager. 'Then, on Thursday, the police came in and asked for him and he walked out with him.'

It is understood that the tabloid initially denied knowledge of the men, but - after being threatened with police action - eventually settled their room bill.

The organ incident was a major embarrassment for Madonna's security team, in particular Jackie Jackson, her deputy head of security who was in charge of the christening operation at the cathedral. An investigation into the breach has now been launched. As local police were quick to point out, it was Madonna's minders and Rock Steady, the private security firm they had employed, who were responsible for security in the cathedral and its grounds.

The arrests were a sour footnote to what had been a hugely successful event on Thursday. As the cathedral shimmered in the Highland mist, the entire local population gathered outside, along with a 500-strong media pack to witness the christen ing. They were not disappointed; Range Rovers delivered a glittering display of Hollywood's finest, including Gwyneth Paltrow, Rupert Everett, Sting and his wife Trudi Styler. Madonna and Ritchie had even played the PR game, stopping to give the crowd a wave and an eyeful as they entered and left the cathedral with their son. Everybody went home happy.

But after the discovery of the Jones infiltration, the celebrities' tactics changed immediately. A media blackout began, and security was stepped up with more guards brought in to patrol the grounds. The equipment they had to hand was as sophisticated as the techniques being employed by the paparazzi, including thermal imaging devices and infra-red cameras. Over the week at least 30 photographers, all of whom were using camouflage gear and commando tactics to evade detection, were caught and escorted off the premises.

One group of three managed to stay in the grounds for three days before they were picked up by heat-seeking equipment and thrown out. In their bags they had packed Arctic warfare suits for camouflage in case it snowed.

The security operation was not a total success. One British tabloid photographer managed to creep into the grounds in the early hours of Thursday morning and get close enough to snap a clear picture of Madonna standing at the breakfast room window, holding her son. The photographer, who asked not to be named, spent 10 hours lying still in the damp, freezing cold, before making his escape under the cover of darkness. 'I was thinking that I might lose a couple of toes to frostbite,' he told The Observer yesterday. 'But with the money this picture could make, I knew I could easily afford the plastic surgery, so I hung on. I'm going to print up a big copy of the picture and send it to Rock Steady security as a Christmas card from the paparazzi.'

Selling the picture has not been straightforward. On Thursday the Court of Appeal ruled that Catherine Zeta- Jones and Michael Douglas were entitled to privacy and could sue a celebrity magazine which published an illicit picture of their wedding in New York last month. The ruling, under the Human Rights Act, has forced tabloid picture editors to take a cautious approach and turn down pictures which previously would have proved irresistible.

The successful Madonna snapper is still expecting a bumper festive season, though. 'I've already sold it abroad,' he said. 'It's going for about £5,000 a time, so it's going to be a jolly Christmas.'

He will not be the only person to profit from Madonna wedding fever. In Dornoch, hoteliers and retailers have enjoyed an unprecedented windfall. At the Dornoch Castle hotel, opposite the cathedral, owner Colin Thompson has pocketed about £5,000 from selling camera positions to broadcasters alone. 'It has been cracking,' he said.

One Sunday newspaper photographer was charged £10 by a barman at the hotel for the privilege of standing on a beer crate for a better view of the cathedral.

As the Madonna camp pulled out of the town yesterday relations remained warm - with locals at least. The media were not so happy. So successful was the news blackout that it was not even clear if Madonna was still at Skibo. Her private jet was seen taking off from Inverness Airport, but only Sting was seen getting on board and the media, who have been camped outside every exit from the castle since dawn, swore blind that she had not gone past them.

Then, at 3.30 pm yesterday, a fleet of three limousines swept out the main entrance, carrying Madonna, her new husband and their minders. They were rumoured to be heading to spend Christmas at Sting's house in Wiltshire.

But nobody really knows the truth. Not for sure.

webTitle: Women to fight on front line

fields.headline: Women to fight on front line
fields.standfirst: Army's secret trials reveal female soldiers perform as well as men in combat
fields.trailText: Army's secret trials reveal female soldiers perform as well as men in combat.
fields.body:
The last barrier to women taking frontline combat roles in the Army is set to be lifted after trials clouded in secrecy concluded that there was no reason they should not fight alongside men.

The controversial findings follow Ministry of Defence attempts to address the rule that women should not go into combat.

A document outlining the results of the trial is scheduled to arrive on the desk of Geoff Hoon, the Defence Secretary, next year, forcing the Government to make a difficult and potentially unpopular decision on the issue before the general election, expected in May.

Last week General Sir Charles Guthrie, Britain's Chief of Defence Staff, said that the Army's combat effectiveness should not be compromised by political correctness.

But MoD sources say that Hoon will find it hard to reject the evidence from the trials and will be forced to increase significantly the range of roles available to women.

The trials took place this autumn at the Army's training grounds on Salisbury plain.

Mixed-sex platoons completed a series of tasks in different settings designed to test female soldiers' aptitude - and their effect on their male colleagues - in everything from peacekeeping and public order situations to intensive combat. An all-male 'control' platoon was also deployed as well as all-women tank crews and infantry units.

The trials were the second stage of an MoD study that is considered so sensitive that only a few senior officers and the specialists involved in it are aware of the results.

'They are so worried about it they have kept it hermetically sealed,' said one military source.

But The Observer has learnt that in the physical trials stage of the study, which is now complete, the two sexes interacted well in almost all situations, even in close environments such as tanks and bunkers and under heavy fire. The presence of women is seen as a significant advantage in the peace-keeping and aid operations that now comprise a high proportion of Britain's overseas deployments. Women already serve in artillery regiments and have been trained as helicopter and jet pilots.

The next phase of the 'The Combat Effectiveness and Gender Study' is a survey of opinion among serving soldiers and their families. Thousands of questionnaires are being circulated to gauge feelings about the issue.

The results, and those of the physical trials, will be combined with other research from foreign armed forces on the issue and sent to generals for their opinion. Senior officers may be able to use the findings from the survey to block any change. Trials for women on submarines resulted in the ban being maintained.

The completed report will be given to a key committee chaired by Hoon for a final decision.

The army is almost unanimously against any further change. 'There is no way that I would want anything other than a single-sex combat command,' said one senior officer, a former commander of an elite infantry regiment. 'It would be immensely destabilising and possibly demoralising. And my wife would go completely mad.'

Others challenge the physical capability of women soldiers. During the rescue of kidnapped British soldiers in Sierra Leone recently, soldiers jumped out of their helicopters and into a shoulder-deep swamp. 'All our lads were big guys,' another infantry officer said. 'There's no point in having a 5ft 2in woman in a 5ft 3in swamp.'

There is also scepticism about the trials themselves. Soldiers say that judging troops on exercise says little about their potential performance in actual combat. 'It's camping with fireworks,' the officer said. 'It's got sod all to do with fighting.'

Giving women combat roles would bring Britain into line with the armies of the US, Canada, Holland and Norway. It is likely, though, that the British forces, with the backing of Ministers, will use stringent testing of any potential recruits to combat units to limit the effect of the change.

fields.headline: Prison staff investigated for corruption
fields.standfirst: Officers charged in bribery and smuggling inquiry as jails chief pledges to fight 'unacceptable behaviour'
fields.trailText: Officers charged in bribery and smuggling inquiry as jails chief pledges to fight 'unacceptable behaviour'.
fields.body:
The Prison Service and the police are investigating a ring of corrupt prison officers who are alleged to have been taking huge bribes from prisoners to transfer them to more convenient jails of their choice.

So far three officers at a prison in the south-east of England have been arrested and charged in the inquiry. A series of similar allegations concerning another prison are also being investigated. Elsewhere prison officers are believed to have accepted large sums in return for turning a blind eye to drugs being smuggled into prisons and the supply of mobile phones used to arrange criminal operations 'on the outside'.

Two prison officers - at Pentonville and at Bullingdon, Oxfordshire - have recently been suspended after being linked to the trafficking of heroin into their prisons. Another officer, at Swaleside maximum security prison in Kent, was alleged to have smuggled a block of cannabis worth £4,000 and a telephone to a convict.

Senior policemen working with the prison service have said that criminals are prepared to pay £30,000, which is twice the salary of a junior prison officer, to staff willing to arrange transfers or turn a blind eye to illegal activities.

'Increasingly sophisticated and well-resourced prisoners have the ability to corrupt or compromise staff. Some are going to be foolish enough to take the money,' Narey told The Observer last week. 'We are facing up to our problems and fronting out unacceptable behaviour.'

New figures obtained by The Observer also reveal a massive increase in the number of prison officers under investigation. Almost 400 inquiries have been launched in the last six months alone into offences ranging from sexual and racial harassment of other prison staff to assisting convicts to escapes from prisons, rape and moonlighting. At least 200 more investigations, started earlier in the year, are still underway. In around half of inquiries misbehaviour by prison officers is confirmed.

Campaigners say the figures show that the prison service remains a bastion of prejudice and brutality despite a raft of reforms introduced by Narey.

'So far it has just been tinkering. The whole system needs to be broken apart and put back together again as something appropriate for the twenty-first century,' said Mark Leech, chief executive of Unlock, a national association of ex-offenders and a former convict himself.

The figures will embarrass Jack Straw, the Home Secretary, who pledged to reform the prison service on coming to power three years ago and will reinforce its 'crisis hit' image. Eleven investigations have been launched into alleged assistance offered by prison staff to convicts in the course of an escape and 18 inquiries initiated into 'inappropriate relationships' between warders and inmates. Sixty-five of the investigations are into assaults on a prisoner and 51 are into sexual or racist harassment. There have even been 35 investigations started into the bullying of other prison officers by staff.

The service is still recovering from the conviction of three officers at Wormwood Scrubs who assaulted a convicted murderer in his cell. They received sentences of up to 18 months earlier this year. Narey has admitted that the service was 'institutionally racist' and spoke of a culture of violence.

Last week he said that he was committed to stamping out racism and physical abuse in prisons. 'It is far better than it used to be but I am determined to get rid of the minority of staff who will abuse prisoners if they can get away with it. A larger minority will turn a blind eye.'

Among the reforms Narey has introduced have been gender and race awareness training instead of drill for rookie prison officers, a streamlined complaints procedure, a drive for recruits from ethnic minorities and drugs tests for service staff.

But his measures seem to have failed so far to stop the indiscipline. A survey published earlier this year by the National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders (Nacro) showed that more than a quarter of black and almost half of Asian inmates said they had been victims of verbal abuse; 12 per cent of both groups reported being attacked by another prisoner or staff member.

Recently released prisoners speak of continuing violence and drug abuse. One prisoner, recently released from Brixton after serving a sentence for fraud, told The Observer that heroin was easily obtainable in the jail.

'The two guys in the next cell were smoking smack all the time. They used to tell me that they'd have me hooked on it before I got out. They never had any trouble getting drugs.'

Another convict, released six months ago after a lengthy term for drugs smuggling, said that violence was particularly bad among Category A high-security prisons. 'There are prisons where everyone carries a weapon almost all the time,' he said. 'If the officers aren't having a go at you then another con will be. Some of these places are nightmares.'

The ex-convict, who spent time in at least six different prisons, said that brutality from prison officers was commonplace, particularly on the segregation units where inmates are sent if they break regulations. 'When you are on the "seg" you are totally alone and everybody knows it. They can do what they want with you. I can remember hearing the beatings during the night I was down there. For every officer who just sees it as a job, there are others who see it as a war.' He pointed out that bringing drugs, alcohol or telephones into a prison was difficult without the collusion of a member of staff.

'You are searched after a visit. How are you going to hide drugs or a mobile? I saw inmates with bottles of whisky. You can't tell me that they were smuggled up a trouser leg.'

Experts say the problems are a result of the fierce debate over the role of prisons in society and conflicting messages sent by politicians. 'The uncertainty feeds through on to the landings. If a Home Secretary says he 'wants decent but austere' prisons some people just hear austere. Most people join the prison service because they want to do some good work. They are then asked, after 11 weeks of training, to do one of the most difficult jobs in the public sector. But what is that job?,' Dr Andrew Coyle, a former governor of Brixton prison, said. 'There has been a quietly smoking time bomb of pressure under the prison service and what we are now seeing is a result of that.'

fields.headline: Carey queries future of 'state Church'
fields.standfirst: Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: The Archbishop of Canterbury yesterday reopened the explosive question of the relationship between Church and State by conceding there was a 'real argument' to be had about its future.
fields.body:
The Archbishop of Canterbury yesterday reopened the explosive question of the relationship between Church and State by conceding there was a 'real argument' to be had about its future.

The Rt Rev George Carey said the situation was constantly evolving, and argued that whether or not the Church of England maintained its special relationship with the Crown, it could still serve the nation.

His words will raise eyebrows, particularly as he is to preach a sermon before the Queen at the Royal Family's own parish church in Sandringham this morning.

They follow political pressure for repeal of the ancient statute preventing Catholics sitting on the throne. Because the monarch is also the head of the Church of England, repeal would break the age-old link between the Crown and the Church.

'Establishment is not about privilege but about service to the nation,' Carey said. 'That service will go on whether the Church of England is disestablished or not.'

He told BBC Radio 4's Today programme the churches were now working much more closely together. 'We are moving away from a competitve spirit, we are co-operating more and that of course is going to affect the matter of establishment.'

Asked about repeal of the Act of Settlement, for which the Observer 's sister paper, the Guardian, has campaigned, Carey said he saw 'no great desire' from the Government for such a change but agreed it was now on the public agenda. His comments will encourage MPs and campaigners who regard the Act as discriminatory and want it scrapped.

Cardinal Winning, head of the Roman Catholic Church in Scotland, has called the Act the 'grubby little secret' of the constitution. And Paddy Ashdown revealed in his diaries that Prince Charles had told him he saw no reason why Catholics should not sit on the throne.

The Act dates back to 1701, when fear of the influence of Rome was so great that the nation decreed only Protestant heirs of Princess Sophia, grand-daughter of James 1, could take the throne.

The Act also decrees that any Royal who marries a Catholic must renounce their rights to the succession.

Meanwhile the head of the Anglican Church in Wales has signalled his impatience with establishment, arguing it gave the Church of England an inflated sense of its own importance.

He also warned in an interview with the Daily Telegraph against a culture of instant gratification which he said could fuel marital problems over Christmas.

The lavishness of Madonna and Guy Ritchie's nuptials symbolised how marriage had become a 'huge consumer event' breeding unrealistic expectations, Dr Rowan Williams said.

webTitle: Lottery grant gives beacon of hope to lighthouse legacy

fields.headline: Lottery grant gives beacon of hope to lighthouse legacy
fields.trailText: The Titanic was guided by the beacon of Blackhead lighthouse as it sailed out of Belfast on its maiden voyage towards disaster in 1912. 100 years after it was built, Blackhead is to be opened to the public for the first time.
fields.body:
The Titanic was guided by the beacon of Blackhead lighthouse as it sailed out of Belfast on its maiden voyage towards disaster in 1912.

By the time of the Troubles, the lighthouse, which remained under all-Ireland control after partition, was unmanned. The lightkeepers' houses on the Antrim coast were empty. But in the new year, 100 years after it was built, Blackhead is to be opened to the public for the first time. A £148,000 grant from the Heritage Lottery Fund has been awarded to the Irish Landmark Trust.

The houses are to be restored and let as holiday accommodation while the lighthouse is to remain operational.

The trust, which leases the small lighthouse complex built in 1901 from the Commissioners for Irish Lights, says restoration work will begin in early January. The scheme is part of a £3.45m investment along the east Antrim shoreline from Belfast to Carrickfergus, Carnlough and Glenarm. Kevin Baird, from the Irish Landmark Trust, predicted the restoration would create full-time employment as well as preserving one of the most famous sights on the coastal edge of the city.

'The Irish Landmark Trust will bring a new use to these important, but redundant, buildings from our maritime past,' he said. 'Securing their future as holiday accommodation in a stunning location not only uses lottery money to preserve our heritage, but also makes a longer-term contribution to the Northern Ireland economy through employment, construction and tourism.'

Blackhead lighthouse stands opposite its twin across the lough at Mew Island. The two were built to protect commercial shipping at the start of the twentieth century and guided the great ships of Belfast's shipbuilding glory days.

Ireland has had lighthouses since the fifth century with the introduction of a lighted beacon at Hook Head in Co Wexford. But the heyday of lighthouse building was during the late nineteenth century.

The Commissioners for Irish Lights was one of the few bodies to remain on an all-Ireland basis after partition in 1921; another was the Royal National Lifeboat Institution. Control over all of the Free State's and Northern Ireland's lighthouses remained with the commissioners' office in Dublin. Having survived as an all-Ireland institution, the commissioners offer a template for new cross-border bodies introduced as part of the Good Friday Agreement.

webTitle: Bold bishop wants to split Church and Crown

fields.headline: Bold bishop wants to split Church and Crown
fields.standfirst:
Richard Holloway may be retired, but in this interview he remains outspoken about politics and drugs

Special report: religion in the UK
fields.trailText: Richard Holloway may be retired, but in this interview he remains outspoken about politics and drugs.
fields.body:
The man often described as Britain's most controversial bishop believes the Church of England must give up its monopoly on the British Crown and recognise it is only one of many different strands in modern society.

The Right Rev Richard Holloway, who retired in October after 14 years as Bishop of Edinburgh and eight years as Scottish Episcopal primus, acknowledges the Church will not readily abandon its established status and politicians would be reluctant to force the change through.

'The English,' he says, 'are pragmatic; they are not revolutionaries. They prefer not to confront abuses but let them wither away.' Only in the unlikely event of the Prince of Wales wanting to marry a Roman Catholic would the reform of the Acts of Settlement have to be confronted. 'Then, but only then, they might very well change the law,' says Holloway.

Bishop Holloway, who gave an interview to The Observer last week, says anyone appointed a bishop in the Church of England soon becomes a believer in establishment, even if they are not one already. But Holloway says he can take a more impartial view 'from the sidelines'. The Scottish Episcopal Church is in the Anglican communion but its head, the primus, is elected and is 'first among equals'.

Unfairly, says Holloway with sudden asperity, it is often called the 'Laird's Church'. It was outlawed after it backed the Jacobites in the 1745 rebellion and for a time survived underground in Scotland. During the days of the penal laws, Episcopalians from down south were allowed to open 'qualified chapels', which became 'embassy churches' for Englishmen living north of the border.

The irony was that, as a consequence, when the penal laws were lifted in 1792, the outlawed Scottish Episcopalians were inevitably thought of as 'the English Church' and the label has stuck. It also became associated with the Scottish lairds who were busy Anglicising themselves in the nineteenth century, but in the cities it continued to be a church of the poor.

Holloway grew up in the Vale of Leven, a cradle of the industrial revolution, where his father was employed in a dye works. His career has taken him to Edinburgh via the United States, where he met his wife, and the Gorbals, where he suffered a crisis of faith.

He has not abandoned his scepticism, believing faith and doubt are two sides of the same human coin, but has adapted to it by interpreting scripture not as historical fact but as message and metaphor - what he has described as theological code. He respects those who believe literally in the Bible - in the historical truth of the Garden of Eden or that Christ walked on water - but calls himself a 'secular Christian'.

Above all he is inclusive; his chief dislike is dogmatic fundamentalism. He recalls that a former Archbishop of Singapore once accused him of hastening homosexuals to hell by denying they were living in sin. He bristles at the memory and says: 'Tolerance has it limits.'

Holloway was a member of the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority from 1991 to 1997. He takes a balanced approach to questions that have pitted some churchmen against science. He welcomed last week's debate on embryo cloning for therapeutic purposes. He said: 'The really interesting thing about most ethical debates is that they rarely raise questions of an obvious right versus an obvious wrong, but rather of competing goods. Good value systems can be in disagreement with each other.' He is in favour of the Abortion Act, which, he recalls, David Steel introduced for 'highly ethical reasons'.

Though he respects the Roman Catholic moral tradition, he does not agree with its view that an embryo is a human being from the moment of reproductive fusion. He supports early-term abortion, because it is preferable to the alternative - women being driven into the hands of back-street abortionists and risking their lives in the process.

He takes a similar view of drugs, believing the policy of interdiction to be a disaster, particularly in the US. 'I am in favour of the full legalisation of cannabis. I believe it should be available over the counter,' he says.

On hard drugs he is more cautious. 'The treatment of heroin and other hard-drug addiction should be a matter for the health service. Prescribing heroin to addicts would break the link with the crime it drives them to commit and take the problem out of the underworld of the schemes and the ghettos.'

Holloway is a member of the Labour Party but admits to a certain disillusion with New Labour, particularly its pandering to a tabloid agenda. Perhaps, he says hopefully, Labour 'will acquire more political courage in a second term'.

As for the row over William Hague's comments on law and order, he acquits the Tory leader of racism while convicting him of 'a kind of political opportunism that is damaging to the public good'. But, he adds, there is an implicit racism in much of what is said on law and order by both the main parties and he regrets the arm-wrestling between Jack Straw and Ann Widdecombe.

But the question of police numbers is, in any case, of dubious relevance. He explains: 'We need to look at the causes of crime, which is what Tony Blair used to say. Crime is overwhelmingly associated with alienated and rootless young men and with poverty. Poverty remains a curse in our society, which must be addressed through policies of redistribution, perhaps in radical and imaginative ways.'

He believes the Scottish Parliament can help. 'I'm a fan,' he says. He thinks Scotland has acquired much more self-confidence; indeed, Scots feel 'compassionate' about the English, who suddenly are confused and threatened about their own identity.

For the time being at any rate, the devolution settlement has defused Scotland's discontents. Even nationalism is 'off the boil' and will revive only if the Westminster Parliament acts with hostility or insensitivity, or if a referendum rejects UK membership of the euro.

He believes Scotland is much more at ease with Europe than England. 'I am quite comfortable with the idea of Scottish independence,' he says, 'but independence in Europe.'

Outside in the Edinburgh shops the tills are ringing amid the symbols of the old Pagan Yule. Unlike many clerics, with their annual denunciation of commercialism, Holloway enjoys the modern Christmas. 'People are kinder at Christmas,' he says. 'In pagan days Yule lit up the bleak midwinter - and it still does.'

Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: NHS drive to clear hospital beds with Relenza prescriptions is attacked by American watchdog.
fields.body:
THE Government's anti-flu campaign has been plunged into chaos after the drug Relenza was linked to 22 deaths in the US.

The disclosure follows a ruling last month by the Government's medicines watchdog, saying the drug should be made available on the NHS to elderly patients and people with breathing problems. This overturned a decision last year that Relenza was ineffective and expensive.

The Department of Health has been hoping that Relenza will help to keep vulnerable people with flu away from hospital, easing the expected NHS winter crisis. However, a respected Washington-based public health body is urging the Department of Health to reverse its decision, warning that prescribing the drug would 'jeopardise the health of many people in the United Kingdom'.

Evidence from the US suggests the very group of patients to which doctors will now be giving Relenza are those most at risk from potentially fatal side-effects.

The drug is administered by an inhaler, and the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has received reports of 22 deaths and numerous hospitalisations from patients who have breathed in the medicine to ward off flu symptoms. Most of those have involved people with existing breathing problems such as asthma, but in some cases the patient has had no history of any illness.

The Washington-based consumer group Public Citizen is urging the Government's medicines watchdog, the National Institute for Clinical Excellence (Nice), to reverse its 'potentially dangerous' decision.

Public Citizen's director, Larry Sasich, said: 'We are extremely concerned that the recent recommendations concerning the in-fluenza drug... will jeopardise the health of many people in the UK. Nice has recommended that the drug may be used in people with asthma or chronic obstructive lung disease, people for whom the US FDA has said the drug is "not generally recommended because of the risk of serious adverse events".'

Similar fears have been raised by health professionals in Britain, who believe that without proof of the drug's benefits it is irresponsible to prescribe it when there are potentially lethal side-effects.

Joe Collier, a professor at University of London's medical school and editor of the influential Drug and Therapeutic Bulletin , said: 'At the moment there is no proof that Relenza is any more effective than paracetemol and cough mixture.'

Collier believes Nice is breaking the law by going against the Department of Health's official evaluation of Relenza. This states: 'Due to the limited number of patients treated, it has not been possible to demonstrate that Relenza is effective in the elderly, patients with asthma or other chronic respiratory diseases, patients with unstable chronic illnesses or immuno-compromised patients.'

Although there have long been doubts about the benefits of Relenza, which is said by its manufacturer to reduce the duration of flu by a day or two, this is the first time serious concerns have been raised about potentially dangerous side-effects.

This month a group of 70 doctors in Devon rebelled against Nice's advice by voting not to prescribe Relenza because it was too expensive and unlikely to have any benefits. Relenza costs £24 per person for a five-day treatment that is expected to be used by 500,000 people, resulting in a £12 million bill for the NHS.

The original decision by Nice to ban Relenza from the NHS prompted an outburst from Sir Richard Sykes, chief executive of Glaxo Wellcome, which makes the drug. He threatened to move research investment abroad if Britain did not accept new drugs. Since then there has been intense behind-the-scenes lobbying of the Government by the company, which hopes to make massive profits worldwide from Relenza.

A spokesman for Glaxo Wellcome said: 'We are confident that the product has an acceptable safety profile. Should Relenza be prescribed to someone with breathing problems, then the patient should be informed of the risks and have suitable medication on hand.'

A statement from the Department of Health said: 'Doctors must exercise clinical judgment when prescribing medicines. It is not the role of Nice to set out all safety warnings, but to offer guidance as to whether a drug should be prescribed on the NHS. '

webTitle: The Observer praised for its clout as it scoops top newspaper awards

fields.headline: The Observer praised for its clout as it scoops top newspaper awards
fields.standfirst: And the winner is...
fields.trailText: And the winner is...
fields.body:
Judges at the influential What the Papers Say awards, screened last night on BBC2, praised The Observer for 'recovering its voice and clout'. The newspaper won more awards than any other title.

Roger Alton, the editor of The Observer, was named Editor of the Year, political columnist Andrew Rawnsley was honoured as Columnist of the Year, and photographers Murdo MacLeod and Tom Jenkins won the News and Sports Photographer of the Year awards respectively for their work on The Observer and our sister paper, the Guardian.

The Observer's new sports magazine, Observer Sport Monthly, was praised for its authoritative features and interviews and its coverage of women's sport. The news pages were commended for their 'sharpness'. The paper's new sections, including the TV guide introduced earlier this month, were praised as authoritative and fun.

The awards come at the end of a year of record success for The Observer. In the six months from June to November, the paper sold 440,793 copies a week - up 9.7 per cent on the same period last year.

The Observer is now the fastest-growing Sunday title. Media critics have praised the paper for its 'professionalism, sense of purpose and humour'.

At the ceremony in London the judges - senior editors and broadcasters - said Alton had 'turned the paper around...It has taken a real effort of will, ingenuity and long-term commitment. In the last year the paper has recovered its voice and its clout'. The newspaper had proved it 'could get and handle big political exclusives'. The judges singled out the bitter attack on Tony Blair by his former confidant and financial backer, Ken Follett, in July and praised The Observer's reporters for their account of the Austrian funicular railway tragedy last month.

The judges said Rawnsley was 'already a respected political commentator before the publication of his new book this year, but the revelations in Servants of the People blew the lid off New Labour. The book showed how the Blair government really worked on the inside and destroyed the myth that Blair led a seamlessly united government. It made his Observer column compulsory reading...'

MacLeod was described as a 'one of the most gifted exponents of the art of newspaper photography' and 'a great constructionist photographer'. A photo essay on grouse shooting in the Highlands in Observer Sport Monthly was highly commended. Jenkins led the field at the Olympics with pictures that captured the emotion of the games. Despite the time difference between Australia and London, Jenkins always managed to come up with the right image. His Olympics photo essay for Observer Sport Monthly was described as 'outstanding and memorable'.

After the awards Alton told Observer staff: 'The award should have gone to the paper as a whole. I am extraordinarily proud of everybody here, and all these achievements, which are very much a team effort.'

MediaGuardian.co.uk

fields.headline: Barbarians at the gate
fields.standfirst: While there were many bright moments, computerised effects and base humour were everywhere
fields.trailText: Film 2000: While there were many bright moments, computerised effects and base humour were everywhere.
fields.body:
Not a bad year, though a disconcerting tendency has been the continued merging of animation and live action movies, through the perfecting of special effects, CGI (computer-generated images) and the increasing realism of cartooning. There were at least 20 movies competing for inclusion in my top 10 favourites, and if I choose Lars von Trier's ludicrous musical Dancer in the Dark as the year's turkey it's because he's a major director and the award of the Palme d'Or to his picture and the Cannes Best Actress prize to Björk makes it a bird worth gunning for.

Part of the encouraging aspects of the year 2000 were the increasingly intelligent decisions of the British Board of Film Classification under Andreas Whittam Smith, who treats audiences aged 18 and over as adults. The saddest feature was the absence from our screens of interesting movies from most parts of the globe - little that aroused critical or public enthusiasm from Africa, Latin America, the Antipodes or eastern Europe.

French cinema girded its loins, sending us half a dozen pictures of value, most significantly Raul Ruiz's exquisite fantasia on Proust, Time Regained; Beau Travail, Claire Denis's poetic conflation of Billy Budd and Beau Geste; and Dominik Moll's homage to Hitchcock, Harry, He's Here to Help, a movie that could have proved a popular triumph were British distributors (and audiences too) not so resistant to subtitles. Most other continental pictures scarcely survived the Channel crossing.

Iranian film-makers have continued to thrive in a regime hostile to the cinema and popular culture. At least three subtle, oblique masterpieces have reached our shores: Majid Majidi's story of a beautiful blind boy, The Colour of Paradise , Abbas Kiarostami's Beckettian The Wind Will Carry Us and the 20-year-old Samira Makhmalbaf's Blackboards , which opens next week.

Moving further East, there was a strong representation of Chinese, Taiwanese and Japanese films at Cannes this year and a trio of remarkable Chinese pictures opened here - Chen Kaige's historical epic The Emperor and the Assassin ; Wong Kar-Wai's mesmerising account of a Brief Encounter -style affair in 1962 Hong Kong, In the Mood for Love ; and Lou Ye's low-budget Suzhou River , a restlessly romantic tale set in Shanghai and clearly indebted to Hitchcock's Vertigo .

The British cinema has gone its absurd way, frittering away lottery money on endless half-baked projects mostly too painful to recall. A feeling has been that our native industry has somehow prospered through Catherine Zeta Jones marrying Michael Douglas and Guy Ritchie fathering a child with Madonna. The tabloids as usual proclaimed another 'The British Are Coming' renaissance at Oscar time when the British stage director Sam Mendes seized a clutch of Academy Awards for his film debut, American Beauty. Next year it will be the turn of another gifted British theatre director, Stephen Daldry, who will certainly be nominated, and possibly rewarded, for his cinematic debut, Billy Elliot. Both made technically accomplished, somewhat derivative, films.

Neither's work in my view compared with the really interesting British movies of the year. They were Mike Leigh's celebration of Gilbert and Sullivan at work, Topsy-Turvy; Terence Davies's austere adaptation of Edith Wharton's The House of Mirth (which compared well and instructively with Merchant-Ivory's more opulent adaptation of The Golden Bowl, by Wharton's friend and mentor Henry James); and my favourite picture of the year, Christopher Nolan's ingenious thriller Memento , made in California and American-financed. Memento fulfilled the great expectations aroused last year by Nolan's shoestring British picture, Following. The enterprising Mike Figgis had three films released this year, the best being Time Code, a virtuoso piece of film-making and a hilarious commentary on Tinseltown.

A moderately impressive year in America was a good time for the girls, with knockout roles for Julia Roberts in Erin Brockovich, Angelina Jolie in Girl, Interrupted and Hilary Swank in Boys Don't Cry, all as resilient trailer-park types battling against a rigidly conformist society. The British cinema gave the Hollywood actress Julianne Moore her best role to date as a middle-class Englishwoman in Neil Jordan's The End of the Affair.

The States provided great parts for British actresses - Samantha Morton in Alison Maclean's Jesus' Son and Woody Allen's Sweet and Lowdown; the Oscar-nominated Janet McTeer in Tumbleweeds; Tracey Ullman in Allen's Small Time Crooks, all playing blue-collar Americans.

The dominant American males were George Clooney, who proved himself the Clark Gable de nos jours in Three Kings, O Brother, Where Art Thou? and The Perfect Storm, and the ubiquitous character actors Philip Seymour Hoffman (Magnolia, The Talented Mr Ripley, Flawless) and Ben Stiller (Keeping the Faith, Black and White, Meet the Parents), all three equally adept in dramatic and comic roles.

Most of Hollywood's major talents either marked time (Scorsese with Bringing Out the Dead) or took a step backward (De Palma with Mission to Mars), though Curtis Hanson followed up his L.A. Confidential with the surprising comedy of the literary life, Wonder Boys, in which Michael Douglas acted his age as a middle-aged novelist in trouble. The obsessive theme, carrying over from millennial angst, was with heaven and hell, good and evil, angels and devils, culminating with Adam Sandler coming to earth as Satan's son in Little Nicky and Elizabeth Hurley personifying the devil in Bedazzled.

The latter, a reworking of a minor 1967 British movie starring Peter Cook, was one of the year's numerous remakes which - depending on the way you look at it - either exposed the creative bankruptcy or Hollywood or exhibited the postmodernist wit of a new generation of writers.

There were good mainstream films, however. David O. Russell crossed over from the independent sector with Three Kings, a devastating re-creation of the Gulf war and its aftermath. Michael Mann's The Insider is social-conscience movie-making on an epic scale featuring outstanding performances from Russell Crowe, Al Pacino and Christopher Plummer. Crowe also had the lead in Ridley Scott's rousing Gladiator, which revived the sword- and-sandal epic after a 36-year hiatus.

There was a steady flow through the year of puerile comedies aimed at American adolescents, most of them seeking to outdo the Farrelly Brothers in pushing the envelope of bad taste. But three comedies stood out - all concerned with showbiz and the cult of personality. They're Dean Parisot's underrated Galaxy Quest, a gentle spoof of the Star Trek cult played straight by Sigourney Weaver, Alan Rickman and Tim Allen; Neil LaBute's Nurse Betty, a black comedy that's part road movie, part satire on the effects of TV soap opera; and Spike Jonze's altogether astonishing movie about fame and identity, Being John Malkovich. I laugh merely thinking about them.

Top 10 films of the year

Beau Travail Claire Denis

Being John Malkovich Spike Jonze

The Colour of Paradise Majid Majidi

Gladiator Ridley Scott

The Insider Michael Mann

Memento Christopher Nolan

O Brother, Where Art Thou? Joel Coen

Time Regained Raul Ruiz

Topsy-Turvy Mike Leigh

Toy Story 2 John Lasseter

Turkey of the year:

Dancer in the Dark Lars von Trier

fields.headline: Strip teasers
fields.standfirst: Roger Sabin looks at the graphic novel, the publishing world's strangest hybrid, and finds it alive and kicking
fields.trailText: Roger Sabin looks at the graphic novel, the publishing world's strangest hybrid, and finds it alive and kicking
fields.body:
The rise of the graphic novel as a format has meant that publishers can market their products to bookshops, and thus reach an audience away from the specialist - and very male-dominated - comics shops. Which is just as well, because those shops have been having a hard time lately. Although things have stabilised since the drastic recession of the late 1990s, it is estimated that there are still only a third of the number in the US and UK that there were a decade ago.

Fortunately, the artform does not equate with the industry, and over a comparable period there has been a creative boom, with a new generation of cartoonists pushing the envelope of what a comic can encompass.

Chris Ware is one of those cartoonists. In his already classic Jimmy Corrigan strips, now collected by Pantheon - The Smartest Kid on Earth (£18.99, pp240) - he uses page layouts as an experimental laboratory. Frequently, the stories are non-linear, with only the smallest of clues to help the reader along. This gives them an almost claustrophobic quality, which complements the grimly amusing content - the hapless Jimmy, a 'kid' with the face of an old man, is forever on the verge of a nervous breakdown.

The laughs - and there are many of them - come unexpectedly and leave the readers feeling a little guilty that they've got so close to the action. Ware has justifiably been compared with the great masters of the early twentieth- century American newspaper 'funnies', and this volume is a great introduction to his work.

Daniel Clowes is another creator who has been garnering a lot of atten tion, not least because his latest graphic novel, Ghost World ( Jonathan Cape £6.99, pp240), has been turned into a movie. The book itself is a triumph of understatement, and follows the friendship between two alienated teens, Enid and Rebecca. Their rapport is caught with cringe-making precision: Enid: 'Those stupid girls think they're so hip, but they're just a bunch of trendy, stuck-up, prep-school bitches!' Rebecca: 'You're a stuck-up prep-school bitch!'

The story is moving and funny, with crisp, duotone art; the only drawback is that the pacing is a little staccato and betrays its origins in a bit-part comic. Whether there's enough here for a meaty movie remains to be seen.

Buy it at BOL

Joe Sacco prides himself on being a 'war junkie', and his comic-book reports on the world's trouble-spots have earned him comparisons with the cartoonists of the pre-camera era, sent to bring back visual impressions of events. But he is more than this, and as his new book, Safe Area Gorazde (Fantagraphics £19.99, pp229), about life in a town in the aftermath of the Bosnian War, shows, his is a very twentieth-century take on New Journalism.

For example, he is unafraid to put himself at the centre of the story, thus challenging our notions of objectivity. Sometimes, he admits, this could be too much: 'I wanted out, out of there... I wanted to put a million miles between me and Bosnia, between me and those horrible disgusting people and their fucking wars and pathetic prospects...'

And yet it's what gives the book its power, more than the scenes of atrocities, more than the reconstruction of the siege of Gorazde itself. Sacco seethes with indignation and the message of this book is clear: if you don't heal the wounds of the past, they will bleed into the future.

Finally, two cartoonists from the hippy underground era have collections out. Robert Crumb, the man who started it all, is up to volume 14 of his Complete Crumb series (Fantagraphics £14.50, pp111), this time focusing on his work from the early 1980s, mostly from the hugely influential Weirdo magazine. There seem to be two Crumbs at work here: one is the radical satirist in the tradition of Hogarth, who can produce strips of such sublime quality as 'Trash', a howl of outrage against wasteful consumer society. The other is someone with the mind of a frustrated 13-year-old, obsessed with big-bottomed women. Thankfully, the output of the former Crumb outweighs the latter.

Buy it at BOL

Hunt Emerson has often been called Britain's answer to Crumb, but he has always ploughed a different furrow. Citymouth (Knockabout £6.99, pp48) is a lightweight, amusing, collection about, well, huge mouths with cities inside. They endure all the problems of modern conurbations - pollution, traffic gridlock, attacks by giant Godzillas etc - and they have the competitiveness of medieval city states.

This is Emerson on surreal override, and for sheer penmanship there are few who can touch him.

Daniel Clowes is another creator who has been garnering a lot of atten tion, not least because his latest graphic novel, Ghost World ( Jonathan Cape £6.99, pp240), has been turned into a movie. The book itself is a triumph of understatement, and follows the friendship between two alienated teens, Enid and Rebecca. Their rapport is caught with cringe-making precision: Enid: 'Those stupid girls think they're so hip, but they're just a bunch of trendy, stuck-up, prep-school bitches!' Rebecca: 'You're a stuck-up prep-school bitch!' The story is moving and funny, with crisp, duotone art; the only drawback is that the pacing is a little staccato and betrays its origins in a bit-part comic. Whether there's enough here for a meaty movie remains to be seen. Buy it at BOL Joe Sacco prides himself on being a 'war junkie', and his comic-book reports on the world's trouble-spots have earned him comparisons with the cartoonists of the pre-camera era, sent to bring back visual impressions of events. But he is more than this, and as his new book, Safe Area Gorazde (Fantagraphics £19.99, pp229), about life in a town in the aftermath of the Bosnian War, shows, his is a very twentieth-century take on New Journalism. For example, he is unafraid to put himself at the centre of the story, thus challenging our notions of objectivity. Sometimes, he admits, this could be too much: 'I wanted out, out of there... I wanted to put a million miles between me and Bosnia, between me and those horrible disgusting people and their fucking wars and pathetic prospects...' And yet it's what gives the book its power, more than the scenes of atrocities, more than the reconstruction of the siege of Gorazde itself. Sacco seethes with indignation and the message of this book is clear: if you don't heal the wounds of the past, they will bleed into the future. Finally, two cartoonists from the hippy underground era have collections out. Robert Crumb, the man who started it all, is up to volume 14 of his Complete Crumb series (Fantagraphics £14.50, pp111), this time focusing on his work from the early 1980s, mostly from the hugely influential Weirdo magazine.
