Buy it at BOL Hunt Emerson has often been called Britain's answer to Crumb, but he has always ploughed a different furrow. Citymouth (Knockabout £6.99, pp48) is a lightweight, amusing, collection about, well, huge mouths with cities inside. They endure all the problems of modern conurbations - pollution, traffic gridlock, attacks by giant Godzillas etc - and they have the competitiveness of medieval city states. This is Emerson on surreal override, and for sheer penmanship there are few who can touch him.

webTitle: Bush passes the buck for future slump

fields.headline: Bush passes the buck for future slump
fields.standfirst:
The President-elect is playing politics with signs of an end to the Clinton boom, reports Ed Vulliamy

Special report: the US elections
Special report: George W Bush's America
fields.trailText: The President-elect is playing politics with signs of an end to the Clinton boom, reports Ed Vulliamy.
fields.body:
'It starts with the little things,' says James Cramer, founder of a website called TheStreet.com - as in Wall Street. 'Fifth Avenue merchants notice the crocodile handbags aren't moving as fast as anticipated. For-sale signs are sprouting up on lawns in unusual numbers.

'Those are the first signs, not massive lay-offs.'

However, end-of-year-accounts by America's biggest companies show some of those too: 15,000 at General Motors; 2,800 apiece at Gillette and Motorola. Along with the first snow of winter comes the chill of a colder wind: maybe not recession, but a few other 'r' words like retrenchment, or at least a reduction in growth sufficient to worry the fortune-tellers at the US central bank, the Federal Reserve.

The latest findings of the Consumer Research Centre at the University of Michigan show that consumer confidence plunged in December, particularly among the affluent.

The confidence index fell to 98.4 this month from 107.6 in November, the fourth-largest drop for a single month since it went monthly in 1978. The three larger drops came before the 1980 and 1990 recessions.

The negative feelings are being spread by word of mouth. But there are positive signs too. The US Commerce Department said that personal income is holding up. So too is consumption - spending on services rose, although spending on merchandise fell.

In Washington, the 'r' word has become a political hot potato. President-elect George W. Bush issues dire warnings about the apparently buoyant economy that he inherits; President Clinton, in turn, says he can see no recession on the horizon.

Bush is making excuses in advance for the economic downturn that may haunt his presidency, and has political motives for his pessimism. He needs to blame whatever is around the corner on the Clinton administration. And he also regards an upcoming recession as a reason to push his controversial tax cut of $1.3 trillion (of which 43 per cent goes to the top 3 per cent of earners) through a divided and sceptical Congress.

Gene Sperling, Clinton's senior economic adviser, lashed back at Bush, accusing the President-elect and his team of 'treating the economy as just another political football' in a way which will 'send the wrong signal to the markets about the seriousness with which they take their economic stewardship'.

The tax-cut plan puts the administration immediately at loggerheads with Clinton's faith in the Federal Reserve as regulator of the economy. Officials at the Fed, meanwhile, told The Observer they are concerned that Bush's Cabinet appointments lack the experience, skills and connections to the financial markets needed to manage the Clinton bequest.

And there is a tinderbox of potential flashpoints between Bush and the Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan, who has enjoyed a warm relationship with Clinton during the years of prosperity.

Federal Reserve officials say the business cycle is turning towards a point at which sections of the economy are flush with over-investment, and subsequent profits, that cannot be maintained.

'The drag on demand and profits,' said the Fed last week, is exacerbated by 'rising energy costs as well as eroding consumer confidence, substantial shortfalls in sales and earnings and stress in segments of the financial markets' which 'suggest that economic growth may be slowing further'.

The Christmas shopping throng in Midtown Manhattan is gridlock as usual. But sales are either down or below targets in the meanest Yuletide since the start of the boom with which America has led the global economic bonanza.

Spokesmen for Macy's and Bloomingdale's are in 'wait and see' mode. Sherry Martins, junior manager at Saks, calls it 'the slowest holidays I can remember'.

The shops are pitching their hopes on this week and the fact that a Monday Christmas will give people an extra weekend to flex their plastic. But the International Council of Shopping Centres reports that sales were down on last year by 12 per cent for the third week in December.

WalMart is a fair measure of how the American public spends money, and this year the world's biggest chain of shops was predicting an increase in sales of between 3 and 5 per cent for November, December and January - after a rise of 6.3 per cent last year. So far, the increase is below 3 per cent.

RCT Systems, which monitors traffic arriving and leaving shopping malls, reports movement to be down on last year by 9.6 per cent in malls and 14.4 per cent in department stores for the third week of the shopping season.

'Everything that could go bad is going bad,' says Daniel Barry, vice-president and senior retailing analyst for Merrill Lynch, who forecasts the worst Christmas since 1990.

At Balthazar's in downtown Manhattan, a Christmas lunch for brokers and dealers from the ING investment bank features Chandon champagne from California. It tastes fine, but it's 'definitely not the French stuff,' complains Jennifer Riley, taking a swig.

This is on the day that the Nasdaq, fearless barometer of the new economy, ended a two-month wild ride and closed at its lowest level since March 1999. 'There's almost no limit to how far these stocks can go down,' says James Raphalian at the S.G. Cowen investment firm.

Few foresaw problems for the apparently ever-expanding dotcom beanfeast, where even the old standbys are now unsafe - Microsoft is down 62 per cent this year, facing its first 'flat quarter' for earnings.

Last week, Bush did little to allay even his own fears. And there were doubts whether his new Treasury Secretary is up to the job of facing down a recession.

Although he is close to Greenspan, Paul O'Neill, former head of Alcoa, the aluminium giant, does not have the links to the financial markets of his predecessors. And between Bush and Greenspan there is bound to be tension. Greenspan strongly favours using budget surpluses to reduce the national debt - in sharp contrast to Bush's preferred tax cut.

With the economy softening, the Bush administration - like that of his father - will be tempted to prod Greenspan to lower interest rates quickly, a situation which soured relations between Greenspan and Bush senior, and a move the Fed refused to make last week in a clear signal to Bush junior.

Whatever happened to the economic miracle?

Five questions on the US slowdown:

Recession? Where did that come from?

If one thing is likely to spark recession, it is politicians talking about it. A nightmare scenario could see consumers cutting back spending, so banks will tighten lending conditions, for fear of bad loans. Businesses will then delay investments and lay off workers, meaning that fewer consumers spend money, and so begins a vicious circle. There is evidence of all of these elements, as well as a marked reduction in the US rate of growth between June and August.

What happened to the rampaging internet-fuelled US miracle?

Since the dotcom share crash in April, the idea that the internet and technology has somehow rewritten the rules of business and economics has been quietly forgotten. The growth rate fell back to 2.2 per cent in November and a host of profit warnings from blue chip technology companies such as Apple, Microsoft, and Intel indicated that demand for computers was not endless, and that businesses were cutting back on other IT investment. The sharp rise in oil prices further jolted markets in autumn, but they have since pulled back.

Has Alan Greenspan lost his touch?

A 'hard landing' or recession was always a threat as the US economy soared ever higher during the Clinton years. Greenspan, chairman of the US Federal Reserve and the revered sage of world economics, faces his ultimate test in negotiating a soft landing. Some analysts say that he stumbled in not cutting interest rates last week, but such an abrupt U-turn in policy would have unsettled the markets. He signalled a clear intention to cut rates, but markets were not impressed.

What is the mood music among American consumers?

In his book, Irrational Exuberance, the economist Robert Shiller argues that post-Cold War economic triumphalism, sports-style reporting of business and internet hype contributed to the creation of a self-perpetuating bubble. All eyes are now on American consumers. Just how less wealthy do they feel since stock markets fell? Have they spent too much on credit cards? Will they stop buying expensive imports? Do they associate the end of the Clinton era with the end of the rosy economic fortunes enjoyed during his presidency? No clear answers to these questions exist yet, but the portents are not good.

Should we be worried?

The cost of borrowing seems to be on its way down. Economists now predict a cut in UK interest rates of 0.5 per cent before June. Holidays in the US should be cheaper too, if the dollar continues its slide against the pound. However, should US consumer confidence really suffer a battering, then exporters in Asia will be in trouble, possibly sparking a global downturn. Some analysts see this as the European economy's big chance. Growth is predicted to be higher in 2001 in Europe than in the US. The euro has benefited from such negative US prospects and looks set to grow stronger. British manufacturing industry may benefit from this development.

webTitle: Comment: A prayer for our children

fields.headline: A prayer for our children
fields.standfirst:
You can't order children to be moral. But you can teach them, and better still show them, says Mary Warnock, if you take the time to talk

Special report: Christmas 2000
fields.trailText: You can't order children to be moral. But you can teach them, and better still show them, says Mary Warnock, if you take the time to talk.
fields.body:
Christmas should be a festival of excitement; for children certainly, but not for them alone. It should stand for continuity, for the comforts of indoors, for the deep pleasures of communication both with those who are present and with the absent. Imagination and sympathy should go into the giving of presents, the cooking of meals, the entering into other people's memories and aspirations.

Even to articulate these banalities is to recognise how dismally far they are from being realised. Looking back, on the very brink of Christmas, it seems to me to have been a bad year; not just because of the collapse of the railways, the floods, the fiasco of the Dome or the demise of Vauxhall at Luton, but because we seem to have sunk into a state of communal despair. The people we rely on, policemen, nurses, teachers, are leaving their professions, new recruits are not coming forward, and there seems no way that civilised society can support itself. And thinking about children, who should be at the centre of Christmas, our despair is absolute.

What has happened? The dramatic horror of Damilola Taylor's death did not seem like a single unrepeatable shaming event, but like a manifestation of an existing, barely hidden corruption, a proof that children can become inhuman, inaccessible, totally beyond control or communication.

At a recent conference of teachers in London, on the subject of bullying, David Blunkett spoke about the Government's determination to crack down on the worst offenders, schools having new powers to exclude those who were persistently violent, and to punish severely all those who persecute other children, even short of stabbing them. Unfortunately, as is usual when Ministers take the time to come and speak on such occasions, neither he nor his civil servants had time to stay to hear the next speaker, nor the reaction of teachers to the Government's tough line.

If he had stayed, he would soon have learned that the teachers thought him utterly wrong to advance a policy which, in their view, could not possibly do anything but harm. He would have heard, too, about the different approach to bullies, practised in a school in Leeds, but gradually spreading elsewhere, by which other pupils in the school are taught how to talk to the bullies, to get them to talk and to explain and express their feelings. And thus the bullies start on the long, slow, painful road, which leads to the recognition that their victims are also human, as they are themselves. For it is of the essence of human beings that they have feelings and can suffer. The typical bully is not only careless of the feelings of others, but only with difficulty acknowledges feeling in himself. He is desensitised.

The bully lacks, but urgently needs, a moral sense. At the very heart of morality is the notion that one's self cannot be given priority over other people; that what I want is no more important, has no higher value, than what other people want.

To understand this involves understanding that all human beings are in the same, precarious boat; that we are social animals, who, necessarily, live in society and depend on the good behaviour of others; and that therefore it is essential, if society is to survive, to want to be good rather than bad, to make things better rather than worse. Moral sense is therefore compounded of sympathy with other humans and a desire to be good. Children are capable of developing such a sense but they need to be taught to cultivate it.

It is the acceptance of this fact - that children need to be taught - which lies behind the Government's insistence that there should be lessons in citizenship. However what we so far know of the proposed syllabus for these lessons seems incoherent and superficial. Information about the workings of Parliament and Local Government, about what are a citizen's rights and legal entitlements, appears to be mixed with virtuous injunctions about what constitutes good behaviour.

Taught in a class of bored teenagers, this will have no effect on behaviour, even if it may, improbably, catch the interest of a few intellectuals. Teaching children to develop and cultivate a moral sense needs to be taught to children when they are very young, and not as a separate classroom subject.

There seems to me no doubt that the teaching of a child to become a moral being, possessed of moral sensibility, must start young, and be carried out through endless conversation. The aim of this will be to open his eyes to the equal worth of other people; to open his sensibilities, perhaps through the telling of stories or the enacting of drama, to the feelings which he and others are capable of; to make him see that there is a sense in which, being human like the rest, he must try to make things better, to do good rather than harm.

All these lessons must start early; and I have no doubt that the Jesuits were right in thinking that they need to get their hands on a child before he was seven. (But they were wrong, in my view, to suppose that the only way to morality was through an acceptance for theological dogma: for some people religious belief may reinforce their moral sense; but no one should be allowed to suppose that if you reject religion you thereby reject morality).

For a sense of morality, of wanting to do right rather than wrong, of seeing yourself as one of the human species who have it in their power to ameliorate the human condition or to make it worse, is an essential element of civilisation - indeed the central element without which society could not survive. Morality is not only the force which can inhibit bullies from tormenting their victims, but it is the framework of the law itself, upon which society depends.

In order to bring about a will to inculcate in children an explicit devotion to the idea of being good rather than bad, there needs to be a cultural revolution, and it is the difficulty of bringing this about that lies behind our current despair. How can society change so as to embrace the concept of morality?

One thing is certainly needed and that is the courage, among all who have to do with children, to be prepared to use a moral vocabulary, to talk, that is, about what is right or wrong, courageous or cowardly, cruel or kind. There are many reasons why this vocabulary is so difficult, or perhaps embarrassing, to adopt at the present time.

One of the difficulties is the widespread fear of being 'judgmental', or seeming illegitimately to occupy the 'high moral ground'. But this is precisely the ground we must adopt (and by 'we' I mean all members of society who have any connection with children). We need to adopt this ground if we are to block the dissent into fear and moral chaos which faces us this year, which has being building up over many years, but which has never faced us so starkly.

We need most urgently to teach children to understand to feel in their gut (or their conscience) what it is to do wrong. Above all, we need to teach them that, being human, we are all subject to temptation; we may all be tempted to cruelty, to a denial of human feeling, or to proving our power over the weak. But also, being human, we can overcome this temptation; wrongdoing is not inevitable.

This lesson will not be taught through threats or aggressions or savage punishment. It can be taught, sadly, only by conversation and example, far more difficult, time consuming and laborious. We must not be so much intimidated by the children in society, for whom we are responsible, that we refuse to contemplate talking to them.

Former Mistress of Girton College, Cambridge, and a prolific scholar of moral philosophy, Baroness Warnock of Weeke's most recent work is An Intelligent Person's Guide to Ethics.

One thing is certainly needed and that is the courage, among all who have to do with children, to be prepared to use a moral vocabulary, to talk, that is, about what is right or wrong, courageous or cowardly, cruel or kind. There are many reasons why this vocabulary is so difficult, or perhaps embarrassing, to adopt at the present time. One of the difficulties is the widespread fear of being 'judgmental', or seeming illegitimately to occupy the 'high moral ground'. But this is precisely the ground we must adopt (and by 'we' I mean all members of society who have any connection with children). We need to adopt this ground if we are to block the dissent into fear and moral chaos which faces us this year, which has being building up over many years, but which has never faced us so starkly. We need most urgently to teach children to understand to feel in their gut (or their conscience) what it is to do wrong. Above all, we need to teach them that, being human, we are all subject to temptation; we may all be tempted to cruelty, to a denial of human feeling, or to proving our power over the weak. But also, being human, we can overcome this temptation; wrongdoing is not inevitable. This lesson will not be taught through threats or aggressions or savage punishment. It can be taught, sadly, only by conversation and example, far more difficult, time consuming and laborious. We must not be so much intimidated by the children in society, for whom we are responsible, that we refuse to contemplate talking to them. Former Mistress of Girton College, Cambridge, and a prolific scholar of moral philosophy, Baroness Warnock of Weeke's most recent work is An Intelligent Person's Guide to Ethics. webTitle: Harry Potter teacher is school role model

fields.headline: Harry Potter teacher is school role model
fields.trailText: Goodbye Mr Chips - the new role model for teachers is the headmaster of schoolboy wizard Harry Potter.
fields.body:
Goodbye Mr Chips - the new role model for teachers is the headmaster of schoolboy wizard Harry Potter.

Eleven per cent of Britain's headteachers admit they are inspired by the example of Professor Albus Dumbledore, the fictional wizard in charge of Hogwarts School.

The bearded professor is the creation of millionaire author J.K. Rowling. Earlier this year her series of Potter books were banned by the head of a primary school for making witchcraft look 'like fun', but a nationwide survey of headteachers released this weekend has discovered that the magical scholar is now almost as popular with the adults inside our classrooms as he is with the children.

While the enduring appeal of James Hilton's earnest hero, Charles Chipping, still placed 'Chips' high up in the results, the more relaxed attitude of Dumbledore scores almost as well.

The survey, which marks the launch of a website for schools set up by The Stationary Office, was designed to find out about attitudes and morale levels in primary and secondary schools.

The fictional character named by most headteachers was Ian George, the beleaguered head played by Lenny Henry in the BBC's drama series, Hope and Glory. An overwhelming 62 per cent of respondents picked George. The answers received from headteachers generally indicated a shift towards more positive and avuncular values and away from the efficient business ethos of the 'superhead'.

'Dumbledore is popular because he is always there when required, but he does not interfere unnecessarily,' said Mike Forster, the former head of a comprehensive school in Worthing.

'He leaves Harry alone to do things and he allows him to make his own mistakes.'

Headteachers reject, it seems, the verdict of the head of Chatham's St Mary's Island School, Carol Rookwood, who banned the younger children in her school from reading the Potter books.

'All headteachers these days need to make the most of scarce resources,' said Forster. 'Perhaps Albus Dumbledore's ability to create school banquets out of thin air is what appeals.'

The professor is extremely popular from the pupil's perspective too.

'He understands the children and treats them fairly,' said Harry Potter fan, Anna, aged 12.

'He is in control of everybody, but not really strict and he is always making sure everything is all right.'

Her friend Megan, also 12, agreed. Dumbledore, she pointed out, is very good at making sure that the punishment fits the crime. 'He would not be horrible if you were just two minutes late,' she said.

'He can be frightening, but only to certain people.'

'He is one of my favourite characters in the books,' adds Bethan, 11. 'He always helps Harry and he makes things happen.'

The role of the professor is to be played by veteran actor Richard Harris in the forthcoming Hollywood film. Harris, who is 70, had not read the books but was persuaded to take the part by his granddaughter Ella.

fields.headline: Cold peace on Earth
fields.trailText: Cards landing on the mat over the past few weeks remind us of the message of the angels in the Christmas story: 'Peace on Earth and goodwill to all people.' This is undoubtedly one of the themes of Christmas to which people, religious or not, can relate. And in general, there is peace in the world this millennium, this Christmas 2000, but it is, as a then-lucid Boris Yeltsin warned of at the end of the Cold War, a cold peace.
fields.body:
Cards landing on the mat over the past few weeks remind us of the message of the angels in the Christmas story: 'Peace on Earth and goodwill to all people.' This is undoubtedly one of the themes of Christmas to which people, religious or not, can relate. And in general, there is peace in the world this millennium, this Christmas 2000, but it is, as a then-lucid Boris Yeltsin warned of at the end of the Cold War, a cold peace.

Christmas is cancelled in Bethlehem. The Balkans may not be so much in the headlines but there are a lot of cold homes there at this time of year - and a lot of cold hearts after all that has been lived through. In our own country the fragile peace in Northern Ireland seems to stand on a knife edge, whilst in Peckham, South London, a 10-year-old boy, Damilola Taylor, has died in a pool of blood, in the stairwell of one of the soulless tower blocks which, until the recent demolitions, have disfigured so many of our cities.

Public reaction to Damilola's death has been akin to the shock that was felt on reading the Macpherson Report on the death of Stephen Lawrence. Following that report, there has been a cold peace between the Metropolitan Police and the black communities in London. The danger now is that the gains made will be set back.

The basic fact of policing urban areas is that there must be adequate numbers of officers, policing with the support of the local community. Since Macpherson several things have happened. There has been a drop in police numbers, although this is now being reversed. It may well be that levels of pay and the cost of housing in London provide one explanation for the drop in numbers. But another element might well have been a certain loss of morale. The term 'Institutionalised Racism' took some getting used to. There was, certainly, a backing-off from stop and search, but it had been the widespread use of stop and search which had most alienated black youth from the police, making them and their elders reluctant to provide vital intelligence and information.

The Metropolitan Police have made a real effort to take on board the lessons of Macpherson and relationships with the black community have improved. This bore fruit in the days following the Brixton bomb. The police gathered a group of local community leaders together and trusted them with confidential information. From that moment the mood was one of police and community working together. It has been in this climate of a growing mutual confidence that a more targeted stop and search has been developing. If this process of co-operation is set back it is the black communities on the housing estates which will suffer, not politicians.

During the summer there was a great deal of loose talk, some of it racist in character, about bogus asylum seekers. As bishops we became worried that such talk might be extremely damaging to the fabric of our society, particularly with a general election on the horizon. With leaders from other churches we visited each of the party leaders and asked them to pledge that if any of their candidates or supporters was tempted to play 'the race card' during the election then they would condemn it. Each of the three party leaders gave us this assurance. I took detailed notes during the two meetings I attended - those meetings with William Hague and the Prime Minister - and in each case we made it clear that what was said was on public record. In both meetings the MacPherson Report was referred to and assurances were given.

I have no doubt that the three party leaders were, and are, sincere in not wishing to see 'the race card' used, but in our situation of a post-MacPherson 'cold peace' it does not take much to inflame old suspicions. When the parents of both Stephen and Damilola have reacted angrily this week to statements from William Hague, it is clear that we are all treading on sensitive ground.

Human-friendly housing will shortly replace the tower-block where Damilola died. In these days of 'cold peace' the people of Peckham have a new determination to work together following the trauma of his death. We would do well to follow their example.

The Rt. Rev. Tom Butler is Bishop of Southwark

fields.headline: A wonderful new law - for the rich
fields.standfirst:
A landmark ruling helps a couple who so favoured their privacy they sold their wedding pictures for £1m

Special report on the Express takeover
fields.trailText: A landmark ruling helps a couple who so favoured their privacy they sold their wedding pictures for £1m.
fields.body:
The human rights legislation in which the Prime Minister and his wife have a vested interest has, as was predicted, finally introduced the notion of a privacy law into our courts.

In the circumstances, it is fitting that the first people to take advantage of it are a very rich film star, Michael Douglas, his new wife Catherine Zeta-Jones and Richard Desmond, the sleazy new owner of the Daily Express .

It was Desmond's OK! magazine which agreed to pay £1 million to the couple for exclusive pictures of their recent wedding in Manhattan. But to their horror, the rival rag, Hello!, got in first with a set of photos taken surreptitiously by one of the guests. In a court hearing last week, Lord Justice Sedley agreed that they were entitled to damages and pronounced the historic judgment: 'It can be said that the law recognises and will appropriately protect a right of personal privacy.'

If appropriately is the word, how appropriate it should be that this landmark ruling should be made in favour of a couple who rated their privacy so much that they were prepared to flog their wedding pictures for £1m to a mass circulation magazine.

And, even more so, that the man behind the deal should be Richard Desmond, a man who has made a small fortune out of pornography and who has been allowed to take over the Daily Express with scarcely a murmur of protest from anyone.

The press is going to have a whole new set of problems with this wonderful new law. But who would have thought that a newspaper proprietor would be one of the first to use it for his own advantage?

No, no, Yvette

We should always be wary of scientists who make claims about the benefits their researches are going to bring to the human race. Particularly so today when most of the research is financed by large commercial concerns, they being the people who are most hoping to benefit.

Nobody knows what the consequences of genetically modified food are going to be. But we are asked to give the idea the green light because it will bring benefits to millions of impoverished people in the Third World. Who could be against that?

It is this same sort of special pleading that ought to make us suspicious about embryo research, which the House of Commons voted for by a large majority last week. Speaking in favour, the Health Minister Yvette Cooper said: 'This is about the woman with Parkinson's who struggles with speech so cannot sing nursery rhymes to her children; this is about the grandfather who cannot enjoy his grandchildren because of the devastation of a stroke.'

No doubt MPs on both sides of the House were weeping into their hankies as the Minister intoned these moving words. But when politicians talk in this way the rest of us ought immediately to be on our guard. Because embryo research is not about old grannies singing nursery rhymes to the kiddies - it is about hard-faced businessmen employing white-coated scientists to do experiments in laboratories.

None of us, not even Ms Cooper, knows what the results of those experiments are going to be. They could be good, they could be bad. All the scientists and their backers want is to go on with their research without too much interference. This, thanks in part to Yvette Cooper's speech, they will now be in a better position to do.

Branson's bubble

Passengers on Virgin Trains may not have had their tempers improved by the pictures of a smiling Sir Richard Branson setting off from the airport en route to his private island of Necker in the Virgin Islands where he intends to enjoy Christmas in the sun with his loved ones and, perhaps, the odd lawyer and accountant.

The fact that the Branson bubble would seem finally to have burst is due more than anything to the Virgin Trains fiasco, most people taking the view, quite rightly, that Branson should get his trains to run on time before trying to take over the Lottery as well. Though delighted to see Beardie getting his come-uppance, I remain indifferent towards the management of the Lottery. What seems to me scandalous is that the BBC should continue to pay Camelot £1m for the privilege of advertising it twice a week.

The Lottery being nothing more than a giant gambling operation, it is questionable whether the BBC, which is financed by a form of poll tax, should be in the business of promoting it in the first place. The BBC is not supposed to advertise and it ought not to encourage people to waste money on a gamble which they are never likely to win.

That they should shell out £1m to Camelot, which is already swimming in money, to help them become even richer makes your average Lottery punter look like a pillar of decency and common sense.

fields.headline: Friends in high places
fields.standfirst: A damning report into two senior Labour officials has been shelved - by Labour. How The Observer broke the story about Dr John Reid who was exonerated with fellow MP John Maxton by the committee chaired by Robert Sheldon. Kamal Ahmed reports
fields.trailText: A damning report into two senior Labour officials has been shelved - by Labour. How The Observer broke the story about Dr John Reid who was exonerated with fellow MP John Maxton by the committee chaired by Robert Sheldon. Kamal Ahmed reports.
fields.body:
In the bowels of the Houses of Parliament is a small room containing a lot of important information. The Vote Office can be found at the bottom of a winding set of stairs, far away from the splendour of the Commons chamber with its green leather seats and ornate Speaker's chair.

Last Friday morning, the list of reports to be published that day was, as usual, pinned to the board next to the Vote Office desk. Between the entry on Scottish Milk Marketing and Unemployment Services, England and Wales, came a much more murky affair. The Committee on Standards and Privileges, second report: Complaint against Mr John Maxton and Dr John Reid. On the shelves behind the desk, the report was piled high.

On the surface, the committee's findings centred on the rather arcane rules surrounding MPs' finances. But it revealed much more than that - the way Parliament works for the public, intimidation and bully-boy tactics, the Government's ability to come up smelling of roses whatever the original stench.

The committee's conclusions were simply put. There was not enough evidence to find Reid, the Secretary of State for Scotland, and Maxton, MP for Glasgow Cathcart, guilty of breaking parliamentary rules on the payment of staff. Reid and Maxton breathed a sigh of relief. They thought they were in the clear.

In Jerusalem, the Commissioner for Standards, Elizabeth Filkin, was on holiday. She heard the news about the report with surprise. She had investigated the allegations against Reid and Maxton and come to a very different conclusion. Public money given to the two men had been used to pay for staff who were actually campaigning for the Labour Party, something which is against the strict rules governing the financing of MPs' offices.

Reid and Maxton had broken the rules, Filkin wrote in her report to the committee.

The committee said that Filkin's investigation 'met appropriate standards of care, fairness and competence'. Her report was more than 100 pages long. She alleged that witnesses had been threatened if they gave honest evidence. But the committee, dominated by Labour members, chose to reject her findings, just as they had done in the cases of John Prescott's union-funded flat and Peter Mandelson's home loan affair.

The committee, chaired by the Labour MP Robert Sheldon, said that it needed a higher level of proof to find Reid and Maxton guilty. Filkin, who spoke to The Observer this weekend, said she stood behind her report. Around the corridors of Westminster, the critics of the standards committee are starting to mutter about political bias.

On January 26, among the pile of correspondence that still needed to be sorted out after the Christmas and New Year lull, a letter arrived at Filkin's office. It was from Dean Nelson, a journalist on The Observer.

Nelson had spent much of the previous year investigating the affairs of Reid and Maxton, and in particular the way their offices were funded. Four days before the letter arrived on Filkin's desk, The Observer had run a story revealing that Reid and Maxton had used public money from MPs' allowances to finance staff working for Labour's Scottish election campaign.

Among the staff being paid was one Kevin Reid, the son of the Scottish Secretary. Nelson also named Chris Winslow, who was then special adviser to Scotland's First Minister, Donald Dewar.

It was incendiary stuff. Senior MPs were breaking the rules. Reid and Maxton denied the allegations, the row raged on for weeks. Filkin launched an investigation.

In the letter Nelson also named a third researcher, Suzanne Hilliard, who was working for Reid. She also had a role in Labour's Scottish election campaign.

Filkin approached Reid and Maxton about the allegations. On Valentine's Day, a letter arrived from Reid. Two weeks later, Maxton also put pen to paper.

'I absolutely reject allegations made by Mr Nelson,' Reid said. 'I do not for one minute deny that I wished to assist the Labour Party. Nor that those who worked for me part-time also worked part-time or voluntarily for the Labour Party in their spare time.'

Maxton was equally forthright in his denials. The two camps had taken up opposite positions and Filkin was charged with finding the truth. She contacted Alex Rowley, the general secretary of the Scottish Labour Party between May 1998 and May 1999. She asked him about the allegations. As far as Filkin was concerned, what he had to say sunk the Labour MPs.

Rowley told Filkin that the Labour Party's campaign budget was 'adjusted' to reflect the fact that Kevin Reid, Winslow and Hilliard, although working for the party, would have part of their salary paid to them through the Office Costs Allowance - the public money given to Reid and Maxton to execute their parliamentary duties.

An internal party briefing note backed Rowley's claims. Detailing the income of Kevin Reid and Winslow, the document included 'income of £10,000 from J Reid MP' for his son, Kevin, and 'income of £6,000 from J Maxton MP' for Winslow. Filkin considered it a clear breach of the rules.

On a cold day in March, Filkin travelled to Edinburgh to interview Rowley. In the main office of the Church of St Andrew and St George in the city centre, Rowley sat with his friend, Yvonne Lord. What he had to say, Filkin later admitted, was very worrying.

Shortly after Filkin started her investigation, John Reid had contacted Rowley and 'made threats of a particularly disturbing kind', Filkin wrote in her report to the committee. Reid had told Rowley that if he continued to give evidence that suggested wrong-doing he could 'face criminal prosecution and risk not being adopted by the party as a parliamentary candidate'. Rowley was so worried about what Reid was saying, he taped their next conversation.

It was a tense chat. During it, Reid said to Rowley: 'You don't have to tell any lies. Do you know what I mean?', later adding: 'They cannot prove anything, Alex.'

Reid denied the accusation, saying that Rowley had brought up the subject and that he was merely pointing out the facts of the situation. Filkin was not convinced. 'Even accepting Dr Reid's account of those conversations at face value, I find what he said disturbing,' she wrote in her report. In an email to Filkin in July, Rowley said that senior figures in the Labour Party were accusing him of 'doing in John Reid'.

Maxton was also attacked for his attitude towards Filkin's investigation. In a blizzard of letters and telephone calls to Filkin's office, Maxton attacked the way the inquiry was being conducted, accused the commissioner of leaking details of the investigation to the press and said that Filkin had deliberately misled him. Filkin described Maxton's interventions as 'hostile in tone' and 'intemperate'.

Maxton later apologised for his actions.

Filkin's report, and its damning conclusions, was sent to the Committee on Standards and Privileges on 25 October. On 7 November, in a room off the ornate committee corridor in the House of Commons, the committee held two sittings, questioning Rowley, Reid and Maxton, as well as John Rafferty, Labour campaigns co-ordinator from January to May 1999. He backed Rowley's claims.

Reid and Maxton again vigorously denied the allegations against them. They told the committee that the claims were motivated by malice and that all three researchers carried out their parliamentary duties 'fully and effectively'. Any hours worked for the Labour Party were a wholly separate arrangement, both men argued.

Parliament's director of finance and administration said that there was no 'prima facie evidence of cross-subsidy from the office cost allowances'. He said that the budget documents that were central to Filkin's investigation could have a wholly innocent and straightforward explanation.

The committee was convinced. Although criticising Reid and Maxton for the way they approached the inquiry, they said there was insufficient evidence to find against them.

Not all the members of the committee were happy with the report. There were long and arduous arguments about how the committee's report could be so obviously at odds with Filkin's thorough investigation. The rows raged along party lines, with the Labour MPs winning out.

The publication date has also been attacked, critics saying that it was not simply coincidence that the report was released on the last day before Parliament closes down for the Christmas holiday.

The Labour Party hopes the row will now die away. The committee report supercedes Filkin's inquiry, Labour supporters say. Filkin is not convinced - and sitting in the office down the winding stairs in the bowels of Parliament is the report that backs her up.
fields.bodyText: In the bowels of the Houses of Parliament is a small room containing a lot of important information. The Vote Office can be found at the bottom of a winding set of stairs, far away from the splendour of the Commons chamber with its green leather seats and ornate Speaker's chair. Last Friday morning, the list of reports to be published that day was, as usual, pinned to the board next to the Vote Office desk. Between the entry on Scottish Milk Marketing and Unemployment Services, England and Wales, came a much more murky affair. The Committee on Standards and Privileges, second report: Complaint against Mr John Maxton and Dr John Reid. On the shelves behind the desk, the report was piled high. On the surface, the committee's findings centred on the rather arcane rules surrounding MPs' finances. But it revealed much more than that - the way Parliament works for the public, intimidation and bully-boy tactics, the Government's ability to come up smelling of roses whatever the original stench. The committee's conclusions were simply put. There was not enough evidence to find Reid, the Secretary of State for Scotland, and Maxton, MP for Glasgow Cathcart, guilty of breaking parliamentary rules on the payment of staff. Reid and Maxton breathed a sigh of relief. They thought they were in the clear. In Jerusalem, the Commissioner for Standards, Elizabeth Filkin, was on holiday. She heard the news about the report with surprise. She had investigated the allegations against Reid and Maxton and come to a very different conclusion. Public money given to the two men had been used to pay for staff who were actually campaigning for the Labour Party, something which is against the strict rules governing the financing of MPs' offices. Reid and Maxton had broken the rules, Filkin wrote in her report to the committee. The committee said that Filkin's investigation 'met appropriate standards of care, fairness and competence'. Her report was more than 100 pages long. She alleged that witnesses had been threatened if they gave honest evidence. But the committee, dominated by Labour members, chose to reject her findings, just as they had done in the cases of John Prescott's union-funded flat and Peter Mandelson's home loan affair. The committee, chaired by the Labour MP Robert Sheldon, said that it needed a higher level of proof to find Reid and Maxton guilty. Filkin, who spoke to The Observer this weekend, said she stood behind her report. Around the corridors of Westminster, the critics of the standards committee are starting to mutter about political bias. On January 26, among the pile of correspondence that still needed to be sorted out after the Christmas and New Year lull, a letter arrived at Filkin's office. It was from Dean Nelson, a journalist on The Observer. Nelson had spent much of the previous year investigating the affairs of Reid and Maxton, and in particular the way their offices were funded. Four days before the letter arrived on Filkin's desk, The Observer had run a story revealing that Reid and Maxton had used public money from MPs' allowances to finance staff working for Labour's Scottish election campaign. Among the staff being paid was one Kevin Reid, the son of the Scottish Secretary. Nelson also named Chris Winslow, who was then special adviser to Scotland's First Minister, Donald Dewar. It was incendiary stuff. Senior MPs were breaking the rules. Reid and Maxton denied the allegations, the row raged on for weeks. Filkin launched an investigation. In the letter Nelson also named a third researcher, Suzanne Hilliard, who was working for Reid. She also had a role in Labour's Scottish election campaign. Filkin approached Reid and Maxton about the allegations. On Valentine's Day, a letter arrived from Reid. Two weeks later, Maxton also put pen to paper. 'I absolutely reject allegations made by Mr Nelson,' Reid said. 'I do not for one minute deny that I wished to assist the Labour Party. Nor that those who worked for me part-time also worked part-time or voluntarily for the Labour Party in their spare time.' Maxton was equally forthright in his denials. The two camps had taken up opposite positions and Filkin was charged with finding the truth. She contacted Alex Rowley, the general secretary of the Scottish Labour Party between May 1998 and May 1999. She asked him about the allegations. As far as Filkin was concerned, what he had to say sunk the Labour MPs. Rowley told Filkin that the Labour Party's campaign budget was 'adjusted' to reflect the fact that Kevin Reid, Winslow and Hilliard, although working for the party, would have part of their salary paid to them through the Office Costs Allowance - the public money given to Reid and Maxton to execute their parliamentary duties. An internal party briefing note backed Rowley's claims. Detailing the income of Kevin Reid and Winslow, the document included 'income of £10,000 from J Reid MP' for his son, Kevin, and 'income of £6,000 from J Maxton MP' for Winslow. Filkin considered it a clear breach of the rules. On a cold day in March, Filkin travelled to Edinburgh to interview Rowley. In the main office of the Church of St Andrew and St George in the city centre, Rowley sat with his friend, Yvonne Lord. What he had to say, Filkin later admitted, was very worrying. Shortly after Filkin started her investigation, John Reid had contacted Rowley and 'made threats of a particularly disturbing kind', Filkin wrote in her report to the committee. Reid had told Rowley that if he continued to give evidence that suggested wrong-doing he could 'face criminal prosecution and risk not being adopted by the party as a parliamentary candidate'. Rowley was so worried about what Reid was saying, he taped their next conversation. It was a tense chat. During it, Reid said to Rowley: 'You don't have to tell any lies. Do you know what I mean?', later adding: 'They cannot prove anything, Alex.' Reid denied the accusation, saying that Rowley had brought up the subject and that he was merely pointing out the facts of the situation. Filkin was not convinced. 'Even accepting Dr Reid's account of those conversations at face value, I find what he said disturbing,' she wrote in her report. In an email to Filkin in July, Rowley said that senior figures in the Labour Party were accusing him of 'doing in John Reid'. Maxton was also attacked for his attitude towards Filkin's investigation. In a blizzard of letters and telephone calls to Filkin's office, Maxton attacked the way the inquiry was being conducted, accused the commissioner of leaking details of the investigation to the press and said that Filkin had deliberately misled him. Filkin described Maxton's interventions as 'hostile in tone' and 'intemperate'. Maxton later apologised for his actions. Filkin's report, and its damning conclusions, was sent to the Committee on Standards and Privileges on 25 October. On 7 November, in a room off the ornate committee corridor in the House of Commons, the committee held two sittings, questioning Rowley, Reid and Maxton, as well as John Rafferty, Labour campaigns co-ordinator from January to May 1999. He backed Rowley's claims. Reid and Maxton again vigorously denied the allegations against them. They told the committee that the claims were motivated by malice and that all three researchers carried out their parliamentary duties 'fully and effectively'. Any hours worked for the Labour Party were a wholly separate arrangement, both men argued. Parliament's director of finance and administration said that there was no 'prima facie evidence of cross-subsidy from the office cost allowances'. He said that the budget documents that were central to Filkin's investigation could have a wholly innocent and straightforward explanation. The committee was convinced. Although criticising Reid and Maxton for the way they approached the inquiry, they said there was insufficient evidence to find against them. Not all the members of the committee were happy with the report. There were long and arduous arguments about how the committee's report could be so obviously at odds with Filkin's thorough investigation. The rows raged along party lines, with the Labour MPs winning out. The publication date has also been attacked, critics saying that it was not simply coincidence that the report was released on the last day before Parliament closes down for the Christmas holiday. The Labour Party hopes the row will now die away. The committee report supercedes Filkin's inquiry, Labour supporters say. Filkin is not convinced - and sitting in the office down the winding stairs in the bowels of Parliament is the report that backs her up.

webTitle: If Westminster silences its own watchdog, we will all pay the price

fields.headline: If Westminster silences its own watchdog, we will all pay the price
fields.standfirst: When MPs believe they are exempt from findings of the Commissioner for Standards, it is time to be very concerned, writes Peter Preston
fields.trailText: When MPs believe they are exempt from findings of the Commissioner for Standards, it is time to be very concerned, writes Peter Preston.
fields.body:
It is only six years since a beleaguered John Major summoned Lord Nolan to the colours and asked him to clean the opened sewers of British parliamentary life. Mr Neil Hamilton is still, alas, vividly with us as a reminder of that dismal era. But see how swiftly such zeal for reform fades. See how quietly the house that Nolan built comes crumbling down.

What were you doing on Friday morning? Running for a train, clearing your in-tray, hunting for the last wretched presents? Perhaps. What you weren't doing was sitting down to read a 350-page report by the Parliamentary Commissioner for Standards into the conduct of two Scottish MPs, one of whom is our current Secretary of State for Scotland. Nor the covering report from the Committee on Standards and Privileges which somehow contrived to set Elizabeth Filkin's findings aside in a mush of shifting words. Eleven months of painstaking work tossed out with the Christmas wrapping paper.

The timing, in its cynical calculation, tells the story. The committee might have published on Boxing Day (indeed, seem to have pondered that ludicrous possibility), but otherwise they couldn't have done more to bury the case of John Maxton MP and, of course, Dr John Reid.

Observer readers may remember that case, because it started here, in these pages. The question was whether Reid and Maxton had used some of their Westminster office funding to pay for three researchers - one of them Reid's son, Kevin - to campaign for Labour in the first Scottish Parliament election. Not quite cash-for-questions, but still a serious breach of serious rules. Why else does Westminster forbid the use of these expenses for any such purpose? Why else was there a £15 million cap on Scottish campaign funding?

Dean Nelson, the Observer reporter involved, complained to Filkin, as was his right. The commissioner concluded, 'on the balance of probabilities', that Commons officials had been deliberately misled by Reid and Maxton.

In short, she upheld the complaint. Worse, she herself complained to her committee masters about the pair's dogged lack of co-operation with her inquiries and about what seemed to her clear evidence of Reid's attempt to interfere with witnesses. There was a tape, produced in evidence, of a disquieting conversation between the Minister and a former general secretary of the Scottish Labour Party.

An open-and-shut matter for censure? A further opportunity for New Labour, who frothed so animatedly through Jonathan Aitken, Hamilton and Tim Smith, to show that we live in purer, more punctilious times? Don't hold your breath. The committee wriggled over Reid's taped telephone calls. They were 'at best unwise'. It ritually deplored the bizarre abuse heaped on Filkin by Reid's QC. (Since when were high-priced barristers called into this act?) But suddenly the standards the commissioner uses - the 'balance of probabilities' which go with her self-regulatory job - were deemed insufficient.

The Labour-dominated committee sought a 'higher standard of proof'. It needed to be persuaded that the allegations were 'significantly more likely to be true than not to be true' - and gosh! it couldn't quite make it. Mince and custard pies all round.

Now, in theory, there's no reason why the committee should always accept the findings of its own commissioner. But the problem of Reid looks more vexed than that: it looks like a pattern. When Filkin finds against an unpopular back-bencher like Teresa Gorman, her balance of probabilities rule OK. But when she finds against a Labour luminary - Peter Mandelson, John Prescott, and now Reid - her verdicts stub their toe on a higher standard of something or other.

That, if Lord Nolan or his successor, Lord Neill, are watching, must give them cause for concern. There was always a solid reason to make independent outsiders, not politicians, the arbiters of parliamentary ethics. But that was a bridge too far for the Palace of Westminster. The commissioners - Sir Gordon Downey, and then Filkin - were the most that MPs would accept.

It begins, more and more, to look like an unworkable fudge, and to promise great trouble in store. Consider how isolated Filkin has become. It's not just her findings which are repeatedly set aside; it's the whispering against her. She has become (one suitably anonymous Labour Minister told The Independent yesterday) the 'Witchfinder-General'. She apparently takes her duties too solemnly. She is not a proper chap in a palace of chaps, but an integrity-crazed eccentric.

The trouble with this kind of lobby stuff, of course, is that it can't be pinned down and thus countered. It destroys by stealth.

I know what the old system was like. I complained to the Committee on Members' Interests about Neil Hamilton and watched in stupefaction as the Government whip on that grouping got to work. Independent justice? Give me the Florida Supreme Court any time.

Filkin has a long and distinguished reputation in public service. She is diligent and concerned to serve the best interests of our Parliament. But can Parliament itself serve those interests? Not when the goal posts of probability are abruptly shifted. Not when cases which matter are slipped out under cover of Christmas.

Either Parliament has a 'watchdog', or it doesn't. Either Filkin - like Downey - has misunderstood the rules, or she hasn't. Either Ministers are different, or they're not. The trouble here isn't one damned thing, but one damned thing after another. If I were Nolan or Neill, I'd be thinking that at least the commissioner should be reinforced by another outsider for future cases involving Ministers.

The system Nolan built is not there for the convenience of MPs - not even Martin Bell. It is there for us, so we can have confidence and trust. Let it slide, and guess who loses?

Peter Preston was editor of the Guardian 1975-95 and editor-in-chief of the Guardian and Observer 1995-96

webTitle: Barbara Ellen: Coming to the aid of the party

fields.headline: Coming to the aid of the party
fields.trailText: Could I be the first person to arrive at a party unfashionably late? I certainly felt slightly unfashionable the other evening, as I arrived at a Christmas do, stone-cold sober, at midnight.
fields.body:
Could I be the first person to arrive at a party unfashionably late? I certainly felt slightly unfashionable the other evening, as I arrived at a Christmas do, stone-cold sober, at midnight. Feeling self-conscious, I made my way over to the 'free drinks' table, to discover several bottles of white wine, standing in melancholic grandeur in an ice bucket full of tepid water with empty matchboxes floating on the top. Delicious, what was everybody else having? A waiter found a glass that hadn't been smashed on the dance floor, and, half an hour later, I was still stood there, still strangely sober, trying to make sense of this strange new world that wasn't blurred and dangerous.

All around me, people I loved and respected were wandering around in various states of alcoholic disarray. I have never understood the fascist, judgmental school of thought that says it is impossible for a sober person not to despise a room full of drunks.

That evening, I felt an overwhelming tenderness for my friends that I doubt would have occurred to me had I been equally intoxicated. They seemed so pleased to see me. Some were positively delighted. They loved me, they really did. They always had done and they always would. I was the only one out of everyone there, in the whole damn party, no, the whole damn world, they had a good word for any more. What that good word was, nobody could quite remember, but when they did, I would be the first to know. If it came down to it, they would ring me at 5am to tell me.

However pleased my friends were to see me, they couldn't help but be alarmed by my sobriety. People kept coming over and staring blearily and impatiently into my face, as if I were some kind of strange impostor, only pretending to be myself. A little like when they change the actor playing a certain character in a soap, and hope that the audience don't notice, but they always do, and they always hate the replacement actor.

Or maybe my friends thought I was my sober twin, and the real Barbara would be along shortly to fall over chairs, give people her firm, colourful views on all manner of subjects she knows absolutely nothing about, swig warm plonk from beer tankards, leer repulsively at married men, and generally behave like she usually does at lunchtime. That's the Barbara they knew, and the Barbara they wanted. Sober Barbara, it seemed, was no good to anyone, least of all me.

This being the Christmas season, the point has to be made - being sober and well behaved is probably the most offensive and disgusting thing you can do at a party. Quite simply, it's the height of rudeness not being rude and drunk at dos. If alcohol is the social oil that lubricates the parts good sense cannot reach, then lack of alcohol is the sleeping policeman that makes even the wildest, most scenic of routes seem terribly ordinary and boring. Recovering alcoholics are exempt from this rule, of course, as they know what it is to be officially 'unwell'. They have enough to cope with, looking forward to a lifetime of taking things one day at a time, while the rest of us find it hard enough to stick to one glass in each hand.

Moreover, proper alcoholics have paid their dues, as it were, and should be allowed to retire in peace, with their glasses of sparkling mineral water, and their brave, tight smiles. It's the other ones, the control freaks and careerists who are sober by choice, because they prefer it, that you really have to watch out for.

There is no hard, fast rule for this. My best friend is the most sober person I've ever met - she has a real non-drinking problem, everyone's noticed it. Then again, it has to be said that, over the years, she has been a lot of fun, as well as very useful, when it comes to such important matters as saving me from arrest and locating my shoes. Moreover, like me, and anybody else with any degree of style, she has a secret soft spot for booze bores.

It is no coincidence that most of us would happily take booze bores over drug bores, travel bores and all other kinds of bores, every time. There's something incredibly warm about boozers that has nothing to do with whisky.

When I felt moved by my friends' drunken greetings and beery expostulations, it was because I felt that, unbuttoned, messy and occasionally indecipherable though they were, what had gone in (the alcohol) had had a lovely effect on what was coming out. By which I mean, warmth, friendliness and humour, and all those other things you don't have to attend to with a mop.

That is why it was a wise man who said not to trust any bastard who doesn't drink, and why sobriety is for losers. Without a little bit of alcohol, it seems that it's the best part of us that disappears down the hatch.

barbara.ellen@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Godfather makes Jesus big in Japan

fields.headline: Godfather makes Jesus big in Japan
fields.standfirst:
Born-again gangster follows star in the East

Special report: Christmas 2000
fields.trailText: Born-again gangster follows star in the East.
fields.body:
A repentant yakuza gangster is trying to achieve what Jesuit priests and Mormon missionaries have largely failed to do: put a little Christianity into the Japanese Christmas.

Body tattoos, chopped-off fingers and a criminal record have made the Rev Hiroyuki Suzuki into one of the most colourful and famous preachers in Japan, where barely 1 per cent of the population believes in Jesus.

He aims to change the perception of Christmas among Japanese people, most of whom associate the season with shopping and sex rather than religion. Christmas Eve is always the busiest night of the year for the nation's 'love hotels', and department stores have been known to put Santa on the cross in seasonal window displays.

In the past week, Suzuki and seven other born-again mobsters have attempted to add a more spiritual note with a series of topless carol performances (to draw attention to their tattoos), television appearances and magazine articles. Tomorrow they will cap this unprecedented media blitz with the preview screening of a new feature film based on Suzuki's remarkable life story. Underlining the growing prominence of the preacher, even Yoshiro Mori, the notoriously Shintoist Prime Minister, is expected to attend.

This is a stunning amount of coverage for a Christian in Japan, where most people are followers of Shinto or Buddhism. Although it has been 450 years since St Francis Xavier set up the first Jesuit mission here, a history of persecution and indifference has ensured that Christianity has never really taken root.

Most of those that go to church are graduates of prestigious Christian schools. With a few exceptions, such as Masaru Hayami, governor of the Bank of Japan, they tend to adopt a low profile in a society famous for its pressures to conform.

Suzuki, however, advocates in-your-face evangelism rather than Bible-study groups. Four years ago he and seven other former gangsters founded Mission Barabas, named after the thief Pontius Pilot freed instead of Jesus. Under the slogan, 'Our boss is God', they have adapted yakuza virtues of loyalty and discipline to their activities. Their territory is prisons and red-light districts. Among those drawn to their small chapel in Funabashi, west of Tokyo, are prostitutes, petty crooks and drug addicts.

'Our allegiances have changed, but in many other ways we are still yakuza,' says Suzuki, dressed in a white robe and dog collar. 'There are many similarities. We call each other "brother", we are bound by blood - though this time it is Christ's not our own - and we fight for our boss, but not physically against other gangs as in the past, but spiritually against Satan.'

True to the style of the yakuza - who often go out of their way to draw attention to themselves in the way they dress and behave - Suzuki the preacher is also Suzuki the self-publicist. Rather than hide his background, he milks it in an attempt to gain new followers. He has written a book, carried a huge wooden cross the length of Japan and lectured overseas. Two years ago he was invited to a White House prayer breakfast.

Suzuki could not adopt a low profile even if he wanted to. His colourful background is there for all to see in the tattoos of carp and mythical beasts that cover his upper back, chest and shoulders like body armour. The violence he has experienced is apparent in the gnarled ends of his little fingers, which were lopped off at the knuckles in acts of contrition to mob bosses and creditors. And there is still a glimmer of the flashy pride of the gangster in his expensively capped teeth.

Until 1988, Suzuki was a member of the Sakaume-gumi, an Osaka mob affiliated to Japan's biggest crime syndicate. He made a living playing Saikoro and Ikasama, dice games loved by the yakuza. In his autobiography he told how he would celebrate at hostess bars with drugs and alcohol when he won. Twice, when he lost heavily, he cut off the tips of his little fingers to apologise for being unable to pay straight away.

When his luck ran out, he fled Osaka, leaving behind his wife and daughter as well as his debts and an angry mob. 'That was the darkest point in my life. There were 800 yakuza trying to kill me and all I cared about was myself. I deserted my family, ran off with my girlfriend and smashed up bars. I had a human face, but I was a monster.'

'For most Japanese who don't believe in God, Christmas is just another festival. But I want to show them that the birth of Jesus was a gift to humanity, a chance to change our lives.

fields.bodyText: A repentant yakuza gangster is trying to achieve what Jesuit priests and Mormon missionaries have largely failed to do: put a little Christianity into the Japanese Christmas. Body tattoos, chopped-off fingers and a criminal record have made the Rev Hiroyuki Suzuki into one of the most colourful and famous preachers in Japan, where barely 1 per cent of the population believes in Jesus. He aims to change the perception of Christmas among Japanese people, most of whom associate the season with shopping and sex rather than religion. Christmas Eve is always the busiest night of the year for the nation's 'love hotels', and department stores have been known to put Santa on the cross in seasonal window displays. In the past week, Suzuki and seven other born-again mobsters have attempted to add a more spiritual note with a series of topless carol performances (to draw attention to their tattoos), television appearances and magazine articles. Tomorrow they will cap this unprecedented media blitz with the preview screening of a new feature film based on Suzuki's remarkable life story. Underlining the growing prominence of the preacher, even Yoshiro Mori, the notoriously Shintoist Prime Minister, is expected to attend. This is a stunning amount of coverage for a Christian in Japan, where most people are followers of Shinto or Buddhism. Although it has been 450 years since St Francis Xavier set up the first Jesuit mission here, a history of persecution and indifference has ensured that Christianity has never really taken root. Most of those that go to church are graduates of prestigious Christian schools. With a few exceptions, such as Masaru Hayami, governor of the Bank of Japan, they tend to adopt a low profile in a society famous for its pressures to conform. Suzuki, however, advocates in-your-face evangelism rather than Bible-study groups. Four years ago he and seven other former gangsters founded Mission Barabas, named after the thief Pontius Pilot freed instead of Jesus. Under the slogan, 'Our boss is God', they have adapted yakuza virtues of loyalty and discipline to their activities. Their territory is prisons and red-light districts. Among those drawn to their small chapel in Funabashi, west of Tokyo, are prostitutes, petty crooks and drug addicts. 'Our allegiances have changed, but in many other ways we are still yakuza,' says Suzuki, dressed in a white robe and dog collar. 'There are many similarities. We call each other "brother", we are bound by blood - though this time it is Christ's not our own - and we fight for our boss, but not physically against other gangs as in the past, but spiritually against Satan.' True to the style of the yakuza - who often go out of their way to draw attention to themselves in the way they dress and behave - Suzuki the preacher is also Suzuki the self-publicist. Rather than hide his background, he milks it in an attempt to gain new followers. He has written a book, carried a huge wooden cross the length of Japan and lectured overseas. Two years ago he was invited to a White House prayer breakfast. Suzuki could not adopt a low profile even if he wanted to. His colourful background is there for all to see in the tattoos of carp and mythical beasts that cover his upper back, chest and shoulders like body armour. The violence he has experienced is apparent in the gnarled ends of his little fingers, which were lopped off at the knuckles in acts of contrition to mob bosses and creditors. And there is still a glimmer of the flashy pride of the gangster in his expensively capped teeth. Until 1988, Suzuki was a member of the Sakaume-gumi, an Osaka mob affiliated to Japan's biggest crime syndicate. He made a living playing Saikoro and Ikasama, dice games loved by the yakuza. In his autobiography he told how he would celebrate at hostess bars with drugs and alcohol when he won. Twice, when he lost heavily, he cut off the tips of his little fingers to apologise for being unable to pay straight away. When his luck ran out, he fled Osaka, leaving behind his wife and daughter as well as his debts and an angry mob. 'That was the darkest point in my life. There were 800 yakuza trying to kill me and all I cared about was myself. I deserted my family, ran off with my girlfriend and smashed up bars. I had a human face, but I was a monster.' 'I hope that people will look at me and say "If a yakuza can start again, then so can I".'

fields.headline: Milosevic party faces defeat
fields.standfirst: Serbs seek a new start for their nation in its first free elections
fields.trailText: Serbs seek a new start for their nation in its first free elections.
fields.body:
Ousted Yugoslav leader Slobodan Milosevic cast his vote yesterday in Serbian parliamentary elections which, according to the opinion polls, were expected to sweep his Socialist Party out of government and erase the last vestiges of his power.

Milosevic and his wife, Mirjana Markovic, made no comment to reporters when they voted at around 8.30am in a polling station in Belgrade's exclusive Dedinje suburb, where they live.

Like other voters in what many observers say will be Serbia's first truly free and fair vote, Milosevic had a finger sprayed with an invisible security spray designed to prevent people from voting twice. The authorities appeared to have overcome a popular suspicion that it causes male impotence.

Around the same time, at a primary school in New Belgrade, a wasteland of high-rise housing on the outskirts of the capital, a weeping woman greeted a new era.

Olga Gavanski Palfi, 62, said between sobs: 'We have to decide if we will finally live like human beings. We have to clean our nation of the trash that made our history and future filthy.'

She said both her brothers had fled to Canada under Milosevic and now she is at home alone with two children. 'I hope these elections mean we will never have to send our children to their deaths again - and they will never again have to flee the country.'

The school is one of 8,700 polling stations in the election, which was set to give the anti-Milosevic coalition a massive mandate for change.

Opinion polls show the Democratic Opposition of Serbia (DOS) coalition gaining at least 60 per cent of the vote, which ought to translate into control of more than three-quarters of the Serbian parliament.

Milosevic's Socialist Party has plummeted in the polls since the October revolution and September presidential and federal elections that ousted him from power. Socialist Party support has dropped from around 30 per cent to 13 per cent.

But there remain some who still respect Milosevic. A 55-year-old Serb who had travelled from Switzerland where he works as a waiter, said: 'He was the leader of this nation for a long period.

'I think in 100 years, he will be viewed as a good ruler. I didn't vote for his party, but frankly I think even today we don't have a better leader.'

A low-key DOS campaign has portrayed the elections as the chance to end the Milosevic era. Zoran Djindjic, head of the Democratic Party, has been named Serbian Prime Minister-designate and has named most of his Cabinet.

Most people believe the new government will improve living conditions and create new opportunities. They also want corrupt politicians and officials to be made answerable: 'I expect the economic situation to be better and I want arrests from the top to the bottom for all those responsible for the situation we are in now,' said clerk Dejan Milinkovic.

Polls opened at 8am and closed at 8pm. Final results are not expected for several days, but early projections were expected today.

Turnout was low in Kosovo, where the UN mission has distanced itself from the ballot. In the divided town of Mitrovica observers from the Belgrade-based election monitors' organisation, CESID, said the number of voters had barely reached 10 per cent by midday.

September's polls saw several voting stations report support at more than 90 per cent for Milosevic's party, claims rebutted by opposition supporters.

Yesterday the extent of fraud in previous elections could be seen in Albanian enclaves in the north of Kosovo. One polling station that covers six Albanian villages had not registered a single vote after three hours of polling. Previously, the area's 2,407 voters had nearly all voted for Milosevic.

'Maybe they were depressed Milosevic is no longer a candidate!' said DOS member Nikola Kabosic.

The UN, which organised 'witnesses' to count the number of voters going into polling stations during the last ballot, said it has had no reason to fear attempts to falsify the result this time.

Officials from the Organisation for Security and Co-operation in Europe were sent to observe the polls in the rest of Serbia, but not to Kosovo.

But a member of CESID's election monitoring team in Mitrovica said the lack of international support may have affected voter turnout.

'The small number of voters is the result of the lack of election publicity, there are no international observers or support, and maybe the lack of financial support has been a reason to do with that.'

Oliver Ivanovic, who is the nominal head of the Serb community in Mitrovica, said people did not give the polls the same importance as the last one. 'Of course, the people are much more relaxed now, and of course some democratisation started in Belgrade some months ago, but we know very well that this democratisation is not finished yet.

While a few voters continued to arrive at the schools used as polling stations in the city, the majority of Mitrovica's population were at the weekend market of stalls lined along the main road in the town centre.

'This time I don't know a thing,' said Miriana Cevic, a 23-year-old unemployed town planning graduate, working at a cigarette stall.

'Yes I'll vote, it's my duty as a citizen, but for whom? Well, as I said last time, for the winner!'
