fields.headline: O little town
fields.standfirst: It was meant to be a time of celebration - peace and goodwill to all men. But 2000 years after the birth of Christ, Bethlehem is in the grip of a bloody and bitter conflict. John Sweeney reports from the unholy land
fields.trailText: It was meant to be a time of celebration - peace and goodwill to all men. But 2000 years after the birth of Christ, Bethlehem is in the grip of a bloody and bitter conflict. John Sweeney reports from the unholy land.
fields.body:
In the town that started it all, Christmas is cancelled. The choirs from around the world that were planning to hallelujah in the first Christmas of the second millennium are not going to make it. To go there these days is to enter a war zone. Some days it is just quiet, almost dull. Every now and then the tourist trap created in the birthplace of the Son of God explodes as tank shells slam in.

A roadblock on the edge of Bethlehem. On this side of the line, Greater Israel, sprawling across the occupied territories, a First World go-getting internet economy that has absorbed a million Russian Jews in a decade. On the other side of the line, the Bantustan of Bethlehem, an Arab-majority town controlled by the Palestine Authority, but entirely encircled by the fire power of the Israeli Defence Force. And in the middle, trying to cross the line in a small and battered car, the head teacher of a local kindergarten, Grace Abu Mohor. Grace is a Christian Arab, of Greek Orthodox family, a tiny fireball of a woman with a riotous sense of the ridiculous and a contagious laugh. In the car with her are two tots who go to the kindergarten, aged three and four.

The Israelis have closed the road to traffic, so that Palestinian cars with green plates cannot enter Israel, and Israeli vehicles with yellow plates cannot enter Bethlehem. This is a new restriction, and it has caught out the mother of the two kids. Although an Arab, she's got yellow plates and cannot drive into Bethlehem to get to the kindergarten and pick up her children.

Grace has got a huge amount on her plate. Not least, her home overlooks the Israeli settlement of Gilo. Palestinian gunmen have peppered Gilo with AK fire; the Israelis have fired back with tank shells. Suddenly, her home, historically a peaceable and plush Christian-Arab village, is on a front line that didn't exist before.

But Grace is a head teacher down to her boots. She feels that she cannot trust the two kids to a taxi driver. They are too young. So she drives up towards the checkpoint, hoping that with her innocent cargo on board she can talk her way through the roadblock and deliver the children safe and sound to their mother.

The dividing line is on a narrow road on top of a bluff. Under a lowering sky, on the far horizon, you can see the domes, minarets and hotel skyscrapers of Jerusalem. Close by, across a deep wadi, is Gilo, a kind of Basildon New Town, homes made of brash new concrete on the top of the hill. Gilo is built on Arab land, of course. It's part of a ring of settlements that encircle Jerusalem and deepen the gloom of the Palestinians. How can they ever have their own state, they say, if Israel keeps building these settlements? You can feel the tension on the line.

Witness the stylised humility of the Palestinian drivers, trying to get through the block. They are Arab drivers with yellow plates who have been literally wrongsided by the new rules, and are now desperate to get their vehicles back across the line, in case they are trapped. Witness, too, the morose arrogance of the squaddies of the Israeli Defence Force. They display a studied toughness they've drunk in from Hollywood. There are four or five of them on the road, automatic rifles strapped to their backs. There is a promise of rain, but even so, one of them is still sporting sunglasses. One is tempted to say, 'You look a right twit in those, son,' but he has a gun. None of them is older than 22.

Their helmets look weird. The soldiers are sporting floppy camouflage bonnets on top of their helmets, as big and silly as the Eccy Thump flat caps worn by the Tetley tea-bag workers, making their heads look huge and misshapen. The reason? The helmet covers will confuse the aim of Palestinian snipers who may or may not be out there.

As the Israeli soldiers strut their stuff, I wonder what's going on inside their helmets. I'm Arnold Schwarzenegger in Terminator 2. Actually, I'm Arnie from Tel Aviv, and I'm only 20, and I don't want a bullet tunnelling through my brain at 900mph. I don't want to be kidnapped. But I'm not going to let any of my mates on the checkpoint sniff my fear, so I'm going to play it as tough as hell.

And here, into the middle of this display of overdog testosterone and underdog anger, comes Grace in her scruffy car with the kids in the back. To control the traffic and show who is boss, the Israelis have created a very tight chicane, by putting down tyre-killing 'shark teeth'. These are strips of heavy black plastic in which are embedded razor-sharp metal teeth, pointing up.

Grace, anxious, slips her car through a gap between a bus and the shark's teeth and gently nudges towards the line. She almost makes it. But the Israeli soldier with the shades, who has been distracted by giving the bus driver a hard time, sees the banned green numberplate and erupts. He can't see the kids. They are too low in their seats. He is raging with fury at Grace, screaming: 'Get back, get back!' Grace wants to get out and say her piece, but she can't leave the kids, and stalls. The soldier becomes yet more enraged at the stupid, bloody woman blocking the roadblock: 'GET BACK, GET BACK!'

Panicking now, Grace reverses back, and blows three of her tyres on the shark's teeth.

O little town of Bethlehem, how still we see thee lie.

It's her fault and it's not her fault. The shark's teeth, being low to the ground, couldn't be seen in her rear-view mirror. The kids are crying, Grace is rattled, angry with herself and the soldier, her car immobilised. The soldier snaps that he didn't let her tyres down, and walks away to block our taxi, with yellow plates, from entering Bethlehem.

Grace uses her mobile to call the children's mother. They are picked up with lots of cuddles and stroking of hair, the mother grateful at Grace's effort, and appalled at the three flat tyres. She leaves Grace, who says she is fine and it will be no problem. Then the rain starts to fall, and Grace is all but crying at the stupidity of it all.

It's not the soldier's fault. He was, as they say, only obeying orders. His tension, his fear, his souped-up testosterone blocked him from looking into the scruffy car and seeing what was in there. They might have been terrorists. But actually they were only Grace and two very small kids. And there you've got it: the agony of the Holy Land in three burst tyres at the Bethlehem checkpoint.

Humanity has a way of seeping through the cracks of adversity. A few Arab teenagers pimp-roll past, see Grace's predicament and, as the rain becomes heavier and heavier, they get stuck in. They change the one good tyre in the boot and arrange for a taxi driver to go down into Bethlehem and buy two new tyres. It's partly common human decency. It's partly a way at getting at the Israeli soldiers. Hey - look, guys! You bully the poor woman into blowing her tyres. We help her out. Call yourself men? None of this is stated. It's all acted out, a silent ballet of puncture repair.

A minibus arrives, in it teachers from Grace's school, going to their homes in Jerusalem. They are Americans, men and women from the moon. They take in the scene, the three flats, the shark's teeth, the soldiers barking at some new trespasser on their authority. In the battle for the world's sympathy, Israel loses a few more votes to Palestine. Our taxi is stuck on the yellow-plated side of the line, but Grace agrees to play tour guide.

The first stop on the bang-bang tourist's Bethlehem is pretty impressive, if you like looking at the intestines of washing machines. The washing machine has taken a direct hit from a tank shell. What's seriously odd is that the front of the machine is almost intact, the white plastic casing slewed and twisted but the makers, 'Frigidaire', and the options 'spin' 'wool' 'rinse only' all still readable. Behind the plastic front, a dirty great hole has been bored through by the shell, wrecking the drum and turning the motor into a puddle of metal. A commotion at the door: another bang-bang tourist has shown up, a tall, silver-haired priest, Father Gockel Guido, a Mill Hill Father working for the Papal Nuncio to the Holy Land. The priest inspects the washing machine.

Tracing the flight path from the washing machine backwards is not exactly difficult. The shell came into the washing machine through a hole in the wall, beyond that the Nazal children's bedroom: a litter of cuddly animals, swaddled in dust and crumbled chunks of wall; a kid's toy-car dashboard, the speedo set to 140mph; kids' clothes, shredded; a Super School Bus Band music machine covered in muck; a mirror smashed to pieces. The shell had entered the house through a window of the kids' bedroom, gone straight through the internal wall and bedded itself in the washing machine.

We are in the suburb of Bethlehem known as Beit Jela, and in the Christian area down the hill from The Church of St Nicholas. The hillside is heavily built up, old Ottoman houses leaning on each other, cheek by jowl.

'The children were sleeping in the room and they woke up and we could hear the sound of gunfire. So we moved them to the back room. And then it happened,' says the man of the house. His wife, Suha Nazal, looks at her four-year-old boy and her two-year-old girl, the rubble, the puddle of metal that used to be her washing machine, and says nothing.

'What time did it happen?' asks the priest. '11.30 at night,' the man says. So they were firing tank shells into a heavily built-up area, blind.

Outside, more destruction. Another shell had crashed into a garage, chewing up a wall and a motorcar, but hurting no one. Up the hill was the most spectacular shot of all. The tank shell had crashed in on the corner of a house that stood proud above the road up towards the church, and taken out a hole 5ft deep by 3ft wide. It, too, had been a bedroom. Now charred bedding, shredded blankets and chunks of wall crackle underfoot. The house is 150 years old, the wall more than a foot thick, built to last. One of the boys of the house picks up what was left of the shell, a base, weirdly compressed by its impact with the wall. It is the size of a big ashtray, but as heavy as 10 housebricks. The family has 11 children: five boys and six girls. By some wonder, none of them was killed. They had all been sheltering in the back room. The mother, Manua Jamil Muslat, sits on a sofa, crying that the children just can't get to sleep at nights. They all think it will happen again, she says. She wears a headscarf cowled round her face like Rembrandt's mother. Next to her, a 10-year-old boy shivers with fear.

Grace drives us to her house, now on the front line. From her front room you can part the net curtains and clearly see the other side of the wadi, on it the Basildon New Town of Gilo, and just in front of the last houses, two tanks, the long black arms of the guns point directly at us. She shows us Manger Square, which is empty, and the low porch to the Church of the Holy Nativity, built to prevent men on horseback from running amok inside. Normally, Bethlehem is chock-a-block with tourists, coaches, guides gibbering away. Now the whole place is as empty as Bournemouth Pier on a wet November morning. And the birthplace itself? It is, as TS Eliot wrote in Journey of the Magi, you may say, satisfactory.

The tanks in Gilo are not difficult to find, the bullet holes fired from the Palestinian side less so. The first shock on approaching Gilo is the roadblock. It doesn't exist. You can drive straight from the centre of Jerusalem into Gilo, and no one checks your passport or hassles you about your numberplates or searches your boot.

No roadblocks, but word blocks aplenty. Settler Uri Bank, 32, strolls up to us, checks our IDs, offers his help. He tells us that he lives in Gilo and is chief of staff for Benny Elon, MP, chairman of the National Union-Israel faction, which is further to the right than Likud.

Where are the bullet holes? The bullets fired by the Palestinian gunmen that necessitate the tank shells by way of reply? I look around, expecting to see a Gruyère of bullet holes, sickeningly familiar from Vukovar, Sarajevo and Kosovo. Nothing. Uri points to a black hole in a concrete wall, as insignificant as a blackhead on one of the Mount Rushmore faces. 'See, that's a bullet hole.'

I loan him my binoculars and show him the house across the wadi on the Palestinian side with the hole made by the tank shell, and resist the temptation to say: 'That's what I call a bullet hole.' You can even see the hole with the naked eye. But I do tell him there were 11 children in the house when the tank shell made that hole.

Uri, who speaks virtually flawless English with an American accent, does not draw breath. 'We're actually being too soft with the terrorists.' I repeat that there were 11 children in the house.

'Then they should take a vacation with a relative in Nablus.' This is another Palestinian-controlled town on the West Bank. I saw five young Palestinians shot dead there one afternoon. The dead included a 12-year-old. The back of his head was blown off by a bullet.

Uri gestures to the other side of the wadi: 'The civilians that stay there are accomplices to terrorism. You cannot expect Israel not to shoot back. More than 20 apartments in Gilo have been hit with bullets. It's a miracle that we haven't had any dead civilians. Our army is being told to go soft, to use too much restraint. If they shoot at a civilian neighbourhood, the army should reply with full fire. And helicopters should be brought in. If people in Golders Green were being shot up, Tony Blair wouldn't allow this to happen. No country would allow this to happen without massive retaliation.'

'... and everywhere
The ceremony of innocence is drowned;
The best lack all conviction, while the worst
Are full of passionate intensity.'
WB Yeats

As often happens, the Israeli soldiers who actually fire the tank shells at the target are much less hardcore than the men who egg them on to greater inhumanity. They sit around sunbathing, chatting, munching biscuits in the bored way of soldiers everywhere. In the most forwardly position of all are an Israeli photographer and three spotters, one of whom is wearing tank fatigues. He is a gentle man, who offers us biscuits. I ask: 'What's happening?'

And the tankie says: 'They shoot at us, and we shoot at them.' He says it in such a bored, matter-of-fact way that the others laugh. I want to tell him about the consequences of his work, when something happens. One of the tanks revs up its engine and its gun turret swivels and arrests, locked on to an unseen target. The officer comes and shoos us away.

The Israeli photographer, Nir, listens to my description of the other side, and grimaces. 'I'm on the left - I don't like the right, the settlers. But, hell, they're shooting at us.' I repeat the imbalance, show him the hole in the house on the other side of the wadi. He studies it and reflects: 'Israel's strength is its weakness. Their weakness is their strength.'

I had set out to meet a head teacher, an Israeli version of Grace. But at the local school the reception is a cold one. Everybody is locked into their own roles, as if they are actors in a play. On the Palestinian side, people are warm to Western journalists; on the Israeli side, they are cold. I saw the same in Bosnia - the Muslims friendly, the Serbs always standoffish to begin with, often paranoid, occasionally just short of murderous. After a time, you can break these barriers down and the real people shine through. But in Israel, these days, there is no time.

The school caretaker will not allow us to stay in the lobby. The secretary, too, gives us the cold shoulder. But a teacher finds us and starts chatting. The caretaker objects, and we walk off the school property.

Hannah is a special-needs teacher, deeply distressed at what is happening now. 'The children are very jumpy. When somebody drops a book on the floor and it makes a bang, everyone leaps up.'

Had she been over there, I ask, pointing to the town barely half a mile away. 'Yes, I have been there, and I want to go again. I want to go to Bethlehem. We are neighbours, not enemies. We used to go there, but not now. It's a shame that they are shooting at us.'

And then she has to go.

The suffering in the Holy Land's latest war is not equal. The dying started after Israel's right-wing opposition leader, Ariel Sharon, inspected a contested holy site in Jerusalem. Since then, 270 people have been killed: of those, 70 are Israeli and 200 Palestinian; of the Palestinian dead, 70 have been children.

Both causes have right on their side. The Palestinians see themselves in a liberation struggle against a hated colonial power. The Israelis are defending themselves from racist attack, the memory of the Holocaust never to be forgotten. It is like watching two people with terrible migraines blaming, then fighting each other in the same room. The Palestinians can be accused with some justification of self-mortification. You can question why parents let their 12-year-olds out on to the streets. But these reflections do not change the big picture. The Israelis are killing Palestinians at a ratio of three to one. After a while, one begins to wonder at the ferocity of the Israelis' response, as if they are suffering from battered-child syndrome on a terrifying scale.

From the roof of Rabbi Michael Melchior's home in southern Jerusalem, you can see Bethlehem. The rabbi leads a strange anomaly, a left-wing religious political party that is a part of Prime Minister Ehud Barak's governing coalition. He's the minister for the Jewish Diaspora - until the elections take place in February. What is happening now is totally unnecessary. The Palestinians were offered exactly what they are fighting for.'

That said, he's aware that compromise is the only way forward: 'I believe in religious dialogue. There are not so many in this market,' he jokes. 'The Middle East conflict is about two peoples claiming the same land. It can only be solved by territorial compromise. The problem is, if you turn it into a religious conflict, then it becomes my God against your God, then... We have to do everything to get back together, to talk again.'

The rabbi's voice is not, by any means, the loudest these days.

Tank shells, machine-gun bullets, automatic rifle rounds scream louder. A few days ago, Grace's home was hit again. Her lounge looks like Gruyère, her vacuum got blasted and there are 40 Israeli bullet holes in her home. With her sister and her elderly aunt, she's had to move out from the family home.

Christmas? In Bethlehem? It's not exactly Jingle Bells.
fields.bodyText: In the town that started it all, Christmas is cancelled. The choirs from around the world that were planning to hallelujah in the first Christmas of the second millennium are not going to make it. To go there these days is to enter a war zone. Some days it is just quiet, almost dull. Every now and then the tourist trap created in the birthplace of the Son of God explodes as tank shells slam in. A roadblock on the edge of Bethlehem. On this side of the line, Greater Israel, sprawling across the occupied territories, a First World go-getting internet economy that has absorbed a million Russian Jews in a decade. On the other side of the line, the Bantustan of Bethlehem, an Arab-majority town controlled by the Palestine Authority, but entirely encircled by the fire power of the Israeli Defence Force. And in the middle, trying to cross the line in a small and battered car, the head teacher of a local kindergarten, Grace Abu Mohor. Grace is a Christian Arab, of Greek Orthodox family, a tiny fireball of a woman with a riotous sense of the ridiculous and a contagious laugh. In the car with her are two tots who go to the kindergarten, aged three and four. The Israelis have closed the road to traffic, so that Palestinian cars with green plates cannot enter Israel, and Israeli vehicles with yellow plates cannot enter Bethlehem. This is a new restriction, and it has caught out the mother of the two kids. Although an Arab, she's got yellow plates and cannot drive into Bethlehem to get to the kindergarten and pick up her children. Grace has got a huge amount on her plate. Not least, her home overlooks the Israeli settlement of Gilo. Palestinian gunmen have peppered Gilo with AK fire; the Israelis have fired back with tank shells. Suddenly, her home, historically a peaceable and plush Christian-Arab village, is on a front line that didn't exist before. But Grace is a head teacher down to her boots. She feels that she cannot trust the two kids to a taxi driver. They are too young. So she drives up towards the checkpoint, hoping that with her innocent cargo on board she can talk her way through the roadblock and deliver the children safe and sound to their mother. The dividing line is on a narrow road on top of a bluff. Under a lowering sky, on the far horizon, you can see the domes, minarets and hotel skyscrapers of Jerusalem. Close by, across a deep wadi, is Gilo, a kind of Basildon New Town, homes made of brash new concrete on the top of the hill. Gilo is built on Arab land, of course. It's part of a ring of settlements that encircle Jerusalem and deepen the gloom of the Palestinians. How can they ever have their own state, they say, if Israel keeps building these settlements? You can feel the tension on the line. Witness the stylised humility of the Palestinian drivers, trying to get through the block. They are Arab drivers with yellow plates who have been literally wrongsided by the new rules, and are now desperate to get their vehicles back across the line, in case they are trapped. Witness, too, the morose arrogance of the squaddies of the Israeli Defence Force. They display a studied toughness they've drunk in from Hollywood. There are four or five of them on the road, automatic rifles strapped to their backs. There is a promise of rain, but even so, one of them is still sporting sunglasses. One is tempted to say, 'You look a right twit in those, son,' but he has a gun. None of them is older than 22. Their helmets look weird. The soldiers are sporting floppy camouflage bonnets on top of their helmets, as big and silly as the Eccy Thump flat caps worn by the Tetley tea-bag workers, making their heads look huge and misshapen. The reason? The helmet covers will confuse the aim of Palestinian snipers who may or may not be out there. As the Israeli soldiers strut their stuff, I wonder what's going on inside their helmets. I'm Arnold Schwarzenegger in Terminator 2. Actually, I'm Arnie from Tel Aviv, and I'm only 20, and I don't want a bullet tunnelling through my brain at 900mph. I don't want to be kidnapped. But I'm not going to let any of my mates on the checkpoint sniff my fear, so I'm going to play it as tough as hell. And here, into the middle of this display of overdog testosterone and underdog anger, comes Grace in her scruffy car with the kids in the back. To control the traffic and show who is boss, the Israelis have created a very tight chicane, by putting down tyre-killing 'shark teeth'. These are strips of heavy black plastic in which are embedded razor-sharp metal teeth, pointing up. Grace, anxious, slips her car through a gap between a bus and the shark's teeth and gently nudges towards the line. She almost makes it. But the Israeli soldier with the shades, who has been distracted by giving the bus driver a hard time, sees the banned green numberplate and erupts. He can't see the kids. They are too low in their seats. He is raging with fury at Grace, screaming: 'Get back, get back!' Grace wants to get out and say her piece, but she can't leave the kids, and stalls. The soldier becomes yet more enraged at the stupid, bloody woman blocking the roadblock: 'GET BACK, GET BACK!' Panicking now, Grace reverses back, and blows three of her tyres on the shark's teeth. O little town of Bethlehem, how still we see thee lie. It's her fault and it's not her fault. The shark's teeth, being low to the ground, couldn't be seen in her rear-view mirror. The kids are crying, Grace is rattled, angry with herself and the soldier, her car immobilised. The soldier snaps that he didn't let her tyres down, and walks away to block our taxi, with yellow plates, from entering Bethlehem. Grace uses her mobile to call the children's mother. They are picked up with lots of cuddles and stroking of hair, the mother grateful at Grace's effort, and appalled at the three flat tyres. She leaves Grace, who says she is fine and it will be no problem. Then the rain starts to fall, and Grace is all but crying at the stupidity of it all. It's not the soldier's fault. He was, as they say, only obeying orders. His tension, his fear, his souped-up testosterone blocked him from looking into the scruffy car and seeing what was in there. They might have been terrorists. But actually they were only Grace and two very small kids. And there you've got it: the agony of the Holy Land in three burst tyres at the Bethlehem checkpoint. Humanity has a way of seeping through the cracks of adversity. A few Arab teenagers pimp-roll past, see Grace's predicament and, as the rain becomes heavier and heavier, they get stuck in. They change the one good tyre in the boot and arrange for a taxi driver to go down into Bethlehem and buy two new tyres. It's partly common human decency. It's partly a way at getting at the Israeli soldiers. Hey - look, guys! You bully the poor woman into blowing her tyres. We help her out. Call yourself men? None of this is stated. It's all acted out, a silent ballet of puncture repair. A minibus arrives, in it teachers from Grace's school, going to their homes in Jerusalem. They are Americans, men and women from the moon. They take in the scene, the three flats, the shark's teeth, the soldiers barking at some new trespasser on their authority. In the battle for the world's sympathy, Israel loses a few more votes to Palestine. Our taxi is stuck on the yellow-plated side of the line, but Grace agrees to play tour guide. The first stop on the bang-bang tourist's Bethlehem is pretty impressive, if you like looking at the intestines of washing machines. The washing machine has taken a direct hit from a tank shell. What's seriously odd is that the front of the machine is almost intact, the white plastic casing slewed and twisted but the makers, 'Frigidaire', and the options 'spin' 'wool' 'rinse only' all still readable. Behind the plastic front, a dirty great hole has been bored through by the shell, wrecking the drum and turning the motor into a puddle of metal. A commotion at the door: another bang-bang tourist has shown up, a tall, silver-haired priest, Father Gockel Guido, a Mill Hill Father working for the Papal Nuncio to the Holy Land. The priest inspects the washing machine. Tracing the flight path from the washing machine backwards is not exactly difficult. The shell came into the washing machine through a hole in the wall, beyond that the Nazal children's bedroom: a litter of cuddly animals, swaddled in dust and crumbled chunks of wall; a kid's toy-car dashboard, the speedo set to 140mph; kids' clothes, shredded; a Super School Bus Band music machine covered in muck; a mirror smashed to pieces. The shell had entered the house through a window of the kids' bedroom, gone straight through the internal wall and bedded itself in the washing machine. One of the boys of the house picks up what was left of the shell, a base, weirdly compressed by its impact with the wall. It is the size of a big ashtray, but as heavy as 10 housebricks. The mother, Manua Jamil Muslat, sits on a sofa, crying that the children just can't get to sleep at nights. They all think it will happen again, she says. From her front room you can part the net curtains and clearly see the other side of the wadi, on it the Basildon New Town of Gilo, and just in front of the last houses, two tanks, the long black arms of the guns point directly at us. She shows us Manger Square, which is empty, and the low porch to the Church of the Holy Nativity, built to prevent men on horseback from running amok inside. Normally, Bethlehem is chock-a-block with tourists, coaches, guides gibbering away. Now the whole place is as empty as Bournemouth Pier on a wet November morning. And the birthplace itself? It is, as TS Eliot wrote in Journey of the Magi, you may say, satisfactory. The tanks in Gilo are not difficult to find, the bullet holes fired from the Palestinian side less so. The first shock on approaching Gilo is the roadblock. It doesn't exist. You can drive straight from the centre of Jerusalem into Gilo, and no one checks your passport or hassles you about your numberplates or searches your boot. No roadblocks, but word blocks aplenty. Settler Uri Bank, 32, strolls up to us, checks our IDs, offers his help. He tells us that he lives in Gilo and is chief of staff for Benny Elon, MP, chairman of the National Union-Israel faction, which is further to the right than Likud. Where are the bullet holes? The bullets fired by the Palestinian gunmen that necessitate the tank shells by way of reply? I look around, expecting to see a Gruyère of bullet holes, sickeningly familiar from Vukovar, Sarajevo and Kosovo. Nothing. Uri points to a black hole in a concrete wall, as insignificant as a blackhead on one of the Mount Rushmore faces. 'See, that's a bullet hole.' I loan him my binoculars and show him the house across the wadi on the Palestinian side with the hole made by the tank shell, and resist the temptation to say: 'That's what I call a bullet hole.' You can even see the hole with the naked eye. But I do tell him there were 11 children in the house when the tank shell made that hole. Uri, who speaks virtually flawless English with an American accent, does not draw breath. 'We're actually being too soft with the terrorists.' I repeat that there were 11 children in the house. 'Then they should take a vacation with a relative in Nablus.' This is another Palestinian-controlled town on the West Bank. I saw five young Palestinians shot dead there one afternoon. The dead included a 12-year-old. The back of his head was blown off by a bullet. Uri gestures to the other side of the wadi: 'The civilians that stay there are accomplices to terrorism. You cannot expect Israel not to shoot back. More than 20 apartments in Gilo have been hit with bullets. It's a miracle that we haven't had any dead civilians. Our army is being told to go soft, to use too much restraint. If they shoot at a civilian neighbourhood, the army should reply with full fire. And helicopters should be brought in. If people in Golders Green were being shot up, Tony Blair wouldn't allow this to happen. No country would allow this to happen without massive retaliation.' '... and everywhere The ceremony of innocence is drowned; The best lack all conviction, while the worst Are full of passionate intensity.' WB Yeats As often happens, the Israeli soldiers who actually fire the tank shells at the target are much less hardcore than the men who egg them on to greater inhumanity. They sit around sunbathing, chatting, munching biscuits in the bored way of soldiers everywhere. In the most forwardly position of all are an Israeli photographer and three spotters, one of whom is wearing tank fatigues. He is a gentle man, who offers us biscuits. I ask: 'What's happening?' And the tankie says: 'They shoot at us, and we shoot at them.' He says it in such a bored, matter-of-fact way that the others laugh. I want to tell him about the consequences of his work, when something happens. One of the tanks revs up its engine and its gun turret swivels and arrests, locked on to an unseen target. The officer comes and shoos us away. The Israeli photographer, Nir, listens to my description of the other side, and grimaces. 'I'm on the left - I don't like the right, the settlers. But, hell, they're shooting at us.' I repeat the imbalance, show him the hole in the house on the other side of the wadi. He studies it and reflects: 'Israel's strength is its weakness. Their weakness is their strength.' I had set out to meet a head teacher, an Israeli version of Grace. But at the local school the reception is a cold one. Everybody is locked into their own roles, as if they are actors in a play. On the Palestinian side, people are warm to Western journalists; on the Israeli side, they are cold. I saw the same in Bosnia - the Muslims friendly, the Serbs always standoffish to begin with, often paranoid, occasionally just short of murderous. After a time, you can break these barriers down and the real people shine through. But in Israel, these days, there is no time. The school caretaker will not allow us to stay in the lobby. The secretary, too, gives us the cold shoulder. But a teacher finds us and starts chatting. The caretaker objects, and we walk off the school property. Hannah is a special-needs teacher, deeply distressed at what is happening now. 'The children are very jumpy. When somebody drops a book on the floor and it makes a bang, everyone leaps up.' Had she been over there, I ask, pointing to the town barely half a mile away. 'Yes, I have been there, and I want to go again. I want to go to Bethlehem. We are neighbours, not enemies. We used to go there, but not now. It's a shame that they are shooting at us.' And then she has to go. The suffering in the Holy Land's latest war is not equal. The dying started after Israel's right-wing opposition leader, Ariel Sharon, inspected a contested holy site in Jerusalem. Since then, 270 people have been killed: of those, 70 are Israeli and 200 Palestinian; of the Palestinian dead, 70 have been children. Both causes have right on their side. webTitle: Albanian threat to kill UK peacekeepers

fields.headline: Albanian threat to kill UK peacekeepers
fields.standfirst: A guerrilla leader threatens to retaliate if his men are fired upon, reports Gillian Sandford
fields.trailText: A guerrilla leader threatens to retaliate if his men are fired upon, reports Gillian Sandford.
fields.body:
An Albanian rebel commander has threatened to 'shoot and kill' British K-For peacekeepers who fire on his guerrillas in southern Serbia and said there could be 'hatred between the two nations'.

In an exclusive interview with The Observer in rebel-held territory, the guerrilla chief, known only as Commander Lleshi, said: 'If a soldier is really in danger, he has the right to shoot and to kill.'

Lleshi is one of three chiefs of the self-styled Liberation Army of Bujanovac, Presevo and Medvedja. It controls 10 key villages in land originally set up as a buffer zone on the Serb side of the Kosovo border.

He called for the area to be included in Kosovo under K-For administration. But Nato, the UN and the US have called on his group to disband and respect current borders.

British peacekeepers were sent in just over a week ago. Since January, US soldiers with K-For had failed to stop insurgents crossing from Kosovo and driving out lightly armed Serb police, four of whom were killed.

Last week British soldiers arrested 13 of Lleshi's rebels illegally crossing the border during a Nato-brokered ceasefire. They had a large cache of weapons.

The buffer zone is part of the Presevo Valley area where most people are ethnic Albanians and describe the valley as 'eastern Kosovo'.

Lleshi is a native of Veliki Trnovac, an all-Albanian village just inside the buffer, and is a hero to its 9,000 people. Old men in the dusty narrow streets and schoolchildren greet him with waves and smiles as he passes. The villages say they are now 'liberated' from Serbian domination.

He told me: 'If the British soldiers were in the position that we are now, they would pass a hundred blockades to go to help their people. We never want to fight against the Britons, but if it goes over the limit, each man who is mistreated or is tortured and sent to prison in that moment could be unhappy and might have a different attitude to the British. So it might happen that there could be hatred between the two nations.'

Lleshi, who fought with the Kosovo Liberation Army (KLA) during the Kosovo conflict, says military and political leaders in Pristina support his army.

He cites a history of Serb oppression of Albanians in southern Serbia under Slobodan Milosevic and says even if the new President, Vojislav Kostunica, gave guarantees of security, virulent nationalists under Belgrade radical Vojislav Seselj could gain power and repeat the repression of earlier years.

When told that K-For has no right to enter sovereign Serbia, he replies: 'K-For had no right even to be in Kosovo, but when they saw the ill treatment of Albanians, international forces became involved in Kosovo, without asking anybody. So they should involve themselves in this part, if we are to have a stable area. In the Yugoslav and Serbian constitution there were rules for all the rights of minorities to be respected. But these were practically eliminated. So we want a monitoring mission and K-For here.'

The Yugoslav army and police cannot enter the three-mile zone in Serb territory without breaching the international agreement signed by Nato and Belgrade after the Kosovo conflict. The British and US peacekeepers can only range their guns and patrol up to the Kosovo border according to the same Kumanovo agreement.

So the rebels, having dug themselves into the three-mile zone, are now protected from Yugoslav and Nato ground assault by the rules of the agreement. On Friday even international diplomats accompanying Yugoslav politicians were blocked from entering Veliki Trnovac by the guerrilla forces. The rebels would have let in the diplomats, but refused the Yugoslavs entry to the zone.

Lleshi says: 'We have promised that we will all die - the children, soldiers, women - not to have any more refugee lines, because that is catastrophic.

'We have some people who have died and blood has flowed. We have too many armed people. Who should disarm them? I think only K-For can. Only with K-For's agreement can these military forces be disarmed and a peaceful solution come. This is the reality, for Albanians and Serbs too.'

The situation highlights the problem of Kosovo's long-term future. Kostunica has said that for the moment Kosovo should remain under UN administration. But all putative solutions raise objections, because of the dangers of redrawing borders.

webTitle: Comment: True face of a Tory

fields.headline: True face of a Tory
fields.standfirst:
Oscar Wilde, by word and even by deed, may yet hold the key to the Widdeworld of modern Conservatism

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Oscar Wilde, by word and even by deed, may yet hold the key to the Widdeworld of modern Conservatism.
fields.body:
At christmas every temporal and spiritual authority enjoins us to think of those less fortunate than ourselves. This season they must surely beg you to direct your thoughts to the most deluded group being cared for in our 'community'. Although outwardly pampered, its members believe they have been robbed blind; although no one stems their wild talk, they see themselves as persecuted dissidents. They are trapped in a fantastic and menacing mental universe which I will call Widdeworld.

In Widdeworld, the Widdemen and women hold these truths to be self-evident.

1. Really, if the lower orders don't set us a good example, what on earth is the use of them?

Wilde's tender feelings for the male sex ensured that all his writings were forgotten by Widdeworlders save for the inspirational thought from The Importance of Being Earnest that if the poor were not always with us, the rich wouldn't know how to behave.

Ann Widdecombe was obliged to abandon her harsh line on cannabis in October after her colleagues in the Shadow Cabinet told her they had been doped out of their heads in their youth. She confessed to the Guardian that she had never wanted the police to arrest Conservative supporters. She was 'keen to stress her policy is not targeted at middle-class people experimenting at university, but at blocking the supply of drugs in run-down estates'.

The Times reported that members of the audience at a Conservative Future meeting had sworn that they had heard Philip Hammond, the Tory MP for Runnymede and Weybridge, say: 'It is more acceptable for middle-class educated people to use cannabis than working-class people on run-down council estates.' Hammond, alas, exiled himself from respectable society when he disowned this sound Widdeist sentiment.

Despite his trimming, it remains incontestable that all notions of equality before the law should be abandoned because in Widdeworld it is poverty, not property, that is theft. Everyone accepts that:

2. The poor are poor because they are stealing all our money.

In June we learned that this seeming paradox had been resolved by Marvin Olasky - an orthodox Jew turned Marxist atheist turned Christian fundamentalist, who earned the wisdom needed to advise George W Bush and William Hague while teaching journalists at the University of Texas, no less. 'Every time we tell someone he is a victim,' Marv explained, 'every time we say he deserves a special break, every time we hand out charity to someone capable of working, we are hurting rather than helping.'

Olasky saw for himself how the poor's dupes were conned into giving them luxuries rather than the essentials of life when he dressed in the rags of a beggar and stumbled onto the streets. He was offered food and shelter by the credulous, but was astonished to find his craving for a Bible was left unsatisfied. Without the Word of God to guide them, the destitute failed yet again to set a good example to their betters. They remained nothing more than 'the victims and perpetrators of illegitimacy and abandonment'.

Alan Duncan, a Tory MP and one of William Hague's spin doctors, agreed that the welfare state led the poor into the wicked ways of the rich. 'When unemployment benefit and income support [are provided] by the Department of Social Security,' he wrote in his apology for his life, Saturn's Children, 'the effect is not to enlarge the moral opportunities open to individuals but to narrow them.'

Both accepted that the only way out of a depraved dependency culture is to get a job. The poor should not, however, expect to receive a living wage for their labours. For in Widdeworld it is axiomatic that:

3. It is bad for business if work makes the poor richer.

One of the first acts of the New Labour Government was to legislate for a minimum wage at the paltry level of £3.70 an hour. Christopher Chope, a Conservative MP, feared that capitalism would be brought to its knees. Ancient liberties - the presumption of innocence, true trial by jury and the right to silence - are dead or dying. It is all very well ranting about the moral lessons of Damilola without visiting Peckham or picking up a phone. If they conceal, there remains a chance - vanishingly faint, but none the less real - that they will be scuppered.

Michael Portillo seems to understand this, and to have grasped that the most effective assault on New Labour would be to counter authoritarianism with freedom. Under his government you would be free to hunt foxes and make obscene sums in the City, but you would also be free to demonstrate and be tried by a jury and keep the state out of your bedroom.

Yet the Conservative press hates Portillo - not least because he had a brief Wildean passion of his own. It condemns its party to live in Widdeworld, a far-away country of which we have heard too much, for far too long.

webTitle: Israel ready to strike deal on Temple Mount

fields.headline: Israel ready to strike deal on Temple Mount
fields.standfirst: Strict limits on Palestinian refugees demanded in return
fields.trailText: Strict limits on Palestinian refugees demanded in return.
fields.byline: Peter Beaumont, foreign affairs editor and Ed Vulliamy in Washington
fields.body:
Israeli and Palestinian negotiators moved closer to a definitive peace settlement yesterday as Israel indicated that it was prepared to hand over de facto sovereignty of the Temple Mount complex in Jerusalem's Old City if Palestinians accepted strict limits on the number of refugee returns.

Under the Washington-brokered deal, Israel would accept Palestinian control of the third holiest shrine in Islam - where the present intifada began earlier this year - but the issue of legal ownership of the site would be left unresolved.

The American formula for the resolution of the status of the Temple Mount would also be applied to other areas of a final peace settlement, with the emphasis on who controls which areas, rather than on a definitive resolution of legal 'ownership'.

The disclosure came as Israeli Foreign Minister Shlomo Ben-Ami, in the United States for talks with American and Palestinian officials, told American- Jewish leaders that Israel was prepared to cede sovereignty over the 'surface layer' of the Temple Mount to the Palestinians, giving them effective control of the site.

The contentious issues of the Temple Mount - site of the al-Aqsa mosque and known as Haram al-Sharif in the Muslim world - and of the return of up to four million Palestinian refugees - are understood to be the final sticking points holding up a peace settlement that would bring an end to almost three months of violence that has claimed 344 lives.

Sources close to the negotiations have told The Observer that the two sides were closer than ever before on the issues of the return of the Occupied Territories, security guarantees for Israel in the Jordan Valley, peace-keeping arrangements after a deal is signed, and the final status of Jerusalem and the Old City.

Israel is understood to be sticking to its insistence that it cannot accept the principle of refugee returns, despite intense pressure from the US to come up with a compromise formula.

Palestinians demand that those who were driven from or fled from Israel - as well as their descendants, who now number several million - be allowed to return to their homes. Israel flatly refuses.

Instead, America is understood to be seeking a pragmatic solution that would see Israel accept the principle of refugee return while binding Palestinians to bring about the return of only the most pressing cases.

Among ideas that are understood to have been floated is that Palestinians agree to limit demands for refugee returns to those who 'were actual refugees of the conflict' and who were pre pared to return to areas of a new Palestinian state specially designated for settlement.

In exchange, Israel would cede its claim to the Temple Mount, allowing Palestine to declare sovereignty over it, while Israel would retain control of the adjoining Wailing Wall and West Wall Plaza.

As part of the deal Palestinians would agree not to make any physical changes to the site or undertake any archaeological excavations that would insult the sentiments of Jews who hold the Temple Mount sacred as the site of the Second Temple.

The thrust of the thinking behind the present negotiations being held behind closed doors at Bolling Air Force base in Washington has been revealed in a discussion document leaked to The Observer, understood to draw heavily on the US draft proposal currently on the table.

The draft peace proposal envisages that Israel will relinquish up to 75 per cent of land occupied for settlement. It will annex the remaining 25 per cent for an area currently part of Israel proper which would be added to the Gaza Strip.

Israel would also give up its claims to the Muslim and Christian quarters of the Old City, while Israeli settlers in these quarters would be compensated.

Israeli security concerns in the Jordan Valley would be met by a non-UN international force that would monitor the peace and border crossings. Israeli troops would be allowed to retain manning at agreed early warning stations and security posts.

Sources familiar with the talks - which are subject to a news blackout - say that despite reports of tense exchanges at the negotiations, observers were now cautiously optimistic that a deal could be signed at a summit to be held before President Bill Clinton leaves office.

President Clinton has been personally receiving members of the negotiating delegations, gathered to thrash out his own personal document around which it is hoped the agreement will be forged. He was due to go in person to the Bolling Air Force base near Washington yesterday, to try to push what both sides are said to have accepted as 'parameters' for a peace treaty.

The President has imposed a deadline of 10 January, 10 days before the inauguration of his successor George W. Bush - whose incoming team has said it will work to impose whatever deal has been made, if any.

'Until the middle of last week, expectations were very low,' said one source. 'In the last three days, however, we have seen some real progress. On several areas both sides are very close to agreement. What is holding the talks up are the issues of Haram al-Sharif and refugee returns.'

webTitle: Now it's unofficial: Gore did win Florida

fields.headline: Now it's unofficial: Gore did win Florida
fields.trailText: As George W. Bush handed further key government posts to hardline Republican right-wingers, an unofficial recount of votes in Florida appeared to confirm that Bush lost the US presidential election.
fields.body:
As George W. Bush handed further key government posts to hardline Republican right-wingers, an unofficial recount of votes in Florida appeared to confirm that Bush lost the US presidential election.

Despite the decision by the US Supreme Court to halt the Florida recount in the contested counties, American media organisations, includ ing Knight Ridder - owner of the Miami Herald - have commissioned their own counts, gaining access to the ballots under Freedom of Information legislation. The result so far, with the recounting of so-called 'undervotes' in only one county completed by Friday night, indicates that Al Gore is ahead by 140 votes.

Florida's 25 electoral college votes won Bush the presidency by two seats last Monday after the Supreme Court refused to allow the counting of 45,000 discarded votes. But as the media recount was suspended for Christmas, the votes so far tallied in Lake and Broward counties have Gore ahead in the race for the pivotal state, and hence the White House.

Gore's lead is expected to soar when counting resumes in the New Year and Miami votes are counted. In a separate exercise, the Miami Herald commissioned a team of political analysts and pollsters to make a statistical calculation based on projections of votes by county, concluding that Gore won the state by 23,000.

The media initiative is likely to bedevil Bush in the weeks to come, thickening the pall of illegitimacy that will hang over his inauguration on 20 January.

It has already led to a face-off between almost all the news media organisations in the state and Bush's presidential team. In the most extreme example of the Bush camp's desperation to avoid a recount, the new director of the Environment Protection Agency, Christine Todd Whitman, has proposed that the Florida ballots be sealed for 10 years.

Bush's spokesman Tucker Eskew dismissed the recount as 'mischief-making' and 'inflaming public passions' while his brother, Florida governor Jeb Bush, accused the papers of 'trying to rewrite history'.

Meanwhile, Bush made his boldest ideological statement yet with the appointment of John Ashcroft as Attorney General.

The appointment is especially significant, because as head of the Justice Department Ashcroft would be the man to bring any felony charges against President Bill Clinton over the Lewinsky affair. During the scandal, Ashcroft was among the loudest and shrillest voices for impeachment.

There have been many calls to President-elect Bush to pardon his predecessor as a sign of peace, but he made a point of rejecting them.

Ashcroft lost his Missouri Senate seat to the widow of the state's popular Democrat governor, Mel Carnahan. From the family of a Pentacostal minister, he is an outspoken social conservative and an ally of the extremist Pat Robertson.

Ashcroft represents a host of militant committees and activist groups, of which the Christian Coalition is most prominent. He is an opponent not only of abortion but even - as he said in one speech - of dancing.

webTitle: Church lobby set for election blitz

fields.headline: Church lobby set for election blitz
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Tories in opposition

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Church leaders are to challenge the three party leaders in a major pre-election campaign to push religious issues to the top of the agenda.
fields.body:
Church leaders are to challenge the three party leaders in a major pre-election campaign to push religious issues to the top of the agenda.

They will issue a manifesto in the new year, calling for faith-based groups to be properly funded and taken seriously as providers of public services, among other recognitions of Christianity in public life. The 'Faith Works' campaign will reignite the combustible mix of religion and politics, spurring both Tony Blair and William Hague to compete for the religious vote.

Led by the Oasis Trust, it is expected to unite mainstream churches and evangelicals. It will stop short of endorsing any particular party but will challenge the main parties to tackle issues of importance to Christians, calling on religious charities not to be ashamed of their beliefs.

The campaign will begin with the launch in February of a pamphlet by the Rev Steve Chalke, an evangelical minister, arguing for a new role for faith-based groups. Catholic bishops are understood to be preparing a document on the family that is expected to call for recognition of marriage in the tax system.

Senior Tory strategists estimate that about 2,000 voters in the average constituency have strong enough religious views to determine their choice at the ballot box, and enough to swing a mar ginal. They hope those voters who were put off by sleaze in 1997 will now return to the Conservatives.

But Labour too has been cultivating links to the churches through Ministers who are practising Christians, such as the Treasury's Stephen Timms and Paul Boateng at the Home Office.

The idea of involving religious groups in welfare services was imported from the United States, where it proved controversial.

fields.headline: My 26-hour Inter-Cities special
fields.standfirst: Nick Paton Walsh tried to visit Britain's three new cities in one day.The trouble is, he had to do it by train
fields.trailText: Nick Paton Walsh tried to visit Britain's three new cities in one day.The trouble is, he had to do it by train.
fields.body:
Take three brand-new cities and a crumbling transport infrastructure. Now try to travel between them in a single winter's day, a little before Christmas. This was my nightmare assignment as I joined the queue on the platform at Inverness station to travel to Wolverhampton and then on to Brighton.

Before leaving, I had checked with a rail expert, Philip Wilks, at the Rail Passenger's Council. What, I asked him, was the most optimistic journey time I could hope for? Before the Hatfield rail crash triggered the current widespread works on the line and the imposition of an emergency timetable, Wilks explained, I could have expected to spend 12 hours and 53 minutes travelling.

In the current circumstances, the National Rail Enquiries line told me, if I left Inverness on Thursday afternoon, I might reach Brighton some time the next afternoon. If I was lucky. Lucky? The woman behind the ticket counter at Inverness was hardly reassuring. 'Just try and get as far south as you can by night,' she advised.

Time passed. The queue on the platform grew frostier with the mist. A toddler began to cry. When they waved us on to the train, we trudged through a mist so thick that I could not see the end of the platform.

We set off at 14.40 and by the time we swung into King-ussie it was getting dark. At Blair Atholl, it was pitch black. Then just after Pitlochry, the first of the gremlins appeared. At 16.20, the driver announced: 'Ladies and gentlemen, we would like to apologise for the slow running of this train. This is due to technical difficulties.'

For 20 minutes we crawled along. The couple next to me began to bicker. The girl opposite told me that a track inspection at Dunkeld was behind the delay.

I arrived at Edinburgh Waverley at 18.25, with a few minutes to rush from platform 5 to platform 20. There, I asked the guard, who stood waving passengers on board if this was the fast train to York. 'Aye. So, so,' he shrugged, almost amused.

On the train a girl sat between carriages on a fold-down stool. She was flicking through a manual. I asked her when the train was due to arrive in York, and she consulted the Great North Eastern Railways emergency timetable: '21.27, if you're lucky,' she replied. The emer gency timetable is a master-stroke of public relations. Trains, instead of being impossibly late, are now largely 'on schedule'.

An hour into the York leg of my journey, however, the ticketing problems associated with the break-up and privatisation of the railways became apparent. A pleasant, but quite insistent, ticket inspector told me that I am not 'valid for this route'.

When I had asked to go to Wolverhampton, the woman at the Inverness ticket counter had told me to go through York and Manchester Piccadilly - the route I was taking. The inspector told me my ticket was only valid for a route via Carlisle on the West Coast route, explaining he would have to 'charge me the excess' and then I would have to reclaim it back from Great North Eastern Railways (GNER). Otherwise, he said gravely, GNER would not get paid for transporting me.

We pulled into York a mere 15 minutes later than the emergency timetable had promised, and I found a hotel for the night.

Power lines were down in the Castleford area, the Tannoy explained, and 'passengers for Manchester Piccadilly should take the 7am to Leeds and change.' I asked an attendant from which platform the 7am left. She said the 7am was actually a bus, leaving from round the corner, that would take me to Leeds in 50 minutes, where a train would take me to Manchester in an hour and a half.

I felt the bus was a little against the rules and sat and waited while the Tannoy announced that the 6.18 and 7.14 had been cancelled 'due to signalling problems in the Castleford area'. Ten minutes later the 6.18 was reinstated, and I joined 10 bored, angry passengers in a carriage that smelt of the crisps and stale beer of the last occupants.

At 7.34 we moved off towards Manchester, and from Manchester caught the 9.17 to Wolverhampton, both of which journeys were marred by occasional unexplained delays on the track. Wolverhampton was a splendid shade of grey when we arrived at 10.51, and still reeling in its millennial splendour at 11.19 when the train to Euston left. I was now on a Virgin train. The trip was about to get much worse.

The Tannoy announced: 'Due to a faulty urn, there will be no hot drinks. Sorry for any inconvenience caused.' As the ticket inspector passed along the aisle, he let slip that 'all the problems are on the other side of Milton Keynes'.

True enough, at 12.56, once we had passed the silver towers that surround Milton Keynes Central, we met the 'speed restrictions'.

We passed a sign warning that the section of track ahead was a 'poor adhesion site' ahead. This means the train doesn't grip the tracks properly. We crawled past a team of track engineers and an empty Stansted Express, sat motionless on the tracks, before entering the tunnel into Euston station. 'Due to track protection, speed restrictions are in place until further notice,' said the Tannoy, before casually saying that from Sunday all trains from the North would stop at Milton Keynes Central to enable emergency repair work.

At Euston the concourse was 30 deep with commuters staring bleakly at the destinations board.

I took the Tube to Victoria to similar scenes of chaos and boarded a packed 'Express' train to Brighton. As I arrived, the guard acknowledged that the 50-minute 'Express' train could be up to 10 minutes late arriving - there were speed restrictions and a landslide at Redhill that had been causing delays.

I sat, exhausted after 15 hours on the train and 26 hours on the move, next to two pony-tailed men in leather jackets, one of whom asked the other if he fancied a game of cribbage later on as we pulled into Brighton.

It was then that I noticed a faint smell. That smell was me.

fields.headline: Live longer with family Christmas
fields.standfirst: You will be healthier if you celebrate in company
fields.trailText: You will be healthier if you celebrate in company.
fields.body:
If you spend Christmas with your family or an extended family group every year, you could live up to six years longer. Close community links are a key indicator of better health and well-being, a major research project is expected to find.

'We now have a body of evidence that there are reduced health risks in terms of heart disease and strokes to people who have good community links,' said Vicky Nash of the Institute for Public Policy Research.

'Local communities are too often regarded as geographic, but they should be more broadly acknowledged as family or extended family too. Spending time together at Christmas is one indicator that a person has the social links which contribute to physical wellbeing. There are certainly short-term correlations between social ties and mental health too.'

Eighty-five-year old Eileen Smart from Brighton was widowed in 1995. After three Christmases alone, she was 'adopted' by an architect and his wife she met through her church. For the past two years she has spent Christmas Day with the Browns, a couple with two children but no surviving parents.

'I used to find I was particularly depressed in December and often susceptible to colds and flu,' says Smart, 'but now I have something to look forward to it makes me much more positive. It's something I'm terribly excited about. I don't get miserable seeing everyone else preparing for an event I won't share. And the children are lovely. As well as being more cheerful, my general health has definitely been better during the winter.'

The links with the Brown family are sustained during the year. Since their first Christmas together, the family have visited Eileen regularly and she has attended their children's school plays.

'Christmas used to be an awful, miserable time,' says 25-year old Justin Webb from north London. 'If you're gay, you feel completely excluded from traditional family and religious celebrations. But now we celebrate our own Christmas with about 12 friends away from the purgatory other people experience.

'Christmas Day will consist of drink and lots of other things. We won't have Christmas dinner, but a series of snacks. It certainly makes me feel a lot happier during the winter than I used to.'

Shaks Ghosh of the homeless charity Crisis, which will help 800 people this Christmas, said: 'About half the people we look after are in temporary or even permanent accommodation. What they need is not housing or government support but family and friends.'

The research being conducted in Britain is sustained by evidence gathered in America. A study in Alameda County, California, established that people with the fewest social ties had the highest risk of death from heart disease, circulatory problems and cancer. Researchers at Carnegie Mellon University, Pennsylvania, found that people with more diverse social ties get fewer colds.

'There is already research on animals,' said Nash, 'which demonstrates that in social isolation some age faster and have greater levels of unhappiness. There may be useful comparisons with humans. The positive health effects of good social contact are estimated to be the same as the benefits of abandoning smoking.' Life expectancy for British non-smokers is six and a half years longer than for smokers.

'Christmas can be tough, even for those who are together with their families,' cautioned Phillip Hodson of the British Association for Counselling. 'However, for those who don't return to families it's even tougher. The divorced, the bereaved and those who do not make successful relationships are all omitted from the festivity, which just makes things worse.'

Nash and her team are involved in a long-term project examining community and social wellbeing in towns across Britain. Final results will be published at the end of 2002.

webTitle: Cannabis makes confused sperm swim more slowly

fields.headline: Cannabis makes confused sperm swim more slowly
fields.trailText: Smoking cannabis slows down more than your thoughts and speech. New research shows sperm swim much slower when exposed to the drug's active ingredient, increasing the chances of infertility among dope smokers.
fields.body:
Smoking cannabis slows down more than your thoughts and speech. New research shows sperm swim much slower when exposed to the drug's active ingredient, increasing the chances of infertility among dope smokers.

American scientists have studied the effects of cannabis on the chemical signals in the reproductive organs. While a small amount of the active ingredient in marijuana smoke, tetrahydrocannabinol (THC), makes sperm more alert and increases the chance of the egg being fertilised, a large dose of THC confuses the sperm, causing them to become sluggish and dopey, and so less likely to penetrate the egg.

'THC is the substance in marijuana smoke that makes people high,' said Professor Herbert Schuel of the University of Buffalo in New York State, author of the research.

'The sperm change their swimming behaviour. [With a low concentration of THC] they swim hyperactively and rapidly, waving their heads from side to side. These are the kind of sperm most likely to fertilise the egg. When the concentration was 10 times higher, the number of sperm showing hyperactivity decreased.'

Schuel examined the role of THC in the cells of the male and female reproductive systems, focusing on its relationship with a similar set of chemicals produced by the body, anandamides. These signal to sperm and nearby cells to become hyperactive by latching on to receptors on the outside wall of cells. But THC latches on to the receptors instead, leaving the anandamides adrift to build up around the sperm. Too many anandamides give the sperm an excess of signals, making them confused and sluggish.

Scientists have known for more than 40 years that cannabis damaged the production of sperm - reducing their numbers and quality - but this research marks a breakthrough in understanding how it affects the action of the sperm on the egg. Schuel first showed that THC could damage fertilisation in a series of experiments carried out in the late 1980s on sea urchins.

Infertility affects one in seven couples trying for their first pregnancy, and 40 per cent of these cases are down to problems with sperm.

Campaigners have long argued for the legalisation of marijuana, citing its medicinal properties as a painkiller and relaxant. The Government is currently assessing the effectiveness of cannabis as a painkiller and hopes to reach conclusions by the end of next year.

The anti-drugs lobby will welcome this finding as it confirms a damaging effect of the drug. Several members of the shadow cabinet recently admitted to having smoked marijuana, and 2.7 million Britons are regular users. The British spend £3.5 billion a year on the drug, and a quarter of 15-year-olds are thought to smoke or to have tried it.

fields.headline: Who needs royals?
fields.standfirst: God bless the queen of pop
fields.trailText: God bless the queen of pop.
fields.body:
When the Observer launched its campaign for Britain to become a republic, a string of pundits warned that the nation would never give up its love of royal ceremony. Was last week the one they were proved wrong?

Millions of people have vicariously enjoyed the nuptials of Mr Guy Ritchie and Miss Louise Ciccone, a foreign princess. For weeks, the popular prints have detailed the couple's genealogy. There was widespread speculation as to whether the bride's dress would be crafted by Miss Stella McCartney, daughter of a Beatle, or Miss Donatella Versace, an intimate of Sir Elton John and the late Princess of Wales. The wedding itself took place with faux Scottish traditionalism accompanied by Puccini and Bach (we all know 'Nessun Dorma' and the Toccata and Fugue, because one is a football anthem and the other a mobile-phone ditty). Mr Gordon Sumner, the artist known as Sting, sang.

Britain has had all the pleasure of a royal wedding without the tedium of watching a three-hour television ceremony during the busy Christmas week. Of equal importance, this delightful occasion did not cost us a penny. Tiaras off to the happy couple.

webTitle: Comment: Comfort out in the cold for ETA and the IRA

fields.headline: Comfort out in the cold
fields.standfirst:
Special report: violence in Spain
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Our Andulucian friends in the small town we visit every summer cannot comprehend what is going on in the Basque country. 'Loco,' the younger generation reply when you raise the spectre of renewed ETA violence at the dinner table.
fields.body:
Our Andulucian friends in the small town we visit every summer cannot comprehend what is going on in the Basque country. 'Loco,' the younger generation reply when you raise the spectre of renewed ETA violence at the dinner table.

Older Anduluz we meet on holiday recall real hunger and poverty in the decades before Franco's death, democracy was restored and Spain 'came back' to Europe. They, too, are perplexed as to why growing numbers of their fellow citizens want to break away from a state that has one of the most generous policies towards its regions in the entire EU. One of our acquaintances, Javier, who runs a taxi service that takes tourists to Granada and the Sierra Nevada, reserves a pithy riposte to those Basques demanding total independence.

'Independence?' Javier exclaims as he swerves around another treacherous bend. 'So who is Athletico Bilbao going to play against then?'

Javier's incomprehension over why the Basques would want to cede from Spain and form a mini-state with their brethren across the Pyrenees in France is founded on sound rational argument. The Basque region is (or, rather, was up until the resumption of ETA terror) one of the most prosperous in Spain. There is parity of esteem between the Basque and Spanish languages. The Basque flag proudly flies from all municipal buildings. In contrast, Irish republicans can't even force the British to allow Tricolours to be flown over Sinn Fein-controlled Ministries at Stormont. There is even a Basque-speaking regional police force. Imagine the police service of Northern Ireland as gael-gors.

There seems no end in sight to ETA's 'armed struggle', short of Madrid caving in to its demands for independence. Last Saturday's Correspondent on the BBC shone new light on ETA's violent resurgence and its fanatical faith to a cause most Europeans regard as at best quaint and at worst dangerously utopian. Phil Rees's film reminded us how an ideal can sometimes be more durable than reality. The most disturbing element of this superb documentary was the interview in Durango with two female student followers of ETA, who, barely out of their teens, talked about being Basque in Spain as if they were Jews in Nazi Germany. Of course their 'Most-Oppressed-People-Ever' rants about the oppression of Basque culture were absurd, but they were heartfelt. I imagined the visages of those attractive young women stencilled on to a banner in a few years' time, commemorated as heroes after immolating themselves while driving a car bomb.

Without didactic voice-over, the message transmitted was that ETA is a nihilistic band of fanatics with no respect for democracy. Certainly, the Conservative Spanish government's stubborn refusal, for instance, to relocate Basque prisoners from jails in Spain to ones in their homeland during the ceasefire was a major mistake. But this can never excuse the murder not only of Conservative councillors, but also those from the Left as well as journalists who dare criticise ETA actions and, above all, the ordinary civilians caught up in their terror.

There was also a subliminal warning here for those in Ireland who believe the Provisional IRA ceasefire and the Good Friday Agreement marks the end of history. If ETA, which has evolved from an anti-Franco resistance movement that splintered into different directions after democratic restoration, can find new followers among people who weren't even born during the dictatorship, then are the prospects for the Real and Continuity IRAs really that gloomy? The level of dissident republican activity and the recent acquisition of arms from Croatia prove that despite Omagh, the Real IRA, to borrow Gerry Adams's phrase 'haven't gone away, you know'.

Republican dissidents like the ETA supporters who support Athletico Bilbao don't care that no one wants to play with them. Sometimes being out in the cold, whether in Durango or Dundalk, can be perversely comforting for those well used to political isolation.

fields.headline: Three cheers for Filkin
fields.trailText: The protective web spin doctors wrap around their politicians is sometimes torn aside and we are given a glimpse of a grubbier world where a thousand ants compete for sustenance. In the case of John Reid and John Maxton, all we need to complete the illusion of nature red in tooth and claw revealed is the soothing voice of David Attenborough.

The protective web spin doctors wrap around their politicians is sometimes torn aside and we are given a glimpse of a grubbier world where a thousand ants compete for sustenance. In the case of John Reid and John Maxton, all we need to complete the illusion of nature red in tooth and claw revealed is the soothing voice of David Attenborough.

But the parliamentary commissioner for standards, Elizabeth Filkin, is a less comforting guide to the interior world of party politics. She, too, has sharp claws. Politicians who mutter that she is a officious pest pay her an unintended compliment. Her report on the complaint brought against the Secretary of State for Scotland and his backbench colleague by Dean Nelson, former Scotland editor of The Observer, is uncompromising.

Ms Filkin found that they broke parliamentary rules over the use of MPs' office expenses for party political campaigning. She concluded the Fees Office had been misled about the arrangements covering two of the researchers involved though not about the third, Reid's son, Kevin. The fact they would be working at least for some of the time for Labour's political campaign was sufficiently formal to have been included in the party's budget assumptions.

An unpleasant picture also emerges of how the MPs attempted to influence events and even 'frustrate' the inquiry. One of the key witnesses, former Scottish general secretary, Alex Rowley, taped telephone calls with Reid in which the Scottish Secretary sought to 'agree a line with Mr Rowley which falls short of a full and comprehensive account of the events of which they both have knowledge'.

The Standards and Privileges Committee, which is, of course, dominated by Labour, came galloping to the rescue like Champion the Wonder Horse. It rejected Ms Filkin's recom mendations, exonerating the MPs by bending the rules. It said that Ms Filkin's findings were on 'the balance of probabilities' but that if the complaints were to be upheld 'a higher standard of proof should apply'. No such criteria might have been applied to a Tory or to smaller Labour fry. Maxton is fortunate that he was not arraigned alone.

All these events flowed from a particularly stressful period as the party was preparing to fight the first election for the Scottish Parliament. There was intense factionalism, simplified in the media as a struggle between Blairites and Brownites.

Rowley was said to be Brown's man, Reid to be the Prime Minister's. But Rowley's real sin, in the world of New Labour, was his resolve to tell the truth, no matter the political consequences - he hopes for a parliamentary seat. It is a pity that more senior figures did not treat the commissioner with equal respect.

These factional battles were heightened by the late Donald Dewar's contempt for what he saw as disloyalty. A certain peevishness, or perhaps fastidiousness, in his temperament made him unwilling to intervene. He was never comfortable with spin and, it is said, used only part of the budget available to the First Minister for political advisers. His successor, Henry McLeish, is correcting that omission, if that is what it was. The Scottish Executive is now more spin-driven than ever before, and has one eye fixed on the Daily Record and the Sun.

From the start, it was probable that Ms Filkin's recommendations would be circumvented, though the committee includes in its own commentary a pious defence of her integrity which smacks of hypocrisy.

Finally, the report vindicates my friend and old colleague, Dean Nelson, and is a testament to his terrier-like qualities as a reporter. An independent and even bloody-minded press remains the best guarantor of parliamentary probity. The Standards and Privileges Committee is certainly not to be trusted to perform that role.
