webTitle: Comment: Right-wing coup that shames America

fields.headline: Right-wing coup that shames America
fields.standfirst: Continuing unofficial counts reveal the full extent of Al Gore's lead and the massive abuses that have put George W. Bush into power
fields.trailText: Continuing unofficial counts reveal the full extent of Al Gore's lead and the massive abuses that have put George W. Bush into power.
fields.body:
I never thought I would live to see it. There has been a right-wing coup in the United States. It is now clear beyond any doubt that the winner of the Presidential election was Al Gore. In Florida the votes are being counted unofficially in a way the Supreme Court would not permit: he was already 140 votes ahead when counting stopped for Christmas and his final lead promises to be in the thousands. Nationally he leads by over half a million votes. What has happened is beyond outrage. It is the cynical misuse of power by a conservative élite nakedly to serve its interests - and all of us should be frightened for the consequences.

The issue is not George W. Bush's conservatism, opponent though I am of what Bush plans to do; a democracy only has vitality and political tension if its philosophy and stream of thinking is articulated and pitches to win elections. The incontrovertible abuse is that Bush has won power despite losing, and critically he only pulled off this feat because the Republicans control the Supreme Court. The Right has subverted pivotal US institutions to win power - a campaign of which the discrediting and attempted impeachment of Clinton was part - and in the process disgraced the legitimacy of US democracy at home and abroad, and undermined conceptions of the rule of law. It is a poor augury for the twenty-first century.

In Britain the response has been woeful - itself a token of our own lack of hard democratic instincts. The commentary, especially in the right-of-centre press, has been to decry Gore as a poor loser and to insist that he had to accept the rules of the electoral game, respecting the votes in the US electoral college which, when Florida was lost, gave Bush the election. But as the great liberal defenders of freedom, Karl Popper and Isaiah Berlin, both argued when unjust, illegitimate governments win power through subverting the rules it is our responsibility to contest them.

The nine-member Supreme Court, apart from the heady decade of the 1960s when it advanced the cause of civil rights in the South, has always been a bastion of a regressive conservatism. In the 1930s it tried to rule that key elements in Roosevelt's New Deal were unconstitutional. Its defence of the sovereignty of states rights has been fundamental in extending capital punishment and allowing bible-belt states to resist implementing federal legislation banning violence against women. Yet its general prohibition in interfering in a state's rights has been overturned in one instance; the highly politicised intervention in Florida.

The more you examine it, the more outrageous the now famous judgement was. What the Court had to do to serve its political purpose was to find a way of acknowledging a sovereign state's rights and the continuing legitimacy of hand recounts in closely contested elections - after all George W. Bush had passed a law as Governor in Texas in 1998 endorsing hand recounts - but at the same time give the election to their Republican champion by finding that events in Florida were a special case.This was tricky. In the first place, even the conservative judges shared the unanimous view that it was reasonable for hand recounts to be undertaken because, as the judgment concedes: 'Punch card balloting machines can produce an unfortunate number of ballots which are not punched in a clean, complete way by the voter.' Consequently individual states are obliged, when the winning margin is tight, to mount an effort to find out what the 'clear intent' of each voter was. In other words Gore was completely within his rights to demand the hand recount.

The five conservatives had a problem. How could they deliver the coup? The solution was elegant. The process was too subjective, said the Supreme Court, unless the Florida court put in place even more protective measures to ensure impartiality than the Florida legislature had provided for - a position that is constitutionally impossible, as the judges knew, because it meant the Court would have to change rather than interpret Florida law. Hand recounts are thus legal in principle but impossible in practice because of possible partiality. And in a telling aside in its judgment, the Court said that hand recounts would 'cast a cloud' over Bush's 'legitimacy' that would harm 'democratic stability'. It never crossed the five-strong conservative majority's mind that the opposite might be the case; that not counting votes which would give Gore the presidency when nationally he had won half a million more votes than Bush would damage, not democratic stability, but the entire democratic principle.

But then right-wing America is not much interested in the democratic principle. It believes that its duty is to sustain America in its unique destiny as a Christian guardian of individual liberty, a place - I joke not - that will deserve Christ's second coming. It sees itself in a holy war against a liberal enemy within, and its uses every tool at its disposal ruthlessly to dispose of its foe.

The Right enjoyed 12 years of power under Reagan and Bush, lost the Presidency to Clinton in 1992 when Ross Perot split the conservative vote and pledged to continue their jihad against what they saw as his illegitimate victory from the beginning. Hence the fantasies of Whitewater. Hence the Starr inquiry into the Lewinsky affair, where now we learn key evidence was fabricated. Hence the attempted impeachment. Mud sticks, they reckoned, and even though they knew impeachment would fail, they calculated it would put any Democrat presidential candidate in 2000 in a presentational bind - association with the successful Clinton years would be attacked as an association with immorality.

But for all their efforts American public opinion remained stubbornly tolerant, sceptical of tax cuts and moderately centrist. To win Bush had to outspend his rival two to one in the last month and build on the strategic dilemma faced by Gore about the Clinton years. But even then it has taken the Supreme Court to complete the coup.

For all the talk of reconciliation Bush is building a tribal conservative administration bent on supporting business at home and asserting US unilateralism abroad. His next Treasury Secretary has been picked not for his capacity to negotiate the US and the world through the minefield of a fragile international financial system, but his interest in feathering the nests of corporate America. And so it goes on, offering the US and the world a policy and perspective not wanted by the majority of Americans.

The consensus view is that within months the whole Florida affair will be forgotten, and Bush will be installed as a legitimate US President. I don't agree. The value of democracies is they produce administrations broadly in tune with the times and will of the people, and thus able to marshal both consent and the correct policy responses for the varying crises that hit them.

Not so in America. Whether the need to respect international treaties abroad or the desire to universalise medical protection at home, the US has the man in power it did not want and whose instincts are opposite to those of the majority. This will prove a disastrous administration for America and the world, and the coup will become widely understood as a moment of partisan infamy. It is a brutal lesson for us liberals. Never, never forget the treachery and poison on the Right.

webTitle: Orange lodge refuses to expel terrorist twins

fields.headline: Orange lodge refuses to expel terrorist twins
fields.trailText: The Orange Order, which insists it will not talk to terrorists, has refused to expel two convicted loyalist extremists from its ranks.
fields.body:
The Orange Order, which insists it will not talk to terrorists, has refused to expel two convicted loyalist extremists from its ranks.

Twins Mervyn and Paul Armstrong remain members of the Boyd Memorial Orange Lodge in Antrim town, despite their conviction for terrorist offences last week. The Observer has learnt that the Armstrong brothers still belong to LOL312, a lodge whose membership includes a former UVF bomber.

John McGrath, Boyd Memorial's secretary, repeatedly refused to confirm or deny that the brothers, both terrorists with the Orange Volunteers, had been expelled. Denis Watson, secretary of the Grand Lodge of Ireland, the Orange Order's ruling body, has publicly called for anyone convicted of terrorist offences to be thrown out.

Asked why the Armstrongs were allowed to stay in the order, McGrath said: 'I don't think it's any of your business. I am not making any statement on it at all; those two lads have been through enough. This is not the business of the public, although the Orange Order doesn't approve of what those boys got themselves into.'

Mervyn Armstrong, 22, of Islandreagh Drive in Dunady, Antrim, was jailed for a total of six years. He had admitted possession of an automatic rifle and documents likely to be of use to terrorists.

His brother Paul, of the same address, was jailed for three years for assisting an offender and having documents likely to be of use to terrorists. Both men, who were studying at the University of Ulster, were members of the Orange Volunteers, a loyalist terrorist group opposed to the Good Friday Agreement.

The documents were British Army intelligence files on republican suspects in south Armagh and Belfast. An undercover RUC unit found the files, which were stolen from army headquarters in Lisburn, in nearby Stoneyford Orange Hall.

fields.headline: 'She cost me £800. And I can sell her for £250 an hour'
fields.standfirst:
'I trade in under-age girls - it's safer for me. The foreign girls don't talk - they're gaga, like babies. They'll do anything. They don't know any better' : There is a new breed of pimp in Britain, men who buy young girls from abroad and turn them into drug addicts. Amelia Hill investigates

Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: 'I trade in under-age girls - it's safer for me. The foreign girls don't talk - they're gaga, like babies. They'll do anything. They don't know any better' : There is a new breed of pimp in Britain, men who buy young girls from abroad and turn them into drug addicts. Amelia Hill investigates.
fields.body:
Carlos has always been an entrepreneur. Ever since he left his Sussex school in the early Eighties and moved away from his affluent, professional parents, the 33-year-old has dabbled with moderate success in different businesses, funded by forays into petty crime and punctuated by spells in prisons around the country.

One year ago, however, Carlos spotted a new gap in the market and moved in. This time his success was instantaneous: he claims to make between £500 and £1,500 a day, money that enables him to rule the streets of south London in his particular brand of the sex industry.

Last week, an investigation by The Observer discovered children as young as six were being sold by their families and smuggled into Britain, where they were imprisoned in west London flats and forced to work as sex slaves.

The Observer spoke to two 13-year-old girls who had managed to escape their tormenters but had ended up walking the streets of south and east London instead, trying desperately to raise the money they needed to satisfy the drug addictions cultivated by their traffickers to increase their vulnerability.

It was the first time proof had been found that Britain was being targeted by child traffickers - experts in the field admitted they were horrified. But The Observer can reveal the increase in trafficking has sparked a second vicious development in Britain's sex industry.

A new breed of pimp is taking control of the streets of Britain, buying children from abroad, encouraging them to develop addictions to crack cocaine and heroin, and then forcing them to work as prostitutes to pay off the debts accrued by their new habit.

Carlos has found that by combining the business of trafficker, drug-dealer and pimp, he has placed himself at the head of the new trend. 'Working with prostitutes is the least criminal thing I can do while raking in the maximum amount of tax-free money,' he said last week, planting his elbows on the table of the trendy Brixton bar and leaning forward with a friendly smile.

'Of course I deal with under-age girls - it's safer for me. Even then, English girls can always bring you down by talking: they've got a right mouth on them, but the foreign girls are a different matter: they don't talk, they're gaga - like babies - and they're primarily bothered about appeasing their boss and the punter. They'll do anything. They don't know any better. They don't understand the culture here, so if they're asked to do something, they don't know if it's out of order or not, and so do it anyway. They're very confused.'

Before crack became widely available on the streets of London about 12 months ago, pimps had virtually disappeared from the British sex scene. Streetworkers realised they could function just as well without the men who took their money and offered them little in return except abuse and degradation. The women started buying their own houses and setting up their own businesses, and the men faded into the background.

But the arrival of crack changed the rules of the game. Streetworkers began courting dealers - usually men - who could provide them with the drug, and it didn't take these men long to realise that, once the women were addicted and in debt, they could exert control over them.

'You can get a young girl for £2,500 from South Africa,' Carlos said, 'but the two I have at the moment cost just £800 each. They come from a deprived area in black South Africa, say they're 14 but I have my doubts - I think they're younger,' he said, pulling his cap down over his eyes and leaning back comfortably in his seat. 'They're going home in a couple of months because they've made so much money. I've been sending between £500 to £700 back to their families each week. It's a two-way deal: they help me, and I help them.'

Buying foreign children and arranging their illegal passage into the country is simple for aspiring pimps, he said. 'You give the money to the courier and they arrange it all. They get the girl from her village to your door, and then she's all yours. You don't get much choice, it's true: you ask for someone young, and she turns up. If you're lucky, she might be pretty. Sometimes she's ugly, and that's what you're stuck with.'

The girls who arrive on his doorstep leave their right to respect and choice at home, Carlos maintains. 'They're not even property: they're commodities,' he said. 'You never use force on an English girl, no matter how young she is, because she can run away or tell the police. But the foreign girls are yours: you've bought them and they have to do what you tell them.'

There are five girls working in Carlos's brothel off Brixton Hill, renting the rooms for £50 a night and depending on him to bring them crack while they work. 'We get them addicted to drugs as soon as we can because they're more docile that way,' he said. 'It's like a fishing line: you just reel them in. A good pimp will have them acting like robots by the end of the programming, which can take weeks or months, depending on how weak the girl is. They end up like cattle - you just order them around.

'My first bordello - I love that word - was in Dumbarton Court, off Brixton Hill,' he added. 'That's where I realised what a fortune there was to be made selling under-age girls. You can charge anything from £100 to £250 an hour, and even more for the foreign ones. It's particularly good working with the foreign girls because on top of everything else, I can charge what I like for the drugs I bring them. They don't know what's going on: I can tell them whatever I like.'

Iowa, a 24-year-old security guard from south London, lives in another local brothel that deals with foreign girls. He takes telephone bookings from punters and helps deal with them when they arrive. 'We call the paedophiles bacon because they're pigs,' he said. 'They're usually white, middle-class professional men who like the freshness of foreign children. They think they're unsoiled.'

This attraction doesn't last long, he admits. 'Three months on the streets for any young girl and she's not young any more,' he said. 'If you look at all those prostitutes, most are really good-looking girls, but they've been battered. Their faces have been kicked in, they don't wash and they have filthy drug habits. The young foreigners are the quickest to disintegrate: they don't even use condoms because they don't know about them. They can't go to the outreach workers for help and advice because they know that if the workers see them, they'll take them straight to the social services or to the police.'

The one thing that will never change about the market place, Iowa believes, is the punter's search for the virgin prostitute. 'That's one of the reasons they like them as young as possible,' he said. 'They ask me for virgins and I lie - and charge them £500 for the privilege. I suppose there's some idea that the foreign children are more innocent and therefore more likely to be virgins.'

Carlos knows his new line of trade would make him a pariah in his parents' society. 'I don't give a shit,' he said. 'If I start giving a shit, I would end up being a social worker. I have morals, but they get pushed out of the window. It's not for me to judge and anyway, if it wasn't me in this business, it would be someone else. At least I treat them with humanity,' he added. 'I know it's a funny thing to say but with me, they get looked after: I clothe them and give them protection. At the end of the day, I'm not forcing anyone to do anything: 80 per cent of these children know what they're coming into this country to do.'

He argues that the police have absolved themselves of their duty to protect the local prostitutes: 'There's no rape suite for prostitutes,' he said. In the absence of police back-up, he says, the girls have no choice but to turn to their own. 'If there weren't people like me around, a lot of those girls would be killed because there are some extremely nasty punters. I don't see myself as a pimp: I'm a personal manager.'

Father Shay Cullen, founder of Preda, the non-governmental organisation nominated for the 2001 Nobel Prize for its work combating the trafficking of children around the world, has watched as the power of pimps across the world has flourished alongside the trade in trafficking.

'It's terrifying,' he said. 'Local pimps are no longer local: they're all realising the benefits to be had by linking forces with trafficking groups around the world who have the power and wealth to corrupt politicians and get more or less whatever they want.

'In the 30 years I've been involved in this area, I've never seen pimps throughout the world so emboldened, confident and so damn clever.'

This time his success was instantaneous: he claims to make between £500 and £1,500 a day, money that enables him to rule the streets of south London in his particular brand of the sex industry. Last week, an investigation by The Observer discovered children as young as six were being sold by their families and smuggled into Britain, where they were imprisoned in west London flats and forced to work as sex slaves. The Observer spoke to two 13-year-old girls who had managed to escape their tormenters but had ended up walking the streets of south and east London instead, trying desperately to raise the money they needed to satisfy the drug addictions cultivated by their traffickers to increase their vulnerability. It was the first time proof had been found that Britain was being targeted by child traffickers - experts in the field admitted they were horrified. But The Observer can reveal the increase in trafficking has sparked a second vicious development in Britain's sex industry. A new breed of pimp is taking control of the streets of Britain, buying children from abroad, encouraging them to develop addictions to crack cocaine and heroin, and then forcing them to work as prostitutes to pay off the debts accrued by their new habit. Carlos has found that by combining the business of trafficker, drug-dealer and pimp, he has placed himself at the head of the new trend. 'Working with prostitutes is the least criminal thing I can do while raking in the maximum amount of tax-free money,' he said last week, planting his elbows on the table of the trendy Brixton bar and leaning forward with a friendly smile. 'Of course I deal with under-age girls - it's safer for me. Even then, English girls can always bring you down by talking: they've got a right mouth on them, but the foreign girls are a different matter: they don't talk, they're gaga - like babies - and they're primarily bothered about appeasing their boss and the punter. They'll do anything. They don't know any better. They don't understand the culture here, so if they're asked to do something, they don't know if it's out of order or not, and so do it anyway. They're very confused.' Before crack became widely available on the streets of London about 12 months ago, pimps had virtually disappeared from the British sex scene. Streetworkers realised they could function just as well without the men who took their money and offered them little in return except abuse and degradation. The women started buying their own houses and setting up their own businesses, and the men faded into the background. But the arrival of crack changed the rules of the game. Streetworkers began courting dealers - usually men - who could provide them with the drug, and it didn't take these men long to realise that, once the women were addicted and in debt, they could exert control over them. 'You can get a young girl for £2,500 from South Africa,' Carlos said, 'but the two I have at the moment cost just £800 each. They come from a deprived area in black South Africa, say they're 14 but I have my doubts - I think they're younger,' he said, pulling his cap down over his eyes and leaning back comfortably in his seat. 'They're going home in a couple of months because they've made so much money. I've been sending between £500 to £700 back to their families each week. It's a two-way deal: they help me, and I help them.' Buying foreign children and arranging their illegal passage into the country is simple for aspiring pimps, he said. 'You give the money to the courier and they arrange it all. They get the girl from her village to your door, and then she's all yours. You don't get much choice, it's true: you ask for someone young, and she turns up. If you're lucky, she might be pretty. Sometimes she's ugly, and that's what you're stuck with.' The girls who arrive on his doorstep leave their right to respect and choice at home, Carlos maintains. 'They're not even property: they're commodities,' he said. 'You never use force on an English girl, no matter how young she is, because she can run away or tell the police. But the foreign girls are yours: you've bought them and they have to do what you tell them.' There are five girls working in Carlos's brothel off Brixton Hill, renting the rooms for £50 a night and depending on him to bring them crack while they work. 'We get them addicted to drugs as soon as we can because they're more docile that way,' he said. 'It's like a fishing line: you just reel them in. A good pimp will have them acting like robots by the end of the programming, which can take weeks or months, depending on how weak the girl is. They end up like cattle - you just order them around. 'My first bordello - I love that word - was in Dumbarton Court, off Brixton Hill,' he added. 'That's where I realised what a fortune there was to be made selling under-age girls. You can charge anything from £100 to £250 an hour, and even more for the foreign ones. It's particularly good working with the foreign girls because on top of everything else, I can charge what I like for the drugs I bring them. They don't know what's going on: I can tell them whatever I like.' Iowa, a 24-year-old security guard from south London, lives in another local brothel that deals with foreign girls. He takes telephone bookings from punters and helps deal with them when they arrive. 'We call the paedophiles bacon because they're pigs,' he said. 'They're usually white, middle-class professional men who like the freshness of foreign children. They think they're unsoiled.' This attraction doesn't last long, he admits. 'Three months on the streets for any young girl and she's not young any more,' he said. 'If you look at all those prostitutes, most are really good-looking girls, but they've been battered. Their faces have been kicked in, they don't wash and they have filthy drug habits. The young foreigners are the quickest to disintegrate: they don't even use condoms because they don't know about them. They can't go to the outreach workers for help and advice because they know that if the workers see them, they'll take them straight to the social services or to the police.' The one thing that will never change about the market place, Iowa believes, is the punter's search for the virgin prostitute. 'That's one of the reasons they like them as young as possible,' he said. 'They ask me for virgins and I lie - and charge them £500 for the privilege. I suppose there's some idea that the foreign children are more innocent and therefore more likely to be virgins.' Carlos knows his new line of trade would make him a pariah in his parents' society. 'I don't give a shit,' he said. 'If I start giving a shit, I would end up being a social worker. I have morals, but they get pushed out of the window. It's not for me to judge and anyway, if it wasn't me in this business, it would be someone else. At least I treat them with humanity,' he added. 'I know it's a funny thing to say but with me, they get looked after: I clothe them and give them protection. At the end of the day, I'm not forcing anyone to do anything: 80 per cent of these children know what they're coming into this country to do.' He argues that the police have absolved themselves of their duty to protect the local prostitutes: 'There's no rape suite for prostitutes,' he said. In the absence of police back-up, he says, the girls have no choice but to turn to their own. 'If there weren't people like me around, a lot of those girls would be killed because there are some extremely nasty punters. I don't see myself as a pimp: I'm a personal manager.' Father Shay Cullen, founder of Preda, the non-governmental organisation nominated for the 2001 Nobel Prize for its work combating the trafficking of children around the world, has watched as the power of pimps across the world has flourished alongside the trade in trafficking. 'It's terrifying,' he said. 'Local pimps are no longer local: they're all realising the benefits to be had by linking forces with trafficking groups around the world who have the power and wealth to corrupt politicians and get more or less whatever they want. 'In the 30 years I've been involved in this area, I've never seen pimps throughout the world so emboldened, confident and so damn clever.' amelia.hill@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Dome Napoleon's last fight
fields.standfirst: After one extraordinary year, P.Y Gerbeau tells Gaby Hinsliff of the mistakes, the highlights - and the day he cried
fields.trailText: After one extraordinary year, P.Y Gerbeau tells Gaby Hinsliff of the mistakes, the highlights - and the day he cried.
fields.body:
P. Y. Gerbeau has booked himself on the latest possible flight home to Paris tonight for a brief Christmas with his four-year-old daughter.

While his compatriots are still digesting lunch, the hyperactive Frenchman running the Dome will be heading back to the office. Nobody could accuse him of sloth, and nor can they fault his optimism - he wanted to open on Christmas Day, until he realised there would be no public transport.

But with only a week to go before the curtain falls on the show the nation loved to hate, even the ever-bouncy Pierre Yves Gerbeau is finally letting his guard slip. The truth is that the end of 'this crazy job' will clearly be a relief.

For 10 months he has weathered personal ridicule, national outrage, financial chaos and a Portakabin office that leaks when it rains. Did he never consider leaving?

'Kind of every day,' he says ruefully. He and David James, the City troubleshooter hired in the summer, take turns to be desppairing and to cheer each other up, he says.

'We take a coffee every morning together and it's pretty much like helping each other survive: "So what happened to you today?" Finding the sense of humour to bring back the fighting spirit for the day - it's like a daily fight.

'It's all about the glass half empty or half full: I always look at the half full part or I would have jumped out of a window by now.'

His current battle is to ensure that the job prospects of the thousands of staff losing their posts next Sunday are not blighted by the Dome. Gerbeau says he is defending its legacy for their sakes.

'My frustration is that we have turned around a failing product into a world-class attraction,' he insists. 'I am trying to get the credit for that for my people, who are going to be on the work mar ket, so that they are not taking the blame for political mistakes.'

He lists those mistakes frankly: a ridiculous 12 million visitors target devised, he says, to make the maths add up; expecting to break even in one year; inadequate contingency and marketing budgets. But most pernicious of all, he thinks, was that the Westminster warfare overshadowed anything the Dome might have achieved.

'I don't think it is construc tive at all to name and shame and blame. That just hurts people, and there were too many people hurt in this place already,' he says.

'But you have seven or eight different government departments [responsible for the Dome]. You are getting instructions from all over the place, it's all conflicting information, it's very hard running a business like that.

'But on the other side, it was very unfair too that the Dome became the ultimate weapon for the Conservatives. I am not a political expert - although I am becoming one - but every day we were in trouble the Conservatives were jumping on our throats to use this as a weapon against the Government.'

He is a 'big fan' of Tony Blair - at least since the Prime Minister granted his pleas to visit the Dome last week. 'I thought it took a lot of courage, because he knew it is not a good story for him to show up. Obviously he has got advisers who I am sure were saying "don't go, don't go" but he went and did a fantastic inspirational speech.'

Meanwhile, there will be a staff party on Friday, a chance 'to hug each other and say "we have survived and we have made it".' Gerbeau talks about his year as if it were like surviving a war. Perhaps unsurprisingly, his role model is Napoleon.

His other hero is his formidable 98-year-old grandmother, a former Resistance fighter and businesswoman who instilled a lifelong Anglophilia in him. He will stay in London when his job ends.

There have been rumours of a love-hate relationship between himself and David James. His critics argue that it is the lower-profile James who really sorted out the finances: and that while Gerbeau now rubbishes the visitor figures, his first revised estimate of 10 million was also unrealistic.

If nothing else, the 'funny little Frenchman' with his hedgehog hair has emerged from a debacle that broke better-known men and women as almost the only one with his reputation intact.

It is partly his disarming manner: P.Y. gets recognised in supermarkets and is in line for a £100,000 bonus, but he turned down the swanky London town house and limo offered him in return for a tiny cottage in Greenwich, 'a kind of terrible hole, a very very small place where it's not fun to go back'.

But the humble lifestyle disguises a healthy ego. Gerbeau describes his past as 'very successful', admitting he could be 'arrogant and ambitious': he is proud both of his former career as an international ice hockey player - ended abruptly by an ankle injury in his twenties - and his subsequent career with Euro Disney.

Early jibes that the Government had got the wrong guy - no Disney whizzkid, but a junior executive in charge of car parks - still rankle. 'But I said to myself, fix this business in a spectacular way and then they will know.'

He was also hurt by scrutiny of his private life. His first marriage collapsed after his injury: his relationship with the mother of his daughter foundered because he was always working. 'Everybody should be very happy I am a workaholic in this job,' he says defensively. His retreat from the pressures is the nearby Royal Blackheath golf club, where they hide the newspapers so he can forget about the Dome, and a day a month in Paris with his daughter. It is a lonely life, but he seems used to it.

'Maybe this is the way I am happy. When you are 18 years old, training six hours a day and on the road with hockey and all your friends are going to parties getting smashed, it was difficult because they were having all the fun, but it's all about making choices. My objective now is to find a balance because you are a better businessman if you do.'

He leaves in mid-January - two weeks early so he does not have to watch the Dome being gutted - for a golfing holiday in Florida. But after that, what he really wants is another lost corporate cause to turn around.

The Britain in Europe campain could do worse than sign him up: the single currency is, he says, 'the only way to go forward' and does not threaten national traditions. 'The single currency was viewed as a big bad dog, the ultimate attack against our culture, when I think it is helpful to have a united front of Europe,' he explains.

And he has been offered a marketing job, book deals, even a career in the media, but says this is not what he really wants. 'My next step is really to focus on this - that my people are secured first.'

In the whole tumultuous year, he says, he cried only once. It was just after his birthday in October: the Dome sale had collapsed, and exhausted, he flew back from France to break more bad news to his staff.

Instead of lynching him, they gave him a standing ovation, which finished him off. 'It was just event after event that week and it was absolutely dreadful. I thought: I can't take this any more. You know your people are going to be disappointed because you have got to give them bad news again. When you have got 1,200 people really under difficult conditions supporting you_ I really lost it.'

Gerbeau will focus to the end for their sakes, he says. Today the Dome has slashed tickets to £1: his critics say it is a desperate lunge for visitors, Gerbeau that it is for the poor. 'I was a garbage boy for three months after hockey, I know what it's like. To live next door to something and not be able to afford to go - I don't want to be seen as some kind of guy just out there to make money.'

The Dome is, admittedly, unlikely to be remembered for ruthlessly pursuing profits. But if it is remembered at all fondly for its Monsieur le Gerbil, that would be a legacy for him to savour.

webTitle: Leader: In with the old, out with the new

fields.headline: In with the old, out with the new
fields.standfirst: Human values have ruled in 2000
fields.trailText: Human values have ruled in 2000.
fields.body:
The year 2000, you will recall, was going to be the year when humanity was digitalised. The experts told us to invest all our hopes and dreams in the e-revolution. As experts tend to be, they could not have been proved more wrong.

While those cutting-edge Americans wasted billions of dollars inoculating their computers against the millennium bug which never bit, the humanly shambolic Italians didn't do a thing and were in the money. Predictions of the perils of new technology did not come true, and neither did the forecasts that it would take over the world. Boom.com turned into Bust.com. Only a minuscule proportion of shopping this Christmas has been done on-line.

As they always have, the high streets and department stores heave with herds of gift hunter-gatherers. Could it be that people actually enjoy each other's company? This season's hot toy is not a games console - it is Tracey Island, headquarters of the 30-year-old Thunderbirds family who, even in their remastered form, show their puppet strings attached. FAB. Many families will spend Boxing Day gathered around the old-fangled wireless and tune into the Home Service's day-long broadcast of Harry Potter, a charmingly timeless tale of boy heroes and wizardry.

The Observer has never been a Luddite, technophobic newspaper. That doesn't prevent us celebrating the consternation of the ambitions of those who would chop us into atomised digital chunks, hard-wired to terminals and Wap phones, removed from fleshy contact with each other. Technology has an important place in most people's lives, but it is never going to be a substitute for having a life. Indeed, as we report today, new research suggests that one of the most reliable ways to extend your life is to spend this season in the company of friends and loved ones.

We wish a merry Christmas to all The Observer 's readers. More than that, we wish you a warmly human Christmas, too.

fields.headline: Branson attacks 'no-risk' British culture
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson has launched a scathing attack on Britain's 'safety first' culture, which he says is stifling the country's entrepreneurial spirit and leaving it lagging behind the US.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson has launched a scathing attack on Britain's 'safety first' culture, which he says is stifling the country's entrepreneurial spirit and leaving it lagging behind the US.

Speaking to The Observer from his private island in the Caribbean, Branson said that Britain's decision-makers were too conservative and would always go for the 'more of the same' option rather than take a risk.

Branson's outspoken attack comes days after it was announced that his People's Lottery consortium had lost the battle to run the National Lottery. He has now given Lord Burns, head of the National Lottery Commission - which made the decision to award the Lottery to Camelot - until 5 January to come up with compelling reasons for the move. If he is not satisfied with the answers he has pledged to launch a legal challenge..

Branson said: 'The dilemma is, do we bow out gracefully, or do we fight? We certainly haven't decided [on legal action] but we want a bloody good explanation and would like somebody to convince us that they know what the hell they are talking about.'

In a letter to Burns, former Permanent Secretary at the Treasury, Branson said that four months ago the commission agreed that he had a robust and credible bid. The letter asks how the commission reached a second, 'diametrically opposed' decision last week.

'Neither side were allowed to change the fundamentals of their bids,' Branson said, referring to the re-opening of the bidding process in September following the successful legal challenge by Camelot against the original decision to award the Lottery to the People's Lottery.

Concern is now growing that if Branson launches a second legal challenge it could jeopardise the smooth handover of the Lottery next autumn. For every day that the Lottery did not operate, £4 million would be lost to good causes.

Branson said that the decision to award the new Lottery licence to Camelot sent a very negative message to the country's innovators which would eventually lead to a decline in economic performance and poorer public services.

'You've got to have a country where people are willing to take risks,' Branson said. 'It is far, far tougher to be an entrepreneur here than it is in America.'

fields.headline: Transport misery for Christmas
fields.trailText: Tens of thousands of travellers faced long delays, packed trains and traffic jams yesterday as Britain's creaking transport system struggled to cope with massive Christmas demand, write Jason Burke and Paul Harris.
fields.body:
Tens of thousands of travellers faced long delays, packed trains and traffic jams yesterday as Britain's creaking transport system struggled to cope with massive Christmas demand, write Jason Burke and Paul Harris.

Many of the speed restrictions imposed by Railtrack after the Hatfield crash remain in place and most rail operators are running a reduced timetable.

Railtrack is preparing its largest ever Christmas engineering programme.

Motoring organisations had predicted a 30 per cent increase in the amount of traffic. Victoria coach station was a scene of chaos as staff tried to manage their busiest day for 10 years.

Traffic on the M4, M5 and M6 was slow-moving - although without major tailbacks.

Airports all reported busy days - two million people are expected to travel by air over Christmas.

fields.headline: A Happ-e Yule for Amazon
fields.trailText: Amazon looks like winning the race to become the UK's number one Christmas e-tailer.
fields.body:
Amazon looks like winning the race to become the UK's number one Christmas e-tailer.

Despite recent gloom surrounding the dotcom sector, new research by analysts at market consultancy AC Nielsen shows that in the run-up to the festive period the Amazon.co.uk site saw a 40 per cent surge in visitors.

In November the online bookseller became the first UK shopping site to break the million-user mark, attracting 1.2 million visitors, up from 865,000 in October.

Rival Bol.com saw its number of visitors rise dramatically from 134,000 to 219,000 over the same period. Electrical e-tailer Buy.com saw visitors to its site jump from 140,000 to more than 244,000. Overall, visitors to UK online shopping sites increased by 10 per cent between October and November.

The last 12 months have seen a number of high-profile e-tail companies collapse. Fashion e-tailer Boo crashed after burning up £100 million, ClickMango, the online cosmetic outfit promoted by Joanna Lumley, followed soon after, while pan-European CD seller Boxman failed to find a buyer.

David Day, director of analytical services at AC Niel-sen, said the new figures showed that some e-tailers could have viable business models. 'This time last year there was a lot of hype around e-commerce that didn't live up to the promise. But these figures show that however the sector as a whole performs there will be some winners this Christmas.'

He warned that the number of visitors to an e-tail site meant nothing if their visits failed to translate into sales. 'Amazon has had a tough year and will be delighted with its audience growth to date. But the key is whether the lookers translate into bookers.'

However, the research will fire a warning shot across the bows of pure dotcom companies. Day said: 'We're seeing established names like Comet and Dixons coming through so strongly now. More and more, trusted brands are finding themselves among the biggest players in UK online retail and this trend certainly will continue .'

webTitle: Football's coming home amid ruins of Chechnya

fields.headline: Football's coming home amid ruins of Chechnya
fields.standfirst: Special report: crisis in Chechnya
fields.trailText: The long-defunct Chechen football team Terek Grozny, formerly based in the region's now shattered capital, has applied to be re-admitted to the Russian league.
fields.body:
The long-defunct Chechen football team Terek Grozny, formerly based in the region's now shattered capital, has applied to be re-admitted to the Russian league.

All of the country's stadiums have been destroyed and the team's star players have defected to rival teams in more peaceful parts of Russia or left to join the fighting which has devastated the republic. Regional sport officials are optimistic that popular affection for the team will help overcome these obstacles.

The Russian Football Union in Moscow is considering a request for Terek Grozny to be included in the championship for next season, but has expressed anxiety about the potential 'security implications' of letting the club back into the league.

Terek made it to Russia's first division in the early 1990s and had strong support from fans across the region. Rebel leader Shamil Basayaev is rumoured to have played for the team before he had his foot and part of his leg amputated as a result of a battle injury. The club was forced to disband when a new separatist Chechen leadership declared independence from Russia in 1991 and the regional football league collapsed soon after Russian forces invaded the country in 1994.

The pro-Kremlin Chechen leadership - which has been charged with overseeing the reconstruction of the region's ruined infrastructure - hopes the resurrection of the club would be an inspiring sign of life continuing in the face of ongoing fighting.

Akhmed Kadyrov, head of the Kremlin-appointed Chechen administration, has agreed to be the club's honorary president and has promised to divert some of a 12 million rouble (£300,000) grant for the new, optimistically conceived Chechen Tourism Department to pay for the project.

'Before the fighting began, Terek Grozny was a very talented team, but then everything fell apart,' said Taus Dzhabrailov, an official in Kadyrov's office. 'The Chechen leadership was only interested in preparing its forces and in training men to fight. The region's sportsmen received no support and all of the talented footballers left.

'But Chechens have always loved football, and despite the fighting every village still has its own team. Reviving Terek is an important part of the rebuilding process.'

Khaidar Aukhanov, a former Terek idol, who now works in the Kadyrov administration, is struggling to resolve the question of grounds for the club. Plans to restore the Grozny stadium where they used to play are under discussion but are not likely to be realised quickly. Money is short, but more crucially the Chechen capital, nominally under the control of Russian forces, remains a war zone.

Federal aviation continues a sporadic bombing campaign on the city, and at the end of last month Russian troops destroyed the central market, main source of food for the people, claiming it was being used as guerrilla headquarters.

In any case, reconstruction of a football stadium - when hospitals, apartment blocks, schools and universities have been destroyed and electricity, telephone and gas structures have collapsed - is unlikely to be made a priority.

In the interim, the team hopes to rent premises in neighbouring regions. Attracting back the players may also prove a problem. Those who support the Chechen rebel cause of independence will refuse to play for a team within a Russian league. Those who have left the region for more stable teams elsewhere may be reluctant to return to the war-torn region.

The Russian Football Union is to make a decision later this week on whether to accept Terek's application. Vladimir Radionov, the general secretary, told sports journal Soviet Sport : 'We are concerned about safety issues, both from the point of view of the participants and spectators; we need to have some kind of security guarantee.'

webTitle: Nation to spend £12.5bn on festive gifts, food and drink

fields.headline: Nation to spend £12.5bn on festive gifts, food and drink
fields.standfirst: Special report: Christmas 2000
fields.trailText: Despite the weather, the nightmare of crowds and a collapsing rail system, British shoppers turned out in droves to make this year the most expensive Christmas.
fields.body:
Despite the weather, the nightmare of crowds and a collapsing rail system, British shoppers turned out in droves to make this year the most expensive Christmas.

Experts believe the nation will spend £12.5 billion on gifts for loved ones and the food and drink that most families need to consume to get through the festive season.

The figure is 5 per cent up on last year and continues an upwards trend that probably started when Father Christmas first got behind the reins of his sleigh.

And in a tradition stretching back to Cabbage Patch Kids, Christmas would not be Christmas without a 'must-have' gift to send parents into a frenzy - Sony's games console PlayStation 2. Hampered by a lack of supplies, the chances of one of these treasures sitting under a Christmas tree are tiny unless money is no option.

Harrods, in London, was able to stock only 24 of the consoles. The retail price is £579, but on the Amazon internet auction site one British seller is offering an unopened console for sale with bids starting at £1,800. Black market consoles are selling for up to £3,000.

'If we had been able to stock a thousand, we would have sold a thousand. As it was the ones we were able to get were cleared off the shelves in about 30 seconds,' said Harrods spokesman Peter Willasey.

Other top sellers this year have been mobile phones. Thousands of chromed mini-scooters too have been sold, either as gifts for children or as 'executive toys' for City workers in a hurry.

Also raising a glass to toast the annual binge will be drinks and tobacco firms. Over the Christmas period the average person will down 23 pints of beer, five measures of spirits and three bottles of wine. More than a quarter of all the blended whisky drunk in a year is consumed at Yuletide.

However, champagne sales have dropped off, though this has been blamed on the 'Millennium effect' which boosted figures at the end of last year. Other not so hot items this year are Japanese toys Pokémon and Furby, which irritated parents and delighted children last year. Instead, more traditional play items have made a comeback with Tracy Island, a model of the Thunderbirds base, selling well.

One thing that is changing about Christmas is the growth of shopping over the internet. Amazon.co.uk has received more than 3 million orders since the start of November.

The deadline for guaranteed delivery passed almost a week ago. But Lastminute.com customers can buy certain gifts up to 4pm on Christmas Eve and still have them delivered before the big day.

However, Christmas would not be Christmas without an element of Scrooge and a new survey has revealed that one in four Christmas shoppers are also buying gifts for themselves.

webTitle: Literary editor's review of the year

fields.headline: Underwhelmed
fields.trailText: If 1900 was oysters and champagne, 2000 is a pint of lager and a packet of crisps
fields.body:
The first year of the new millennium has not, I submit, been an exceptional one for books. By contrast, the dawn of the twentieth century saw the publication of Conrad's Lord Jim, Dreiser's Sister Carrie, Well's Love and Mr Lewisham and Freud's Interpretation of Dreams. It was also the year in which Ruskin, Nietzsche and Wilde died. Looking further afield culturally, it also witnessed Puccini's Tosca, Mahler's Fourth Symphony and Elgar's Dream of Gerontius.

This is with hindsight, of course, but on the evidence of what's crossed the literary radar so far, it's a hard act to equal, let alone surpass. If 1900 was oysters and champagne, 2000 is a pint of lager and a packet of crisps.

The literary debut of the year, which The Observer was among the first to salute, was Zadie Smith's White Teeth. It's perhaps too early to say exactly how good this novel is, but there's no doubt that it marks an important literary watershed in much the same way as the publication of Midnight's Children or The Buddha of Suburbia. Certainly, Smith has been influenced by Rushdie and Kureishi, but she is triumphantly original and unquestionably a new writer to watch closely.

Another, rather different, milestone occurred in March with the launch of the online edition of the Oxford English Dictionary. The experience of voyaging through cyberspace at www.oed.com was an extraordinary one and a vivid reminder that we are living through a second Gutenberg revolution. Many commentators have argued recently that the language used in some form by about one third of the world's population should be known as World English. With the publication of the OED Online, that moment has surely arrived. As the year ends, the dot.com bulls have become bearish. The mad dreams inspired by internet mania are fading in the harsh light of economic reality. But it's hard to see how we can ever look at lexicography in the same way again.

One literary phenomenon which will surely have a secure place in the next edition of the OED is young Harry Potter. In July, Pottermania swept the English-speaking world with the publication of the voluminous Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire. I spent a long summer Saturday reading and then reviewing HPIV (as it's known).

In smart literary circles, it's become fashionable to disparage J.K. Rowling, but there's no escaping the fact that her success is based not on hype, but on that pure gold of publishing - word of mouth. Love it or loathe it, there are hundreds of thousands of readers out there who cannot get enough of Harry Potter. I still find her prose as flat (and as English) as old beer, and Harry himself is a cipher, without depth or subtlety. But her storytelling is highly accomplished and her stories (to her myriad fans) unputdownable. J.K. Rowling has mastered the first (perhaps the only) three lessons of bestsellerism: plot, plot and more plot.

HPIV was an example of a book that created its moment by force of advance publicity. The Observer 's Andrew Rawnsley had a succès fou with Servants of the People, which was the exact opposite, a gripping example of the right book published at the right time. With the Government reeling from the petrol protest, Rawnsley's compelling, and almost incredible, portrait of the inner councils of New Labour seemed to be the perfect commentary on New Labour's inferiority complex.

Not one of the other hotly-tipped political blockbusters of the autumn (Heseltine's memoirs, Clark's and Ashdown's diaries) generated anything like the same heat, or even light.

If there was a reassertion of old Labour values it came not from Westminster, but from an ex-schoolteacher living in Oxfordshire. The Amber Spyglass, the concluding volume of Philip Pullman's critically acclaimed trilogy, His Dark Materials, is a brilliant fantasy replete with a subtle assertion of the political and cultural values I grew up with, values which have been ruthlessly trampled on and betrayed by New Labour.

And so to the greatest and most welcome return to form of a writer who last found national acclaim in the dark days of the Seventies. John le Carré's The Constant Gardener is a passionate and enthralling examination of the West's failure to deal with things that the end of communism should have made it easier to confront - corporate greed and domestic political corruption. As an examination of the human soul in the age of No Logo (another notable publication of the year), it must stand a better chance than most of surviving into the near and middle future.

Finally, on an elegiac note, no review of this year should conclude without a remembrance of the poet Adrian Henri. He was eclectic, he was free and his poems were a celebration of love. I bet he'll be read with delight in the year 2101 and beyond.

And what's more...

webTitle: Review: The Wandering Jews by Joseph Roth

fields.headline: The ghetto blaster
fields.standfirst: Adam Mars-Jones is unsettled by  Joseph Roth's  The Wandering Jews
fields.trailText: Adam Mars-Jones is unsettled by Joseph Roth's The Wandering Jews
fields.body:
The Wandering Jews

Joseph Roth

translated by Michael Hoffman

Granta £12.99, pp146

Buy it at BOL

This rich and rather baffling little book, written in the 1920s and only now appearing in English, is the workof a novelist who was also one of the highest-paid journalists of his time. Joseph Roth's Foreword is pugnacious, listing those by whom 'this book does not want to be read', among them those who want to distance themselves from their embarrassing forefathers, and 'objective' readers who, 'out of sheer humanity, are struck with pity at inadequate sewage systems, and whose fear of contagion leads them to lock up poor immigrants in tenements where social problems are solved by simple epidemics'.

His journalism is usually impressionistic, though it breaks out occasionally, as the translator drily remarks in his Preface, into 'anxiety and statistics'. This, for instance, is from his description of the Jewish quarter of Odessa: 'The evening there is a curse, the rising moon a mockery. A thick fog presses down like a condemnation behind each window, which also serves as a door, is the workshop; behind that is the bed. Over the bed are the children, suspended in bassinets, which misery rocks to and fro.' An evocation of Yom Kippur uses a similarly literary register: 'Heavy tears trickle down their old beards, and their hunger is taken away by so much pain in their souls and by the immemorial melodies that fill their ecstatic ears.'

Roth's gift of phrasing, which can switch without warning from lyrical sentiment to irony, never deserts him, but the clarity, though intense, is local. It would be unreasonable to expect a responsible commentator to be satisfied with any one of the options open to European Jews at the time - assimilation, emigration, Zionism - but in different parts of the book Roth seems to be on both sides of every question.

Assimilation is a form of cultural suicide, given the 'deadly, antiseptic boredom' of Western civilisation. Jews newly arrived in the West, who compromised their traditions, 'gave themselves up. They lost themselves. They shed their aura of sad beauty. Instead, a dust-grey layer of suffering without meaning and anxiety without tragedy settled on their stooped backs'. Sometimes, he seems doctrinaire as well as simply unsympathetic - 'The assimilation of a people always begins with the women'. For Jews who have so identified themselves with their country of residence as to fight and die in wars he reserves his harshest verdict: 'I blame them for it.'

Zionism, though, is no sort of answer, already in its way a byproduct of assimilation since nationality is a Western invention. Roth more or less treats nationhood as an aspect of their history that Jews have overcome. Way back in the past, they defended their borders, conquered cities, crowned kings and paid them taxes. Why regress, when nations invariably have 'vested interests that insist on sacrifices'? By defining the essence of Jewish experience as he does, Roth is able to engineer a superb paradox, that any future Palestine might be a sovereign nation - 'but it wouldn't have any Jews in it'.

As for emigration, it can't be considered separately from the question 'where to?', and Roth is unconvinced by any destination. He pictures emigrants to America languishing behind bars on Ellis Island in an interminable quarantine, dreaming that their children will become 'kings of some mineral or manufactured substance'. He has more faith in the good intentions of Soviet Russia (a faith nervously reasserted in his preface to the new edition of 1937). But even there, the best-case scenario is only assimilation into minority nation status. Though as an ideologue of the Left he can salute the freeing of the victim from his torments and the bully from his compulsion, he is still attached in some way to hardly compatible religious ideas of 'the divine grace of suffering'.

The strangest thing about The Wandering Jews, as Hoffman acknowledges, is that Roth nowhere identifies himself as Jewish. When he says 'we' or 'us', he means Western Europeans, indeed Germans, and it's hard to describe this as anything but assimilation. The cultural law that Jewish jokes can legitimately be told only by self-identified Jews seems to govern passages where the irony is hard to assess, like his jaunty tribute to the heroism of Jews who chose to mutilate themselves rather than serve in the Great War. The book is full of passages that seem close to contempt: 'The Eastern Jew is afraid of ships. He doesn't trust them.' 'Jews are easily moved - I knew that. But I didn't know they could be moved by homesickness.' If his intention was to avoid special pleading, then it is an admirable one, but the effect is still highly unsettling. No doubt our modern commentaries are vitiated by a debased politics of personal authenticity. But the combination of passion and the third person will always stir echoes of the rhetoric of hatred, even when the intention is quite opposite: to create a rhetoric of love.

webTitle: The Wrong Boy, written and read by Willy Russell

fields.headline: The Wrong Boy, written and read by Willy Russell
fields.standfirst:
Harper Collins
£12.99
Buy the book at BOL
fields.trailText: Willy Russell doesn't read - he performs. With his Rochdale accent, flattened adolescent intonation, his whispering, jibbering and shouting, he fills the listener's head
fields.body:
If Albert Goldberg's wasp-stung willy hadn't swollen up so painfully, no one would ever have known about the innocent fly-trapping craze down by the canal, and very ordinary Raymond Marks would never have been suspended from primary school. He'd never have become the Wrong Boy.

Raymond's life is full of 'if onlys'. If only he hadn't thrown himself into the canal to retrieve the boy he used to be, the boy his mother used to love and make milky coffee for, at the very moment the little girl was fleeing from her father's assault... If only Raymond's tough old Gran, who always fought for him, hadn't lost interest in everything except Kentucky Fried Chicken.

As it is, Raymond's life is a heart-breaking tale of how our social system can destroy a boy dealt a poor hand. It's rescued from tragedy by wicked humour, a tremendously gutsy narrative voice, and an ending suggestive of real hope. Willy Russell doesn't read - he performs. With his Rochdale accent, flattened adolescent intonation, his whispering, jibbering and shouting, he fills the listener's head - and creates Raymond, the real boy. It's a remarkable performance and should be compulsory listening for those hot on tackling crime without trying to understand the causes of crime.

fields.headline: Idealism, fighting and hope
fields.trailText: Michael Mellor finds radiant images in Andreï Makine's Confessions of a Lapsed Standard-bearer plus Hurricane: The Life of Rubin Carter, Fighter; The Politics of Hope; Driving the Heart and The Haunt
fields.body:
Confessions of a Lapsed Standard-bearer
Andreï Makine
Sceptre £6.99 , pp136
Buy it at BOL

Addressing his friend Arkady - long since departed for the New World - Alyosha, chronicler of the Old, recounts their times together in the Young Pioneer Troop, singing, as they marched, of a 'superior tribe, untouched by the imperfections of communal life'.

In fact, the troops were marched in circles to protract their exercise, and as the narrative gyres outwards from the shaded courtyard of home - the domino players and scrap of sky - some part of Stalin's corroded dream crumbles away. Yet the movement is not from idealism to cynicism, but illusion to wisdom. Translated from the author's second language, the poetry remains blindingly brilliant, the spiral momentum bringing the reader back to its radiant images, again and again.

Hurricane: The Life of Rubin Carter, Fighter
James S. Hirsch
Fourth Estate £7.99, pp358
Buy it at BOL

Rubin Carter, who looked like he had 'muscles he hadn't even rippled', felled the US Army's champion in his first fight and won the first honorary world-championship belt. After becoming the victim of one of America's most notorious miscarriages of justice, Carter showed himself to be the very spirit of defiance, denying the existence of the prison as his suit rotted off his back in solitary.

Carter had supported Malcolm X and Martin Luther King and run guns for Biko, making him an ideal target for a preposterous frame-up when Paterson's police force became fanatical about charging someone for the city's most horrific triple-shooting. Muhammad Ali campaigned for Carter's exoneration and Dylan wrote one of his finest protest songs on his behalf. Hurricane has all the ingredients of tragedy: phenomenal physical and mental heroism, eloquence and exactitude, universal resonance but also historical truth.

The Politics of Hope
Jonathan Sacks
Vintage £7.99, pp295
Buy it at BOL

Regardless of your beliefs, in separating the Church and State, modern society has lost much. State laws are prohibitive and restrictive, rather than cautionary, advisory and (ideally) liberating, as moral codes are more likely to be. However, coercion to believe cannot bring about true belief, let alone community, and Hobbes's arguments against the legitimacy of ecclesiastical power are given due consideration, as are those of every major thinker from Aristotle to Marx. Sacks demonstrates the need for 'covenantal' as opposed to contractual relationships, preferring mutuality and trust to legal or financial power. A good society, by his defini tion, is one that 'offers its members equal access to hope'. A splendid book should guarantee its readers the same equal access to understanding and encouragement; there is no doubting that is is one such book.

Driving the Heart
Jason Brown
Vintage £6.99, pp 224
Buy it at BOL

Eking out existences as organ deliverymen, coroners and addicts, Brown's cast could just as easily have found a home in the lyrics of a Springsteen album - the recently revived Nebraska in particular. Anonymous, marginalised and clinging to every scrap of hope a childhood memory or glimpse of the American Dream affords, they never quite descend into pessimism (as parents, pets and transplant organs die) but neither do they succeed in any of their endeavours. What propels them, and the reader, is more like morbid curiosity. The longest story is almost a crash course in forensics; as a whole, this is a view of the human body and mind rarely seen, under unflattering lights. Superficially, the language is functional and the stories repetitive, but having pursued this lost highway to the bitter end, from gloaming to pale dawn, it is tempting to turn round and make the trip once more.

The Haunt
A. L. Barker
Virago £6.99, pp185
Buy it at BOL

A peculiar and brittle book, the haunt of the title is the Bellechasse Hotel, where normality is left at the door and lives and distorted memories intersect. An agony uncle is pursued by an investigative journalist, Senga (Agnes backwards); an artist refuses to let a relationship end; an old woman reads and rereads the romanticised dogfights of a dead Luftwaffe pilot she once found in her tree; an eccentric New Age type tries to convince her pragmatist husband he can heal the sick and lame.

Barker has a rare economy of expression, but there's no rationing of emotion. Ultimately, this is as intriguing as a dream that refuses to divulge its meaning. It hints at hidden, perhaps disturbing, things but does so with a fragmentary, perverse charm.

webTitle: Review:   Take Me To The River by Al Green

fields.headline: The soul man was born  to sing. But not to write
fields.standfirst: Burhan Wazir finds Al Green's  Take Me To The River a flawed read
fields.trailText: Burhan Wazir finds Al Green's Take Me To The River a flawed read
fields.body:
Take Me To The River

Al Green (as told to Davin Shay)

Payback Press £14.99, pp350

Buy it at BOL

Schizophrenia is not a trait normally associated with Al Green. As the last soul titan of his era, he remains etched in the annals of pop culture as a debonair figure, a product of the cultural boom in American urban pop.

Yet only three pages into his autobiography, the singer illustrates his identity crisis. He writes: 'There's Al Green, the last of the Great Soul Men; Al Green, the Country Preacher with the common touch; and Al Green, the family man. And most of the time you never know which Al you're going to get. And neither does he.'

Green rose to fame in the early Seventies: a heart-throb balladeer for black America, with a string of hits including 'Tired Of Being Alone', 'Let's Stay Together', 'I'm Still In Love With You'. Backed by Willie Mitchell's Hi Records' soul orchestra, Green's dazzling voice sang of both romance and his concern for the faltering civil rights movement. For a handful of years at the start of the Seventies, he could do little wrong.

Green's career trajectory knew no limits: and he enjoyed the benefits of his poster-boy image. In Take Me To The River, however, he circumnavigates his excesses, relegating them to a misspent youth. In October 1974, at the height of his creative powers, Green's former girlfriend, Mary Woodson, broke into his Memphis home and poured boiling grits on him as he was bathing. She later committed suicide.

Green interpreted the incident as a sign from God that he should enter the ministry, and in 1976, he purchased the Full Gospel Tabernacle in Memphis, where he preaches to this day. Here, he writes: 'Who can say why one man is born again and another stays dead in his sins? Who knows why God picks one and passes over the other? None of us can say what the plan of God may be for our lives, the number of our days, or the purpose to which they will be put. But I do know this: The choices we make follow after us, lifting us up or dragging us down. God may choose you or me or anybody He pleases. But we have to choose back, every minute of every day.'

The born-again psychoanalysis is particularly dissatisfying: Take Me To The River is part of Green's reinvention. The singer has, throughout the past 25 years, sought to distance himself from his repertoire and reputation - only occasionally resurfacing for a handful of shows. His reputation now solely rests on a handful of early-Seventies albums - Al Green Gets Next To You, Let's Stay Together, Call Me, Al Green Explores Your Mind and Belle. A pop album, touted since the early Nineties, has failed to surface. And the potential of that lyrical voice ebbs away year after year.

Ultimately, the book is little more than a seriously flawed read - disengaging the reader with half-memories and biblical sermons. At times, it reads like an exercise in self-help. Compared with comprehensive soul biographies of the past - Doug Carter's The Black Elvis: Jackie Wilson, Steve Turner's Trouble Man: The Life and Death of Marvin Gaye and Daniel Wolff's You Send Me: The Life and Times of Sam Cooke - Green's effort fails to contextualise his career. By the last page, that soaring voice has barely been explained and the singer remains as intangible as ever.

webTitle: Review: Nabokov's Blues by  Johnson and Coates

fields.headline: Got those old butterfly blues
fields.standfirst: Lucy Moore finds that Nabokov's passion for writing was matched only by his lepidopterous pursuits in Johnson and Coates' Nabokov's Blues
fields.trailText: Lucy Moore finds that Nabokov's passion for writing was matched only by his lepidopterous pursuits in Johnson and Coates' Nabokov's Blues
fields.body:
Nabokov's Blues

Kurt Johnson & Steve Coates

Zoland Books £18.99, pp372

'The more things we know, the better equipped we are to understand any one thing and it is a burning pity that our lives are not long enough and not sufficiently free of annoying obstacles, to study all things with the same care and depth,' said Vladimir Nabokov to his literature students in 1946. At this time, Nabokov was one of the best-known Russian writers in the world, but his great works in English were as yet unwritten. He still harboured ambitions of success in another field: lepidoptery - the study of butterflies. While he became perhaps the first modern literary celebrity after the publication of Lolita in 1958, scientific recognition always eluded him.

Earlier this year, Nabokov's biographer, Brian Boyd, brought out a selection of Nabokov's lepidopteral writings, both fictional and scientific, fittingly entitled Nabokov's Butterflies, its cover adorned with a charming photograph of a be-shorted Nabokov, net grasped firmly in hand, and the fixed glare of the collector in his eyes.

Nabokov's Blues - the Scientific Odyssey of a Literary Genius also deals with Nabokov's interest in butterflies, but in a different way.

While Boyd and his co-editor, Robert Michael Pyle, collected and collated any reference to butterflies in Nabokov's work, Kurt Johnson (a lepidopterist) and Steve Coates (a journalist) have made his posthumous entrance into scientific history into a lucid, wide-ranging narrative that illuminates not just Nabokov's life and his interest in butterflies but also why their study is so important to science and conservation efforts, and how his contribution to lepidoptery, almost unnoticed until the past few years, is now seen as of fundamental scientific importance. All through his life, Nabokov held that he would have been as happy, if not happier, as an entomologist as he was as a novelist. 'I want no other fame [but] the immortality of this red label on a little butterfly,' he wrote in 1942, during his tenure at the Museum of Comparative Zoology at Harvard, years which he described as 'the most thrilling in all my adult life'.

Nabokov was both a 'joyfully promiscuous' collector of butterflies and moths and a serious scientist, whose specialisation was a genus of butterfly commonly known as the Blues. In the 1990s, three scientists went to South America to study the species Nabokov had examined in his groundbreaking but largely ignored 1945 article, 'Notes on Neotropical Plebejinae'. (One of the reasons Johnson and Coates posit for this oversight is that his scientific works were unreadably dense.)

Their findings showed Nabokov's ideas about classification to be more accurate than the ones previously used, and they named an infratribe (several related genuses) based on his ideas Nabokovina. In addition to this, they also discovered many new species of Blue which they named using Nabokovian themes. In Peru and Chile there are Blues called Lolita, Kinbote and Pnin. Nabokov might well have been more pleased about this than about any of his other achievements.

'My desire for it was one of the most intense I have ever experienced,' said Nabokov of a butterfly he saw when he was six. Lepidoptery is a passion as consuming for the amateur as for the expert, but it takes a professional to explain it to the uninitiated. Johnson and Coates beautifully describe the appeal of Nabokov's chosen genus, the Blues, with their understated beauty. 'They are, perhaps, an acquired taste but one well worth acquiring.' It is typical of Nabokov to choose butterflies which appear ordinary but in which he was able to see extraordinary things.

Rarely is the connection between art and science, portrayed since the famous debate between Keats and Newton as incompatible, as lucidly encapsulated as in the work of Nabokov. He loved the merging of 'the precision of poetry and the excitement of pure science. I cannot separate the aesthetic pleasure of seeing a butterfly and the scientific pleasure of knowing what it is'.

Nabokov's Blues is interesting partly because of this unusual blend of scientific rigour (thankfully diluted enough for the lay reader) and literary passion, partly because of the verve and enthusiasm with which Johnson and Coates recount their story, and partly because anything by or about Nabokov is worth reading. One of the ways in which we define a great artist is that his work, though varied and variable, is instantly recognisable as his own. Perhaps the greatest of Nabokov's hallmarks, those 'little gems of discovery' he hid in his work for careful readers, which make his books so exciting to read and reread, is his love of moths and butterflies.

It would be a slight to Nabokov's Blues to suggest that enhancing an understanding of his fiction is the best reason to read it; it is such a rich discussion of the discipline of collecting, the urgent need to name new species before we enter a new era of extinction, and the importance of biodiversity for the world's survival, but this has to be as good a reason as any.

fields.headline: Forgotten poet
fields.standfirst: Joanna Griffiths picks out Charlotte Mew's Complete Poems
fields.trailText: Joanna Griffiths picks out Charlotte Mew's Complete Poems
fields.body:
Charlotte Mew: Complete Poems
edited by John Newton
Penguin Books £7.99, pp176

Buy it at BOL

Charlotte Mew has defied Virago-ish reclamation of the 'forgotten woman' kind, partly because she is so spiky and peculiar and fails to fall into any genre.

She lived a straitened, strange existence between 1869 and 1928, and was briefly an 1890s New Woman. Her work appeared in the rakish Yellow Book, a journal boasting Aubrey Beardsley as its art editor and Henry James as a contributor. In 1916, Mew became not quite a Bloomsbury poet, published by the philanthropic Poetry Bookshop where there was a poets' meeting room run by Harold Monro. This collection, The Farmer's Bride, sold scarcely a quarter of its print run.

She was also nearly what might be called a lesbian, but found her passions unrequited.

Mew's poems range from the faintly fey Victorian elegy to the fierce, surprising, chaotic song of desire, searching, fear of ageing and death. She is said to have influenced T. S. Eliot; Ezra Pound published her in the Egoist; Virginia Woolf thought her very good and unlike anyone else.

She is at times a Georgian, a Modernist and a high Victorian, but refuses to stay put, just as she scampered away from literary cliques and tea parties at Ottoline Morrell's.

One of Mew's poems is currently featured on the London Underground; 'Sea Love' is not one of her best, but Thomas Hardy liked it, and transcribed it for himself. Her most beautiful, strange lyrics - 'In Nunhead Cemetery', 'Madeleine In Church', 'The Fete' - are a fascinating collision between Browning-esque monologues and a modernist fractured consciousness.

Editor John Newton supplies a clean, sensible edition with an informative, decently accurate introduction in which he suggests that Mew might be a forgotten genius of the twentieth century.
