At times she seemed almost dismissive of him, at others proud, citing his songwriting as an inspiration. 'I didn't realise it for years, but I was brought up to agitate,' she said recently. One of the songs on Titanic Days, 'Bad', alluded to her familial baggage. 'I've been the token woman all my life/ The token daughter and the token wife,' it started, referring not just to her father but to her husband, the record producer Steve Lillywhite, with whom she had just broken up. 'The implication is sometimes that I only went into music because certain men guided me that way,' she complained,' whereas I'd been making records for five years before I even met Steve.' Kirsty was fiercely righteous about the deal the music business hands to women, especially the idea that having a couple of children meant she had given up the creative ghost: 'I'm constantly asked, "How do you combine a career and a family?" They never ask my husband or Sting that question. It's plain old sexism, really.' The demands of motherhood must, nonetheless, have played their part in the six-year break between Titanic Days - which she referred to as her 'sad divorce album' - and this year's magnificent Tropical Brainstorm . For two years she didn't write any songs at all. 'I used to worry about writer's block, but I think this time it was God's way of saying: "You've got nothing to write about, so shut up." In any case, I didn't want to make another melancholy record. That would have been grim. Instead I started to do some of the things I'd wanted to do since forever.' One of those things was travelling to Cuba, which she did first in 1992, and thereafter on a regular basis. MacColl, who had a Latin track on Electric Landlady and had sung on David Byrne's Rei Momo album, had liked Latin music for a long time. Her fascination stretched back to her childhood, when her father gave her an album of Mexican mariachi music. The young Kirsty was fascinated by the gaudy cover, the band's exotic clothes and instruments, the carnival atmosphere of the music. 'I think that's where I got it into my head that anybody who spoke Spanish was having a better time than me.' Once she'd visited Cuba, the Latin bug bit hard. When her Best Of compilation appeared in 1995, there was Kirsty on the cover dressed in Castro cap, lighting a fat cigar with a US dollar bill. She became a regular at Cuban Solidarity Campaign shows, and took Spanish classes. Here she met a Brazilian who became her lodger at her Ealing home, paying his rent with Portuguese lessons. Her love of Cuban music extended to Brazil, which she also visited. Her travels, many of them alone, fed into Tropical Brainstorm, a record which fused her songwriting with her passion for Latin music. In a more just world, she would have been back in the UK charts this summer with one of the record's highlights, 'In These Shoes', a salsa tale of lust and non-sensible footwear that was picked by Adidas for an ad campaign. The single became a hit in Europe, but not at home. Kirsty, who complained that, 'Radio 1 won't play my singles now I'm over 30', had made a documentary series on Cuban music for Radio 2, which was due to kick off last week, but which has now been deferred. 'I didn't want to recreate an authentic sound,' she said of Tropical Brainstorm , 'first of all cos I'm not Celia Cruz, and a lot of people like my music mostly because of the lyrics. I didn't want to try and fail at being the Buena Vista Social Club. I wanted to succeed at being Kirsty MacColl.' Kirsty MacColl, singer and songwriter, born 10 October 1959, died 18 December 2000.

fields.headline: Wishing well
fields.standfirst: Rather than making the usual resolutions, says Barefoot Doctor, make New Year's Day the first day of the new you
fields.trailText: Rather than making the usual resolutions, says Barefoot Doctor, make New Year's Day the first day of the new you.
fields.body:
Strange, isn't it, that in this age of digitally enhanced reality, in which old-school religious ways are rapidly declining and the main area of growth in spiritual interest is 'new age', we still subscribe so viscerally to Christmas?

There is a historical, almost archetypal, pre-Christian precedent for celebration and spiritual renewal at this, the darkest (hence most yin) time of year. The Celts, Romans and Greeks celebrated the winter solstice as the Festival of Lights, a bacchanalian feast where fires were lit to symbolise the coming of spring (rising yang).

This is probably where the gift exchanging and face-stuffing urge first implanted itself in the group consciousness. This feast's primary symbolic function is to celebrate the germ of one's own rebirth along with the rebirth of nature as we pass the darkest point of the year. So in the light of that sentiment, let all family grievances and stress be put to one side, and celebrate the nativity of that pure essence within us.

But what, if you don't mind me asking, are you doing on New Year's Eve? Are you bracing yourself for the big moment - that moment when you feel compelled to feel something, even if you don't - when if you haven't got someone to drunkenly kiss you, you feel like a sad loser?

The idea of a year coming to an end and a new one beginning is so entrenched in our collective consciousness that we forget it is just an arbitrary Gregorian concept that took root in the mass psyche. The seasonal cycle occurs due to a combination of the earth's axial tilt and its heliocentric orbital trajectory. Any division of this cycle is symbolic. We live immersed in the details of our daily lives hardly aware that we allow our experiential process to be governed by the world of symbols. Think of flags, nations, religions, corporations or fashions. These are merely concepts we bring into being by breathing (individually and collectively) the fire of belief into them. Over time, we pledge allegiance to a series of ideas and live our lives by them. Knowing this helps us transcend the moment-to-moment drama of life. A glimpse of the enormity of the impact of the symbolic on our very daily existence is enough to remind us how little we explore our choices at a radical level.

When the clock strikes 12 - that moment of gay abandon when you jump into the pool of unclear ebullience and jubilation - you are in fact celebrating an idea by a guy called Gregory.

Not that there's anything wrong with the name - it's a grand name and well worthy of a calendar, but is it something worth getting your party knickers in a twist over?

Auld lang syne aside, isn't 12 o'clock on the first of the first just another moment in time, no more or less important than any other? That moment's main difference is that we choose to celebrate it. How about this for a resolution? 'I choose to celebrate every moment of my existence from now on.'

To help you support such resolve, be constantly aware of your breathing: nothing is more central to your (ongoing) physical existence - or so centring. In line with the illusion of new years, it can be an effective psychic clear-out to make a list or picture of all the 'stuff' (behavioural patterns, thought patterns, qualities, situations and so forth) you want to leave behind. Then rip it up or burn it and flush the bits down the loo. Now make a list or picture of all the 'stuff' you want to take on in the new year. You can fashion your life into a totally different shape if so inclined. Be bold with yourself and make the view as beautiful as can be. Finally, hide the document till next year and check off how much of it came to pass.

We live in a world of symbols, and we have it in our power to reconstruct our reality from the ground up by visioning it differently, or revising it at that level of mind that responds to the symbolic.

While we're on this side of the annual divide, however, I would like to take this opportunity to thank everyone who has been following these textual antics for the past six months, especially those who've written in with problems. If I could heal everyone personally, I would - as it is, it's always my intention to send the healing through these words in the hope it's coming through loud and clear. Happy New Year - BDoc!

Your letters

Dear Barefoot Doctor, I'm dreading the annual Christmas visit to my family, as it is always fraught and makes me very tense. How can I relax more?
Sarah Keynes, Banbury

Dear Sarah, The only way round this is to perceptually reframe the experience by disciplining your mind to imagine that your family are gurus, who, though quirky and irritating, have your best interests at heart and are there to promote your enlightenment. To aid you in this process, spend the time in a semi-meditative state. So though your behaviour appears normal, internally you are concentrating on the passage of air in and out of your nostrils and on relaxing your chest to enable your 'goodwill' energy to flow. Remember, your parents are not immortal and no matter how irksome you find their company, one day you'll miss them. Benefit from their flesh-and-blood company while you can.

Dear Barefoot Doctor, How can I avoid the inevitable bloating that I seem to suffer after Christmas lunch? Have you any suggestions? It always feels rude to refuse what's put on the plate.
John Dyke, Ashford

Dear John, Start the day with a drink of hot boiled water to cleanse your digestive tract, followed by a serious exercise session to get your blood and energy flowing. Avoid mixing protein and carbohydrates. Avoid too much cream or rich sauces, and above all eat slowly, chewing each mouthful at least 18 times. You may also find it helpful to down a cup of dandelion tea after eating to help support your liver, which is the organ most affected by heavy eating and drinking and which causes bloating and flatulence when strained.

webTitle: The way we live now: Christmas celebrations

fields.headline: What are you doing tomorrow?
fields.standfirst: Christmas celebrations
fields.trailText: Christmas celebrations.
fields.body:
Martin Gayton, station officer, Lambeth Fire Station, London
'A few weeks before Christmas we put everybody's name in a hat and pull out the three lucky ones who'll have Christmas Day at home. It's a funny atmosphere when you arrive at the station on Christmas Day, because the people who are on duty from the night before will be waiting for us at the door. They'll go off and the day will start for us in quite a sombre mood. We'll have a buffet for lunch so people can help themselves when they want to. Coming up to 6 o'clock, you begin to think ahead to going home and having a nice glass of wine. Most people save their traditional dinner with their family for the evening, which means that everyone in the family suffers a bit as well.'

Mick Jones, elephant keeper team leader, Chester Zoo
'The animals are what count and they need us to look after them, even though it's Christmas Day. I try to give them a treat. Just because I'm daft about them I'll give them a melon or a pineapple. We try to be as festive as we can while we're shovelling shit. We put on seasonal music and turn all the Christmas lights on. My friends all wait until I get home to have dinner. There's never any question. I'm the elephant keeper, and they accept what I do.'

Angelo Maresco, manager, Savoy Grill, London
'Years ago, Christmas really happened at home, but now more and more people go out for Christmas lunch. People work so hard and more wives work, and they don't want to spoil their day by cooking and washing up, so they come here and let us do it for them. I believe people should be at home at Christmas, but that's how it is these days.'

Rosie Stewart, student, London
'Living the vegan alternative lifestyle that we do, my friends and I are a little overwhelmed by the commercialism of Christmas. So we try to get back to basics and use it as a chance to see friends and enjoy each other's company. We won't do lots of shopping and buy each other presents, but just before we all go home for Christmas, we'll get together and share a big meal. We're a mixture of meat eaters, vegetarians and vegans, so we'll all pitch in and share the cooking. It'll be a case of too many cooks and it will get too much at one point, but there'll be lots of wine, so we'll have great fun. On Christmas Day, I'll be with my nan and she'll make sure that there's plenty of vegan food for me to eat.'

Stephen Green, ward manager, King's College Hospital, south London
'We'll get the usual admissions throughout Christmas. Along with many people who have fallen off rollerblades or other Christmas presents, there's a lot of: "Here, Grandma, have a go on my skateboard... crunch !" We try to keep it very light. Hospital is the last place you want to be on Christmas Day, so our nurses wear tinsel and Santa hats. The patients all have a drink - the ladies will have sherry and the gentlemen a beer. I'll pop to the off-licence to get non-alcoholic beer for anyone who is on antibiotics - it makes your day worse if you can't have a beer. We'll have a traditional Christmas dinner. It's theoretically hot, but hospital food is hospital food.'

Julie Jameson, lifetime member, Weight Watchers, Richmond
'I think more about the time immediately after Christmas than most people. It's easier to compromise during Christmas than to have to go to a Weight Watchers meeting in January and have 4lb or 5lb to lose. It's nice to come through the other side without that horrible feeling of nothing fitting you. I avoid buying huge boxes of chocolates and 48 mince pies, like I used to. I live next door to Twickenham rugby ground, and I think people must have thought that I was feeding the entire English team. It's much more satisfying to have more expensive things and eat just a few than to face January with all the food no one wanted calling you from the cupboards when there's nothing on television and you're really bored.'

Neil Oliver, Christmas cruise manager, P&O Aurora
'I would never tell anyone who wants to get away from Christmas to come on a cruise because it is everywhere. Before we leave Southampton, a company that usually decorates shopping malls and department stores blitzes the ship. One lounge is a quiet room, without any of the usual Christmas entertainment. People may have bad memories of Christmas - they may have lost a loved one at this time of year, so we want to give them the option of going somewhere calm. The same goes for dinner - I'll be hosting a table that includes three or four single ladies and gentlemen. We always have a contingent of people travelling alone, so we keep our eyes open for some little old lady who may need company so she's not lonely for Christmas dinner.'

Richard Johnson, jockey, racing at Kempton Park on Boxing Day
'My family comes first on Christmas Day, but racing's a very close second. I definitely won't miss Christmas lunch, but I might have a smaller one - I need to be 10st for racing on Boxing Day. I'll have just one roast potato and one piece of turkey, and then a run in the afternoon and a hot bath. It's not a nice feeling if you have to miss Christmas dinner - I'm lucky because I'm quite light, but a lot of the bigger lads will have a tough time. We do this job because we love it, though, and we want to give 110 per cent on Boxing Day.'

Priti Patel, pharmacist, Brighton
'We're Hindu but we have celebrations on Christmas Day anyway - it's a great excuse for a family get together. The kids have picked up the traditions in school, so we're keen to keep them alive in our own way. All the women gather in the kitchen to make curry and vegetarian dishes. We have 25 people for dinner, so keeping everyone happy is a delicate balance.'

John Downie, director, Aldgate Homelessness Advice Centre, London
'A lot of people come to us for Christmas lunch because they need someone to talk to. We give them a welcome, a good hot meal and some company. Rather than people queuing up for their food, the tables are laid in a festive manner and people are served by our staff and volunteers. Coming to us is a major highlight in what is otherwise a barren week. Most of the people who attend like to hear Christmas music because they don't really hear it anywhere else, but there's no guarantee that we'll have money for any live entertainment. We're inundated with volunteers at this time of year. I think it gives a hint of what other people's Christmases are like. There are lots of unhappy people who don't want to be on their own on Christmas Day.'

Denis Cobell, ceremonies co-ordinator for the British Humanist Society (south-east region)
'The festivities associated with Christmas - feasting and exchanging presents - predate Christianity, and at one point Christians dissociated themselves from the excess. In the northern hemisphere, it's part of the winter solstice activities, a way to deal with the darkest days of the year. Romans called this time of the year Saturnalia, the return of the unconquered sun. The round pudding, set alight with alcohol, was once a solar symbol. By celebrating at this time of the year, we're keeping ancient traditions alive.'

Samantha Macmillan, cabin crew, Virgin Atlantic
'I have a whale of a time when I fly on Christmas Day. We all wear Santa hats, reindeer ears and lots of tinsel. We hold competitions and sing Christmas carols over the PA. We really want passengers to enjoy themselves, so staff at the boarding gate are the most dressed up. I love seeing children on board because they're so excited they really create an atmosphere. The menu on Christmas Day is easy - we go around saying, "Would you like turkey, turkey or turkey?" I can't wait to go to work this year.'

Phil Hogan, Observer columnist, Hertfordshire
We'll be tucking into a naff melon starter, a free-range turkey and probably a Christmas pud from Waitrose. Our four children are quite fastidious, so as usual we'll be foisting all kinds of stuff on them they don't like - sprouts, bread sauce, broccoli, stuffing, horrible crystallised fruits. I usually cook a special nut roast for our vegetarian to turn his nose up at. Everyone will love the roast spuds and little sausages and afterwards we'll open a dustbin-sized tin of Quality Street. A big tradition with us, too, is to buy a box of dates to throw away unopened some time in July.'

 Phil Hogan returns on 7 January.

webTitle: The bizarre career of Amanda Lear

fields.headline: At the court of Queen Lear
fields.standfirst: A close friend of Salvador Dali and an object of rock-star desire, Amanda Lear kept her myth and her private life apart. Last week tragedy struck.  Andrew Anthony  charts her bizarre career
fields.trailText: A close friend of Salvador Dali and an object of rock-star desire, Amanda Lear kept her myth and her private life apart. Last week tragedy struck. Andrew Anthony charts her bizarre career.
fields.body:
Back in the sixties and Seventies, Amanda Lear was a stalwart of London's demi-monde , an exotic name on the nightclub circuit. She was linked, as they say, with a string of rock stars, a kind of up-market groupie with her own cachet. Although never as well-known as Bianca Jagger or Marianne Faithfull, she was a regular fixture in the gossip columns. And then she disappeared. The house also contained her husband, Alain-Philippe Malagnac d'Argens and his 20-year-old friend, Didier Dieufis, a cat breeder. But in the reports the deaths of these two men seemed almost incidental, merely the surreal background to the main tragedy, the damage to a few surrealist paintings.

Thus the weirdness overshadowed the horror, as if to imply there was more to the story than a simple fatal accident. But then everything about Lear's life appears to have been shaped by distortion and disbelief. Some observers have even gone so far as to suggest that not only was the former model and pop singer Dali's devoted protégée , but also the late artist's strangest creation.

Lear's background remains a mystery. She has variously let it be known that her mother was English or French or Vietnamese or Chinese, and that her father was English, Russian, French or Indonesian. She may have been born in Hanoi in 1939, or Hong Kong in either 1941 or 1946. Once she said she was from Transylvania. And to this day, it is a matter of conjecture as to whether she was born a boy or a girl.

'The sort of people,' says writer Jonathan Meades, 'who once shared a line with someone who once shared a line with a Rolling Stone.'

Lear went one better and developed a friendship with the Rolling Stones guitarist Brian Jones. It was through Jones, according to Lear, that she met Dali in 1965. He told her she had a 'beautiful skull'. Yet the story that Meades heard, and which followed Lear around London, is that two years earlier Dali had paid for her sex-change operation, which was carried out in Casablanca by Dr Bourou, who was at the cutting edge of transgender surgery.

Lear has never confirmed these details, although she was happy to trade on the notoriety they generated. 'It makes me mysterious and interesting,' she said. 'There is nothing the pop world loves more than a way-out freak.'

Later, however, she denied she was ever a man, insisting it was never anything more than a myth to gain publicity, a PR campaign whose architect, she said, was Dali. Or David Bowie. Or herself.

April Ashley, the transsexual who had once been George Jamieson, a Liverpudlian seaman, has long claimed she worked with Lear in the Fifties at Le Carrousel, a transvestite revue in Paris. In her book, April Ashley's Odyssey , she recalls a man named Alain Tapp, whose stage-name was Peki d'Oslo, later to become Amanda Lear. According to Ashley, Dali met Peki at Le Carrousel in 1959.

Whatever the origin of the relationship, Lear and Dali were to remain close for the next two decades. 'I knew nothing when I first met him,' she admitted before Dali's death. 'He taught me to see things through his eyes.' Between summer stints at Dali's home in Cadaques, she would return to London. 'I was a bit disenchanted,' she observed, 'because I had just left a genius and found myself passing the joint with someone in the King's Road who was talking nonsense about changing the world.

Lear, who once acknowledged her interest in one-night stands with the comment 'five hours is all you need with anyone', went on from Jones to move in with David Bowie. In fact, Bowie is one of the few men whom Lear has ever referred to as a 'lover'. Subsequently she was also linked with Bryan Ferry, having appeared as the cover girl on Roxy Music's For Your Pleasure album

For a brief period in the early Seventies, the glam-rock years, sexual ambiguity was highly fashionable. Lear represented what Freudians like to call the Other, and back then everyone who was anyone wanted a bit of the Other. But there was little space for Lear's camp glamour in British subculture with the advent of punk.

By that time, though, she had reinvented herself as Euro Disco Queen. She credits Bowie with encouraging her to be more than a model, although she has said he was only attracted to her as an album cover. 'I realised after a while that he was in love with a picture, not with me.' Her first album was knowingly titled I Am A Photograph.

While she made little impact on the British charts, by the end of the Seventies she was a notable success in other parts of Europe with her brand of deep-voice disco pop. Lear's assessment of her appeal was as cynical as it was clever.

'In Italy I'm big because they're all so sex-obsessed. In Germany I succeeded because they've been waiting for someone like Marlene Dietrich to come along ever since the war. I played on their need for a drunken, nightclubbing vamp. And I've won the gays, who are crucial because they have all the best discos, entirely because of the extraordinary legends about me.'

She also appeared naked in Playboy, in a series of photographs designed to end the rumours, and hosted a chat-show in Italy, where she enjoyed her most lasting fame. 'I am,' she explained, 'the Italian Janet Street-Porter.'

With her ahistorical self-invention and ironic contempt for old-fashioned concepts like the 'truth', Lear has been in many ways the prototype of the postmodern celebrity age. Meades recalls her driving ambition to be famous, without any specific plans about what shape that fame should take: 'She wanted to be famous for being Amanda Lear.'

Duncan Fallowell, co-author of April Ashley's Odyssey, says that in his experience few transsexuals harbour dreams of being a 'normal' woman. 'They aspire to this sort of glamourised ideal of womanhood.' He also suggests that in making, as it were, a public spectacle of themselves, transsexuals often have a paradoxical need for an intensely private life.

Lear did find a private life with her husband, Alain-Philippe, a former record producer whom she married in 1979 in a ceremony in Las Vegas at which Twiggy and Sacha Distel were said to be the witnesses. Lear and Malagnac d'Argens settled in the small village of Saint-Etienne-du-Gres, not far from St-Remy-de-Provence.

When Meades visited the house in 1985, he described it as 'a shrine to herself and, in a smaller way, to Dali'. He remembers Lear's husband as a shy man who preferred to stay in the background, and Lear herself as very much in charge. 'She didn't drink or take drugs and she was very regimented about exercise. The impression I got was that she wanted to be in total control of her environment.' But one woman who stopped by to see the couple was surprised to find such a domesticated setting. 'She was really very homely.'

Having spent decades moving around, erasing herself as she went, Lear had found a permanent role at home. Now that home is in ruins and her husband in dead. While she was away on a brief trip to Italy, the life that she spent years carefully building, her real life, her private life, turned suddenly, and horribly, public.

fields.headline: Travel sickness
fields.trailText: As one of those millions of people who disregarded the constant criticism of the Millennium Dome by the media and various politicians and greatly enjoyed the experience, I intended to visit it it again in November, only to be thwarted by the disruption to the railway system.
fields.body:
As one of those millions of people who disregarded the constant criticism of the Millennium Dome by the media and various politicians and greatly enjoyed the experience, I intended to visit it it again in November, only to be thwarted by the disruption to the railway system.

The train which I had booked had been cancelled, the delays to and from Nottingham were unacceptable and it was difficult to rearrange the visit due to the uncertainty of travel. Perhaps the loss of 250,000 visitors between October and November has more to do with the rail crisis than many commentators would acknowledge in their zeal to knock the Dome.
Charles Tyrie
Nottingham

fields.headline: Delete the élite
fields.trailText: Liberal it might be but not one of the élite appears to put socialism into practice (Focus, last week).
fields.body:
Liberal it might be but not one of the élite appears to put socialism into practice (Focus, last week). This New Labour network take high incomes, live in luxury, distance themselves from deprived estates, and insist that they - not the poor - must have power. In short, they reinforce inequality. Socialism is about promoting equality by having just a modest income, by being close to the materially needy, and conceding power to the socially deprived. Is there a single one of this liberal élite prepared to be a socialist example?
Bob Holman
Glasgow

 Forty years ago, the British Left was concerned with economic and social justice for the mass of ordinary people. Finding this too difficult a task, the Left fell under the spell of the politics of 'gender', 'sexuality' and 'ethnicity'. The payoff for the Left was that it gained the endorsement of the so-called 'liberal élite'. This paved the way first to a hearing in the media and then to power. The great triumph of this alliance has been to convince so many people that making sure a few more women, homosexuals and non-whites get cosy, well paid jobs, 'at the top', is a major contribution to producing a more equitable society. It isn't.
Dr Les May
Rochdale, Lancs

webTitle: Family tragedy as five die in plane crash

fields.headline: Family tragedy as five die in plane crash
fields.trailText: A family's holiday to Majorca ended in tragedy yesterday when a pilot, his two children and two friends died as their plane crashed in flames shortly after take-off.
fields.byline: Jason Burke and Nick Paton Walsh
fields.body:
A family's holiday to Majorca ended in tragedy yesterday when a pilot, his two children and two friends died as their plane crashed in flames shortly after take-off.

The jet had left Blackbushe Airport near Yateley, Hampshire, in thick fog at about 1.50pm. They flew less than half a mile before the Beech 200 Super Kingair eight-seater plunged into a plastics and rubber factory, exploding with a blast that blew out the walls of the building.

All five people are believed to have been killed instantly. Last night the blaze was still too hot to allow rescuers to check that the factory was empty when the plane struck it. One body had been recovered and rescue workers were combing scattered, tangled debris for the others.

Clouds of poisonous fumes billowing from the building prompted the evacuation of local residents. 'It was in trouble from the moment it took off,' said an eyewitness. 'It narrowly missed a crane on the industrial park, skimmed the roofs of two other factories and then lost height and crashed straight through the front doors of a huge rubber-making factory.'

Steve Haire, ambulance incident officer at the scene, confirmed the plane had gone straight through the front of the aluminium building and had then skidded on for about 25 metres inside.

'It set the building ablaze and, although fire crews have brought the blaze under control, the fuselage is still on fire inside the building. There was a very large explosion because of all the aviation fuel aboard,' he said.

'The force of the blast and blaze has blown out the sides of the building and we cannot get anywhere near it. No crews will be allowed inside until the building has been made safe.'

About 50 firefighters were tackling the blaze. David Askew, of Hampshire Fire and Rescue Service, said seven fire appliances were at the scene. Firefighters had recovered an engine from the plane but the factory unit - thought to be the Linatex plastics manufacturing plant - was still in flames.

Experts say the Super Kingair has a good safety record. Chris Yates, Aviation Security editor for Jane's magazines, said: 'The most likely causes are engine failure on take-off or a weight distribution problem. Pilot error is unlikely though there is a chance the pilot might have had a heart attack.'

webTitle: We're only here because of the beer

fields.headline: We're only here because of the beer
fields.standfirst: Our ancestors' capacity for alcohol was a major factor in saving Western civilisation.  Robin McKie  reports
fields.trailText: Our ancestors' capacity for alcohol was a major factor in saving Western civilisation. Robin McKie reports.
fields.body:
It may be the mocker of hopes and dreams, the devil's brew, the curse of the working class - but alcohol was also the saviour of Western civilisation. Without booze we would have poisoned ourselves with contaminated water centuries ago, say scientists.

Their research has also revealed that alcohol consumption has left Europeans with a distinctive evolutionary legacy. People of Caucasian origin can consume vast quantities of wine, beer and spirits at a single sitting. By contrast, many individuals with Oriental roots need only take a sip of sweet sherry to trigger crippling allergic reactions.

'Brewing beer and fermenting grapes saved us from drinking polluted water, and meant that alcoholic beverages became our staple drink for thousands of years,' says Dr David Sherman, of Central Middlesex Hospital in London. 'People in the Far East tackled the pollution problem a different way - by boiling their water to make herbal infusions, like tea. As a result, they did not evolve the power to break down alcohol, which explains why so many suffer reactions when they drink today.'

In other words, the average Briton's ability to hold 12 Sea Breezes and six whisky chasers at the office party is a genetic inheritance from ancestors who were simply trying to avoid getting cholera.

The crucial point is that clean, drinkable water has only been publicly available since the Victorian era. For millennia before that, people faced a major health headache - their water supplies quickly became polluted with their own waste products, making them dangerous, even fatal, to consume.

'How many of our progenitors died attempting to quench their thirst with water can never be known,' states Harvard scientist Bert Vallee, who argues that alcohol played a major 'nurturing role' in Western society. 'A safe bet is that a remarkably large portion of our ancestry succumbed.'

Salvation came with the production of beer and wine. Their natural antiseptic powers and acidity killed off most harmful microbes and led to the drinks' widespread popularity. As a result, the Old and New Testaments have virtually no references to water as a common beverage. By contrast, wine is recommended. 'Drink no longer water, but use a little wine for thy stomach's sake,' states St Paul in his First Epistle to Timothy.

Similarly, Columbus made his voyage with wine, not water, on board; the Greek word akratidzomai - 'to breakfast' - literally translates as 'to drink undiluted wine'; while Frederick the Great, in a diatribe against the spread of coffee-drinking in Prussia, said his armies had been victorious because his soldiers were 'nourished on beer'.

Then there was Jesus's transformation of water into wine, 'an act that may acknowledge the goodness of alcohol versus the polluted nature of water,' says Vallee.

So from the Iron Age to the Middle Ages many people existed in states of blissful intoxication. Then, in the nineteenth century, doctors began to appreciate the dangers of alcohol indulgence. At the same time, the first great engineering works that brought clean water to the public were launched, while religious groups began campaigning for tight controls of alcohol. The all-day drinking of beer and wine by adults and children died out.

Yet we still carry the biological legacy. Virtually no person of European origin is unable to break down alcohol, thanks to a set of genes that firstly convert alcohol into acetaldehyde, and then into acetic acid. By contrast, more than 40 per cent of people of Eastern origins lack the gene.

The question is: which came first? Did the ancestors of Western people start drinking wine and beer because they were already genetically equipped to cope with it, or did that ability evolve after they started to exploit alcohol? In other words, having started on the booze, did we then have to evolve genes to cope with it properly? Or did we take to booze in the first place because we could already handle it, leaving Orientals - who could not - to find other routes?

'It's a difficult one,' admits geneticist Steve Jones. 'However, there have only been about 500 generations of humans since the dawn of the agricultural revolution. So it is probably more likely that Europeans were already able to break down alcohol, and so took to the stuff in a big way. We have certainly made use of it since then, of course.'

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Jimmy Shand, Scotland's accordion wizard, dies at 92
fields.body:
Jimmy Shand, Scotland's accordion wizard, dies at 92

Sir Jimmy Shand, accordionist and maestro of Scottish country dance music, pictured right, died in Perth Royal Infirmary aged 92. He had been suffering from pneumonia.

Born in Fife, he worked in the mines before being offered a job by Forbes Music. He made his first recording in 1933 and formed his band in 1945 after his debut on radio.

His music was much loved in Scotland - he attracted 20,000 to a concert in Aberdeen in the Fifties - but he became a familiar name throughout the UK. He made many television appearances and his 'Bluebell Polka' reached No 20 in the charts in 1955. He appeared on This Is Your Life in 1978. His band played with snap and sparkle, and the Queen, who knighted him last year, was among his fans.

Crash royal goes hunting

Princess Anne's daughter Zara Phillips, 19, went out with the Old Berkshire Hunt, 24 hours after escaping serious injury when her Land-Rover turned over in Gloucestershire.

Cute asses

Seven rescued donkeys from Sidmouth Sanctuary, Devon, have paid more than 1,000 therapeutic visits to nursing homes and hospitals.

Sprouts win

An Asda survey says Brussels sprouts are more popular at Christmas than cake, pudding or sherry.

A ringing endorsement

Tory MSP Ben Wallace (North-East Scotland) sent colleagues a Christmas email with the breasts of topless women swaying to Max Bygraves's 1959 hit 'Jingle Bell Rock'. The email, which was called 'Jingle Boobs', was a riposte to the Blair family card. Wallace, 30, is a former major in the Scots Guards.

Pop star postman dies

A Grimsby postman whose success as a Sixties novelty pop star led to tragedy in his own life has died aged 73.

The Singing Postman, Allan Smethurst, had a number of hits with comic songs performed in Norfolk dialect including 'I Miss My Miss from Diss' and 'Oi Can't Get A Noice Loaf of Bread'.

But his biggest hit was 'Hev Yew Gotta Loight, Boy?', which won an Ivor Novello award for best novelty song in 1966.

Smethurst, who always performed in his Royal Mail uniform, suffered from crippling stage fright and could not cope with the transition from postie to pop star - he became an alcoholic and appeared in the dock in a number of humiliating court cases.

He spent the last 20 years of his life in the Brighowgate Salvation Army hostel in Grimsby, despite the thousands of pounds earned from the 80 songs he recorded. He kept his Ivor Novello trophy in his room.

'He was well liked by everyone who stayed at the hostel,' said manager Mike Hardy. 'He is going to be missed.'

Police in South Yorkshire warned nightclubbers of the risks of 'moshing' after James White, 25, died of a brain haemorrhage in Doncaster. The dance involves violent head-shaking, crashing into other clubbers and mock head-butting. Apolice spokesman said: 'It can be an aggressive dance and people do get over-excited.' Moshing, an offshoot of the pogo, developed in the mid-Eighties in post-punk clubs in the US.

Lorry driver Richard Hudson, of Findern, near Derby, who was blamed for a fatal crash and spent 17 months in a Macedonian jail, thanked fellow trucker 'T-pot' Jenkins, 43, from Telford, Shropshire, for helping to secure his release. webTitle: £35,000 could save retired racehorses from slaughter

fields.headline: £35,000 could save retired racehorses from slaughter
fields.standfirst: Uncertain fate for a former winner
fields.trailText: Uncertain fate for a former winner.
fields.body:
Once they were champions of the turf who brought joy to their owners, jockeys and thousands of punters as they galloped across the finishing line ahead of the field.

But now a stable of 15 former racehorses faces being taken to the knacker's yard because the money to pay for keeping them alive has run out.

Whether they survive or suffer the same fate as Christmas turkeys depends largely on Andrew Parker Bowles, the former husband of Camilla, Prince Charles's partner.

Four months ago Parker Bowles, chairman of the British Horseracing Board's benevolent fund for needy animals, pledged to provide £50,000 to ensure the former mounts were cared for. Since then, though, only £15,000 of the £50,000 has arrived and the sanctuary looking after the horses is on the brink of having to close.

The financial crisis at the Greatwood sanctuary in Okehampton, Devon, is so severe that Michael and Helen Yeadon, the two passionate horse-lovers who run it, have already had to turn away one animal because there was no money to feed him. He was taken away and shot. Others asking the Yeadons to take in an unwanted beast have also, reluctantly, been told they cannot be helped.

The Yeadons have devoted the past 12 years to rescuing horses found abandoned in fields and sheds, starving and distressed, and nursing them back to health. They began their work when they saw horses going through the sales in an appalling condition. 'We bid and bought them against the meat trade. We couldn't bear to see them taken away to be shot,' explained Michael Yeadon. 'Horses come here off the racecourse distressed, thin and desperate for patience, love and attention. Some arrive in a terrible mess.'

During those 12 years the Yeadons have saved and found new homes for about 50 animals. Many of those have gone into showjumping, point-to-pointing and been used as hacks. For the first 10 years the couple put up every penny themselves; they used all their savings to keep the centre going. Once they even sold their furniture to pay the bills.

But now they face the heartbreak of having to close their doors. Despite turning their sanctuary into a charity 18 months ago and raising £80,000, there is no money left.

Fearing the worst, they have already found new homes for 10 of the 25 ex-racehorses they were looking after, but are 'frantic' that the remaining 15 may not be so lucky. They include Gilberts Girl, a regular winner, who was found 'in a dreadful state and deeply distressed'.

The couple last night appealed to Parker Bowles to release the rest of the £50,000 so that they do not have to close down and dispose of their animals.

'We are desperate, so utterly depressed and running out of time. As we stand, we'll grind to a halt before the end of January,' said Michael Yeadon. 'Back in August, Andrew Parker Bowles promised us £50,000 from the fund to cover the next 12 months, which we hoped would become an increasing, annual contribution. We received £15,000 in September, but nothing else has so far come our way.

'We do not want to fall out with Andrew Parker Bowles, but we are committed to these horses and love them dearly. We are determined to do everything we can for them.'

Besides being a senior figure in the Jockey Club and an ex-rider himself, Parker Bowles is also chairman of the BHB's Rehabilitation and Racehorses Trust Committee. It helps support the country's handful of thoroughbred rehabilitation centres, which include the Yeadons' one in Devon. Without them, countless ex-racehorses would have died of hunger or thirst or been shipped abroad and chopped up for the dinner plate.

Up to 4,000 racehorses come out of training every year and many are later found abandoned.

Parker Bowles was 'too busy' to comment, but Annie Dodd of the BHB did not hold out much hope for the Yeadons. 'I am aware of Mr Yeadon's situation, but I don't think there is an immediate solution', she said. 'Though we can give an indication that people will probably have money from us, we cannot give a guarantee. We realise this doesn't help Michael Yeadon, but we will do everything for the horses, should they have to leave.'

The entire horse-racing world has accepted its responsibility to relieve the problem of ex-runners nobody wants. Jockeys and trainers have agreed to add £10 to their annual licence fee to boost the BHB's benevolent fund for abandoned animals, racecourses donate £50 each race-day and breeders give £7.50 for every registered foal they rear. Owners pay 5p for every horse entered to run while 'substantial contributions' have been promised by the Tote, Levy Board, bloodstock agents, auctioneers, transporters and the Jockey Club. Even the bookies have handed over £60,000.

webTitle: Italy turns political tragedy into an opera

fields.headline: Italy turns political tragedy into an opera
fields.trailText: A hero of the booming Eighties, a villain in the corruption-tainted Nineties, Bettino Craxi has now become the unlikely protagonist of an opera oratorio.
fields.body:
A hero of the booming Eighties, a villain in the corruption-tainted Nineties, Bettino Craxi has now become the unlikely protagonist of an opera oratorio.

The rise and precipitous fall of the former Italian Prime Minister, who died in exile in Tunisia almost a year ago, has provided the inspiration for B.C, an 'opera oratorio in three short acts'.

The authors are putting the finishing touches to the work, which resuscitates in a musical setting a figure more commonly evoked in courtrooms and political polemics.

To add to the incongruity of the spectacle, the Socialist protagonist will be accompanied on stage by singers portraying members of the Craxi family and leading politicians. Identified only by their Christian names, but immediately recognisable, are Bettino's wife Anna, his political rival Giulio (Andreotti), his faithful lieutenant Claudio (Martelli), and current Italian Prime Minister Giuliano (Amato), represented, perhaps unflatteringly, by a counter-tenor.

'The work is not intended to be provocative, it simply bears artistic and musical witness to an event that has touched the consciences and sensibilities of the Italians,' said Francesco Reggiani, the librettist, whose day job is as head of the audio-visual archive of the Rome Opera.

Reggiani said he had chosen to focus on the human dimension of Craxi's tragedy, as the dying statesman looks back on a career that took him from the prestige of being Italy's longest-serving post-war Prime Minister to convictions for corruption, disgrace and exile.

While not intended as satire, the material offers plenty of scope for irony. The oratorio includes a number of dances, among them a 'minuet for dwarves and dancing girls' - a reference to a famously caustic definition of the atmosphere in Craxi's political court.

The composer, Claudio Cimpanelli, has drawn on the theories of the Jewish Kabbala to create a melody based on the letters of Craxi's name. Each letter corresponds to a number, which in turn becomes a note, with the pitch chosen by the composer. 'It has produced a melody that is at once enigmatic and sweet and which contrasts with the strong character of the protagonist.'

A classical and jazz composer who has also written for the cinema, Cimpanelli said he had chosen opera oratorio to brush away the cobwebs from a musical form which in Giuseppe Verdi's day could inflame political passions.

The authors, who are in negotiations with both an Italian and an American conductor for the first performance of the work, have tried to be even-handed towards Craxi. 'There is no such thing as impartiality,' said Reggiani. 'I did not want to paint him as a Robin Hood, nor as someone who had been sadly misunderstood.'

The role of narrator is entrusted to two choruses, one made up of 'courtiers, the people, supporters, journalists, industrialists, friends' and the other of 'suicides' (eight voices, baritones and basses).

Despite the sensitivity of the subject matter and the strong emotions Craxi arouses, the authors believe the work will be staged. 'It would be very grave if it fell victim to political censorship,' said Reggiani. 'I have great faith in the progress made by our country in terms of democracy.'

webTitle: Film: Time to bury the Cratchits

fields.headline: Time to bury the Cratchits
fields.standfirst: We would all be better off if Hollywood stopped reheating A Christmas Carol.
fields.trailText:
The Family Man (126 mins, 12)
Pokémon 2000 (102 mins, PG)
Merlin: the Return (88 mins, PG)
fields.body:
The Family Man (126 mins, 12) Directed by Brett Ratner; starring Nicolas Cage, Téa Leoni, Don Cheadle
Pokémon 2000 (102 mins, PG) Directed by Kunohiko Yuyama
Merlin: the Return (88 mins, PG) Directed by Paul Mathews; starring Rik Mayall, Tia Carrere, Patrick Bergin

Ernest Hemingway famously remarked that 'all modern American literature comes from one book by Mark Twain called Huckleberry Finn'.

By the same token, you could say that all Christmas movies come from one book by Charles Dickens called A Christmas Carol. Every Yuletide is the turn of the Scrooge, who this year takes the form of Dr Seuss's killjoy in The Grinch and Wall Street magnate Jack Campbell in The Family Man.

The Family Man opens in 1987 when Jack (Nicolas Cage), at the check-in counter for his flight to London, resists the pleas of his lovely girlfriend Kate (Téa Leoni) to remain Stateside and marry her. 'You've got a scholarship at a great law school and I've got this internship at Barclays,' he says and departs.

Cut to 13 years later and our hero has been turned by those hard-faced British bankers at Barclays from gentle Jack into Gordon Gekko. He's now a ruthless Manhattan arbitrageur, living in a luxurious bachelor pad and planning a multi-billion-dollar merger in the health sector.

'You're a credit to capitalism, Jack,' the company's admiring chairman tells him, and so important is his work-in-hand that Jack orders his underlings to assemble on Christmas Day at their Wall Street headquarters.

On the way back to his flat on Christmas Eve, Jack encounters a young black criminal, Cash (Don Cheadle), whom we soon recognise to be the local manifestation of Jacob Marley's ghost, or of Clarence, the second-class angel in It's a Wonderful Life.

This numinous stranger is the man who'll give him a glimpse of an alternative life and, sure enough, Jack wakes up on Christmas morning in a dreary, lower-middle-class New Jersey suburb married to his old love, Kate, and with two small children. Instead of fashionable art works by Francis Bacon and Cy Twombly on his walls, he's surrounded by kitsch. The $3,000 suits in his wardrobe have been replaced by the cheap plaid shirts and the denim jacket with his name on it that he wears as chief tyre salesman at Big Ed's, his father-in-law's garage. His new friends are ineffably vulgar, preferring beer to fine wines, hamburgers to gourmet foods and bowling alleys to the ski-slopes at Aspen.

As Jack finds his way in this strange new world, there are amusing incidents, especially the idea of his six-year-old daughter thinking he's an extraterrestrial in need of guidance. And Cage's James Stewart-type cadences would make us think of Frank Capra's take on A Christmas Carol, even if we hadn't noted the obvious parallels with It's a Wonderful Life.

Jack's experience is, in fact, that of Capra's George Bailey turned on its head - this is the life he might have led had he become an ordinary, small-time guy and stayed at home. Where it's supposedly superior to his life in the metropolitan fast-lane is that he has love, a family and warm friendships.

We later discover that Kate, who, in the alternative New Jersey life, is an idealistic pro bono lawyer, has become in her 'real' life a hard, power-dressing, unmarried, big-time corporate attorney.

Predictably, having had his glimpse of what it would have been like to be a suburban Bob Cratchit, this Manhattan Scrooge returns to affluent Wall Street determined to be a kinder, more caring man. The film obviously springs from, and salves, the dodgy consciences of Hollywood moguls.

They are cynical, avaricious people who produce films proclaiming the rewards of the simple life and denouncing materialism in a society where the gap between rich and poor is growing ever wider. The film's moral is that it's OK to be rich and happy, provided you occasionally pay a little lip service to those who are poor and happy. So Tinseltown feels better after imbibing the very brew that it distils.

Christmas charity should dictate restraint in dealing with the other two movies. But a stern, little voice inside me says: 'Bah! Humbug!' Pokémon 2000 is a poorly animated, badly written, scarcely comprehensible tale of an American lad called Ash becoming 'the chosen one' to confront a wicked Pokémon collector and find three treasures representing fire, ice and lightning that will save the world from extinction. It may make more sense in the original Japanese version, though I doubt it.

'The chosen one' in Merlin: the Return is, naturally, King Arthur (Patrick Bergin). Along with other denizens of Camelot, he's been awoken from Merlin's 1,500-year-old spell by an interfering modern scientist (Tia Carrere), and once more he battles with Mordred to save the world.

In the title role, Rik Mayall, who probably seeks to emulate Nicol Williamson's exasperated Merlin in John Boorman's Excalibur, struggles with a hopeless script and inept direction.

The film looks terrible from its first shot and when early on someone says: 'Guinevere, move your arse and pass the wine', you know there's no hope.

Why this witless film, a co-production between Britain and South Africa, didn't go straight to video is a mystery. I'd have called it bad beyond belief, except that these past two years British films have been so bad we have come to believe in their infinite awfulness.

fields.headline: Reality rules and that's a fact
fields.standfirst: Real life - past, present and odd - outdid drama for impact on viewers
fields.trailText: Real life - past, present and odd - outdid drama for impact on viewers.
fields.body:
Shiver me corsets! The biggest TV drama of the year turned out to be the docusoap's bastard offspring, and (only) a game show to boot. But even aside from the Big Brother phenomenon, it was still the numerous incarnations of reality TV featuring real(ish) people - from Taransay's beleaguered castaways to the quaking contestants on Who Wants To Be a Millionaire? and The Weakest Link - who consistently provided the tabloid headlines and compelling 'Did you see?' office water-cooler plotlines.

As channels continue to proliferate and viewers' attention spans falter, what used to be known as 'appointment television' - the blockbuster drama series and classy sitcoms baby boomers grew up with (and probably assumed we'd also grow old with) - may not yet be dead in the schedules, but their failure to engage us in 2000 proved they are appointments that are increasingly easy to break.

Perhaps overblown series like Gormenghast and Anna Karenina foundered partly because, as with water divining and healing with herbs, we've all but lost the will, if not the ability, to follow a plot from week to week. Or because the traditional big-budget costume indulgence seems increasingly out of step with the emotional needs of the TV audience.

The success of Elizabeth, Time Team and A History of Britain reveals that we currently prefer our TV history brought bang up to date with a bit of psychological spin. Simon Schama, for example, made the Bayeux Tapestry speak to the twenty-first-century viewer by helping us picture, in our mind's eye, the women who stitched it.

Interestingly, it seems we're no longer looking to TV to provide us with a romantic escapist dramatic landscape, a parallel world in which happy endings are sealed with kisses, confetti and wedding bells, but to provide imaginative takes on issues that affect us. Many of this year's most successful contemporary dramas - Clocking Off, Fat Friends or Cold Feet, for example - have capitalised on this millennial self-absorption while also recognising a collective commitmentphobia- cum-attention-deficit disorder, providing self-contained storylines in each episode. Needless to say, the two-parter running on consecutive nights will increasingly dominate the drama schedules. Cast your mind back and you'll remember when they used to be called mini-series.

The way we watch TV has evolved, of course, and all those daytime hits on the Big Brother website have proved that the boundaries between broadcast TV schedules and casual net browsing will increasingly be blurred. This is TV treating itself as breaking news, even as breaking news is now often trailed like drama. Prime-time TV is no longer a cosily communal activity, topped and tailed by the family supper and A Book At Bedtime, as the modern family home quite often sustains a box in the living-room, one in the kitchen and one in each of the kids' rooms. For some, this prompts a sigh of nostalgia for the days when the whole country could share a first-hand opinion on Angela Rippon's legs and whether or not the moon might in fact be located on a Hollywood backlot.

But, personally, I think the idea that we all share a collective yearning for the good-old-days of fireside TV (if not actually The Good Old Days) is a con. The way we watch TV now is less a manifestation of the breakdown of The Family, as endorsed by some dread, imaginary liberal elite, but merely proof that we now lead much more interesting lives and therefore have far more choice about how we choose to fritter away our leisure time. Indeed, it makes stumbling across a genuine collective 'Did you see...?' TV moment - from Judy's embonpoint to Cheggers's appendage to Nasty Nick's unmasking - all the more enjoyable.

Despite huffy-puffy debates about broadcasting White Papers, the role of the BBC, dumbing down and stripping off, thus far I think that twenty-first-century TV is in pretty good shape: there is still an embarrassment of riches alongside the crass and the cheap, and if we don't like it at least we can switch off and go and do something less boring instead.

And finally...

 The 'They Don't Make Them Like They Used To' Pride and Prejudice Memorial Award for Best Costume Drama: Longitude (Worst: Gormenghast).

 Best Drama Set On a Relentlessly Grim Council Estate: Never Never.

 Best Drama Set On a Relentlessly Grim Council Estate and Masquerading as a Docusoap: Bad Girls (Worst: Cutting Edge's Shooters).

 The 'Laugh? I Nearly Got a Commission from Channel 4' Award for Madcap Comedy: Black Books (Worst: Randall and Hopkirk: Deceased).

 The Silver Hearse Award: Victor Meldrew (Runner up: Morse).

 The 'Angry of Tunbridge Wells' Award for the Best (and Worst) Offensive Surrealist Sketch Show: Jam.

 The Golden Handcuffs Award for an Outstanding Celebrity Vehicle: Sarah Lancashire in Seeing Red (Worst: Robson Green in Blind Ambition).

 Best Series About Hopelessly Self-Absorbed Twentysomethings: Hearts and Bones (Worst: Metropolis).

 The 'Now That's Why We Pay Our Licence Fee' Award: Joint winners: Elizabeth and Simon Schama's A History of Britain.

 The Man-Sized Kleenex Award for a Heart-wrenching Documentary Series: (Joint winners) Love Is Not Enough and Surrogate Babies.

 The Award for Best Use of Lawnmowers and Rotary Clotheslines at an International Sporting Event: The Olympic Games Opening Ceremony.

 The David Coleman Spattered Microphone Award for Outstanding Sports Commentary: John McEnroe.

 Best Category-Defying One-Off Arts Documentary Shot Mostly In Black and White: Arena - Wisconsin Death Trip.

 The 'Gotta Catch 'Em All' Gold Pokémon Award for Catchphrase: Anne Robinson for 'You are the weakest link. Goodbye!'

 The Pringles Addict Award for Best Cheesy-Yet-Compulsive Prime-Time Drama Series: Fat Friends (Worst: Reach For The Moon).

 The 'Urgh! There But for the Grace of God...' Award for A Documentary About Very Strange People: Horizon: Body Dysmorphia (Runner Up: Hidden Love's erotomania episode).

 The 'You're Not Going Out Dressed Like That' Gold-Plated Barbie Award for Helping Over 30s Keep In Touch With The Youth of Today: Ant and Dec for SM:tv Live.

 The Edge of the Sofa Statuette for Deliciously Cheap Voyeurism: (Joint winners) Big Brother and Judy Finnigan.

A History of Britain BBC2

fields.headline: Bach, not byte
fields.standfirst: Millennium projects and an anniversary cluster gave performance the edge over MP3
fields.trailText: Classical 2000: Millennium projects and an anniversary cluster gave performance the edge over MP3
fields.body:
Individual moments of glory aside, 2000 was not a vintage year for music. Inevitably, the millennium was celebrated with a panoply of new works, beginning with Jonathan Dove's deft piece for midnight at the Dome on New Year's Eve, followed by John Tavener's Fall and Resurrection at St Paul's Cathedral a few days later. Of this substantial and ethereal work I can recall shamefully little, except the curious, bobbing repetition of the word 'apple'.

Tan Dun's 2000 Today: A World Symphony for the Millennium fell short of the mark but the Proms saved the epoch, as it were, with two BBC commissions: a fine 'millennium cantata' by Jonathan Harvey, Mothers Shall Not Cry, and Robin Holloway's ambitious Symphony which pretty well succeeded in summing up the twentieth century in music.

Indeed it was a pivotal year for the BBC and the Proms all round: Sir Andrew Davis bowed out as popular chief conductor of the BBC Symphony Orchestra with a repeat of his witty G&S showpiece on the last night, and the orchestra celebrated its seventieth birthday with a new American conductor, Leonard Slatkin, and a new concert home at the Barbican. Anniversaries drive the season, sometimes to maddening excess. Aaron Copland's centenary led to the overdue reassessment of this all-American maverick, with Kurt Weill and Sullivan enjoying birthday attentions. But it was Bach, in the 250th year since his death, who dominated the concert schedules - who can complain of that?

The most consistently impressive act of love was John Eliot Gardiner's Bach pilgrimage, with his Monteverdi Choir and English Baroque Soloists. They performed 198 cantatas in 90 concerts across 15 European countries at a cost of £6 million. Not all was plain sailing. Two managers departed and recording plans were severely trimmed. Deutsche Grammophon changed hands and the new owner, Universal, was less than enthusiastic at the vast scheme it had inherited, agreeing to a mere dozen discs instead of the proposed 60.

The Royal Opera House, once again, dominated the headlines as the company struggled to work out how to push the right buttons in the new building in its first full season. The revival of Harrison Birtwistle's spellbinding Gawain ground to a halt when equipment broke down and other productions (not to mention audiences) suffered comparable insults and injuries. Some of the best ROH events of the year were actually those staged by the Kirov, whose phenomenal summer season of Prokofiev, Mussorgsky and Tchaikovsky will live long in the memory.

While at the ROH the scaffolding came down, at the Coliseum it went up in the form of Stefanos Lazaridis's fixed set for the recent Italian Season. Not everyone loved this building-site feel, but it got us in hard-hat mood for a £30m revamp in time for the building's centenary celebrations in 2004.

Artistically, English National Opera had highs and lows. Let's concentrate on the former. For pure enjoyment and level of achievement, the long overdue first London staging of John Adam's Nixon in China was unbeatable. Mark-Anthony Turnage's The Silver Tassie lived up to its promise and Jonathan Dove's community opera Palace in the Sky in Hackney, co-ordinated by the ENO Studio, was a delight.

Richard Jones's Opera North production of Pelléas and Mélisande penetrated to the heart of Debussy's elusive work. Elsewhere, Welsh National Opera enjoyed a triumph with, among other things, Tchaikovsky's Queen of Spades. Scottish Opera, whose forthcoming season has been cut back for lack of funding, achieved spectacular results with Wagner (Parsifal, and the start of a new Ring cycle, which continues next summer at the Edinburgh Festival).

The South Bank continued to emit an air of stagnant confusion, one-off events notwithstanding. The muddle over building plans seems to have filtered down to concert life where there are enough 'strands' to knit a polychromatic tea-cosy. Next year, its fiftieth birthday, presents an opportunity for clarity.

The Barbican, enlivened by the continuing high standards of the LSO and the new relationship with the BBCSO, has generated more energy and achieved higher profile. In Birmingham the CBSO continues to thrive with Sakari Oramo and its new chief executive Stephen Maddock. So too does its sister contemporary music group, BCMG. The Hallé has the bonus of Mark Elder as its new conductor, making it properly competitive with the redoubtable BBC Philharmonic. The Royal Liverpool Philharmonic and Bournemouth Symphony struggle on manfully against mighty financial odds.

Pierre Boulez's seventy-fifth birthday was celebrated in style. Two musical titans, William Glock and Lord Yehudi Menuhin, died.

Technophile excitement over MP3 and the prospect of piratically 'downloading' music free of charge flowered and died. The livelihood of musicians and recording companies seem marginally safer than they did a year ago. Now, after all the millennial frenzy, musical life can get back to normal.

TOP 10 MUSICAL EVENTS OF THE YEAR
Nixon in China ENO, Coliseum
The Last Supper Glyndebourne Touring Opera
The Silver Tassie ENO, Coliseum
Jane Eyre Music Theatre Wales, Cheltenham Festival
Palace in the Sky ENO Studio, Hackney Empire
The Trojans LSO, Barbican
Queen of Spades Welsh National Opera, Cardiff
Das Rheingold Scottish Opera
Tristan und Isolde Royal Opera House
Beethoven's Op 131 Takacs Quartet, South Bank
TURKEY OF THE YEAR
Italian Season ENO, Coliseum

fields.headline: They struck the jackpot
fields.standfirst: Apart from that tent, it's been a bumper year for Lottery-funded projects
fields.trailText: Architecture 2000: Apart from that tent, it's been a bumper year for Lottery-funded projects.
fields.body:
Much as we might prefer to forget, this was meant to be the year of the Dome. 'Believe me, it will be the envy of the world,' said Tony Blair unveiling those first gaudy computer renderings back in 1998. The Prime Minister professed to be so confident, because 'we can boast of a richness of talent in this country that is unparalleled, the finest artists, architects and designers... we are leading the world in creativity'.

The wonder is that, despite the Prime Minister's frantic efforts to make us all stop worrying and love the Dome, Britain's architects have managed to emerge from disaster relatively unscathed. The Dome was the embodiment of the new, architect-designed Britain, the Britain of New Labour and new media. Most of it has gone down the dotcom drain. But seen simply as a work of architecture, the Dome itself has had a surprisingly easy ride - it is big, impressive and instantly recognisable.

What really sticks in the craw is the profligate, wrong-headed, insane waste of money its contents represent. Despite the Prime Minister's claim that the project would not 'cost any taxpayer's money, just £400 million of lottery money', it is unlikely to leave much change from £1 billion, including the £150m it cost to clear toxic waste away from the site.

If British architecture is as costly as all that, it's amazing that there has not been a more militant reaction against it. Yet despite revelling in the difficulties of the wobbling footbridge and the French stone palmed off on the British Museum, we still seem to be in love with our architects. They have, if nothing else, managed to make some pretty murky corners of Britain look glamorous. But as the Peckham tragedy played out on the security cameras of the same library that had flashed across our television screens a week earlier as the winner of the Stirling Prize, it showed design is not a magic wand wishing the traumas of a troubled society away.

It has been a remarkable year by any standards, one of those once-in-a-generation moments when an entire country undergoes an architectural transformation. In London, the Royal Opera House, the National Portrait Gallery, the Wallace Collection, Somerset House, Tate Modern, the Royal Court, the British Museum and the Science Museum have all emerged blinking into bright, new early twenty-first-century garb in a way not seen since the Edwardians rebuilt the city 100 years earlier.

Outside London, there has been the Walsall Art Gallery, the Eden Centre in Cornwall, the Lowry in Salford, the Bristol 2000, the Seed Bank in Sussex, the new Welsh Botanical Gardens and a horde of others. We are not allowed to call these places museums or galleries any more, they are centres, a term considered to be far less stuffy. In a decade, they will be just as much period pieces as the monuments of the Festival of Britain, distinguished by structural exhibitionism, Arne Jacobsen café chairs and limestone floors.

The architects will not see the like of the past year again, and they should be grateful, not least to John Major to whom came the whole idea of using a lottery to pay for refurbishing Britain's cultural plant. We are already falling out of love with the glut of Lottery-sponsored bread and circuses. We've begun to worry about their long-term appeal.

Sheffield's National Centre for Popular Music turned out to be the first documented casualty, but the Earth Centre and the Royal Armouries have both been badly hit by numbers that didn't stack up. These flops, together with the fiasco of the Dome contents, may yet produce a reaction if not against British design, then a backlash against the condescension of turning culture into a question of interactive, spoon-fed display.

Not all the changes in the past year have come from the Lottery. The single most impressive project of 2000 has been the extension of the Jubilee Line. Its stations, designed by architects from Will Alsop to Lord Foster, are a stunning reminder of what a civilised city's public realm can be like.

Nor is it Lottery money that is responsible for the massive transformation that has overtaken so many of Britain's cities. From Canary Wharf to the centres of Glasgow and Manchester, there has been a decisive shift in the climate in which we approach architecture and the city. Lord Rogers's years of plugging away at the urban agenda, alongside the way city-centre lofts now look so much more appealing than Brookside Closes, have triggered a change in our attitudes to the city.

But just how convincing do the Prime Minister's claims about the quality of British architecture really look? It is noticeable that the single greatest architectural success of the year, Tate Modern, is the product of the austere Swiss partnership, Herzog and de Meuron; the new Walsall Gallery, designed by Caruso St John, is a handsome but equally austere building which very much follows the same European direction. And in many ways, British architecture seems to be more peripheral to the main direction of architecture internationally than it has done for decades.

Of course, the two big names - Norman Foster and Richard Rogers - carry enormous clout, and operate on a global scale. Their impact at home has been to transform the expectations of the big corporations who are now ready to work with them. Britain has been rebuilt with an architectural repertoire that was essentially forged by the Pompidou and the Hongkong and Shanghai Bank in the Seventies and Eighties. Now it needs a period to recharge its architectural batteries.

Top 10 buildings of the year

Tate Modern Herzog and de Meuron

National Portrait Gallery Jeremy Dixon and Edward Jones

Jubilee Line extension Various architects

Walsall Art Gallery Caruso St John

Royal Opera House Dixon and Jones

London Eye Barfield and Marks

Eden Centre Nicholas Grimshaw and Partners

The Lowry Michael Wilford and Partners

British Museum Great Court Foster and Partners

Dulwich Picture Gallery extension Rick Mather

Turkey of the year

Vauxhall Cross flats Broadway and Malyan

Sheffield's National Centre for Popular Music turned out to be the first documented casualty, but the Earth Centre and the Royal Armouries have both been badly hit by numbers that didn't stack up. These flops, together with the fiasco of the Dome contents, may yet produce a reaction if not against British design, then a backlash against the condescension of turning culture into a question of interactive, spoon-fed display. Not all the changes in the past year have come from the Lottery. The single most impressive project of 2000 has been the extension of the Jubilee Line. Its stations, designed by architects from Will Alsop to Lord Foster, are a stunning reminder of what a civilised city's public realm can be like. Nor is it Lottery money that is responsible for the massive transformation that has overtaken so many of Britain's cities. From Canary Wharf to the centres of Glasgow and Manchester, there has been a decisive shift in the climate in which we approach architecture and the city. Lord Rogers's years of plugging away at the urban agenda, alongside the way city-centre lofts now look so much more appealing than Brookside Closes, have triggered a change in our attitudes to the city. But just how convincing do the Prime Minister's claims about the quality of British architecture really look? It is noticeable that the single greatest architectural success of the year, Tate Modern, is the product of the austere Swiss partnership, Herzog and de Meuron; the new Walsall Gallery, designed by Caruso St John, is a handsome but equally austere building which very much follows the same European direction. And in many ways, British architecture seems to be more peripheral to the main direction of architecture internationally than it has done for decades. Of course, the two big names - Norman Foster and Richard Rogers - carry enormous clout, and operate on a global scale. Their impact at home has been to transform the expectations of the big corporations who are now ready to work with them. Britain has been rebuilt with an architectural repertoire that was essentially forged by the Pompidou and the Hongkong and Shanghai Bank in the Seventies and Eighties. Now it needs a period to recharge its architectural batteries. fields.headline: On the wall, off the wall
fields.standfirst: William next to Peter Blake, Turners with no frames and still lifes to die for
fields.trailText: Art 2000: William next to Peter Blake, Turners with no frames and still lifes to die for.
fields.body:
This was The Year of Art - if measured entirely in figures. Sponsorship boomed. Art prices soared. New galleries opened their doors. Tickets to the launch of Tate Modern changed hands for a grand, and those who tried to sneak in through the café entrance were sent to the back of a mile-long queue. Three and a half million people visited in the first six months, prompting the critic of the New York Times to declare the British out of their minds. Others sneered that the only draw was the vast scale of the Turbine Hall. How wrong could they be? Consider the figures for the Dome.

William Blake reversed the fortunes of Tate Britain - nothing but bare ruined choirs since the mass exit of international art to Tate Modern. Apocalypse was a sell-out for the Royal Academy, despite the best efforts of high and mighty critics who could barely squeeze through the coal hole that led into Gregor Schneider's dripping cellar and the rest of this horror-and-beauty spectacular. The National Gallery began the year with Seeing Salvation, the only millennium show devoted to Christ. It welcomed an equally massive congregation of worshippers at the close of 2000 with Impression - Monet, Renoir and the rest.

Walsall got a wonderful new museum, perfectly tailored, like some wood-lined house, to the page-sized scale of its Rembrandts, Goyas and Cézannes. The Dulwich Picture Gallery reopened. So did the Wallace Collection, with more capacity for Laughing Cavaliers. Somerset House opened two new galleries, one for the Gilbert Collection, the other for a Thames-side satellite to the Hermitage. Both are currently displaying expensive forks - but we live in hope.

This was the year of the game show, and the game was a free for all. Art was displayed in every possible way except for the traditional hang. Chronology was junked, movements and context were scrambled. Tate Britain hung William next to Peter Blake, Maggie Hambling next to Hogarth. Tate Modern plumped for the four seventeenth-century academic genres: landscape, history, still life and the nude. Some people hated seeing Duchamp in Still Life or Dan Flavin's neon tubes in History. But the rooting of the modern back to its ancient origins was rational, if not conservative. By the end of the year, though, with The Human Image at the British Museum, this trend was leading to chaos.

Far more serious was the complete lack of innovative contemporary shows in many public galleries. The Serpentine played safe with Gillian Wearing. But the Whitechapel was all retro, harking back to the Sixties and Seventies in most of its shows. Oxford's Museum of Modern Art, the Fruitmarket in Edinburgh and the Arnolfini in Bristol all wandered without purpose or direction. As for the British Art Show 5, this lame dog is still limping around the country.

There were other baffling questions. What happened to the promised instalment of Neurotic Realism, due at the Saatchi Gallery in the spring? Why did Saatchi pay Damien Hirst £1 million for an outsize Humbrol toy? Did Hirst really think he could get away with simply enlarging Norman Emm's original plastic model from 10 inches to 20ft of bronze? On the subject of bronze, why is Bill Woodrow's monumental sculpture still lodged on the fourth plinth in Trafalgar Square long after its removal date?

Scotland had a hot summer with its festival exhibitions - Constable, Spencer, Dali and a full-dress show of Paul Klee, the first in Britain for 40 years. Its National Gallery, meanwhile, put on another of those classically boring shows that make you wonder anew why Timothy Clifford keeps being touted as the next director of the V&A.

Tate Liverpool had a stream of hits: Tony Cragg, Mark Wallinger and Turner's paintings shown without glass, frames or electric bulbs - his ever-changing rhetoric of light seen, as it were, in a radical new light. Telly didn't bother with Turner, 150 years after his death, having spent most of the year following the grand projets of Tate Modern and the British Museum. But it did turn out a snappy documentary about Blake, in which tearful celebrities paid tribute to the visionary spirit of this penniless genius. A few weeks later, the schedules gave us the Turner Prize, handed to a former fashion photographer by a back-slapping fashion designer.

Awards of the year must surely go to Tate Modern: fully a thousand works displayed in room after elegant room, unfolding like some cool, contemporary Versailles towards vistas of the river and the London skyline. Everyone knew it would be the People's Palace - and it was. But the most beautiful show of the year could have fitted into a single corner of Tate Modern. Chardin at the Royal Academy gave you the greatest still life painter in the history of art. A few glowing strawberries, a herring or two, some crusts and a glass of silvery water: humble objects, once transformed by his art, that will never look the same again.

Top 10 arts events of the year

Chardin Royal Academy

Tate Modern

1900: Art at the Crossroads Royal Academy

Seeing Salvation National Gallery

Turner: The Sun is God Tate Liverpool

Paul Klee Scottish National Gallery of Modern Art

William Blake Tate Britain

Brice Marden Serpentine

Art Nouveau V&A

Mariele Neudecker Ikon Gallery, Birmingham

Turkey of the year

Ant Noises I and II Saatchi Gallery
