webTitle: Kathryn Flett: No Yule like an old Yule

fields.headline: No Yule like an old Yule
fields.standfirst: A typical feast of festive viewing includes a turkey, toys, death, chestnuts and yet more   turkeys
fields.trailText:
Cutting Edge: A Very British Christmas C4
Hamleys: a Real Toy Story C4
A Christmas Carol ITV
Mirrorball BBC1
Death of The Dome BBC2
fields.body:
Cutting Edge: A Very British Christmas C4
Hamleys: a Real Toy Story C4
A Christmas Carol ITV
Mirrorball BBC1
Death of The Dome BBC2

Paul, a turkey farmer interviewed in Cutting Edge 's 'A Very Cynical Christmas' - no, sorry, make that British Christmas - gave us a tour of his premises, which looked like Sizewell B: 'Five to six hundred thousand eggs in the summer... incubated at a temperature of 37.3 degrees... humidity at 29.5 degrees... eggs rotated through 90 degrees every hour... then from the hatchery - the maternity ward! - to the despatch room, where they're sexed... we do 20-hour days in the three or four days before Christmas... eating turkey every day for a fortnight... tasting a bird from each flock.' Flock: that was a tender, even twitcherly touch, given that Paul's turkey chicks don't really have the chance to get in touch with their inner flock, just blink, bob and gobble in their trays like a strain of feathery Pokémon.

Paul gave us some tips for turkey roasting: 'Pre-heat oven to 200 degrees... bird in the tin breast-down... 10 minutes a pound... turn over to brown breast off half an hour before it's finished cooking... test with a fork deep into the thigh muscle... if the juices run clear, it's cooked.'

Now, like Paul, too much exposure to turkeys has made me keen on the idea of a Christmas goose, even though the last time I cooked one my husband left me shortly afterwards. How could I have known he was that fond of turkey?

In Hamleys: a Real Toy Story, maintenance men Roy and Pat sat with their flasks under the strip-lighting in the Regent Street sub-basement ('near the Underground') and bemoaned the fact that 'this used to be the finest toyshop in the world, but it's gone down a bit'. At the end of 1999, the venerable institution's annual profits had plummeted from £7 million to £27,000, so there was a new boss (cheerful Simon, fresh from Virgin) and his deputy (scary John, Mr Flipchart, the Management Moonie). John corralled the sales staff and bullied them a bit ('dirty, dirty, dirty') before building them up again. 'We have the chance to do something about it, yeah?' 'Yeah,' muttered Andrew from toy soldiers and Libby from teddy bears half-heartedly.

Elsewhere in Hamleys in 1999, Ian, a toy buyer like the Tom Hanks character in Big, went to New York to try to replicate his finest professional hour. In 1988, Ian had brought the dancing flower to Britain and was thus something of a legend in the business. 'It's one line in a lifetime,' he mused wistfully. 'I don't think I'll ever find another line like that.' Last Christmas, however, Ian surpassed himself, introducing the nation to both the microscooter and Big Mouth Billy Bass.

The shop refit turned out to be the nightmare before Christmas. At the Nuremberg toy fair (who would have thought Nuremberg could be so much fun ?), Simon spotted a big train set he wanted to install in the shop, but you knew it was all going to go a bit Willy Wonka when he came home and commissioned a British company to provide the track. Dismalness ensued and the result was indeed, as Simon said, 'embarrassing, pathetic, boring'. The film crew even captured a disturbing close-up of a miniature derailment.

Simon's CV does not, however, include Virgin trains, which is probably why he's become chairman and turned the company around. Though I do think he should give Fran ('I've been in showbusiness all my life') back her puppet show. And when, after 47 years of mole-like service, Pat retired his flask and handed over his keys to Roy, shouldn't he have been presented with an engraved Billy Bass?

The best, and worst, thing about Christmas television is its awesome predictability, a feeling reinforced by ITV's A Christmas Carol, the festive vehicle for Ross Kemp. Like Scrooge during one of his groundhog Christmas Eves, the sharp-eyed viewer may have recognised that we've been here before. In this modern adaptation, Kemp played a loan shark whose beat was a council estate and, funnily enough, this was the very same council estate that, just a few weeks ago, acted as the backdrop for John Simm's loan shark in the excellent Never Never, so I hope the residents are on a profit-share scheme from the rental of their location and will now have a very merry Christmas without the distraction of any more unpleasant murders taking place in the underground car-park.

Though Kemp's Scrooge all too predictably revisited the ghost of Grant Mitchell's past, this wasn't a bad Christmas Carol and there were some funny, panto-villainesque lines. When, for example, Bob Cratchit pleaded for time off work ('Tim's in hospital again, so I was thinking of the whole day'), Kemp, a thoroughly modern, Tropicana-orange- juice-drinking, Plasma-screen-watching Scrooge, added Loaded-style lairiness to the traditional litany of hisses and humbuggery: 'And I was thinking of inviting Britney Spears over for an eggnog.'

Déjà-viewing, too, in Mirrorball, in which Jennifer Saunders has reconvened the Ab Fab team as a bunch of variously unsuccessful and monumentally talentless luvvies. Saunders's Edina is now Vivienne Keill who spent six years in Hollywood wearing a small rubber trunk in Star Trek, but admits that the 'peak of my career might have been playing Twisted Labia, sidekick to Little Nell in the non-Derek Jarman sequel to Jubilee - and even in that I wandered around with "No Future" felt-penned on my forehead.'

Vivienne managed to beat off competition from Bonnie Langford (a multi-tasking enigma is Bonnie: she sent herself up beautifully here in the same week she appeared playing it straight on Barrymore and showing off her new baby in Hello! ) to win herself a role in the musical version of Angela's Ashes - her audition masterstroke a brogueish rendition of Send in the Clowns with a little light Riverdancing on the side. Meanwhile, Joanna Lumley's Patsy has been reconfigured as Jackie Riviera, star of Disco Follies '77 and a bottle blonde with black tips, exactly like an ageing Christina Aguilera.

Mirrorball lacks Ab Fab 's Zeitgeisty absurdity, but you couldn't not giggle and everybody got a good line or two (the resting actress who had just lost her role in 'Tony and Cherie: the Musical', for example. All together now: 'We live at Ten and Eleven/ but we're all sixes and sevens...') and there was a tour de force from Jane Horrocks as the miserablist Nordic Yitta Hilberstam, whose CV included 'skippings, spinnings, dancings and showings at the Millennium Dome'. While Yitta sang 'Show Me the Way to the Next Whisky Bar', Vivienne watched admiringly: 'I should have done Brecht.' 'It's Weill,' said Jackie. 'It's working,' countered Viv.

Though Mirrorball was billed as a pilot, I suspect Viv and Jackie might find themselves working in the longest run of their lives.

In Death of the Dome, the world's emptiest metaphor was described by a gleeful cartoonist as 'a gift from God'. A gift from God, too, for the makers of last year's riveting Trouble at the Big Top, whose final visit this was. It was good to catch up with the cast again: bow-tied, buffoonish Derek, creator of the Earth Zone; that nice couple with the baby who had created the Play Zone (and won an award for it. Presumably the only award the Dome has ever received that hasn't been subsidised by the tax payer), and John Hackney, the man who filled the Body Zone with Tommy Cooper and pubic hair.

The show was unadulterated joy: from the footage of the PR débcle that was last New Year's Eve (and from which the tent never recovered, as small children cried before they'd even set foot in the place and angry broadsheet editors bristled), right up to the final shots of piled-high mini Domes reduced from £10 to £4.99. 'There were problems with people not knowing how to turn it on in the morning,' said Hackney of his beleaguered body, though next week the Body Zone will finally be able to sigh and say: 'Not now, Monsieur Gerbeau, I've got a headache,' and get away with it.

Predictably but perversely, this knowledge made me want to rush straight to Greenwich, if only because, having sold so few of them, the souvenirs are bound to become very collectable.

fields.headline: Go on, take the money and hum
fields.standfirst: Vacuous hits ruled the charts, but there was fine music on the margins
fields.trailText: Pop 2000: Vacuous hits ruled the charts, but there was fine music on the margins
fields.body:
It was a year whose hottest act wound up in court in handcuffs, whose biggest rock band released an album with scarcely a song or a guitar on it (they then toured in a circus tent), and whose biggest selling album came from a group celebrating the thirtieth anniversary of their break-up. Take a bow Eminem, Radiohead and the Beatles.

As ever, 2000 gave us fine, occasionally great music. There were intriguing debuts (Badly Drawn Boy, Coldplay, Tom McRae) and convincing returns (U2, PJ Harvey). The British underground conjured up another genre, UK Garage, and the artists to take it to the mainstream (Craig David, Wookie). From America's margins, outfits such as Lambchop and Grandaddy issued lo-fi gems and African-Americans confirmed their rediscovery of their soulful traditions with albums by D'Angelo, Jill Scott, Erykah Badu, Angie Stone and more. There was more music than ever, from more sources, with Brazil a pervasive flavour (Bebel Gilberto, Da Lata, Virginia Rodriguez).

And yet, and yet pop 2000 was at ease with neither itself nor its place in the world. In the perennial conflict between artistry and commerce, self-expression and cynical marketing manoeuvre, there was no doubt which emerged the winner. In the new millennium, popular music is too fragmented and too compromised by corporate power to wield any real cultural clout. Mainstream pop and mainstream values now bleed seamlessly into each other.

Take the most enduringly successful UK chart album of the last 12 months, Moby's Play. Every one of its tracks has now been licensed for a movie soundtrack or a TV ad, at least one of the latter being for the motor trade - pretty rich for a self-avowed Christian ecologist (pretty rich being the apparent operative principle).

If music and marketing are now interchangeable for musicians, how much more so for record company boardrooms, where the number crunchers and demographics experts hold sway as never before. In the UK at least, their strategy is brutally short-term. Obsessed with snatching a bite of the pre-teen market, they have thrown money at anonymous boy and girl groups rather than developing talent that might provide long- term returns via album sales.

Coupled with the fame- school ethic that has invaded British pop - it doesn't matter whether you make it as a soap star, a games show presenter or a pop star, as long as you make it - one result has been a succession of vacuous hits.

Another has been the decline of the British music industry as a global force, able to punch above its weight by producing influential, internationally renowned acts - the Beatles and Stones legacy. Sure, we still export Robbie Williams and Blur to Belgium and Australia, but in the all- important American market, only one British act made any serious impact in 2000 - Radiohead, whose defiantly experimental Kid A album hit the top of the US charts. The managing director of Radiohead's record company, Tony Wadsworth of EMI, bravely observed that 'the message is clear for UK record companies: take risks, ditch the formulae and support creative artist development, because it pays off.' Ironically, EMI, the last British major record company left standing, spent the year expecting to be merged with one or another multinational conglomerate; first Warners, then Bertelsmann, owners of the BMG group.

At times British pop seemed degraded into an adjunct of Celebrity Squares. Posh'n'Becks, Madonna'n'Guy and Liam'n'Nicole merged into one continuous Heat cover story, and record companies fought to put out singles by Big Brother contestants. Add to that the ascendancy of the manufactured teen idol - Christina Aguilera, Britney Spears, S Club 7 - and the decline of pop as a form of vigorous self-expression is obvious, and, as the feeble output of the solo Spice Girls attests, it doesn't make for memorable music. Or memorable viewing. It was in character with the year that the one television music show that doesn't follow the agenda of Saturday morning kids' telly - Later - found itself under threat.

The rise and rise of teeny pop partly reflects the long- term decline of the rock band as pop's driving force, a decline attested to by the closure of Melody Maker and Select, and neatly symbolised in the feud between Robbie Williams and Liam Gallagher. Guys with guitars aren't going away, but they're no longer centre stage, not in the era of rap, disco divas and the Ministry of Sound. Bono, who fulminated against the young breed of pop star, is just going to have to live with it. To drive the point home came a characterless fourth album from Oasis, followed by a live record which suggested their mutation into a Spinal Tap for the new century.

The phenomenon of the year was Eminem. The brattish rapper not only shipped bucketloads of The Marshall Mathers LP, but put on a non-stop show in which bad behaviour, unsavoury attitudes and provocative insight came hopelessly jumbled. His trailer-trash tales, an accurate reflection of the nihilism and dystopia of the American underclass, disturbed his homeland's rose-tinted view of itself, while his misogyny and homophobia made him a hostage to fortune. Being sued by your own mother, though, is a new trick even to pop.

Eminem had plenty to say about the issue which loomed like a storm cloud over the music business in 2000; the internet. His vow to 'beat the shit' out of anyone posting his music on the internet, there to be downloaded free, summed up the attitude of many musicians faced with their copyright melting into cyberspace. Led by Metallica, who bizarrely threatened to sue their own fans, the music biz waged war against Napster, the site which had caused a furore by offering a way for fans to trade MP3 music files. But in October music giant BMG signed a deal with Napster to become web partners.

The battle is in the balance, and the war over copyright, and how you exercise it, is only beginning. Will pop survive? It's survived home-taping, Sonic the Hedgehog and comedy, all of them touted as its nemesis. The real issue is whether pop can survive the music industry.

TOP 10 ALBUMS OF THE YEAR
Badly Drawn Boy The Hour of Bewilderbeast (Twisted Nerve/XL)
Johnny Cash American III; Solitary Man (Columbia)
Coldplay Parachutes (Parlophone)
Da Lata From The Tin (Palm Pictures)
David Gray White Ladder (East West)
Doves Lost Souls (Heavenly)
Lambchop Nixon (City Slang)
Tom McRae Tom McRae (DB)
Jill Scott Who is Jill Scott (Epic)
Wookie Wookie (Soul II Soul)
TURKEY OF THE YEAR
Marilyn Manson Holy Wood (Nothing)

fields.headline: Smooth bores and rough shooters
fields.standfirst: The newly nuptialled queen of pop has decided she wants to be true blue, but shooting furry little flying things is hardly the correct way to go about it, suggests  Euan Ferguson
fields.trailText: The newly nuptialled queen of pop has decided she wants to be true blue, but shooting furry little flying things is hardly the correct way to go about it, suggests Euan Ferguson.
fields.body:
It is hard to see how Madonna could have got it any more exuberantly wrong. I mean, good luck with the honeymoon and the new life in Britain, but... has some so-called friend been deliberately nasty here? In 1967, the New Statesman ran a now-famous competition inviting readers to give misleading advice for first-time visitors to London - do try the famous echo in the British Museum Reading Room; do not insult a cabbie by offering him a tip; it is impolite not to help a fellow rail-traveller stuck on a crossword clue - that kind of thing. Today, we can only look at the new Mrs Ritchie and sigh, sadly assuming that some maleficent scapegrace pulled her aside a few weeks ago and offered the following weasel words: 'British people will think you possess class if you go shooting.'

There is no excuse. Even had she simply stuck with the clay-pigeon stuff she still would have been stranding herself firmly below the salt, condemned to a dire netherworld where the gauche and the déclassé bask queasily in the flatus of past mediocrity. Roger Waters goes clay-pigeon shooting; Mark Knopfler goes clay-pigeon shooting. Everyone who has ever produced a 'concept album' would appear to feel the need to fire a shotgun aimed, quite unaccountably, away from their face. And these are the talented ones. Jeremy Clarkson shoots. Ronan Keating shoots. Dani Behr shoots. What a lovely paragraph this would be without the full stops. Sad, damp, middle-of-the-litter marketing managers with failed 'careers' and thin, bitter wives go clay-pigeon shooting together, between their damn seminars. And they all buy the same horrid stuff, the waxes and pouches and nettings and straps and tailormade Purdeys, all greasily reeking of greed and stupidity; and they preen over the tags and logos, thinking they confer an air of élan rather than conferring an air of belonging to a club of vulgar, blank-eyed, spoon-fed ox-people.

So that would have been bad enough. But Madonna went further and shot things, real flapping things, on a real estate in Scotland. This, you might think, should at least free her from the horrible nouve stigma of the clay-people; at least the real toffs wear proper logo-free clothes, old battered socks sewn together from ancient tramps' noses and grim Highland tabards steeped for a decade outside some festering Harris hovel in a butt of crofter's urine.

Wrong. It's still not classy. For this is what we should be objecting to: the tawdry coarseness of the whole thing. It's not the flapping, furry things - we don't normally give a damn, do we, what happens to them? When the Queen was pictured strangling that pheasant a few weeks ago, we weren't all that moved for the pheasant. Who, honestly, had wondered, the day before, 'Hmm... wonder how Walter the Pheasant's doing up at Balmoral?'

No, it's not the birds that should concern us but the sheer dumb baseness and tat of the whole gun business. It encapsulates the precise opposite of what can be beautiful, clever, inspiring and tasteful about British life. How smart do you have to be to pull a trigger back half an inch? What majestic co-ordination of the senses do you need in order to hit one of 20 birds flapping across your vision eight yards away? Remember - the people who go shooting are the kind of people who think black labradors are intelligent dogs.

And the kind of people who think bloodlust is a Good Thing. For that's precisely the emotion it inspires, and no one is immune. An ex-girlfriend remembers being shocked as a child by the change which swept across her father, in other times a kindly, artistic soul, on the moors. 'He got so excited about it that he made me remove my coat just so he could use it to hold the red-hot barrels and keep on firing. Then my scarf, then my jersey, then my hat.'

The aristocracy's best argument is that shooting preserves the countryside. This is, in fact, partly valid, for no one else has the money or the inclination to preserve it; it's flawed only in that no one else gets to see the saved countryside. But we're not concerned with those arguments here, and nor should Madonna be: this is a question of taste. You were wrongly advised, dear lady. Shooting is not vogue.

fields.headline: What a duff Plum
fields.standfirst: Derek Deane's Nutcracker has gone trendy, complete with mobile phone
fields.trailText: Dance: Derek Deane's Nutcracker has gone trendy, complete with mobile phone
fields.body:
The Nutcracker English National Ballet, London Coliseum

In Derek Deane's modern staging of The Nutcracker, a party guest dances with a mobile phone pressed to her ear, longing to be elsewhere - at The Lowry in Salford, perhaps, where Birmingham Royal Ballet is presenting its magical Nutcracker, or the Royal Opera House for its Victorian version.

No nostalgia for Deane. He expects his audience to identify with trendy toys and adulterous relationships. Father's mistress threatens to disrupt the Christmas party and the family; little Clara in distress is distracted by her bachelor godfather, Drosselmeyer. He entertains the children by bringing their presents to life: a Barbie doll, a Robocop and a Michael Jackson mannequin - must-haves of the Nineties, when the production was new, but by now the children would prefer Pokémons and PlayStations.

The updating is only half-hearted, for this is a traditional Nutcracker in disguise. Clara may come from a worldly family but she still dreams of snowflakes and sweeties. Alice Crawford is childlike without being cute, her wondering face and ecstatic dancing like Gelsey Kirkland's in the 1977 video of Baryshnikov's Nutcracker. Deane as Drosselmeyer has toned down the child molester implications of the role: the ugly Nutcracker doll is his alter ego, putting a brave face on his need for love.

The wooden toy transmutes into a danseur noble - Tetsuya Kumakawa on Tuesday, the London season opening night. Kumakawa left the Royal Ballet two years ago, partly because he was typecast as a jester rather than a leading man. He set up his own touring company, K Ballet, in Japan, persuading five Royal Ballet men to join him. (Their experiences are documented in a Channel 4 film, Ballet Boyz 2, scheduled for 28 January 2001.) This is the first time he has danced in London since then and his fans were out in force to see him.

He has matured in manner, though his partnering is still imperfect. Less of a firecracker, he can still float his jumps, cushioning their impact with supple pliés. He let rip with some virtuoso leaps and turns in the snowflakes scene, upstaging Deane, who had to try to keep pace with him. Although the Nutcracker Prince has plenty to do in this staging, Drosselmeyer intervenes throughout; it's his show and he's going to banish the Nutcracker before Clara can have him.

The Prince is claimed, in any case, by the Sugar Plum Fairy, who puts in a guest appearance at the last minute. Viviana Durante, now a freelance ballerina, reminded us of her elegance, though she seemed ill at ease with the choreography. Deane has embroidered the Sugar Plum's variation, attributed to Lev Ivanov in 1892. But it always includes a step that any Sugar Plum worthy of the role has to bring off: a series of gargouillades, a tricky jump like a cat shaking its paws in mid-air. And Durante could not do it.

The Nutcracker is a frustrating ballet for starry dancers, since the brief chances to shine are so exposed. Among the home team, Erina Takahashi was outstanding as a crystalline Ice Queen and Yat Sen Chang as an ebullient Cossack. The rest of the cast - rats and mice, snowflakes and peonies - make the performance an enjoyable one; Tchaikovsky's music conducted by Anthony Twiner, delivers the the thrill of an ideal white Christmas.

This is Deane's last winter season with English National Ballet, which he leaves in July after seven years as artistic director. Matz Skoog is to take over, inheriting a company with high standards of dancing and an alarming lack of money for new productions. Skoog, a dancer with the company from 1979 to 1989, developed into a sought-after teacher and producer before becoming artistic director of the Royal New Zealand Ballet in 1996.

He is a good choice to keep ENB on course, leaving Deane free to mount his arena-scale productions elsewhere in the world.

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: Christmas is the hardest time of the year for Derek Hicks, whose son Kevin disappeared without trace 14 years ago. Janet Newman of the National Missing Persons Helpline has been a constant source of support to him
fields.trailText: Christmas is the hardest time of the year for Derek Hicks, whose son Kevin disappeared without trace 14 years ago. Janet Newman of the National Missing Persons Helpline has been a constant source of support to him.
fields.body:
Derek Hicks: Kevin went missing on Sunday 2 March 1986. He was 16. It was bitterly cold, down to -8 degrees centigrade. It was a normal Sunday. Kevin was checking what he needed for domestic science on Monday and realised he was a few eggs short. At 8.30, he went to the shop, carrying just £1. He should have been 10 to 15 minutes, but hadn't returned by 10pm. It was totally out of character.

That first night was terrible: I visited the hospital, and reported him missing, and my wife Terry and I took it in turns to drive around looking for him.

The police interviewed Kevin's friends, teachers, the people he worked with. Everyone in the community was involved. There were even nationwide television appeals. They found nothing. This will be our 14th Christmas without him. My heart gets stuck in my throat at the thought of receiving a card or a phone call - any form of communication. And as it's a family time, a lot of thought goes out to him.

The police put us in touch with the National Missing Persons Helpline and Janet became our caseworker. She was a godsend. Other people would think you had done something wrong. Not Janet. When someone goes missing, you feel numb, you can't grieve properly because there's no body. Janet was someone to bounce ideas off and she'd make you feel you were contributing, whereas most of the time you'd feel helpless. Sometimes I'd think I could cope better if he'd been killed, or phoned and said he didn't want any contact. Not knowing is hard: you can't move on and you feel guilty for not thinking about him.

Kevin going missing took its toll on the family - my wife and I would blame each other, we'd also become overprotective of his sister Alex and she'd become resentful. Janet was always cool, calm and reassuring; she'd help get things back into perspective.

When my wife died of a tumour, Janet was there to console me, which was what I really needed. I really appreciate Janet's friendship, as well as her support. We are united by a common goal: we both want to find my son, and it's reassuring to know she's out there trying to make that happen.

Janet Newman: When Kevin disappeared, the only information on missing people that existed was a photocard index at Scotland Yard listing only the basic details. My sister and I had been working with the police on a missing person case and they encouraged us to start a support network. This laid the foundations of what was to become the Missing Persons Helpline.

We look after the family of the missing person, help them when they're vulnerable, talk to them when they feel low and offer friendship. We also generate publicity in the hope of finding the missing person.

The Hicks family was one of the first cases we took on. I was their caseworker from day one. I would try not to get too involved, but I inevitably did. Derek and his wife were tremendously brave. They were bewildered as to what had happened. For Kevin to visit the corner shop and then vanish into thin air was just unbelievable. Every day was like living in a fog. Practical things, such as leaving the house, would become an effort - they'd be terrified to go out in case they missed a vital phone call.

Then and now, it was easier for Derek to talk to me. Neighbours and friends tend to appropriate blame. Derek and I would talk about other things, anything that would give some clues. Sadly, we drew a blank. There was nothing to give any indication as to why Kevin would go missing, and all I could do was keep supporting the family.

Even when Terry was terminally ill, they still went ahead with a television appeal, and it's tragic that she never knew what had happened to her son. I was shattered for Derek when she died; they were a lovely couple and had been through so much.

I'm still here for Derek. Even now we're exploring new angles. This month we are releasing an age-progressed photo of what Kevin would look like aged 30. Christmas is a vulnerable time; it can make the loss all the more profound. Emotions may have eroded over time, but they never go away.

I admire Derek for his inner strength - he'll never give up. But I hope that there will be a conclusion, because the saddest thing of all is when there isn't.

And as it's a family time, a lot of thought goes out to him. The police put us in touch with the National Missing Persons Helpline and Janet became our caseworker. She was a godsend. Other people would think you had done something wrong. Not Janet. When someone goes missing, you feel numb, you can't grieve properly because there's no body. Janet was someone to bounce ideas off and she'd make you feel you were contributing, whereas most of the time you'd feel helpless. Sometimes I'd think I could cope better if he'd been killed, or phoned and said he didn't want any contact. Not knowing is hard: you can't move on and you feel guilty for not thinking about him. Kevin going missing took its toll on the family - my wife and I would blame each other, we'd also become overprotective of his sister Alex and she'd become resentful. Janet was always cool, calm and reassuring; she'd help get things back into perspective. When my wife died of a tumour, Janet was there to console me, which was what I really needed. I really appreciate Janet's friendship, as well as her support. We are united by a common goal: we both want to find my son, and it's reassuring to know she's out there trying to make that happen. Janet Newman: When Kevin disappeared, the only information on missing people that existed was a photocard index at Scotland Yard listing only the basic details. My sister and I had been working with the police on a missing person case and they encouraged us to start a support network. This laid the foundations of what was to become the Missing Persons Helpline. We look after the family of the missing person, help them when they're vulnerable, talk to them when they feel low and offer friendship. We also generate publicity in the hope of finding the missing person. The Hicks family was one of the first cases we took on. I was their caseworker from day one. I would try not to get too involved, but I inevitably did. Derek and his wife were tremendously brave. They were bewildered as to what had happened. For Kevin to visit the corner shop and then vanish into thin air was just unbelievable. Every day was like living in a fog. Practical things, such as leaving the house, would become an effort - they'd be terrified to go out in case they missed a vital phone call. Then and now, it was easier for Derek to talk to me. Neighbours and friends tend to appropriate blame. Derek and I would talk about other things, anything that would give some clues. Sadly, we drew a blank. There was nothing to give any indication as to why Kevin would go missing, and all I could do was keep supporting the family. Even when Terry was terminally ill, they still went ahead with a television appeal, and it's tragic that she never knew what had happened to her son. I was shattered for Derek when she died; they were a lovely couple and had been through so much. I'm still here for Derek. Even now we're exploring new angles. This month we are releasing an age-progressed photo of what Kevin would look like aged 30. Christmas is a vulnerable time; it can make the loss all the more profound. Emotions may have eroded over time, but they never go away. I admire Derek for his inner strength - he'll never give up. But I hope that there will be a conclusion, because the saddest thing of all is when there isn't.

webTitle: 28 die in Turkish battle for jails

fields.headline: 28 die in Turkish battle for jails
fields.standfirst: Militant prisoners are crushed after protest against smaller cells
fields.trailText: Militant prisoners are crushed after protest against smaller cells.
fields.byline: Firdevs Robinson in Ankara and Burak Baktir in Istanbul
fields.body:
Burnt books, smashed chairs and charred mattresses littered the halls of a prison in Istanbul yesterday. The authorities displayed weapons they found inside - pistols, home-made flame-throwers, bows and arrows tipped with syringe needles.

After four days of fighting that left at least 26 inmates and two soldiers dead, with 133 injured, the Turkish government regained control of 20 jails across the country. The last to resist, Umraniye jail in Istanbul, was retaken on Friday when 430 inmates surrendered.

According to the Interior Ministry, 16 of the inmates who died over the four days burnt themselves alive. For an operation named 'Return To Life', it was a bloody legacy.

Yesterday the authorities began the task of explaining to their own people and the international community - long critical of a prison system riddled with corruption and violence - why the assaults had been necessary.

Interior Minister Hikmet Sami Turk said: 'I would like the Turkish nation to openly see how the terrorist organisations were dragging our young into a quagmire.'

The government has been under growing pressure to impose discipline on Turkey's jails. The latest bout of unrest began months ago, when the authorities decided to dismantle the large wards which, they said, were ungovernable and often no-go areas for staff, and replace them with smaller units.

Militants said that they feared the authorities would abuse them if they were separated from each other, and hundreds began a hunger strike that they vowed to continue until they died or the government backed down.

The government's offer to postpone opening the new jails had no effect. On Tuesday, hundreds of troops stormed 20 prisons.

Inmates who had been on a hunger strike for almost two months were taken to hospitals, where many were refusing medical treatment. Officials have said they will be fed by force if necessary.

The authorities took the media to some of the prisons involved. At Istanbul's Bayr-ampasa jail they said that the wards, holding more than a dozen prisoners each, were being run by the inmates and had, in effect, degenerated into militant training camps.

Bayrampasa housed the leaders of the militant left- wing Revolutionary People's Liberation Party Front, the Turkish Workers and Peasant Liberation Army, the Marxist-Leninist Communist Party and the Kurdistan Workers Party, the PKK, which had called off its hunger strike.

Police showed reporters captured weapons, including a Kalashnikov assault rifle and 57 spent bullets, four pistols, 101 knives and dozens of arrows topped with needles from syringes. The inmates also had makeshift gas masks made of plastic soft-drink bottles, as well as a home-made satellite dish.

On Tuesday soldiers burst in and fought their way into the wards - the first time the authorities had entered some of the areas in almost a decade.

Days later, bullet holes could be seen in the doors and walls of the wards. Black soot covered most of the living quarters of the two-floor wards, which were littered with charred mattresses.

The downstairs area was covered with broken desks and chairs. A smashed aquarium lay scattered in the corner of one ward.

In the garden outside one of the wards sat a large cage filled with 30 black-and-white pigeons that the inmates were raising. The cage was partly smashed open, but the pigeons remained inside. Raising pigeons is a popular hobby in Turkey.

In other jails, overcrowded wards housing 100 inmates were controlled by Stalinist organisations or by the extreme Islamist groups. If it wasn't one of the political organisations, it was mafia- type gangs that ruled the roost.

In the new prisons, called F-type, individual cells or rooms house two or three people. The authorities showed journalists around, pointing to the better personal space and modern facilities.

But human rights groups say the problems go much deeper than the accommodation. They include corrupt warders and systematic violence against prisoners.

'If you want to measure the value of human life in a society, look at the prisons,' says Yilmaz Ensaroglu, president of the human rights group Mazlum Der. 'The scene at the end of this latest crackdown is the glorification of death by the militants and the scant disregard for human life by the officials. What I see in this mirror horrifies me.'

In addition to the move to small cells, the Turkish government has begun freeing thousands of inmates to reduce overcrowding and make it easier to take control of the prisons.

The government freed hundreds of prisoners on Friday as the widespread amnesty began.

The amnesty will free half of the country's 72,000 prisoners, but will not apply to prisoners who opposed the state. That includes Islamic, Kurdish or left-wing radicals such as those at Bayrampasa.

fields.headline: Millennium madness regained
fields.trailText: The posters on lamp-posts promise millennial madness (of the night-club variety); the sportscasters hail Real Madrid's victory in 'the last local derby of the century'; and discerning shoppers seize upon vast candles moulded into the legend 'XXI Century'.
fields.body:
The posters on lamp-posts promise millennial madness (of the night-club variety); the sportscasters hail Real Madrid's victory in 'the last local derby of the century'; and discerning shoppers seize upon vast candles moulded into the legend 'XXI Century'.

In Spain, at least, the Millennium will soon be upon us. Anyone who feels it flopped first time around can simply visit Madrid to welcome the Third Millennium. There will be no rivers of fire, no tricksy new architectural structures and nothing like a Dome, just fireworks and partying across the city.

It was some time during the autumn of 1999 that the residents of Madrid began to pick up official rumblings about plans to ring in 2000 - vague talk of light shows along the central Paseo de la Castellana, a string of concerts...but of course by then it was a bit late and we made do with Ketama (a modern flamenco fusion group) in the Plaza Mayor and the traditional 12 grapes, one for each strike of the clock.

This year Madrid is better prepared: the Festival of the Millennium, sponsored by the regional government, opened on Tuesday with a recital by Basque soprano Ainhoa Arteta, accompanied by flamenco dancer Sara Baras, an international rising star. The programme of concerts concludes at the end of January with Van Morrison.

'I think it's called this because the first millennial festival in Barcelona, last year, was so successful,' said Martín Pérez, whose company, Concert Studio, is organising the event.

In Madrid, the Mayor plans to spend 135 million pesetas (£502,000) on celebrations, with more than 100 musical and comedy acts playing in the city over the next two weeks.

The more high-minded have spent the past few months debating 'Two Millennia in Spanish History', or 'The Keys to Twentieth-Century Spain'. Next year there will be an exhibition in Seville, '1,000 Years of the Horse in Spanish Art', conferences such as 'The Book and the Archive in the Twenty-first Century', and the millennial prize for Mathematical Exposition.

And for those who think this simply amounts to a typically Mediterranean disregard for punctuality, the State Society for the Transition to the New Millennium is there to prove you wrong.

'The end of the millennium is definitely now,' said a society spokeswoman firmly. 'But of course the round numbers of the year 2000 were very charming, so people were bound to celebrate then.'

The society, set up by the government in June 1999, has a budget of 3,000 million pesetas (£11.1m) to organise millennial celebrations, but rather than build anything it has chosen to focus on culture, sponsoring exhibitions, concerts and conferences.

Even without a showy centrepiece, the media have slipped smoothly into line: we have celebrated the last lottery, EU meeting or judicial pardons of the millennium. And Fifa seems to agree on something, naming Real Madrid the football team of the century - even if on Wednesday Valencia sneaked ahead on goal difference to lead the Primera Liga into the Third Millennium.

Still, a few old-fashioned ways have lingered - the Millennial Society, for instance, manages to field 14 directors, 13 of them men. Some things never change.

fields.headline: A funny thing happened on the way to the studio
fields.standfirst: The live circuit continues to be the bedrock of comic talent, and there are plenty of up-and-coming acts to savour
fields.trailText: Comedy 2000: The live circuit continues to be the bedrock of comic talent, and there are plenty of up-and-coming acts to savour
fields.body:
For most of the 40 years since Beyond the Fringe there have been two competing versions of comedy - live and televised - feeding off and interbreeding with each other so furiously the lines now are all blurred. In 2000, you could watch a TV presenter such as Johnny Vaughan and see an old-school, ad-libbing stand-up comic; or you could go to French & Saunders 'live' and be presented with a fully scripted sketch show reliant entirely for its ideas and images on the crystal box.

In such a cockeyed universe, it is impossible to tell which is parasite and which host. Most of the big live comedy festivals on the planet - Edinburgh, Montreal, Melbourne - are at their core not much more than mass pitching sessions for TV; and yet the hyperreal stars of TV - Ruby Wax, Graham Norton, Lenny Henry - return to clapped-out theatres in Britain's dusty old provincial towns in search of some elemental comedic truth.

Both sides of the comedy business have thrived this year, and not only in monetary terms. It was not a watershed year, but the ills long diagnosed in British TV comedy (flat characters, gaggy dialogue, narrow, suburban vistas) and in British live comedy (lame observations, laddish innuendo, the imaginative spark of an anemone) seem to be being cured. There was a noticeable effort to promote innovation and intelligence.

The Royle Family, flagship of the BBC's new quest for naturalism, moved from BBC2 to BBC1 without losing any of its gorgeous stains, wrinkles or pauses. The second series of The League of Gentlemen took the show's dark surrealism into catchphrase country without sacrificing its scarily believable heart. Repeats of Father Ted and How Do You Want Me? revealed their brilliance more fully on second viewing - and readvertised the talents of Graham Linehan (co-writer of Ted) and Dylan Moran (star of How?) ahead of their glorious collaboration on Black Books, which looks so vital and anarchic next to the slickly predictable cleverness of Friends and Frasier.

Nevertheless, the nine-months-a-year entertainment offered by American writing teams remains the holy grail for many in British TV. Which explains the money pumped into Sky One's Time Gentlemen Please (the successful transformation of Al Murray's live character, the Pub Landlord) and BBC1's My Family. Neither set the world alight, but there is a solid intelligence to both. At least the knee-jerk, cowardly desire to get laughs by throwing in dumbly punning one-liners was absent. Sadly, the same could not be said of the massively disappointing Hippies, which ruined its rich material by sneering at rather than inhabiting the times. Elsewhere, the filming of Chris Morris's Blue Jam radio series - renamed Jam - gave a rare, nasty bite to TV comedy but lost the floating otherworldliness of the audio version. The 11 O'Clock Show went into terminal decline as its star progeny, Ali G, turned a guerrilla sketch character into a youth icon.

But, as the success of Moran, Murray and the League of Gentlemen proves, the bedrock of TV comedy remains the live circuit: all three are winners of the Edinburgh Fringe's Perrier Prize. This year's winner, Rich Hall, is neither young nor homegrown - he's a grizzled American comedy veteran - but his live character comedy show, Otis Lee Crenshaw, mixes country music, sublimely smart humour and occasional outrageousness into the best night out since the glory days of the Pub Landlord. As for homegrown British talent, the brightest new hopes were Noble & Silver, winners of the Perrier Best Newcomer award, who blend the demands and strengths of live and televised comedy into startling new shapes. They are daring, innovative, funny and genuinely new.

TOP 10 COMEDY SHOWS OF THE YEAR
Black Books C4
Otis Lee Crenshaw
The Royle Family BBC1
Noble & Silver
Third Rock From the Sun BBC2
The League of Gentlemen BBC2
Jam C4
Dave Gorman
Time Gentlemen Please Sky One
My Family BBC1
TURKEY OF THE YEAR
Hippies BBC2

webTitle: Review:  The Corrs at Wembley Arena

fields.headline: Corrs and effect
fields.standfirst: It's not that the Corrs are dreadful, but they really ought to do something about the people who attend their gigs
fields.trailText: It's not that the Corrs are dreadful, but they really ought to do something about the people who attend their gigs
fields.body:
The Corrs

London Wembley Arena

'The Corrs always remind me of Fleetwood Mac,' opined a friend, shortly before I made my way to Wembley last Thursday evening. It is an obvious comparison to make. Both bands are winsome, radio-friendly and have sold records by the truckload.

Onstage and knee-deep in swirling strings and breathy backing vocals, the Corrs do indeed invoke Fleetwood Mac to a degree. Their cover of 'Dreams', in fact, receives the loudest cheer of the evening.

But the fabled British/ American group produced three classic AOR albums in their commercial heyday, all borne to fruition by the inter-relationship wrangling of key members Stevie Nicks, Lindsey Buckingham, Mick Fleetwood and Christine McVie.

The romantic turmoil of aborted and then resumed alliances produced Fleetwood Mac, Rumours and Tusk. It's clear that the Corrs have no such angst to distil into their songwriting. The three sisters and one brother grin at each other throughout the show, occasionally breaking into familial hugs. There are few discernible signs of sibling rivalry. The only sign of an abundant ego rests with the violin player, Sharon, who stands in front of a fan that blows back her immaculately tailored tresses.

The lead vocalist, ever-blushing Andrea, sashays across the stage dressed in a halter top, a bejewelled belt draped across her bean-pole waist. Andrea pouts and preens under the Wembley stage lights, and the fans scream their approval at her every movement. And with a voice that tends towards the diva-esque, Andrea certainly can sing: she'll probably be the first Corr to go solo.

The music isn't appalling: merely inoffensive in its lack of soul. That needn't always be a bad thing - Seventies rock has, in recent months, been re-appropriated by dance groups like Phoenix who plagiarise West Coast rock for its wealth of sheer irony. The fact that the Corrs do the same with such reverence irks me throughout the performance - why can't they poke fun at themselves?

Only Caroline, the drummer, seems not to relish the group's schmaltzy material, preferring to pound on the drums as if hoping to win an audition for Iron Maiden. Caroline, I surmise, would much rather be a stadium drummer, and she thunders out salvoes on her kit at any opportunity.

The violin-and-tin-whistle instrumentals prove annoying: co-opting British regional music into mainstream pop is almost always a bad idea. Back in 1982, Scots rockers Big Country enjoyed a mainstream success similar to that of the Corrs, emphasising vocalist Stuart Adamson's Scottish influences (his adopted home-town was Dunfermline).

Wringing bagpipe sounds from their instruments, the group released two commercially successful - albeit musically diabolical - albums and a handful of hit singles. But they failed to extricate themselves from their kilts'n'Kirkcaldy imagery and subsequent albums failed to ignite the imagination.

But while Big Country threw themselves into the politics and spirit of the era, the Corrs make no attempts at social commentary. Their only concession to human kind is a gut-churning version of John Lennon's 'Happy Xmas [War Is Over]', itself a blood-curdling indicator of the late Beatles's egotistical nature.

As Sharon, Caroline and Andrea wave to us and chant 'War Is Over', the crowds at Wembley hold hands: three generations of one family stand up behind me and embrace in a group hug. I look for the nearest exit.

Looking across the crowd at Wembley - middle aged, suburban, reluctant to dance - you feel the Corrs' audience mightn't ever tire of listening to these airbrushed hymns to Ireland.

And yet the music isn't so dreadful, nor will it sound dated this time next year. No, the Corrs have another problem - a hurdle only they can overcome. Put the fiddle and the tin whistle into storage: some national artefacts are worth leaving alone.

The violin-and-tin-whistle instrumentals prove annoying: co-opting British regional music into mainstream pop is almost always a bad idea. Back in 1982, Scots rockers Big Country enjoyed a mainstream success similar to that of the Corrs, emphasising vocalist Stuart Adamson's Scottish influences (his adopted home-town was Dunfermline). Wringing bagpipe sounds from their instruments, the group released two commercially successful - albeit musically diabolical - albums and a handful of hit singles. But they failed to extricate themselves from their kilts'n'Kirkcaldy imagery and subsequent albums failed to ignite the imagination. But while Big Country threw themselves into the politics and spirit of the era, the Corrs make no attempts at social commentary. Their only concession to human kind is a gut-churning version of John Lennon's 'Happy Xmas [War Is Over]', itself a blood-curdling indicator of the late Beatles's egotistical nature. As Sharon, Caroline and Andrea wave to us and chant 'War Is Over', the crowds at Wembley hold hands: three generations of one family stand up behind me and embrace in a group hug. I look for the nearest exit. Looking across the crowd at Wembley - middle aged, suburban, reluctant to dance - you feel the Corrs' audience mightn't ever tire of listening to these airbrushed hymns to Ireland. And yet the music isn't so dreadful, nor will it sound dated this time next year. No, the Corrs have another problem - a hurdle only they can overcome. Put the fiddle and the tin whistle into storage: some national artefacts are worth leaving alone.

webTitle: Photography review: Freeze Frame: Jacques Henri Lartigue

fields.headline: If it moves, shoot it
fields.standfirst: In the paradoxical world of Jacques Henri Lartigue, time is frozen and gravity defied
fields.trailText: In the paradoxical world of Jacques Henri Lartigue, time is frozen and gravity defied
fields.body:
Freeze Frame: Jacques Henri Lartigue

Michael Hoppen Gallery, London, until 31 January 2001

Although Jacques Henri Lartigue was nearly 70 when his photographs were first exhibited, the work in his inaugural show was primarily that of a child artist. Of the 42 pictures on the walls of New York's Museum of Modern Art in 1963, only three were taken after the First World War.

It says something about the quality of all of Lartigue's work that his earliest could be seen as representative. There is an infectious, childlike glee in his photographs, from a shot of his uncles fighting, both straddled on a log laid across a stream, to a luscious picture of cabaret dancers relaxing on the Riviera. He was a master of the family snapshot, the fleeting moment, the sunny smile.

Lartigue was born in Paris at the end of the nineteenth century into a wealthy, high-society family with a few eccentrics in its midst. His father was a banker and keen amateur photographer. His grandfather was one of the inventors of the monorail system, and his elder brother designed and built aeroplanes as early as 1908. In his twenties, Lartigue married Bibi, the daughter of André Messager, a composer, conductor and manager of the Paris Opera.

Later, he became involved with a succession of beautiful women - Renée, Coco, Florette - all of them the epitome of Parisian chic. Lartigue was given his first camera at the age of seven, and from that moment he photographed this life - of winters spent skiing in Chamonix or St Moritz, of summers in Nice, promenades in the park and days at the races; Bibi in the bath on their honeymoon, Florette splashing water on her infinite fingernails, Renée as a smoky cover girl in an open-topped car. He was never a reporter - just a man with a camera and an unfailing eye.

When he was five, Lartigue developed a sort of pre-photographic trick. He was too young to join in his brother's games, but he found a fun way of watching them by opening and shutting his eyes, so that all the images he liked were frozen and stored in his brain.

When he came into contact with photography, he was frustrated that his trick didn't work on film - his father's large-format camera could only capture still objects, whereas he wanted to record speed, to stop time in motion. As soon as he was given his own small camera, Lartigue was in his element. He had a passion for capturing things and people in mid-air - a jump or a splash or a twirl would be frozen half-way through, absurd and elated. When his brother tried out his new glider, Lartigue was there, tracking its halting progress through the sky. When a hot-air balloon was sent up, when a grinning woman leapt down the stairs, when his cousin fell into the water - Lartigue was there.

Michael Hoppen's small exhibition is like a crystallisation of the best of Lartigue. As its inspired title suggests, the show brings together several mid-air shots, many of which have never been seen before, and combines them with a winter theme. They were taken between the ages of nine and 86; in a neighbouring room, vintage prints are for sale, including the very first photograph Lartigue took.

In the main room, vast expanses of beautiful whiteness, directly opposed to the better known summer scenes, give the impression that the jumping skier, the spinning skater or the speeding sled have been frozen on to the photo's surface literally, by some act of nature. The photographer's cousin, Simone, does a twirl on the ice rink in the arms of her partner; a somersaulting skier hangs vertically from the sky looking down at the snow, as if he has somehow misunderstood the sport.

My favourite is the ultimate freeze frame: an action portrait of Francis Pigueron skating, his arms spread out, his legs in the middle of a balletic spin, floating high above the ice. He is even above, in this perspective, the tall pine trees in the distance and caught, like a puppet, between two perfectly equidistant Alps.

For many early photographers, the magic of the medium was the way it captured light. For Lartigue, it was the way it sealed off time.

But looking at these snowy views, you begin to wonder if the young cameraman might have believed his new toy had even greater powers - to interfere with the laws of physics and stop the pull of gravity.

fields.headline: Flying visits
fields.standfirst: The world's top performers came to show us what they can do
fields.trailText: Dance 2000: The world's top performers came to show us what they can do.
fields.body:
The year got off to a deceptively flying start as aerial dancers swung across the canopy of the Dome in the hyperinflated Millennium Show. The performance, with its elaborate set assembled and dismantled several times daily, was the best thing in the doomed Dome. Its portentous subject - life'n'death, peace'n'war, love conquering all - took second place to the scale of the spectacle. Pity the poor performers, many in their first job: they had to carry on resolutely while high hopes fell around them.

Otherwise, it was a splendid year for dance, with eagerly awaited visits from the world's top-league companies. At long last we have theatres that can accommodate them and impresarios and festival organisers prepared to present them. The Kirov Ballet came to Edinburgh and London, the Paris Opera Ballet to Salford, and New York City Ballet to the Edinburgh Festival; the Mark Morris Dance Group returned to the Coliseum, collaborating with English National Opera; autumn saw the great American contemporary dance companies of Merce Cunningham, Paul Taylor and Trisha Brown.

The Lowry in Salford joined the growing list of large stages for dance - though svelte French dancers were still picking their way through builders' rubble as the dramatic waterside complex opened with La Bayadère in May. Well run-in now, the Lowry has become the Christmas home for Birmingham Royal Ballet's Nutcracker, while the Birmingham Hippodrome undergoes modernisation.

Adventures in Motion Pictures, which took Matthew Bourne's 'auto-erotic' Car Man on the road earlier in the year, has been running it in London for an extended season (until March 2001) at the Old Vic, where the company will remain in residence for three years.

Sadler's Wells, which sought out stimulating companies - Paul Taylor's, back after a 10-year absence; La La La Lock from Montreal; Le Ballet Preljocaj from France - also hosted some dire, bloated spectacles: Joaquín Cortés's flamenco 'Soul', Maurice Béjart's 'Ballet For Life' to music by Queen, Peter Schaufuss's 'The King' to Presley songs. The dancers were excellent, let down by director-choreographers out to court a gullible public.

A rash of resignations marked the start of the new century. Michael Kaiser quit as executive director of the Royal Opera House after less than two years. Anthony Dowell, longest- serving artistic director of the Royal Ballet, announced his departure for mid-2001; Ross Stretton, director of the Australian Ballet, will replace him.

Derek Deane is to leave English National Ballet, also in the summer of next year, after eight years as artistic director. In spite of his mass-audience productions (The Sleeping Beauty was staged in June in the Royal Albert Hall), the company has no money for new ballets, so Deane is taking his talents elsewhere. His replacement will be Matz Skoog, the Swedish ex-dancer who is now director of the Royal New Zealand Ballet.

Former ENB dancer Stefano Gianetti resigned as director of Northern Ballet Theatre after a short time in the hot seat, due to 'creative differences'. He managed, however, to create a successful narrative ballet for the company, based on Dickens's Great Expectations.

If there is a theme running through the year's productions, it is that of looking to the past to illuminate the future. The Kirov returned to its pre-Soviet roots by reconstructing, as far as is feasible, the original Imper ial Ballet Sleeping Beauty of 1895. Covent Garden audiences loved it, unlike the Russians and other Europeans who apparently could not see the point in harking back. Both the Royal Ballet and the Kirov revived ballets from the Diaghilev era - and the Royal paid tribute in a series of programmes to the English choreographers in its repertoire.

Birmingham Royal Ballet recreated Ashton's wartime 'Dante Sonata' and mounted part one of David Bintley's epic English ballet, Arthur . Bintley proposes a parallel between the Dark Ages of the first millennium and the ethnic wars and brutality of our own time. Christopher Bruce revived his anti-tyranny works, 'Ghost Dances' and 'Swansong', for Rambert Dance Company, while continuing to tour his account of Chaucer's Canterbury Tales . Bruce returned briefly and memorably to the stage in his 'Moonshine', originally created for the veteran dancers of Nederlands Dans Theater 3.

Even Julie Walters had a go at dancing with Jamie Bell, young hero of Billy Elliot, the film that has made ballet hotter than mince pies.

Top 10 dance events of the year

Sleeping Beauty and Jewels Kirov Ballet season
Marguerite and Armand, Jeux recreation, Lilac Garden programme Royal Ballet
Agon, The Four Temperaments New York City Ballet
Barbican season Merce Cunningham
Coliseum season Mark Morris
Rite of Spring/Sacre du printemps Tamara Rojo for ENB/ Paul Taylor's company
Aeon trilogy and Symbiont Wayne McGregor
Romeo and Juliet Angelin Preljocaj
Car Man Matthew Bourne
Fleeting Opera on the Thames

Turkey of the year

Ralph Steadman's designs for The Crucible

webTitle: Classical: The sisters aren't bad either...

fields.headline: The sisters aren't bad either...
fields.standfirst: In the Royal Opera's classy Fifties take on Rossini, Cinders gets a designer kitchen and goes to the ball in a Rolls-Royce
fields.trailText: La Cenerentola, Royal Opera House, London WC2.
fields.body:
La Cenerentola Royal Opera House, London WC2

Cinderella's glass slipper, one of the most resonant and miraculous moments in any fairytale, does not appear in Rossini's version of the story. Its very existence, anyway, is a happy result of a mistranslation, though how much more magical, fragile and dangerous is a shoe 'en verre' than the fur slipper ('pantoufle en vair') of Perrault's seventeenth-century original. In Rossini, footwear has been replaced, less erotically, by a silver bracelet. Indeed, La Cenerentola (1817) bears only a superficial resemblance to the story we know, largely perhaps because of the need to feature its star tenor, the Prince, long before we get to the palace.

Angelina is Cinderella. She has two stepsisters but no pumpkin carriage or fairy godmother. Rossini was always more concerned with human foibles than supernatural happenings. Thus power, influence and disguise replace magic. Alidoro, the Prince's mysterious tutor, dresses up as a beggar and goes in search of a worthy wife for his pupil.

Having found Cinders, he makes sure that she does go to the ball, in a peacock-blue Rolls-Royce. The Prince in turn disguises himself as his valet Dandini, while the valet has fun (somehow more than we do) playing at being the Prince - all of which gives Rossini ample opportunity to indulge in several of the brilliant 'confusion' ensembles which are a hallmark of his comic operas.

The wonder is that anyone can keep up the pretence of not knowing who each other is for as long as they do. During the not infrequent longueurs, you feel like shouting out: 'It's Cinderella!' Hurriedly written in only three weeks, with a rambling structure, La Cenerentola has little drama.

The Royal Opera's shiny new production kept the pace moving. In Mark Elder, singers and orchestra had a conductor who understands Rossini's taut, percussive rhythms. He negotiated the score's brittle musical wit with grace, like a cat running across burning coals.

You knew the performance was in good hands from the crisply played overture which the composer, a keen recycler, borrowed from his own opera, La gazzetta . The bassoon rattled out his belching arpeggios with gunfire rapidity. Woodwind detail sounded zestful and bright. All relished the crescendo which gradually consumes the entire orchestra, one of Rossini's oldest tricks and still one of his best.

Moshe Leiser and Patrice Caurier, fresh from recent successes at Opera North and Welsh National Opera, made their Royal Opera debuts as directors. Action is removed to the 1950s, with the ugly sisters, Clorinda and Tisbe, as film starlets chased by trilby-wearing paparazzi. Tisbe looked especially fetching as a décolleté prelate in swathes of crimson silk and skull cap.

Christian Fenouillat's sets, complete with tubular chairs, octagonal Bialetti coffee pot and other apt period detail, looked clean and handsome. Different shades of lighting (designed by Christophe Forey), from lime to lilac, created variety. The transformation from Cinders's kitchen to the royal ballroom was swift and efficient - still a novelty to be able to say that of the Royal Opera's potentially versatile new stage equipment which has so often held up or let down proceedings.

Best of all, the cast were experienced Rossinian singers. Occasional lapses aside, they knew the idiom and the elaborate, many-layered sextet in which the confusion is unravelled, was carried off superbly. As the Prince, the slightly built, intense Peruvian tenor Juan Diego Flórez announced his quality as a singer from his first inconsequential notes. When he reached his great three-tiered aria in Act II, his voice shone out with steely magnificence and brought the truest dramatic moment of the evening.

The Sicilian bass-baritone Simone Alaimo is a celebrated Rossini singer, and a regular at the annual Pesaro festival devoted to the composer's works. As the gruesome stepfather Dom Magnifico, he had a natural sense of comic timing. Two British singers, Nicole Tibbels and Leah-Marian Jones, proved entertaining as the preening ugly sisters, with another Italian, Sonia Ganassi, in the title role. She had brilliant moments but seemed uncertain how to add flesh to this mouse-like role. Never mind. The production has charm and energy. It should be a box-office hit. Or see it on BBC2 on Boxing Day at 2.50pm.

TV schedulers, a peculiar breed, seem to assume that socially inept music lovers, bereft of concerts, will have nothing to fill the long festive hours. Accordingly, they squeeze a year's worth of viewing into a long weekend. If you watched everything, you could certainly escape all other obligations. Here are some of the best: Choir of the Year (BBC2 today, 26 and 27 December); Glyndebourne's La Bohème (Christmas Day, Channel 4); and an Alfred Brendel documentary (BBC2 Christmas Day).

On New Year's Day, the new digital channel, Artsworld, shows the marvellous Cecilia Bartoli singing Vivaldi. Radio 3 is full of seasonal treats, including La Traviata Live from the Met on 30 December. And once you've tired of rissoles and réchauffés (genres not unknown to the opera world), you can watch Elijah Moshinsky's production of Die Entführung aus dem Serail filmed in Istanbul (BBC2, 29 December). Since the title was thought too daunting for TV viewers, they have plumped for a name which sounds like the ultimate seasonal dish: Mozart in Turkey.

webTitle: Humbug? Scrooge and I just watch the pennies

fields.headline: Humbug? Scrooge and I just watch the pennies
fields.standfirst: William Maxwell, who is playing Ebeneezer at Battersea Arts Centre, tells Natalie Sutton about the financial lot of an actor
fields.trailText: William Maxwell, who is playing Ebeneezer at Battersea Arts Centre, tells Natalie Sutton about the financial lot of an actor.
fields.body:
Stingy old Ebeneezer Scrooge was notoriously careful with his cash. Although he's not mean, William Maxwell, the actor who plays our favourite miser in A Christmas Carol at the Battersea Arts Centre, is still cautious when it comes to personal finance.

The 63-year-old thespian first trod the boards with the RAF and hasn't looked back since. After the Second World War he decided against becoming a public health inspector and became a professional actor instead. 'I've done pretty well,' he says 'with about 25 to 30 good years over my career.'

Following a universal low patch for arts funding during the Eighties, William persevered and appeared in Brookside as a murderer and potential bigamist, as well as featuring in several television programmes and commercials. He played with the Royal Shakespeare Company and has performed in theatres nationwide. He has just completed The Temple Project, a film directed by James Marquand to be released next year. 'An actor's life is a bit iffy,' he says when discussing his income. 'You can't really afford not to be careful. You always have to think about putting a bit by because you never know what will happen next.

The daft thing is that you get paid for the dull stuff and that makes up for the interesting work, which you pretty much do for love.'

He has saved over the years and last year paid off his mortgage.

He tells the story of playing Dolittle in a production of Pygmalion in Ipswich, which allowed him time to nip off and film commercials for British Lamb. Three ads featuring William as a butcher led to an exploitation fee, secured on his behalf by Equity, when a still photograph from the campaign adorned the walls of most British butcher shops. 'They'd made me up to look much older,' laughs William, 'so it didn't hurt my career at all and I managed to put a downpayment on a house as a result.' He has two private pension schemes and will qualify for a state pension.

But what about Scrooge? According to William, Ebeneezer often went to the City but nobody took much notice of him, so he was unlikely to be a big mover and shaker on the stock market. 'I don't think he'd be much of a gambler. He would only take risks if he were pretty sure that they'd pay off.'

'No,' says William, 'I think he's more likely to consult a damn good financial adviser who would be given the push if Ebeneezer discovered that he was a ha'penny down.' It is, of course, poor Bob Cratchett's job to balance the books, and he gets the blame if the profit margins are not as big as they should be. Christmas is hard work for Scrooge - he has many outgoings and the end of the year sees him obsessed with adding up the columns in his ledgers.

He doesn't believe in charity but is in favour of the Poor Law and supports prisons and workhouses, with the odd donation to keep the poor incarcerated. Though wealthy, Scrooge is never satisfied. 'He's a miserable old sod,' says William, chuckling. Bah humbug.

Uncle Ebeneezer - A Christmas Carol is at Battersea Arts Centre until 20 January. Box office 0207 223 2223.

fields.headline: Cars firms win levy reprieve
fields.trailText: The Government is poised to throw a lifeline to the troubled motor industry by giving it a major discount on the deeply unpopular climate change levy.
fields.body:
The Government is poised to throw a lifeline to the troubled motor industry by giving it a major discount on the deeply unpopular climate change levy.

Carmakers have identified the levy, which taxes companies on their output of carbon dioxide, as an unwelcome addition to costs in the highly competitive international motor manufacturing market and as a disincentive for investment.

Other energy-intensive industries, such as glass, steel and cement, were given discounts from the levy in principle soon after it was unveiled in 1999, although the details have been subject to tortuous negotiation.

Motor manufacturers were not initially included, but the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders has been lobbying hard for discounts.

The SMMT and carmakers told The Observer that the Government has indicated its application for a negotiated agreement, in which manufacturers will reduce CO2 emissions by 12 per cent from 1999 levels over 10 years, is likely to be agreed in the new year. The deal represents an 80 per cent discount on the levy and will delight bosses of UK-based motor manufacturers after a year in which Rover was dumped by BMW, Ford ended car production at Dagenham and Vauxhall announced plans to close its Luton plant. Nissan is currently deciding whether to build its new Micra in Sunderland or in France.

Although the sums involved are small, margins are tight and any additional costs cause problems. According to the SMMT, the levy would have cost manufacturers £9 million on total energy bills of about £100m. With the discount this will fall to around £1.8m.

An SMMT spokesman said: 'This was a very high priority, particularly for companies like Nissan. All of the companies are in a cost-down world, and any set of circumstances where costs are going to increase is a problem.'

A Toyota spokesman said: 'This is an additional cost and a concern in considering investment in the UK. We calculated that at current production levels, the levy would have cost us £5 a car. With a discount this falls to £1.50.'

fields.headline: Catching the big waves
fields.trailText: Radio 2000: This was the year I met someone who admitted to spending £800 on a digital radio because he wanted to listen to the Proms without crackle.
fields.body:
This was the year I met someone who admitted to spending £800 on a digital radio because he wanted to listen to the Proms without crackle. Compared with what it would have cost him to go to the Albert Hall every night for two months (he lived in Scotland), it was a snip.

Perfect radio deserves perfect reception and there were many instances of perfect radio last year. Whoever had the idea of celebrating the tribute to Shakespeare Man of the Millennium by getting ordinary people to stop whatever they were doing during the course of an ordinary day and read their favourite Shakespeare sonnet deserves prizes and promotion.

We heard Fiona Shaw in a couple of inspiring masterclasses demonstrate the power and subtlety of Shakespeare's language. And in an explosive lecture we heard Michael Bogdanov predict that unless we took Shakespeare out of tights and into a modern context, he would go the same way as the Dodo. But Norman, a dairy farmer sitting on his tractor, engine idling while he read sonnet 130 ('My mistress's eyes are nothing like the sun'), was living proof that WS is still very much alive, kicking and rooted in reality.

There were other unforgettable moments: Ann Widdecombe in Dead Ringers begging John Humphrys - hands roughened from toiling in his organic garden - to hold high his hose and water her compost; the woman who phoned Jimmy Young's resident sex therapist to ask if he could recommend any other way of achieving orgasm apart from lying on her stomach with a full bladder. There was the evening Eddie Grundy came home to find that poor old Joe had lost his marbles and killed the ferrets, and the unmistakable husky voice of Radio 5 Live breakfast presenter Victoria Darbyshire, doing more to cheer up drenched homeless flood victims than the arrival of Noah's Ark.

Memorable radio drama included not just classic productions of Coward, Pinter, Shakespeare and Shaw but new specially commissioned works like the moving Child of Our Time series and the feisty 2000 Tales, an update on Chaucer's Canterbury pilgrims. Grim reality made Ambridge an obligatory destination every night - for news of Ruth's breast cancer, Sid's divorce, Elizabeth's treachery and Clarrie representing beleaguered farmers' wives from Devon to Dumfries desperately trying to make ends meet.

Radio 1 brought in earthy Sarah Cox to replace the bouncing Miss Ball as it's early-morning presenter. Kids think she's great but mothers strapping children into Volvo seatbelts prefer Henry Kelly's Classic FM School Run selection for children who have done their piano practice.

What I'll miss more than anything when the man from Digital One comes round next month to reclaim the set he allowed me to test drive for the past four months is having the World Service on tap. Meridian and Outlook are the most entertaining and far-reaching arts programmes on the air, and Westway - an everyday story of health centre folk - is soap with soul.

Radio's magic, and art, was summed up for me by the Royal Ballet's Deborah Bull describing the rigours - every muscle and demi-semiquaver - of dancing Swan Lake. If it's in your head, it's on your radio.

Sunday Format (R4)

Outlook (World Service)

Sunday Service (R5)

Faultline (R3)

Batman and Rosie (R4)

Jonathan Ross on Saturday (R2)

Dead Ringers (R4)

Dirty Tackle (R5)

Hotel Europe (R5)

Turkey of the year:

Yes Sir I Can Boogie (R4)

webTitle: Bob the builder sets off for US

fields.headline: Bob sets off to build a US empire
fields.trailText: He has knocked gangsta rap star Eminem from the No 1 slot in the UK pop charts and his plastic figurine is in the top 10 of the most popular toys this Christmas. Now Bob the Builder is aiming for global domination, writes Jamie Doward. In two weeks' time Bob faces his greatest challenge when he attempts what numerous pop stars and actors have failed to achieve: to make it big in America.
fields.body:
He has knocked gangsta rap star Eminem from the No 1 slot in the UK pop charts and his plastic figurine is in the top 10 of the most popular toys this Christmas. Now Bob the Builder is aiming for global domination, writes Jamie Doward. In two weeks' time Bob faces his greatest challenge when he attempts what numerous pop stars and actors have failed to achieve: to make it big in America.

HIT Entertainment, the company behind the TV character, will screen the Bob series on the Nickelodeon children's channel six days a week, opening up potentially lucrative merchandising streams. About three quarters of HIT's revenues come from the UK but the company is hoping the Bob phenomenon can be exported successfully across the Atlantic, following its launch in Germany and Japan.
