fields.headline: Have you been drinking, Gordon?
fields.trailText: You are not going to believe this, but guess who was sitting at the next table recently when I paid my monthly trip to the tremendously fashionable Granita's restaurant in Islington, North London? Fortunately I had a state-of-the-art, New Labour-activated tape recorder with me, and can pass on the results as a Christmas present to all my readers.
fields.body:
You are not going to believe this, but guess who was sitting at the next table recently when I paid my monthly trip to the tremendously fashionable Granita's restaurant in Islington, North London? Fortunately I had a state-of-the-art, New Labour-activated tape recorder with me, and can pass on the results as a Christmas present to all my readers.

Blair: Why did you insist on coming back here of all places?

Brown:: I just thought it might help us to recollect that conversation - a return to the scene of the crime, as it were.

Blair: I'm not sure I can remember much about it. Seems a long time ago.

Brown:: Tony, it was at this very table that you made me a promise.

Blair: Come off it, Gordon. Everybody in the country knows by now that I'm much too vague to make specific promises.

Brown:: Well, at the very least, you gave me to understand ...

Blair: Can I pour you a drink, Gordon?

Brown:: I never drink until there's no danger of facing the cameras.

Blair: There are no cameras here - only office parties.

Brown:: All right, as it's Christmas. But we should keep our wits about us. What you say to me tonight will be vital to my future.

Blair: Future? I'm beginning to worry about the future too. I was just looking at the estate agent's window down the road. Do you know what's happened to property prices in Islington since the election?

Brown:: Under my policies of stability and the avoidance of boom and bust I am sure they have held their value.

Blair: Held their value, Gordon? They've doubled.

Brown:: Well, why are you complaining? Haven't you got a house here?

Blair: I had a house. We sold it. Under your boom and bust policies Cherie and I have missed out. We're bust.

Brown:: Come off it. You've got a Prime Minister's salary. She's a top barrister.

Blair: But she'll take a pay cut if she becomes a judge. Do you realise, Gordon, we won't be able to buy the kind of house we've become accustomed to.

Brown:: You could always go into a deprived area and mix with the people. No, Tony, that was a joke (pause). Or perhaps you could get a loan from Geoffrey.

Blair: Gordon, that was in very bad taste.

Brown:: Surely you're insured?

Blair: Yes, with the Equitable ...

Brown:: Like half the media. That's why a boring insurance story is getting so much publicity.

Blair: The media? Oh God. If there's one thing I'd like to nationalise it's the media. Just think how much better our image would be if we were in total control.

Brown:: I'm sure your man Campbell's working on it.

Blair: But seriously, Gordon, I know everybody thinks you've abolished boom and bust - you've certainly talked about it until you're blue in the face - but why can I no longer afford to buy a house in London?

Brown:: It's capitalism, Tony. It's what you believe in.

Blair: Well, you know what this means, don't you?

Brown:: What?

Blair: Cherie and I will just have to stay where we are. All that stuff about handing over to you during the second term will just have to be forgotten.

Brown:: Ah! You remember you said it! I thought the scene of the crime might help.

Blair: Gordon, I don't think you've quite taken in what I'm saying. Put it this way: would you like to be Foreign Secretary?

Brown:: No.

Blair: Would you like to carry on being Chancellor?

Brown:: Not indefinitely. You know perfectly well there's only one job I want and it's yours. There's no other 'third way' solution.

Blair: Difficult, isn't it. Let's talk about something else. What about Europe?

Brown:: Europe? I hate Europe. Europe hasn't passed my five tests yet.

Blair: Peter rings me every morning urging me to take the plunge.

Brown:: Huh. As his adventures with Geoffrey's house-loan ought to have warned you, Mandelson isn't very good with figures. He doesn't understand what joining at this exchange rate would do to our industry.

Blair: That's not a problem. The euro's reviving. The experts tell me the pound's on the way down. Europe needs us.

Brown:: You may be right there. Germany's flexing its muscles. Did you see it reported that the Chancellor (I mean Schrder) now regards post-Nice Germany as 'emancipated' from France?

Blair: The whole point of the European Union has been to tie Germany and France together.

Brown:: Tony, this is serious. It may be time for the Churchill Solution.

Blair: The Churchill Solution?

Brown:: In 1940 Churchill proposed a merger between Britain and France - a 'Franco-British Union'.

Blair: I don't know about that. But France certainly needs us as a counterweight to Germany.

Brown:: I know what. I'll declare that the five tests have been passed on New Year's Day, and we'll go for it. You can be President of Europe - they'd love to have you - and I can be Prime Minister.

Blair: Gordon, I know there are no cameras, but just how much did you drink on the way here?

webTitle: On the wing of a millennium prayer

fields.headline: On the wing of a millennium prayer
fields.standfirst: As part of our festive look back at the year's hottest share tips from the Trading Floor team of experts*, we calculate that you will now be exactly 3,456.65 per cent** better off if you followed our advice than if you had bet an average of £600 a week on randomly chosen horses. So let's relive those financial highlights once again
fields.trailText: As part of our festive look back at the year's hottest share tips from the Trading Floor team of experts*, we calculate that you will now be exactly 3,456.65 per cent** better off if you followed our advice than if you had bet an average of £600 a week on randomly chosen horses. So let's relive those financial highlights once again.
fields.body:
January The millennium celebrations had been an anti-climax and the fuss about the Dome was starting. Our advice was to buy the IM group, led by Bob Edminston, a Midlands Christian fundamentalist who spent the back end of last year hyping Sir Cliff Richard's record Millennium Prayer to the top of the charts.

Bob did his bit by placing large orders for the record with sneering assistants in Birmingham multiples and then watching the CD beat the pants off the infidel opposition. And we told you to sell all UK brewery and pub chain stocks on news that George Best had been ordered to give up drinking.

February The hot tip was the London Rubber Company (ie Durex) on news that the company had a legal battle gaining entry into the Japanese condom market, the biggest in the world. The wise investor takes a broad interest in the world and Trading Floor brought the news that the Japanese invented the first modern condom, known as the Kabutogata, in the nineteenth century. The Kabutogata was made of tortoiseshell.

The LRC at the same time claimed the first-ever condoms were used 3,000 years ago in Egypt to protect the wearer from insect bites.

March Spring was in the air, along with talk of global warming. The team picked out companies likely to do well in a future tropical Britain, led by Rentokil.

Early in the month the market slaughtered the stock, wiping £888 million off the company's value in a single day after disappointing results, ignoring long-term prospects, which were excellent, on news (in the same week) that a colony of wild spectacled cayman alligators now resident in Newcastle had become active again after the winter break.

This followed the discovery of nests of Tunisian scorpions in Kent, venomous miniature Portuguese men-of-war in the tepid Bayou of the Norfolk Broads and the identification of rapine flocks of razor-beaked tropical parrots in Epping Forest.

April Keeping up the environmental theme, the tip of the month was to stockpile and sell on mountain ranges. The Clan MacLeod wanted a mere £10m for the entire Black Cullin range on the Isle of Skye. At the same time Ben Nevis was sold for £450,000, the average price of a warehouse conversion in Docklands.

In view of the booming demand for conveniently located second mountains, our advice to readers was to check behind the back of the mantelpiece clock to see if they owned all or part of a mountain and cash in while the going was good. But nobody, as far as we can now tell, did so and mountains remained sluggish and failed to peak all year.

May Hazards in the workplace was one theme in May, with advice to sell the Prudential and all other suppliers of medical insurance on official news that the workplace, and everywhere else, was a much more hazardous place than any sane person had previously thought.

DTI figures revealed that 723 people had sustained injuries 'caused by accidents involving envelopes', 3,554 had turned up at accident and emergency departments with wounds 'attributable to flower pots' and no less than 37,048 had come to grief as a result of calamities 'related to the wearing of carpet slippers'.

The number of people with toes stuck up bath taps or saucepans stuck on their heads was not reported - the figure presumably included under the heading of 'hurt while involved in no activity in particular' (439,000 cases). All very tragic. But it was hard to feel much sympathy with the 59 people who last year were 'injured by Blu-tak'.

June Anarchists and anti-globalisation campaigners rioted in the City as part of a Carnival Against Capitalism. They planted cannabis in the grounds of Parliament, spray-painted abuse on statues of military leaders and gave the statue of Winston Churchill a green Mohican hairstyle fashioned out of a sod of grass.

In response, City workers avenged these insults by attacking the Glastonbury Festival under the heading of 'Carnival Against the Crusties'. But the protest never materialised, possibly due to leaders having being hospitalised by Blu-tak mishaps (see May).

July The stock tip of the year was Wessex Water, which had worked out a way of taking away people's sewage, processing slightly and selling it back to them as garden fertilizer. Noting the huge success of businesses such as Sky TV and the pop music racket generally, the team observed: 'Dotcoms come and dotcoms go, you can't go wrong backing a business based on selling shite.'

August Big Brother was a sensation on TV and we advised buying Planet 24/Carlton on news that company kingpin Charlie Parsons had claimed the show was his intellectual property, worth millions. We printed the transcript of tapes proving that Parsons and former creative partner Janet Street-Porter might soon be claiming to have invented other things.

Here are extracts from tape of their brainstorming Session: CP: 'What do you say we sort of think of a way of somehow connectin' up all the computers in, like, the Whole World so that they could all communicate with each other usin', y'know, advanced file transfer protocols and, whachamcallit, HTML, in sort of one big, vast inter-connected computer network, using satellites and modems and everything?

JS-P: 'Well wicked, innit?'

(Royalty claim: Total cash flows of world wide web and internet, to include all content and revenues accruing to associated businesses such as Microsoft and IBM).

September The month was dominated by panic-buying of petrol and mass hysteria leading to the hoarding of bread and other basic foodstuffs.

October Buy Bayer Inc, the world's leading supplier of blood and blood products to hospitals. The blood-supply wing of the company's UK branch, already owner of such brands as Glucobay, Kognate and Nimotop, could be about to soar in the wake of the impending arrival in the UK of the last living relative of the original Dracula - the equally impressively titled exiled Prince Ottomar Rudolphe Vlad Kretzulesco Dracula of Transylvania.

Vlad current resides in Castle Dracula, Schenkendorf, Brandenburg in the former East Germany. He has done much public-spirited work helping to publicise the German blood donor service, presumably carried out between the hours of sundown and sunrise so as not to get in the way of his day job as an antiques dealer.

He says that he wants to come to the UK in order to work for the blood transfusion service and because he is being persecuted by, of all people, neo-Nazi football hooligans.

November Hoarding, petrol crisis? Sell everything - on increasingly strong rumours, following the proposed total ban on workplace smoking, that the next and even more serious occupational hazard in the sights of the developed world's health bureaucrats is workplace working.

Scientists have long suspected a link between work and both physical and mental fatigue, despite efforts in all sectors of the economy to reduce the total number of jobs.

New types of 'low work' occupations, such as colour therapy, graphic design and management consultancy - hyped under the slogan 'all the flavour of a real job without the effort' - have become more popular in recent years.

But even these elite jobs do little to curtail symptoms of habitual working, which experts say range from 'feeling a bit knackered'at the end of the day, through inexplicable desire to sit in traffic jams and leading, in millions of cases, to boney fingers, full-scale toxic shock and nervous breakdown.

Even the increasingly large majority who have managed to quit working in the workplace (or who never took up the habit in the first place) face the danger of so-called passive working. This happens when somebody innocently pretending to read the Financial Times, trying out the colour combinations on their computer desktop or downloading massive quantities of hard-core pornography from the internet, is suddenly and inadvertently exposed to a work-related email or phone call, indirectly resulting from some inconsiderate colleague's selfish determination to do some work.

Dentists, meanwhile, are the latest group to feel the ill effects of work en mass. It was reported last week that work is causing many to turn to alcohol and experience problems with sleep. The campaign to make workplace working illegal was further boosted by a report, published in the latest Journal of Electromagnetic Hazards, that 'a significant number' of people are allergic to microchips.

The journal's editor, Simon Best, told a newspaper that sufferers can fall unconscious at any time. They are also plagued by nausea, blurred vision and migraines after contact with a computer. People simply punt their credit cards into cyberspace, and, hey presto, a pile of mud arrives at the door. The company offers various mud supply options, starting with a £2.50p pauper's starter pack through a 'hippo' option to a 'deluxe executive service' involving the delivery of 500 kilos of mud (with a choice of topsoils). The whole thing is based on the premise that anyone stupid enough to buy anything over the internet would buy anything.

fields.headline: Camelot to pay GTech £230m
fields.standfirst:
New contract raises questions over National Lottery's dependence on disgraced US gaming giant

Special report: the lottery
fields.trailText: New contract raises questions over National Lottery's dependence on disgraced US gaming giant.
fields.body:
National Lottery operator Camelot is set to face fresh controversy after it emerged that the company is to pay disgraced gaming giant GTech more than £230 million over the course of its new seven-year licence.

The move means that GTech will be substantially better off under the terms of the new licence than the current one and will focus attention on Camelot's pledge, made in September, that it will act 'totally independently' of the US company.

GTech will receive between £27m and £30m a year from the UK operator - in return for providing it with the computer software needed to power its network of lottery terminals.

GTech's decision to hide a long-running software glitch that distorted payouts for National Lottery winners almost lost Camelot its bid for the next licence.

In addition, Camelot is to pay GTech around £45m to build and link a network of 25,000 new terminals to replace the old system. A further contract, giving Camelot exclusive rights to use GTech's specialised internet gaming security system, developed by its UWin! subsidiary, is due for negotiation next year.

According to the most recent set of annual reports seen by The Observer, those for 1998, GTech makes around 30 per cent gross margins on its servicing contracts and more than 40 per cent margins on its product sales.

Camelot would have preferred to keep a lid on the huge sums it is due to pay GTech, but under US Securities and Exchange Commission rules the company is forced to publicly disclose such contracts.

In a statement made to the New York Stock Exchange last week the company announced: 'GTech will allow Camelot exclusive rights to operate GTech's gaming system software in the UK for the term of the new licence. In return, GTech will receive a software-licensing fee for the term of the contract. On an annualised basis, the software licence is expected to produce revenues for GTech in the range of $40m-$45m.'

The news will highlight how dependent Camelot continues to be on GTech's expertise, despite the fact that the operator has pledged to run its lottery terminal network on its own by buying in a team of software engineers and maintaining the system itself - something that is currently the responsibility of GTech's UK subsidiary.

In a bid to distance itself from the US firm, around 40 of GTech's 100 UK lottery engineers will become Camelot employees in the new year. Camelot took the decision after the National Lottery Commission made it clear that it was unhappy about the probity of GTech's management. GTech's chairman resigned as a result of the software glitch cover-up scandal, which emerged earlier in the year when a former GTech software engineer blew the whistle.

Camelot has stated that the move to buy out GTech's UK division will allow it to 'take total control of the running and management of the UK National Lottery software'. But last week one of the National Lottery Commissioners, Hilary Blume, resigned after expressing concerns about Camelot's new arrangement with GTech.

'I carry forward concerns over issues of propriety and Camelot's continued dependence on GTech,' Blume said.

The massive cash windfall for GTech - around 10 per cent more than the company enjoys under the terms of the current licence - will give fresh ammunition to Sir Richard Branson's People's Lottery Consortium, which lost out to Camelot at the eleventh hour after having been originally granted preferred bidder status. Branson subsequently described the lottery regulator's decision to re-award the contract to Camelot as 'deeply flawed'.

Simon Burridge, chief executive of the People's Lottery, said last night: 'We share Hilary Blume's concerns that Camelot's new arrangement with GTech is purely cosmetic and does not address concerns expressed by the NLC over issues of propriety. If GTech is not deemed to be fit and proper it's absolutely outrageous that it will now be earning even more from the UK lottery. This is yet another instance of the full story not being told.'

Lottery experts have been privately sceptical about whether Camelot can categorically reassure the regulator of its independence from GTech.

A number of experts told the Observer that the revised Camelot bid would require a number of modifications of GTech software if the UK operator is to take it in-house and said that this would not be easy to achieve under an 'arms length' arrangement - forcing the need for an overlap of staff in the interim.

'The degree of support for this new version of the GTech product will be high for the first couple of years. GTech will find it difficult to do under the remote arrangement,' one senior lottery industry source said.

The experts also questioned whether the operator will be able to incentivise and retain key software personnel over the full seven-year period.

A Camelot spokesman denied it would have difficulty ensuring that it observed an arms-length arrangement with GTech.

'By the start of the next licence Camelot will have sole responsibility for the software operations the UK lottery.

'The licence agreement we've struck with GTech is common to other countries around the world,' he said.

The spokesman defended the revised deal with GTech as the best way of ensuring it would meet its commitment to make £15 billion for good causes during the course of the new licence. 'GTech lottery technology is the best in the world and we're pleased to have secured this deal,' the spokesman said.

fields.headline: True grit
fields.trailText: Courage comes in many different forms, something seemingly beyond the grasp of Carol Sarler (Comment, last week).
fields.body:
Courage comes in many different forms, something seemingly beyond the grasp of Carol Sarler (Comment, last week). The Collins definition reads as follows: 'The power or quality of dealing with or facing danger, fear, pain etc.'

If she had checked her facts, she might have seen that all 12 children who were honoured in this year's Woman's Own Children of Courage Awards fit the criteria only too well. Perhaps she would like to explain to the parents and families of these children just why she deems them unworthy winners.
Terry Tavner
Editor, Woman's Own
London SE1

fields.headline: Private lives
fields.body:
Thatcher's grand plan to ease wholesale public sector sell-off by long-term underfunding and demoralisation ensuring public disaffection, continues to work as 'New Labour' fails to reverse her strategy.

The unpalatable truth, therefore, is that these services are now dangerous and anyone with any nous and the wherewithal will run for cover to the private sector to buy what their votes could not secure. The agonising of Guardian columnists over how they moved house or put Ben down for common entrance will soon be followed by similar articles on how, when it came to their hip-replacement, there was no alternative but to use the private sector as the sheer filth of the public hospital, let alone the waiting time, became a real prospect.
P.F. Kay
Solihull
West Midlands

fields.headline: Fiction friction
fields.trailText: It beats me how Robert McCrum (Books, last week) can think that the publication of journalism by Dickens and Simon Schama's TV series,  History of Britain,  show we're 'braining up'.
fields.body:
It beats me how Robert McCrum (Books, last week) can think that the publication of journalism by Dickens (a good writer, but no philosopher and sociologist) and Simon Schama's TV series, History of Britain, (naive empiricism: one bloody battle and monarch after another) show we're 'braining up'.

Our society may be exposed to more information, but that does not make it wiser unless the information includes how to reason, think and evaluate. What of recent, lucid and imaginative books on philosophy and social science which teach these skills (while explaining the ruling Cartesian ideology that undermines them)? The cult of fiction, journalism and the novel over such books carries a heavy cost. A culture inept in assessing views and values is one hellbent not just on its own but our planet's destruction.
David Rodway
London SW10

fields.headline: Tinseltown Tat
fields.trailText: I think it is nothing short of a tragedy that Hollywood has completely lost the knack of entertaining and satisfying a huge and very varied audience week in week out, something they did superbly well for more than 50 years (Focus, last week).
fields.body:
I think it is nothing short of a tragedy that Hollywood has completely lost the knack of entertaining and satisfying a huge and very varied audience week in week out, something they did superbly well for more than 50 years (Focus, last week). To use the word 'cinema' to describe the works of Eisenstein, D.W. Griffiths and Orson Welles as well as for today's lamentable productions is like using the word 'art' for Picasso as well as for chocolate box tops. When I see what movies get the Oscars these days I feel like giving mine back!
Walter Lassally
Director of Photography, Oscar-winner 1965 for Zorba the Greek

To use the word 'cinema' to describe the works of Eisenstein, D.W. Griffiths and Orson Welles as well as for today's lamentable productions is like using the word 'art' for Picasso as well as for chocolate box tops. When I see what movies get the Oscars these days I feel like giving mine back! Walter Lassally Director of Photography, Oscar-winner 1965 for Zorba the Greek

fields.headline: Illogical, Richard
fields.trailText: The presence of only four women of 169 assembled political leaders in New York is proof to Richard Ingrams that women are not interested in power (Diary, last week).
fields.body:
The presence of only four women of 169 assembled political leaders in New York is proof to Richard Ingrams that women are not interested in power (Diary, last week).

The logic is as incomprehensible as one of my colleague's statements that women candidates should not be appointed to junior surgical training posts as experience shows that they rarely become consultant surgeons. Prejudice is still the most powerful weapon in halting the advancement of an individual's development.
Clara Lowy
London W3

fields.headline: Safety first
fields.trailText: The Trade Union Eurocontrol Maastricht, which represents staff based at the Eurocontrol Maastricht Upper Area Control Centre, categorically refutes all allegations of a lack of safety in Maastricht UAC operations.
fields.body:
The Trade Union Eurocontrol Maastricht, which represents staff based at the Eurocontrol Maastricht Upper Area Control Centre, categorically refutes all allegations of a lack of safety in Maastricht UAC operations.

It is scientific nonsense to speak of increasing crash risks from the implementation of the Reduced Vertical Separation Minimum next year. Air Traffic Control operations at the Maastricht UAC are supported by one of the most modern and sophisticated ATC systems in the world.

Very strict safety regulations are in place throughout the whole of Europe and air traffic controllers are given the best possible tools to make safety the priority.

We consider that passengers receive the confirmation that they have flown safely through the Maastricht UAC airspace for the past 29 years and that they will continue to do so in the future.
Bjorn E. Neher
President of TUEM
Maastricht
